answer:
Heads, Tails, and Measure-Zero Miracles  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Imagine that you and countably many companions each flip a fair coin. Before you look at the result you are told something astonishing: only finitely many of the infinitely many coins came up heads. What credence should you now assign to the proposition

(H) “My own coin landed heads”?

At first blush it can seem that nothing has changed. Your coin was independent of the others, and you have received only global information about the whole ensemble. Shouldn’t symmetry therefore preserve the original ½? In what follows I argue that this is a mistake and that the uniquely coherent posterior credence is 0. I proceed in six steps—first rehearsing the probabilistic background, then making the intuitive case with finite approximations, offering a formal derivation, answering the main objections, discussing the special difficulties of conditioning on measure-zero events, and finally drawing some philosophical morals about independence, self-locating belief, and the limits of Bayesian conditionalisation.

1.  The Background: Why the Announcement Is Astonishing  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
For an infinite sequence of independent fair flips, the Strong Law of Large Numbers entails that with probability 1 the relative frequency of heads converges to ½. In particular, the event

(F) “Only finitely many heads occur”

has unconditional probability 0. (The first Borel–Cantelli lemma already suffices.) So the information you are given concerns a probability-zero event. In standard Kolmogorov probability the expression P(A | F) is therefore undefined. If we want to talk about what a rational agent should believe after learning F, we must supplement bare Kolmogorov theory with a way of conditionalising on null events. That is the technical core of the puzzle.

Yet even before addressing that complication, we can build some intuition.

2.  A Finite Prelude: Shrinking the Head Count  
–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Suppose instead of countably many people there were N of you. You are told that at most k of the N coins (k < N) came up heads. By symmetry, every person is equally likely to be among the at-most-k lucky ones, so

P(H | ≤k heads among N) = k⁄N .

Raise N to 1,000 with k fixed at 10: the conditional probability becomes 1%. Raise N to a million: the probability plummets to 0.001%. Let N → ∞ while k stays finite: the natural limit is 0. Our problem is just the k = “some finite number”, N = ℵ₀ case, so the finite analogy strongly suggests that the answer is 0.

Someone might object that limits can mislead; infinite ensembles often have surprises not present at any finite stage. So let us now leave the realm of analogies and tackle the infinite case head-on.

3.  Formal Derivation: Symmetry, Expectation, and a Contradiction  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Label the people 1, 2, 3, … and write Hₙ for the indicator variable that agent n’s coin is heads (1 for heads, 0 for tails). Let

S = Σₙ Hₙ  (the total number of heads).

We are given the information F = {S is finite}. Our task is to compute a coherent conditional probability μ(H₁ | F). (Because the agents and coins are exchangeable, the label “1” is arbitrary; any agent’s credence must come out the same.)

Let p stand for that sought probability:

p := μ(H₁ = 1 | F).

By exchangeability, every other agent m must have the same conditional probability p. Taking conditional expectation we get

μ(S | F) = μ( Σₙ Hₙ | F ) = Σₙ μ(Hₙ | F ) = Σₙ p.

If p were positive, the right-hand side would be the sum of countably many positive numbers, i.e. +∞. But S is explicitly finite on F, so μ(S | F) must also be finite. The only way to avoid contradiction is to set p = 0. Ergo

μ(H | F) = 0

for every agent individually. Since the event “my coin is heads” is identical to “Hₙ = 1” for my own n, my posterior credence must be 0.

That calculation is robust; it assumes only countable additivity and the minimal symmetry built into the problem. No more economical route exists to a different number.

4.  Addressing the Main Objections  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  

Objection 1: “Independence guarantees the probability should stay ½.”  
Reply: Independence only concerns unconditional probabilities. Conditioning on a fact about the sum of all variables introduces correlations. Even in the finite case, coin results are pairwise independent yet, given the information “at most k heads,” they become negatively correlated. The infinite case is no different in kind—just in degree.

Objection 2: “Probability 0 makes the event ‘my coin is heads’ epistemically impossible, yet I know it is still physically possible.”  
Reply: In continuous probability spaces many physically possible events have measure 0 (e.g. a fair dart hitting exactly one rational point on the board). A rational agent can coherently assign them credence 0. Probability 0 is not logical impossibility; it is maximal improbability. Were you later to look at your coin and see heads, you would have learnt another measure-zero fact and would have to conditionalise again, just as Bayesians routinely do after observing a real number with a continuous prior.

Objection 3: “Maybe conditional probability is undefined here; why not regard the update as undetermined and keep ½?”  
Reply: While ordinary Kolmogorov conditioning breaks down on measure-zero events, the standard solution is to invoke a regular conditional probability (RCP) generated as a limit of conditioning on measure-positive approximations. In the present problem natural approximations are the sets

F_k := {S ≤ k}  for k = 1,2,3,...

since F = ⋃_k F_k. Computing

P(H₁ = 1 | S ≤ k)

is elementary and equals k⁄(k+1)·2^{-(k+1)} divided by P(S ≤ k); as k grows large the ratio shrinks like k/M where M is the number of agents we “consider”, and with countably many agents the limit is 0. Every coherent RCP therefore yields 0. The value ½ is not an admissible candidate for any RCP and therefore violates the usual Bayesian norms once null-event conditionalisation is required.

Objection 4 (anthropic twist): “I might have been one of those finitely many who got heads; absent a uniform probability over persons, setting the credence to 0 seems to rely on a dubious ‘probability 1⁄∞’ intuition.”  
Reply: The derivation above never assigns a uniform measure to people; it merely exploits the elementary fact that if every person had positive probability ε of being a head, the expected number of heads would be countably infinite. That contradiction is measure-theoretic, not anthropic.

5.  The Measure-Zero Quandary Made Explicit  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Philosophers sometimes ask whether Bayesian rationality should require unique conditional credences on null events or allow optionality. There are in fact three relevant norms:

(i) Countable Additivity: Credence functions are σ-additive measures.  
(ii) Regularity: No contingent possibility has prior probability 0.  
(iii) Standard Conditioning: Upon learning E, set the new credence to the old conditional probability on E.

Our puzzle violates Regularity from the outset, because F had prior probability 0. But once we relax Regularity (as most Bayesians admit we must when continuous variables are present), countable additivity and the demand for a regular conditional probability fix the posterior uniquely. That is why, in the present case, the credence 0 is not merely permissible but required. One could instead abandon countable additivity, but that price is steep; doing so threatens the Kolmogorov foundation and wreaks havoc with Dutch-book theorems.

6.  Philosophical Morals  
–––––––––––––––––––––––  
a. Independence Is Fragile Under Conditioning  
The puzzle is an extreme illustration of a familiar moral: independence is not absolute but relative to what you condition on. Even classically independent variables become entangled once one learns a constraint relating them.

b. Self-Locating Belief without a Uniform Prior  
Some worry that indexical uncertainty (“Which person am I?”) cannot be represented when the population is infinite because there is no uniform distribution on ℕ. But we did not need one. Exchangeability results suffice. The lesson generalises: one can reason coherently about one’s own chance of having a property even in infinite settings that forbid a uniform personal prior.

c. Updating on Impossibilities  
Learning that F occurred is learning the logically consistent yet probabilistically null fact that the real world is extraordinarily atypical. The standard Bayesian recipe of conditioning on measure-zero events—via regular conditionals or limits of positive-measure events—handles that scenario smoothly. We should resist the temptation to treat null evidence as delivering no information.

d. The Spectrum of Credence Revision  
At one pole lie “sharp” updates that drive probabilities to 0 or 1 despite the physical possibility that things could be otherwise. At the other are “smeared” updates that retain much of the prior. Puzzles like ours show that sharpness is sometimes forced by coherence. That observation may matter when considering epistemic permissivism or imprecise-probability approaches; one cannot in general maintain the old credence just because the new evidence is global or “distant”.

Conclusion  
––––––––––  
Once we treat the announcement “only finitely many heads” with the same probabilistic seriousness we accord any other information, the original symmetry that supported the ½ credence evaporates. Conditioning on a global constraint that can be satisfied by at most finitely many of countably many independent trials induces an extreme negative correlation: almost every coin must be tails. Formal symmetry, countable additivity, and the existence of a regular conditional probability together force the posterior credence for any particular coin to 0. Philosophically, the case drives home how learning measure-zero facts can rationally swamp previous independent evidence, and how the concepts of independence, self-location, and conditionalisation interlock when infinity intrudes.

Only rarely in everyday life do we confront evidential situations in which (i) the evidence we receive has prior probability zero and (ii) the population with respect to which we locate ourselves is infinite.  When both ingredients are present, our ordinary heuristics—“update by conditionalising,” “independent events stay independent,” “if nothing distinguishes me from the others, treat myself as a random member”—start to pull in different directions.  The case of the “miraculous room” of coin-tossers is a paradigmatic laboratory in which to examine the tensions.  I shall argue for the following thesis.

Thesis Upon learning that only finitely many of the countably many coins landed heads, a rational agent should set her credence that her own coin landed heads to 0.  Although the event on which we condition has prior probability 0, a well-motivated regular conditional distribution exists and yields that value.  The appearance that the answer ought to remain ½ stems from a misplaced appeal to independence; once we condition on the global event, the outcomes of the individual coins become stochastically dependent, and that dependence—together with a self-locating symmetry principle—drives the conditional credence to 0.

The argument proceeds in five stages.  I (1) lay out the set-up formally and show why the ordinary rule of conditionalisation is seemingly silent.  I then (2) develop an intuitive “ratio of heads to people” argument that strongly suggests the answer 0.  Because intuitive counting is cheap currency in infinity, I (3) prove a theorem establishing the same result via a standard measure-theoretic construction of regular conditional probabilities.  I then (4) answer three objections, the most important of which presses that we are not “randomly selected” from the population.  Finally (5) I draw some philosophical morals about conditioning on null events, independence, and self-location.

1.  Formalising the problem

Let Ω = {H, T}^ℵ₀ be the sample space of all bi-infinite sequences ω = (ω₁,ω₂,…) of coin tosses, where ω_i = 1 (“H”) or 0 (“T”).  The probability measure P is the usual product measure assigning probability (½)^n to each cylinder determined by finitely many coordinates.  For each i∈ℕ, let H_i be the event {ω : ω_i = 1}.  Let F be the σ-algebra generated by the cylinder sets.

Define E = “only finitely many coins land heads”, i.e.

E = {ω ∈ Ω : Σ_{i=1}^∞ ω_i < ∞ }.

Kolmogorov’s zero-one law or any elementary application of the strong law of large numbers shows P(E)=0.  We, the agent indexed as i=1 without loss of generality, learn E.  (If you prefer, rename the people after the fact while keeping the σ-algebra and measure fixed; the symmetry considerations below remain intact.)  We want P(H_1 | E).  Ordinary conditional probability is defined only when P(E)>0.  We thus need some principled extension of conditionalisation to null events.

Two general responses are available:

A.  Scepticism: because conditioning on measure-zero events is undefined, rationality places no constraint on our credence; retain ½ or pick whatever feels right.

B.  Regularisation: look for a well-behaved family of conditional probabilities {P_E} (“regular conditionals”) that extend the ordinary definition.  In standard Borel spaces such families always exist and can typically be rendered unique by natural symmetry constraints.

I pursue route B.  But before plunging into the formalities, it helps to see why the answer ½ is already doubtful.

2.  The ratio-of-heads argument

Imagine walking around the (possibly infinitely large) room after the tosses have taken place but before anyone has looked.  God tells the crowd: “Only finitely many of you have a heads.”  Instantly everyone realises that, for all but finitely many people, their personal outcome must be tails.  Equivalently, among the population of observers there is a set H_* of heads-holders that is finite, and its complement T_* is infinite.  Now ask: if you pick a person uniformly at random from a set containing finitely many heads and infinitely many tails, what is the probability that the person picked has a head?  The natural answer is 0, because any finite subset has measure zero relative to an infinite one when we use the natural count (cardinality) to induce the uniform distribution.  Since (under typical symmetry principles) each person should regard herself as such a “randomly selected” member—there is nothing that distinguishes me from you before we look at our coins—each individual should give weight 0 to being in the finite, exceptional class.

One might immediately object: uniform selection from a countably infinite set is itself problematic.  Indeed, there is no finitely additive, countably additive measure on ℕ that gives every singleton equal positive weight.  But the weight 0 conclusion we just drew does not rely on assigning a positive probability to each individual.  Instead it exploits a simple domination principle: if X is finite and Y is infinite and we attach equal mass to each element, then for any finitely additive measure that treats singletons equally, μ(X)=0 and μ(Y)=1.  So the intuitive verdict (credence 0) emerges even without a non-paradoxical “uniform” distribution over ℕ.  The real worry, then, is not in the counting but in the symmetry claim that justifies treating oneself as an arbitrary member of the population.  I postpone discussion of that until Section 4.  First we show that the 0 answer survives more rigorous scrutiny.

3.  A theorem about the regular conditional

Because E is a tail event (its truth is unaffected by altering any finite set of coordinates), the Kolmogorov zero-one law ensures P(E)=0, but it also furnishes a canonical family of regular conditionals constant on tail σ-algebras.  Here is the crucial lemma; the proof uses only exchangeability and elementary inequalities.

Lemma Let E_n = {ω: Σ_{i=1}^∞ ω_i ≤ n}.  For each n, P(E_n)>0.  Define

p_n = P(H_1 | E_n) = P(H_1 ∧ E_n) / P(E_n).

Then (i) p_n ≤ n/m for every m∈ℕ, and hence (ii) p_n = 0 for all n.  Therefore any limit of {p_n}—and hence any regular conditional probability obtained by approximating E by the nested sequence {E_n}—must assign probability 0 to H_1.

Proof Sketch.  Fix n.  Let m be arbitrary.  By exchangeability, the expected number of heads among the first m coins conditional on E_n is m·p_n.  But on E_n there are at most n heads in total, so certainly at most n among the first m.  Hence m·p_n ≤ n, i.e. p_n ≤ n/m.  Since m can be made arbitrarily large while n is fixed, p_n=0.  QED.

Because {E_n} ↓ E, Theorem 33.2 of Billingsley (Probability and Measure, 3rd ed.) guarantees that any regular conditional probability obtained via such a nested approximation is unique P-almost everywhere.  Accordingly, P(H_1 | E)=0.

Readers anxious about the dependency of the regular conditional on the choice of approximating sequence may note two points.  First, the sequence {E_n} is the most natural of all: it mirrors the content of E exactly.  Second, any other “reasonable” sequence that captures E from above will produce the same limit because Lemma 1 actually shows p_n=0 already, with no passage to the limit required.

Thus, on the best worked-out theory we have, the answer is unambiguously 0.

4.  Answering objections

Objection 1:  “Independence says my coin is fair no matter what happens elsewhere.”  
Reply.  Independence licences factorisation for unconditional probabilities: P(H_1 ∧ A) = P(H_1)·P(A) when A depends only on other coins.  But the event E is not independent of H_1; it explicitly contains information about ω₁.  Conditioning typically destroys independence.  Simple finite analogues illustrate the point: if two fair coins are tossed and you learn “at most one head occurred,” the conditional probability that your coin is heads is ⅓, not ½.

Objection 2:  “I am not randomly selected from the crowd; I am a particular individual.  Why should a counting argument that treats me as typical matter?”  
Reply.  The force of the counting argument resides in a self-locating symmetry principle (“indexical indifference”): before you look at your coin, there is nothing in your experiential state that picks you out from the rest.  If the physical setup is completely symmetric and you have no evidence of being special, rationality demands credences invariant under permutations of the observers.  From that symmetry, it follows that your credence must coincide with the probability that a randomly chosen observer (according to the symmetric measure) has heads.  One can deny the symmetry principle, but doing so generates implausible epistemic asymmetries.  For example, if you insisted on ½ while I adopt 0, yet both of us occupy observationally identical roles, our difference would be epistemically arbitrary.

Objection 3:  “Conditionalisation on null events is ill-defined; different approximations could yield different answers.”  
Reply.  Two responses.  First, even if strict Bayesianism declined to constrain your credence, you still need some rational principle to exploit the information that tails overwhelmingly dominate heads.  The symmetry-based regular conditional offers such a principle; the ½ rule offers none.  Second, the alleged non-uniqueness is illusory here.  Any approximating sequence that (a) is measurable with respect to the same tail σ-algebra and (b) captures the essential content of E must, by Lemma 1, yield probability 0.  The independence of the answer from the chosen route thus mimics the well-known uniqueness of conditional expectation in L².

5.  Philosophical morals

5.1  Conditioning on probability-zero events.  
Cases like ours tempt one to abandon conditionalisation altogether when P(E)=0.  That move is premature.  Regular conditional distributions extend the Bayesian machinery smoothly whenever the underlying probability space is standard Borel—exactly the situation in which almost all scientific models live.  Learning E is akin to learning that a continuous random variable took some definite value.  Bayesians routinely handle that by invoking densities or Dirac deltas.  Our scenario is no worse.

5.2  The fragility of independence.  
Independence is not a metaphysical relation; it is a statistical property encoded in a probability measure.  Conditionalisation often destroys it.  That fact bears on recent debates about so-called independence principles in epistemology and philosophy of science.  For instance, some advocates of the Principal Principle (linking objective chance to credence) insist that conditionalising on “admissible” information should never alter one’s credence about an outcome’s fairness.  The miraculous-room example shows that even purely chancy information about distant tosses can be inadmissible once we pass to global events relating the tosses.

5.3  Self-locating uncertainty.  
Observers commonly treat themselves as typical among some reference class.  The Sleeping Beauty debate, Doomsday reasoning, and Boltzmann-brain puzzles all turn on which class is relevant.  The present case is unusually clean: every observer is qualitatively identical prior to looking at her coin, and the global information E does not break that symmetry.  Hence the principle of indifference over persons seems mandatory.  Critics sometimes complain that indifference is untenable in infinite contexts; but the regular-conditional machinery shows that the principle works fine so long as we combine it with countable additivity and the humility to assign probability 0 to being in special, measure-zero sub-classes.

Conclusion

The miraculous announcement “only finitely many heads” is powerful information.  Far from being irrelevant to the fate of your own coin, it virtually guarantees that you got tails.  Both intuitive counting and rigorous measure-theoretic analysis agree: the unique, well-motivated posterior credence is 0.  The case teaches three lessons of general philosophical interest: (i) Bayesian conditionalisation extends coherently to probability-zero events when regular conditionals are available; (ii) conditional independence is fragile, so one must not naïvely import prior independence into the posterior situation; and (iii) self-locating symmetry arguments remain compelling even in countably infinite settings, provided we are willing to let “typicality” be represented by probability 0 events.  Recognising these morals helps immunise us against the seductive but mistaken thought that, in the face of miraculous global information, “my coin is still fair.”

Only finitely many heads were tossed.

If there were only three people in the room, that declaration would immediately change your credence in the obvious way.  Learning that at most one head was tossed among three fair and independent coins makes it very unlikely that yours is the lone head.  What is puzzling in the present case is simply the scale: an ω-sized population of tossers and—exactly as in the finite case— the information that “the total number of heads is finite.”  Should that information matter to *your* toss?

Many philosophers’ first reaction is: “It cannot possibly matter.  My own coin is still a fair, independent coin; whatever the others did is irrelevant.  The right answer is ½.”  A second reaction, usually occurring a few minutes later, is: “Wait—if all but finitely many coins are tails, then almost everyone’s coin is tail.  Surely I should expect to be ‘typical’; so my probability of heads should plunge toward zero.”  The tension between these two reactions turns on deep questions about (i) what it means to update on an event of probability zero, and (ii) how to think about self-location in an infinite population.  I shall argue that, given familiar Bayesian principles extended to cover zero-probability evidence, the rational credence in Heads after receiving the report is *not* ½ but 0.  I then explain why the contrary view is tempting and why one might, under different epistemic norms, indeed stick with ½.

Outline of the discussion

1. Precisifying the case  
2. The zero-probability obstacle and “limit” conditionalisation  
3. A simple but decisive expectation argument for Pr(H | F)=0  
4. Steelmanning the ½ view: independence, self-locating indifference, and regularity  
5. Reconciling the two reactions: what the case teaches us about updating on measure-zero information  
6. Concluding moral

1.  Precisifying the case

Let 〈X₁, X₂, …〉 be a sequence of i.i.d. Bernoulli(½) random variables with Xₙ=1 when the n-th coin lands heads and 0 otherwise.  Let F denote the event that Σₙ Xₙ < ∞ (i.e. only finitely many heads).  Standard probability theory tells us Pr(F)=0, because by the Strong Law of Large Numbers the proportion of heads converges to ½ almost surely.

Everyone in the room is labelled by a natural number.  You know you are person i for some fixed, publicly known i (say, #1), and you have not yet looked at your own outcome.  The evidence you receive is precisely F.  The evidential question is: what is Pr(Xᵢ = 1 | F)?

2.  The zero-probability obstacle and “limit” conditionalisation

Bayesianism says: update by conditionalisation.  But conditional probability Pr(A | F) is undefined when Pr(F)=0.  Philosophers and probability theorists have responded by enriching the formalism:

Popper-Renyi conditional probabilities  
Radically, one simply takes conditional probability as primitive, allowing Pr(A | B) to be coherent even when Pr(B)=0, provided certain axioms are met.

Regular conditional distributions  
Within Kolmogorov’s framework one can define Pr(A | ℱ) for a σ-algebra ℱ, and then obtain Pr(A | F) by taking limits of more elementary events that approximate F from “within.”  In our case the natural approximating family is  
Fₖ : “At most k heads in total,”  k=0,1,2,…

Each Fₖ has positive probability, and F = ⋃ₖ Fₖ.

Limit-based conditionalisation (Bacchus, Goldblatt, McGee) adopts:

Pr(A | F) := limₖ→∞ Pr(A | Fₖ) whenever that limit exists and is independent of the approximating sequence.

I shall employ that rule, noting that alternative Popper-style accounts deliver the same verdict in this case.

3.  A decisive expectation argument: Pr(H | F)=0

Because the coin tosses are exchangeable, conditioning on any permutation-invariant event (and F is such an event) must treat each position identically.  Hence there is a single number p_k = Pr(X₁=1 | Fₖ) that also equals Pr(Xₙ=1 | Fₖ) for every n.

Now compute the expected number of heads given Fₖ:

E[Σₙ Xₙ | Fₖ] = Σₙ Pr(Xₙ=1 | Fₖ) = Σₙ p_k.

But by definition of Fₖ, at most k heads occur, so that expectation is ≤ k.  If p_k were any positive real, Σₙ p_k would diverge to ∞, contradicting that bound.  Therefore p_k must be 0.  

Taking limits:

Pr(X₁=1 | F) = limₖ→∞ p_k = 0.

So your rational credence in Heads, conditional on F, is zero.

The underlying intuition is simple.  F implies that only finitely many people landed heads.  If *any* fixed positive proportion of the infinite crowd retained a non-zero chance of heads, the expected total number of heads would explode.  The only way to cap the expectation is to reduce the per-person probability to 0.

A quick objection dealt with  
“But *some* people *did* land heads; the probability cannot be zero for them!”  Correct: conditional on F there is a finite, but random, set of indices whose coins are heads, and for each such ‘lucky’ index it is true that Xᵢ=1.  What the calculation shows is that the *prior* probability that any *given* index is among that finite set is 0.  A perfectly possible outcome may have zero probability in an infinite sample space; this is as unremarkable as the fact that any exact real number has probability 0 when you pick uniformly from [0,1].

4.  Steelmanning the ½ view

Although the expectation argument is decisive within standard probability theory, the opposing reaction deserves respect.  Let me reconstruct it as a principled position.

(4.1) Independence.  You were told in advance that the coins are independent.  Independence, on a frequentist reading, implies that learning about the other coins tells you nothing about yours.

Reply: Independence means Pr(Xᵢ=1 ∧ Xⱼ=1)=Pr(Xᵢ=1)Pr(Xⱼ=1) at the *prior* stage.  After conditioning on F the variables are no longer independent; indeed they become strongly negatively correlated.  Conditionalisation can destroy independence.

(4.2) Self-locating indifference.  You know you are a specific person i; nothing in F singles you out.  By a ‘principle of indifference among labelled individuals’ you should regard yourself as randomly located among the ω people, and since the *frequency* of heads conditional on F is 0 (in limit) but not identically 0, the self-locating probability should remain ½.

Reply: Indifference among labels is already accounted for by the exchangeability argument above.  An indifference that insists on Pr(Xᵢ=1 | F)=½ in the teeth of that argument amounts to denying that learning global information can affect self-locating beliefs.  That is tantamount to Lewis’s “Principal Principle” deprived of its conditional clause; few Bayesians accept such a restriction.

(4.3) Regularity.  Many Bayesians impose the ‘Regularity’ norm that every logically possible proposition must have non-zero prior probability.  They then find it unattractive to set Pr(Xᵢ=1 | F)=0, because that would violate Regularity at the posterior stage.

Reply: Regularity is already lost the moment we conditionalise on F, since F itself had prior measure 0.  Once one accepts zero-measure updating, nothing in Regularity prevents zero posterior probabilities for contingent propositions.

A popular slogan is ‘zero-probability events carry no information.’  That slogan is false.  The catch is that a *true* measure-zero proposition can be hugely informative exactly because its truth zeroes in on an extreme corner of the sample space that the prior probability function had almost rejected.

5.  Reconciling the two reactions

The philosophical anxiety behind the half-and-half reaction is the sense that “my own toss was independent, so why should what happened en masse matter?”  The mathematics shows why it must matter; but one can tell an intuitive story as well.

Imagine a finite but very large crowd of N people and suppose you are told “at most k heads were tossed,” with k ≪ N.  Now your chance of having heads is k/N: tiny.  Let k stay fixed while N→∞.  The chance goes to 0.  The infinite-crowd/finite-heads scenario is simply the limit.  So nothing mysterious is happening; the infinite case merely packages up an elementary finite-case inference.

What is unfamiliar is merely that the evidence F had prior probability 0.  In everyday life we rarely receive such information.  But theoretical physics and cosmology are beginning to force similar updates upon us (e.g. zero-measure anthropic conditionals); so we had better have a doctrine for them.  Bayesians do: adopt a conditional probability function (Popper-style) or define limits via a net of positive-measure approximants.  Once one does, the present puzzle evaporates.

But why does the ½ intuition arise with such force?  Partly because people tacitly apply ‘screening off’ principles valid only for *finite* collections.  With infinite collections, events about the *ensemble* (σ-algebra generated by tail events) can correlate strongly with each individual element without singling any of them out.

Indeed Kolmogorov’s 0-1 law asserts precisely that: any ‘tail’ property of an i.i.d. sequence has prior probability 0 or 1, yet conditioning on such a property can drastically alter probabilities of initial coordinates to 0 or 1.  Our event F is a tail event; the 0-1 law predicts the extremal update we just derived.

6.  Concluding moral

Your rational credence that your coin landed heads, upon learning that only finitely many heads were tossed in the room, should be 0.  The core reason is that a single person’s chance must be small enough to make the expected number of heads finite, and exchangeability then forces that chance to be zero.  The fact that F had prior probability 0 is no barrier to updating; modern Bayesianism handles it by taking limits of positive-measure approximations or by treating conditional probability as primitive.

The puzzle presents a vivid lesson: global information about an infinite system can overwhelm local independence, and measure-zero evidence can rationally drive posterior credences to the extremes.  Those who instinctively retain the ½ credence are implicitly assuming a norm—that independent causes remain probabilistically independent after any learning—that is false once one confronts the mathematics of infinity.

Rational belief, like physics, sometimes does surprising things at the infinite limit.  What matters is that our epistemic principles be capable of accommodating the surprises without contradiction.  On that score, the Bayesian machinery passes the test: it tells us, unambiguously and for good reason, that the chance your coin shows heads is—given the remarkable announcement—zero.

Heads or Tails After the Miracle?
Updating on Zero‐Probability Events in an Infinite Coin Room

1. The problem and the thesis  
Imagine an ω-sized hotel ballroom. Each occupant flips a fair coin, pockets it without looking, and waits. A public announcement is then made: “Only finitely many of the coins just tossed landed heads.” In the prior measure, that announcement reports an event of probability 0; indeed, by the Strong Law of Large Numbers, with probability 1 there are infinitely many heads. What, given the announcement, ought your new credence be that your own coin shows heads?  

I shall argue that a rational agent should assign credence 0 (or as close to 0 as one likes) to the proposition that her coin is heads. More carefully: every principled method of updating that (i) respects independence for finite approximations, (ii) treats indistinguishable observers symmetrically, and (iii) is defined for conditioning on measure-zero events, drives the posterior P(H │ F) to 0, where H is “my coin is heads” and F is “only finitely many heads occurred.” I also examine two rival lines of resistance—the “independence defence,” which would leave the credence at ½, and the “agnostic defence,” which would declare the posterior undefined—and explain why neither is ultimately satisfactory.

2. Why independence collapses once we condition  
Pre-announcement, the coin tosses are pairwise independent. A hasty reasoner therefore proclaims: “Whether there are finitely many heads among the others is independent of my individual throw, so my credence stays ½.” The step is illegitimate. Independence is destroyed by conditioning on F. The intuitive reason is clear: learning that the rest of the infinite population produced at most finitely many heads drags down the *overall* head-count; my own toss now helps constitute the finite set of potential heads, so information about the total bears directly on it.

This is a generic lesson: in probabilistic models, X and Y may be independent unconditionally yet correlated in every strict conditional circumstance. (Schervish and Seidenfeld 1990 formalise the point.) So we need an explicit conditional probability P(H │ F). Ordinary Bayes’ rule is silent because P(F)=0; but the need for a posterior constraint is not thereby removed. The question becomes: how should a rational Bayesian extend her credence function to handle zero-probability information?

3. Regular conditional probabilities by approximation  
A standard strategy is *van Fraassen–style limiting conditionalisation*: pick an increasing sequence of positive-probability “approximation events” whose intersection is F, condition on them in the normal way, and take the limit. Let  

F n m  = “among the first m+1 people, at most n heads occur.”

For fixed n, m, F n m has positive probability because it imposes only finitely many restrictions on finitely many tosses. Moreover  

⋂ n ⋂ ∞ m=n F n m  = F.

Compute

P(H 0 ∧ F n m ) = ½·P(≤ n−1 heads among the other m people)  
                 = ½·2 −m ∑ k=0 n−1 ( m k ).

P(F n m ) = 2 −(m+1) ∑ k=0 n ( m+1 k ).

Hence

P(H 0 │ F n m ) = ∑ k=0 n−1 ( m k ) / ∑ k=0 n ( m+1 k ).

Elementary asymptotics show that the denominator’s leading term ( k = n ) grows like m n /n!, whereas the numerator’s leading term ( k = n−1 ) grows like m n−1 /(n−1)!. The ratio therefore goes like (const)/m and tends to 0 as m→∞. Because the bound is uniform in n, the double limit (first m, then n) is 0. That proves:

lim n lim m P(H 0 │ F n m ) = 0.

On the hypothesis that rational update proceeds by such limits, your post-announcement credence in heads should be 0.

4. A combinatorial intuition: almost nobody can be a head-toss­er  
Even without the calculus, the underlying idea is compelling. The announcement partitions the ballroom into two camps: finitely many “heads people” and countably many “tails people.” Grant an undifferentiated symmetry principle—each person is qualitatively identical before the announcement—and the only σ-additive probability measure compatible with the symmetry, when restricted to F, assigns total mass 1 to the infinite block of tail-holders and 0 to the finite block of head-holders. The reason is simply cardinal arithmetic: you cannot sprinkle equal, strictly positive mass over ω+1 many atoms and still have a σ-additive measure summing to 1. One must give the ω-set full measure and the n-set zero. Learning that F is true pushes you into a world where observers with tails form a metrically overwhelming majority; the chance of being one of the rare heads collapses.

Think of an *infinite lottery*: tickets numbered 1,2,3,… are sold; finitely many are painted red. If you are told “the winning ticket is red,” your posterior probability that you hold the winning ticket is 0, because there are only finitely many candidates. The present case differs only in that you are both the ticket and the lottery participant.

5. Popper functions: a formal framework for 0-probability updating  
Some philosophers mistrust limit procedures and demand a primitive conditional defined for every ordered pair (A,B) with P(B)≥0. Popper functions meet that demand. Starting from the Kolmogorov field generated by all coin-toss propositions, one can extend the prior into a Popper function *P\** whose defined conditionals include P\*(H 0 │ F)=0. The construction (e.g. McGee 1994) picks an ultrafilter over countable tails events and singles out a finitely additive measure that, when regularised to σ-additivity, yields the same limiting behaviour just exhibited. So the limit argument is not a crutch; it merely *reveals* what any sensible completion of the probability space must say.

6. Self-locating belief and the reference-class problem  
Could one resist by denying that “I am a random member of the ballroom” is licit? Without a uniform distribution over ω many indices, maybe the symmetry argument falls. Yet the update we derived does not presuppose any antecedent random selection. All it presupposes is that before the announcement you were willing to assign positive probability ε>0 to being *any particular* person. That is already built into the original indifference over people; otherwise your prior was defective. Once F is learned, the *relative* weights of individuals cannot remain equal, for that would allocate ε to each of countably many tails-people and blow up normalization. The standard way to repair normalization is to keep the equal-weight assumption among the tails (they are still symmetric) and shrink the weight of each head-person to 0. The result is exactly the Popper function above.

More intuitively, in scenarios of infinite duplication, indexical information often swamps non-indexical evidence. Learning “only finitely many heads” is indexical if we describe it as “I find myself in a world in which only finitely many heads were tossed.” The anthropic literature (Bostrom 2002; Sider 2008) teaches that such indexical updates can drive probabilities to extremal values. The present case is a bloodless illustration.

7. Objection I:
“The announcement had probability zero, so Bayesianism supplies no mandate. Rational belief becomes undefined; ½ remains permissible.”  

Reply: Bayesianism without a rule for zero-probability learning is incomplete. Real agents learn all sorts of measure-zero data (exact measurement readings, for instance). Either one supplements standard Bayesianism with a regular conditional or one accepts Dutch-book vulnerability. Suppose you retained credence ½ in H after F. A clever bookie offers you, at fair odds, a bet that pays $1 if your coin is heads and costs $½ to buy in. Simultaneously, she sells each *other* agent an exactly compensating bet whose price is set using the same ½ posterior you profess. Because only finitely many of those other bets can pay off, while countably many will collect stakes from their buyers, the bookie’s net exposure is bounded but her income is unbounded. You are part of a group sure to lose money in aggregate, revealing incoherence in the alleged ½ posterior.

8. Objection II:
“Independence is a *logical* fact. No information about other coins can rationally affect my belief about mine.”  

Reply: The alleged logical fact is a misapplication of probabilistic independence. If I condition on “exactly one of the two fair coins came up heads,” the probability that my coin is heads is ½? No, it is ½ *given the independence* of the tosses preconditioning, but the conditioning destroys independence; in fact the posterior is ½ exactly *because* the event is symmetric between the two coins. Remove symmetry by changing “exactly one” to “at most one,” and my posterior probability that I am the head increases to ⅔. Analogously, the claim that F is information about “other coins only” is false: F is a conjunction across *all* coins, including mine. My toss is one of the infinitely many constrained by F; hence it is evidentially relevant.

9. Residual worry: numerical extremity  
Credence 0 may feel too strong: shouldn’t an event of probability ½ retain *some* weight, however tiny? The answer is that “my coin is heads” is not a mere event of prior probability ½; it is one component of an outcome space whose structure has been radically re-weighted by the new evidence. After conditioning, every finite set of people bears probability 0 of containing you, and the head-people constitute a finite set. Since H entails your membership in that finite set, H acquires probability 0. Nothing prevents you, as an ideal Bayesian, from assigning credence 0 to events that were formerly quite live; what matters is coherence relative to the total body of evidence.

10. Agnostic alternative: imprecise credence  
Suppose someone balks and adopts an imprecise posterior interval, say [0,½]. Must we label her irrational? I think yes, because the interval still permits ½, and any selection function that chooses ½ is open to the Dutch-book just sketched. More generally, imprecision theories gain plausibility when rival precise updates look arbitrary; here the precise update to 0 is not arbitrary but uniquely justified by both the limiting and the symmetry arguments. Imprecision therefore buys only the superficial comfort of refusing to commit.

11. Philosophical morals  
(i) Zero-probability learning is not exotic; it is the rule whenever infinite random structures are involved. One needs a formalism (Popper functions, Lévy conforms, or limits) that makes sense of it.  
(ii) Self-locating information interacts dramatically with cardinality. In finite cases, learning “exactly k heads” keeps the symmetry between heads and tails conjointly intact; in infinite cases, learning “finitely many heads” breaks the symmetry, because the tails retain ω-cardinality while the heads do not.  
(iii) The epistemology of infinity forces extremes: once the informational content picks out a set of possible observer-moments of lower cardinality than its complement, the smaller set generically gets probability 0 (or 1, if roles reverse). This is a special case of a theorem due to Gaifman (2004) on Boolean algebras of infinite partitions.

12. Conclusion  
You started in an impartial, fair-coin world. The announcement that only finitely many heads occurred is nothing short of miraculous, but *assuming you trust it*, rationality compels you to update radically. Formal Bayesianism extended to handle measure-zero events, intuitive symmetry reasoning, and Dutch-book arguments converge: your posterior credence that *your* coin shows heads should be 0. Hanging on to ½ misdiagnoses the evidential relevance of the announcement and violates coherence; declaring the posterior undefined leaves you without betting guidance where a uniquely coherent answer is available. In the strange evidential landscapes carved out by infinity, extremal credences are not merely permissible—they are sometimes mandatory.

Only a philosopher would try to form a belief about the outcome of a coin she has not looked at after being told something that—by her own lights—had probability 0 of happening.  Yet the puzzle is more than a curiosity about infinitesimals.  It presses on deep issues about (i) how Bayesian agents should conditionalise on probability-zero information, (ii) the relation between indexical or “self-locating’’ belief and ordinary objective probability, and (iii) whether the independence of coin tosses survives the imposition of global, highly‐improbable constraints.  My thesis is that, once the problem is sharply framed, a rational agent’s credence that her own coin landed heads should drop to 0.  The route to that verdict is instructive, both because it reveals why the competing “keep it at ½’’ intuition is seductive and because it shows how familiar Bayesian machinery must be supplemented when we confront infinite systems.

I.  Setting the stage

Let ⟨C₁, C₂, …⟩ be a countable sequence of independent fair coins, where Cᵢ = 1 for heads and 0 for tails.  Let Ω = {0,1}^ℕ with the usual product σ-algebra and product measure μ.  In that measure, the random variable H = ∑_{i=1}^{∞} Cᵢ is almost surely infinite; indeed, by the second Borel–Cantelli lemma, μ(H = ∞) = 1.  Hence the event

 F := {ω ∈ Ω : H(ω) < ∞}   (“only finitely many heads’’)

has μ-measure 0.  You are told that F is actual.  What, now, is P(C₁ = 1 | F)?  The catch is immediate: ordinary Bayesian conditioning requires dividing by μ(F), but μ(F)=0.  Formally, the question is ill-posed until we say how to extend conditionalisation to measure-zero events.

II.  Three misleading lines of thought

1.  Naïve independence.  One might argue: “My toss was independent of the others, so learning about them tells me nothing; credence stays at ½.”  That is wrong.  The event F is not solely about the other coins; it includes a claim about C₁.  C₁ is independent of the σ-algebra generated by {C₂, C₃, …}, but F is not in that σ-algebra.  Global constraints couple otherwise independent variables.

2.  “I am a particular person, not a random sample.”  True, you are person #1 by stipulation; yet conditional probability concerns possible states of the world compatible with one’s evidence, not metaphysical modality about “which person I am.”  Evidence F restricts possible ω; within those ω, C₁ sometimes lands heads, sometimes tails.  We seek the ratio of possibilities, not a sampling interpretation.

3.  Finite‐approximation scepticism.  Because F has probability 0, perhaps no “sharp” answer exists and rationality imposes no constraint.  That is too pessimistic.  Probability theory offers regular conditional probabilities—generalised posteriors defined μ-almost-everywhere, often fixed by natural limiting procedures.  Although they are not unique on measure-zero sets, additional symmetry principles can still single out a canonical answer.

III.  A canonical limiting procedure

The orthodox way to condition on a μ-null event is to approximate it by a decreasing sequence of positive-measure events and then take a limit of ordinary posteriors.  Let

 Fₙ := {ω : H(ω) ≤ n}.

Each Fₙ is measurable and μ(Fₙ) > 0 (in fact μ(Fₙ) decreases super-exponentially with n).  Note that F = ⋂_{n=1}^{∞} Fₙ.  Define

 pₙ := μ(C₁ = 1 | Fₙ) = μ(C₁ = 1 ∧ Fₙ)/μ(Fₙ).

If the limit lim_{n→∞} pₙ exists, Bayesians usually take it to be μ(C₁ = 1 | F).

A quick calculation shows pₙ = 0 for every n.  Why?  Suppose C₁ = 1.  Then the remaining infinitely many coins must contribute at most n−1 heads.  But by the same Borel–Cantelli argument applied to coins 2,3,… the probability of that is 0.  So μ(C₁ = 1 ∧ Fₙ) = 0, whence pₙ = 0.  The limit is trivially 0.

Thus, by the most straightforward regularisation, μ(C₁ = 1 | F)=0.

IV.  Exchangeability and the “random observer’’ angle

There is another, conceptually illuminating route to the same answer.  The joint distribution of the Cᵢ is exchangeable; informally, everything is permutation-invariant.  De Finetti’s representation theorem tells us there is a latent parameter Θ with a Uniform[0,1] prior such that, conditional on Θ=θ, the coins are i.i.d. Bernoulli(θ).  The event F occurs exactly when θ=0: if θ>0 then almost surely infinitely many heads occur; if θ=0 then almost surely none do (a fortiori finitely many).  Because the prior puts zero probability on a point value, μ(Θ=0)=0, cohering with μ(F)=0.

Now suppose, arguendo, that we did learn Θ=0.  Given that parameter value, each coin is independently heads with probability 0.  So P(C₁ = 1 | Θ=0)=0.  Since F implies Θ=0, we recover the previous verdict from a different perspective.

V.  Why ½ still tempts us

Many people react that the argument just given must be illicit, for a world with only finitely many heads still allows C₁ to be heads; surely a rational agent should acknowledge that possibility.  Two remarks deflate the worry.

1.  Possibility versus probability 0.  That C₁=1 is not ruled out logically but can still receive credence 0.  Standard probability theory assigns probability-0 to each individual point of ℝ without thereby declaring them impossible.  A posterior that makes the exceptional cases measure-zero is perfectly orthodox.

2.  Countable sums of 0 can be positive.  If each agent assigns P(Cᵢ=1 | F)=0, the expected number of heads conditional on F is indeed the countable sum of zeros, which is 0; yet F allows worlds in which exactly 5 heads appear.  That is not a contradiction.  Conditional expectation is itself an integrable random variable; the fact that its integral can differ from actual realisations is familiar from, e.g., the law of large numbers.

VI.  The role of indexical information

Could “self-locating’’ information salvage the ½ answer?  Suppose (controversially) that on learning F you are entitled to treat yourself as a randomly selected member of the infinite population.  Given that only finitely many heads exist, the chance that the random selector picks a head-owner is 0.  One again obtains credence 0.  In fact, trading on indexicality strengthens rather than weakens the zero result.

VII.  Is the answer forced?

Because regular conditional probabilities are not uniquely determined on null sets, one might suspect that some rival regularisation could deliver ½.  Technically that is true: we could define a quirky conditional distribution that assigns P(C₁=1 | F)=½ while still agreeing with μ on every positive-measure event.  But such a distribution would violate permutation invariance.  Symmetry under permutations of the coins is part of the background—and rational agents ought to respect available symmetries unless compelled otherwise.  Among all extensions, the invariant one is uniquely fixed and yields 0.  So, given a minimal symmetry principle, the answer is forced.

VIII.  Lessons about Bayesian norms

1.  Conditionalisation:  The example vindicates the common Bayesian policy of “approximate, then limit’’ rather than the naive ratio formula, which breaks at μ(F)=0.

2.  Regularity:  Finite additivity is sometimes proposed to handle conditioning on null sets, but here the finitely additive versions that make P(C₁=1 | F)=½ behave badly—they violate conglomerability across the permutation partitions.  Hence σ-additive orthodoxy earns its keep.

3.  Independence:  Learning a global, holistic fact can create dependence between previously independent variables.  That moral carries over to epistemology: extremely low-level correlations can spring into existence once we condition on a highly specific total state of the universe.

IX.  Two objections answered

Objection 1: “Your approximation argument secretly assumes C₁ tails; it is therefore question‐begging.”  
Reply: No.  For each n, the event Fₙ already constrains the infinite tail of the sequence enough to make the joint probability of (C₁=1 & Fₙ) vanish.  That vanishing is a theorem of the original product measure, not an assumption.

Objection 2: “If your credence is 0, you would refuse an offer that pays \$1 if your coin is heads at a price of an arbitrarily small ε>0; that seems irrational because you might be throwing away free utility.”  
Reply: A fair bet is one whose price matches expected value.  Conditional on F, the expected value of the ticket is 0; so any positive price is unfavourable.  The fact that you might get lucky is irrelevant—exactly the same as refusing a lottery with probability 10^{-100} of winning \$1 and price 1 cent.

X.  Comparison with finite analogues

In a finite room of N people, being told “at most k heads were flipped’’ would lower your credence from ½ to k/N (by simple symmetry).  As N→∞ while k stays fixed, that posterior tends to 0.  The infinite case can thus be viewed as the limiting behaviour of perfectly mundane finite cases.  The result is therefore not an artefact of infinity but a discontinuous limit we should have expected.

XI.  Broader philosophical pay-off

1.  The case dramatizes how qualitative information (“only finitely many’’) can swamp ostensibly local independence.  That phenomenon underwrites several anthropic puzzles, e.g. about freak observers in an infinite multiverse.

2.  It gives a concrete reason to distrust “keep old priors unless forced’’ rules of thumb.  Sometimes learning φ with prior probability 0 forces drastic, not incremental, revisions.

3.  It counters the lingering suspicion that probability-0 events are necessarily “beyond the scope’’ of Bayesian epistemology.  With the right tools (regular conditional probabilities plus symmetry) rational posteriors are well-defined and verdictive.

XII.  Conclusion

A rational agent who learns that, in a countably infinite sequence of fair, independent coins, only finitely many landed heads should assign credence 0 that her own coin landed heads.  The naive ½ intuition rests on a misunderstanding of conditional independence and on an implicit refusal to extend Bayesian conditioning to probability-zero events.  Once those misunderstandings are cleared, the zero answer emerges inexorably and survives scrutiny from approximation, exchangeability, and self-location alike.  The case illustrates—not for the first time but in a particularly stark form—how infinite idealisations force us to refine both our probabilistic techniques and our philosophical intuitions.

Only finitely many heads: what it means, why it matters, and how to think about your own coin

1. The set-up and the puzzle  
You and a countable infinity of other agents each toss a fair coin in the usual way. After the tosses you are told, with certainty, that only finitely many of the infinitely many coins came up heads. Call that piece of information F (“Finitely many heads”). Because the coins are independent and fair, the prior probability of F is 0. The question is what your posterior credence in the proposition H (“my coin landed heads”) should now be. There are two natural initial reactions.

A. Independence reaction.  My coin was fair and was flipped independently of all the others.  Independence seems to insulate it from whatever aggregate fact you just learned.  So keep credence ½.

B. Scarcity reaction.  If only finitely many heads were produced among countably many coins, heads are incredibly scarce.  In a situation in which almost every coin in the room is a tail, it looks unreasonable to assign ½ to the hypothesis that one’s own coin is a head.  So lower the credence—perhaps all the way to 0.

Both reactions have intuitive force; the task is to decide which, if either, survives careful scrutiny.

I shall argue that the rational posterior credence for H, conditional on F, is 0.  The core of the case is a symmetry argument that shows that any permutation-invariant way of updating on F must assign zero probability to head for every individual coin.  I then explain why the argument does not violate independence, why its crucial premise—a symmetry constraint—is compulsory in this context, and why the competing ½ answer collapses under pressure.  Finally I discuss what the episode teaches about conditionalising on events of probability 0 and about self-locating credences more generally.

2. Conditioning on measure-zero events: what is even at stake?  
Ordinary Bayesian conditionalisation is silent when the evidence E you learn had prior probability 0, because the Bayes quotient P(A & E)/P(E) is undefined.  The standard fix is to invoke a regular conditional probability (RCP).  For a probability space ⟨Ω, Σ, P⟩, a RCP for a σ-algebra 𝔽 is a family of probability measures P_E such that for all E∈𝔽, P_E concentrates on E and, for measurable A, the map E↦P_E(A) is a version of the conditional expectation of 1_A given 𝔽.  In nice spaces (Polish spaces with Borel σ-algebra), RCPs always exist but need not be unique.  What do you do when they disagree?  You add rationality constraints—symmetry, independence-preservation where appropriate, minimal updating, etc.—that pick out a privileged RCP.  The present case turns on one such constraint.

3. The symmetry of the problem  
The original product measure P on Ω = {0,1}^ℕ (“1”=head) is invariant under every finite permutation of coordinates, and indeed under every bijection of ℕ that moves only finitely many points.  Call this family of permutations G.  The evidence F (“there are only finitely many 1’s”) is also invariant under G.  A guiding norm of Bayesian rationality says: if both your prior and your new evidence treat certain transformations as symmetries of the situation, your posterior should too, absent further symmetry-breaking information.  Formally, we require:

(Equivariance)  For every g∈G and every measurable A, P_F(g A) = P_F(A),

where P_F is the posterior measure conditional on F and g A is the image of A under g.  The requirement is not ad hoc; without it, the ‘‘update’’ would arbitrarily distinguish coin tosses that are objectively indistinguishable given all your information.  Any posterior that violates Equivariance would be open to a dominance argument: a symmetry lottery would reveal a sure-loss if you violate the symmetry, paralleling probabilistic versions of the Dutch book.

4. The symmetry argument for P(H | F) = 0  
Let X_n be the indicator of “coin n landed heads.”  Equivariance implies that for all n,  

q := P_F(X_n = 1)  

is the same number; the conditional distribution treats each coordinate identically.  (Intuitively: after we learn F, nothing picks out any particular coin as special.)

Now ask about the expected number of heads under P_F:

E_F[Σ_{n=1}^∞ X_n] = Σ_{n=1}^∞ E_F[X_n]    (by linearity of expectation)  
                  = Σ_{n=1}^∞ q  
                  = q · ℵ₀.                                             (1)

But F tells us that the actual number of heads is some finite k (possibly 0).  Therefore the conditional expectation on that σ-algebra must be finite—indeed E_F[Σ_n X_n] ≤ sup{k∈ℕ}.  The only way (1) can be finite is if q = 0.  Hence

P_F(X_n = 1) = 0 for every n.                                           (2)

In particular, P_F(H) = 0.  Your credence that your own coin came up heads should crash from ½ to 0 when you learn F.

5. Why the independence objection fails  
The coins are independent in the prior measure, but they are not independent conditional on F.  F contains information about every individual coin: if my coin is heads, the finite bound on the total number of heads is already one notch closer to being exhausted, so the joint possibilities for the rest of the sequence tighten correspondingly.  Put differently: conditional independence requires that

P_F(X_n = 1 & F_other) = P_F(X_n = 1) · P_F(F_other),

where F_other is an event concerning only the other coins.  Nothing like that is true here; indeed P_F(X_n = 1) = 0 makes independence impossible (unless P_F(F_other)=0 for every nontrivial F_other).  So appealing to independence to hold onto ½ is question-begging: it assumes a structural property that fails, given the very information we are updating on.

6. The “why not ½?” objection in detail  
Suppose against the argument that you insist on P_F(H) = ½.  Combine that with Equivariance and countable additivity.  Then, as in (1), E_F[#heads] = ½·ℵ₀ = ∞, contradicting F.  To escape the contradiction you must jettison at least one of:

(i) Equivariance (symmetry with respect to G),  
(ii) Countable additivity,  
(iii) Bayesian conditionalisation via a RCP.

Option (ii) courts fanaticism; rejecting countable additivity would ripple destructively through standard probability theory.  Option (iii) would mean you refuse to conditionalise when you gain information, hardly a defensible stance for a Bayesian.  So you are forced to abandon (i), i.e. to adopt an asymmetric posterior measure that arbitrarily designates some infinite subset of coins as “likely heads” and the rest “likely tails,” even though nothing in your total evidence distinguishes them.  That strikes most philosophers—and virtually all decision-theoretic protocols—as irrational.

7. A concrete regular conditional that realises the 0 answer  
It is worth seeing that the 0 answer is not merely an abstract existence proof.  One explicit RCP goes like this:

• First choose a finite K with prior P(K = k | F) proportional to 2^{−2k}.  
• Then choose K distinct indices n_1,…,n_K according to the uniform distribution on k-element subsets of ℕ.  
• Put X_{n_i}=1 for i=1,…,K, and X_m=0 for every other m.

Because K is almost surely finite and because the index-selection step treats all coordinates symmetrically, (2) holds: each fixed coordinate has probability 0 of being among the selected n_i’s.  The construction shows the abstract argument is implementable inside the standard probability space.

8. Worries about being “randomly selected”  
Some philosophers resist the scarcity reaction by pointing out that there is no uniform probability distribution over ℕ; so what licenses treating “my coin” as though it were selected uniformly at random from the countable set?  The symmetry argument above avoids that pitfall: it derives P_F(H)=0 without presuming such a selection.  What does the heavy lifting is the permutation symmetry of both prior and evidence, not an assumption of a uniform prior over people.  The very same reasoning would apply if the coins were labelled by the rationals or by the nodes of an infinite binary tree; indeed it applies to any countably infinite indexing set endowed with the natural product measure.

9. Lessons about self-locating belief  
The problem is a cousin of the Sleeping Beauty family of puzzles, which mix ordinary empirical information with indexical “where am I in the world?” information.  In Sleeping Beauty, the crux is whether Beauty should treat awakening on Monday as evidence about the coin outcome, given that the number of awakenings depends on that outcome.  Here the pity is reversed: we condition on a global structural feature (finitely many heads) that correlates with our indexical location (which coin we are).  The correct resolution in both cases depends on respecting symmetry constraints.  In Sleeping Beauty, the symmetry supporting the “⅓ view” is between awakening tokens within the same experimental run; in our puzzle it is permutation symmetry between coins.  The moral is that self-locating information need not break all symmetries, but when it leaves some intact, rational credences must respect the residual invariance.

10. Objection: “But probability-1 events can fail to happen; why should facts of probability-0 dictate certitude?”  
You are not asked to be certain that your coin is tails; you are asked for a credence.  If P_F(H)=0, that is a rational degree of belief, not a claim of metaphysical impossibility.  In standard probability theory, assigning probability 0 to an event is compatible with its truth (Lebesgue-almost-everywhere arguments rely on that).  What the argument shows is that rationality forces the credence to 0; it does not show that heads for you is logically impossible.  Indeed, under P_F the event “my coin is heads” can happen, but it is an event of measure 0 inside a σ-field that already represents maximal information compatible with finitely many heads.

11. Objection: “Doesn’t Kolmogorov’s 0-1 law say tail events have probability 0 or 1?  Why doesn’t it force P_F(H)=1/2?”  
Kolmogorov’s 0-1 law applies to the original product measure P and to events in the tail σ-field (those unchanged by altering finitely many coordinates).  F is a tail event, which is why P(F)=0.  But H is not a tail event; it depends on coordinate 0.  The 0-1 law therefore has nothing to say about P_F(H).

12. Objection: “The Borel paradox shows that conditioning on measure-zero events is path-dependent.  Why trust the symmetry-based route rather than the independence-based route?”  
The Borel paradox warns that different ways of obtaining the same zero-probability information may justify different conditionals.  In our set-up the manner of learning is fully specified: you are told F, full stop.  That information has the described symmetry, and any way of learning it that breaks the symmetry would introduce extra evidence (for instance, being shown a particular cutoff N after which all coins are tails).  Once those extra details are included, the posterior for H can indeed be higher than 0 (for example, if you are told “from coin #10,001 onwards all coins are tails,” your own coin’s probability of head is 2^{−10,000}).  The lesson reinforces, rather than undermines, our conclusion: update only on what you have actually learned, and respect its symmetries.

13. A final intuitive picture  
Imagine the infinite line of people stretching out to infinity.  A booming voice announces: “Only finitely many heads!”  What could that world look like?  There must be some last head.  Maybe it occurs at position #12, maybe at #2,087, but there is some finite terminal index N beyond which every coin is a tail.  Now pick any particular person far enough down the line—say #1,000,000.  That person is almost certainly beyond N, hence almost certainly holding tails.  Because your epistemic situation is symmetric with that person's (you do not know your own index, and evidence does not distinguish coins), the same reasoning applies to you.  In the limit of that reasoning—made rigorous above—the ‘almost certainly’ becomes probability 0 of being a head.

14. Summary of the argument  
1. Our prior product measure and the evidence F are invariant under all finite permutations of the coin indices.  
2. Rationality requires the posterior to respect that symmetry (Equivariance).  
3. Equivariance forces every coin to have the same conditional head-probability q.  
4. If q > 0 the expected number of heads after conditioning is infinite, contradicting F.  
5. Therefore q = 0 and P(H | F) = 0.  
6. Attempts to retain ½ must violate symmetry, countable additivity, or conditionalisation; the first is irrational, the second radical, the third Bayesianly unacceptable.  
Hence rational credence that your coin is heads, after learning that only finitely many heads occurred, should be 0.

15. Broader moral  
The puzzle dramatises two morals that reach well beyond its toy setting.

First, zero-probability evidence can carry real epistemic weight.  Bayesianism handles it by conditionalising with respect to an appropriately symmetric RCP; doing so can change your subjective probabilities dramatically, as here from ½ to 0.

Second, global constraints (here, the scarcity of heads) can swamp local independence.  Independence facts are not sacrosanct; they are defeasible by new information that introduces correlations.  Recognising when that happens—and which symmetries survive the new information—is essential for rational belief revision.

Credence 0 may feel extreme, but extremity is enforced by the same probabilistic machinery that licensed your initial ½.  Fairness is not a magical shield around your coin; like any piece of evidence, it is revisable in the light of global information.  Once you discover that heads are finitely many in an ω-sequence where fairness almost surely produces infinitely many, the honest Bayesian verdict is: “Mine isn’t one of them.”

Heads, Tails, and Measure-Zero Miracles  
———————————————————————————————  
Consider the following epistemic situation.  A countable infinity of agents—call them 0, 1, 2,…—each tosses an independent fair coin but is not allowed to look at the outcome.  An experimenter then announces the astonishing fact F:

 F: “Only finitely many of the coins landed heads.”

You are agent 0.  Given that you now take F to be true, what ought your credence be that your own coin landed heads?  Should it remain at ½, drop to 0, rise to 1, or take some other value?  I shall argue for the following thesis:

 Thesis: Once you accept F, the rational credence that your own coin landed heads is 0.

I proceed in six steps.  (1) I explain why the ordinary Bayesian update rule breaks down when one is asked to condition on probability-zero information, and I motivate a natural repair.  (2) I offer two elementary but powerful symmetry arguments for the thesis.  (3) I derive the 0-answer by an explicit limiting-ratio calculation that makes the intuitive symmetry precise.  (4) I address two objections, one centred on the thought that “I learned nothing about my own coin,” the other on the suspicion that updating on probability-zero events is illegitimate.  (5) I contrast the present verdict with rival regular conditional probability proposals and explain why the rival that yields ½ is unstable.  (6) I extract two general morals about self-location and about reasoning in infinitary probability spaces.

1 Why ordinary Bayesian conditionalisation is silent here  
---------------------------------------------------------  
Classical Bayesianism tells us to update by conditionalisation:

 Credence_new(H) = Credence_old(H & E) / Credence_old(E)

when Credence_old(E) > 0.  In our set-up, however, the event F has unconditional probability 0.  (By the second Borel–Cantelli lemma each individual agent’s coin shows heads infinitely often with probability 1, so Credence_old(F)=0.)  The usual quotient formulation is therefore undefined, and Bayesianism offers us no unique updated distribution.  We need a supplementary norm: a rule for learning probability-zero propositions.

A standard suggestion (Kolmogorov 1950; Blackwell & Dubins 1962) is to approximate F by a nested sequence of positive-probability events F₁⊂F₂⊂… whose union is F, set conditional probabilities relative to each F_n, and take the limit if it exists.  I shall adopt that rule of thumb, but first some quick intuitive reasoning already points toward the 0-answer.

2 Two quick symmetry arguments  
------------------------------  
2.1 The “thin-needle” argument  
If only finitely many heads were tossed among countably many coins, then the set of heads is scattered sparsely through an ocean of tails.  Heads are like a finite number of needles in an infinite haystack.  Nothing distinguishes you, agent 0, from agents 57 or 882, except your index—an arbitrary label independent of the outcomes.  Because there are only finitely many needles but infinitely many stalks of hay, the probability that a randomly chosen stalk is a needle should be 0.  Since you have no reason to believe your index is special with respect to the outcomes, you should regard yourself as a “randomly chosen” agent for present purposes; therefore your credence that you are a needle (a head) should be 0.

2.2 The “lottery” argument  
Imagine instead that after all coins are tossed an omniscient being writes the indices of heads on slips of paper and places them in an urn.  F tells you that the urn contains only finitely many slips.  Now suppose, purely for the sake of vividness, that you do not know your own index; it will be revealed by drawing one slip uniformly at random from all indices (heads and tails alike).  Under F the urn of heads is finite while the population of slips representing tails is infinite.  A uniform draw from a countable infinity that includes a finite distinguished subset will almost surely miss that subset.  Hence the probability that you find your own index in the urn is 0.  Removing the picturesque disguise leaves the same conclusion for the original problem.

Neither argument pretends to be a formal deduction, but both embody the same probabilistic symmetry: conditional on F, heads are a measure-zero subset of agents.  The next section makes this rigorous.

3 A limiting-ratio calculation  
------------------------------  
Let H₀ be the event “my coin is heads.”  Fix any natural number n and let F_n be the event “at most n heads occur in total.”  We have  

 F = ⋃_{n=0}^{∞} F_n and F_n↑F.

Because each F_n has positive probability (indeed, extremely tiny but non-zero), ordinary conditionalisation within F_n is legitimate.  Define  

 p_n := Credence_old(H₀ | F_n).

We will show lim_{n→∞} p_n = 0, whence the limit-of-approximations rule mandates Credence_new(H₀)=0.

Computation.  Write Y for the number of heads among the coins tossed by agents 1,2,3,… (everyone except you).  Then

 H₀ & F_n  ≡ (H₀ & Y ≤ n – 1).

By independence,  

 Credence_old(H₀ & F_n) = ½ · P(Y ≤ n – 1).        (1)

Similarly,  

 F_n = [T₀ & Y ≤ n] ∪ [H₀ & Y ≤ n – 1],

where T₀ is the event “my coin is tails.”  These two subevents are disjoint, hence  

 Credence_old(F_n) = ½·P(Y ≤ n) + ½·P(Y ≤ n – 1).        (2)

Dividing (1) by (2) we obtain  

 p_n = P(Y ≤ n – 1) / [P(Y ≤ n) + P(Y ≤ n – 1)].        (3)

Now observe three facts about Y.

a) Y is the sum of countably many i.i.d. Bernoulli(½) variables, so Y=∞ with probability 1.  
b) Hence for every fixed n, P(Y ≤ n)=0.  
c) Nevertheless P(Y ≤ n) is not identically zero inside finite truncations; rather it tends to 0 extremely fast.

From (b) we immediately have P(Y ≤ n)=P(Y ≤ n – 1)=0, and hence the ratio in (3) takes the indeterminate form 0/0.  To break the tie we use finite-population truncations.  Consider the first m other agents and let Y_m be the number of heads among them.  Define p_{n,m} analogously:

 p_{n,m} := P(H₀ | H₀ ∪ T₀ together with Y_m ≤ n) = (½·P(Y_m ≤ n – 1)) / (½·P(Y_m ≤ n) + ½·P(Y_m ≤ n – 1)).

For each fixed m the underlying distribution is binomial, so P(Y_m ≤ n) > 0 whenever n ≥ 0.  Elementary algebra gives  

 p_{n,m} = P(Y_m ≤ n – 1) / [P(Y_m ≤ n) + P(Y_m ≤ n – 1)] ≤ P(Y_m ≤ n) / P(Y_m ≤ n) = 1.

More importantly, for fixed n we have lim_{m→∞} P(Y_m ≤ n)=0; that is, tails will almost surely swamp heads as we consider larger and larger prefixes only if n grows with m.  A standard ε-δ argument then shows lim_{m→∞} p_{n,m}=0 for every n.  Since p_n := lim_{m→∞} p_{n,m}, we obtain p_n=0.  Finally, lim_{n→∞} p_n=0, establishing the announced result.

Intuitively the calculation says: if you are told that at most n heads occurred altogether, and you let the population of tossed coins grow without bound, the chance that you are one of those ≤ n special heads shrinks to 0, no matter how large n is.  Learning only that the actual number of heads is finite offers no refuge.

4 Two objections answered  
-------------------------  
Objection 1: “But F tells me nothing about my own coin.  Why shouldn’t my personal credence stay at ½?”

Reply.  F does not single out your coin, but it does create a global correlation.  Think of a simplified variant with only three agents A, B, C who toss fair coins and are then told: “Exactly one coin landed heads.”  Each coin is still fair in isolation, yet every agent who accepts the announcement should assign credence 1⁄3, not ½, to her own coin’s being heads.  The reason is simple: exactly one of the three coins can be heads, and symmetry dictates equal chances that it is each of A, B, or C.  Our infinite case merely pushes the same logic farther: “exactly finitely many heads” instead of “exactly one.”  When the distinguished subset shrinks to measure zero, the personal credence shrinks to 0.

Objection 2: “Updating on probability-zero events is illegitimate.  Better to ignore F as a hallucination.”

Reply.  In ordinary life we do sometimes learn things that had prior probability 0: a perfectly precise real-number measurement, an unexpected theorem that falsifies a mathematical conjecture we had taken to be necessarily true, and so on.  Bayesian epistemology does not tell us to discard such information; it tells us to refine our prior or supply a conditional distribution that respects the new evidence.  In the present problem F is stipulated as fact, so any adequate epistemic rule must yield a determinate posterior.  The limit-of-approximations method, defended above, does just that and points to credence 0.  Ignoring the evidence is not rational change; it is refusal to update.

5 Why some rival proposals say ½ and why they fail  
---------------------------------------------------  
A number of philosophers (e.g. Hájek 2003 on analogous examples) have proposed supplementing Bayesianism with a “principal principle” for conditioning on events of probability 0: simply retain the original conditional probability P(H₀ | information about other coins only), which by independence is ½.  Formally, one chooses a *regular conditional probability* P*(H₀ | σ(Y)), where σ(Y) is the σ-algebra generated by all other agents’ coins.  Because H₀ is independent of σ(Y), one obtains P* = ½ almost surely, even on the zero-probability realisation Y=finite.

The difficulty is that regular conditional probabilities are not unique on measure-zero sets; different versions agree almost everywhere but can disagree on precisely those outcomes we now learn have obtained.  The ½-answer therefore hangs on an arbitrary choice.  A rival version is obtained by taking limits along the approximating events F_n, yielding the 0-answer.  Since both are mathematically permissible, which should an epistemic norm favour?

Three considerations tilt decisively toward the 0-version.

First, *conglomerability*.  An updating rule should not assign higher probability to an event than every member of a partition does.  But the ½-rule violates conglomerability relative to the partition {H₀, T₀}: conditioning on F yields P(H₀)=½ even though conditioning further on T₀∧F forces P(H₀)=0.  The limit-version respects conglomerability.

Second, *countable additivity of epistemic value*.
