Section II assesses substantive or content-based proposals and argues that they blur the distinction between autonomy and welfare.  Section III develops the historical alternative and explains how it handles paradigm cases of adaptive preference.  Section IV meets three major objections—paternalism, epistemic inaccessibility of causal history, and the charge of infinite regress—by refining the view into a “relational-historical” account.  Section V closes by sketching practical upshots for policy and personal responsibility.

I.  The Subjectivist (Procedural) Approach: Endorsement Without Independence

Frankfurt’s classic model (1971) defines autonomy in terms of a hierarchy of desires: a first-order desire is autonomous iff the agent has a second-order desire to have (or to be moved by) that first-order desire, and no higher-order conflicts unsettle her identification.  Subsequent proceduralists—Gerald Dworkin, Laura Ekstrom, and David Velleman—develop similar structures emphasizing reflection, coherence, or reasons that the agent herself can endorse.  What matters is not *what* is desired but *how* the desire nests within the psyche.

At first glance, the model appears tailor-made for adaptive preferences.  Suppose Lindiwe, a woman raised in an isolated rural community with no realistic economic prospects, says she *wants* early marriage and many children—and, at a reflective remove, declares she *wants* to want these things.  On Frankfurt’s test, Lindiwe’s preference enjoys full autonomy; she endorses it wholeheartedly.  Yet, many find it implausible that her wanting is entirely self-governing, because (a) her preference arose under severe informational and material deprivation, (b) it serves the very social structures that constrain her options, and (c) she could not easily cultivate or evaluate alternative ideals of life.

The proceduralist may reply that Lindiwe’s endorsement is corrupted by *coercive* socialization: she could not have rejected the preference without sanctions or ostracism, so endorsement is not truly free.  But Frankfurt’s own analytic machinery lacks the resources to register that corruption unless its traces persist as *psychic* conflict.  If social power succeeds so well that the agent experiences no internal ambivalence, the hierarchical test yields a false-positive for autonomy.  The approach therefore threatens to turn social domination into an *explanatory black hole*: once oppression colonizes the higher orders of desire, nothing in the procedure detects alien control.

Two further problems deepen the worry.

1.  Wholehearted endorsement can be *manufactured* by subtle manipulation—consider Robert Goodin’s example of a state that bombards citizens with propaganda until they “freely” embrace the party line.  Frankfurt’s model cannot distinguish this from genuine self-governance.  

2.  Proceduralist theories depend on an internal vantage point, but adaptive preferences are precisely those whose suspect origins lie in the *external* environment.  Even scrupulous first-person scrutiny may miss the relevant heteronomy.

Hence, while endorsement is plausibly *necessary* for autonomy—it captures the agent’s felt ownership—it is not *sufficient*.  The subjectivist diagnosis leaves the fox’s sour-grape preference entirely up to the fox, missing the explanatory role of the fence.

II.  The Content-Based Approach: Autonomy Versus Flourishing

Faced with these shortcomings, some theorists point to the *substantive* content of the preference.  Martha Nussbaum, in Women and Human Development, proposes a list of central human capabilities.  Preferences that renounce or undermine these thresholds, she argues, betray a failure of autonomy because they reflect adaptation to deprivation.  On this view, Lindiwe’s desire for early marriage is non-autonomous because it blocks her pursuit of education, political participation, and bodily integrity—goods she has a moral claim to enjoy.

Substantive theories score an important victory: they explain why adaptive desires are suspicious even when internally endorsed.  Nonetheless, they face three persistent objections.

1.  The conflation problem:  autonomy and well-being are different.  Someone might autonomously choose a course detrimental to welfare (e.g., the artist who opts for poverty to pursue her craft).  Content-based tests risk declaring such choices heteronomous merely because they harm the chooser’s interests.  That seems conceptually sloppy.

2.  The free-monk counterexample:  A cloistered monk voluntarily renounces sex, private property, and political agency—capabilities on Nussbaum’s list.  If his life choice flows from religious devotion and not coercive scarcity, most would deem it autonomous.  The content-test yields the wrong result unless ad hoc caveats are added.

3.  Cultural pluralism:  Assessing autonomy by universal goods invites charges of paternalism.  Cannot a person autonomously value familial interdependence over individual independence?  Content-based theories must either water down their list to near triviality or accept paternalistic implications.

In short, while appealing for egalitarian policy, substantive accounts mislocate the autonomy failure.  The problem with Lindiwe’s preference is not *what* she values but *why* she has come to value it under constrained and unjust circumstances.  The historical dimension still does the real explanatory work.

III.  The Historical (Etiological) Approach: Causal Pathways to Desire

Historical theories center autonomy in the genesis of a preference.  David Velleman’s “co-authorship” condition, Paul Benson’s “responsibility-compatibilist” model, Marina Oshana’s relational view, and Serene Khader’s work on adaptive preferences all share a core insight:  A desire is non-autonomous if it results from processes that bypass or subvert the agent’s critical capacities in ways she could reasonably resent.  The preference’s present-tense endorsement and content are secondary; what matters is whether the agent *could have shaped* that preference under fair conditions of dialogue, information, and social power.

Consider three stylized cases.

Case A:  The Peasant Wife (from Nussbaum).  She says she *prefers* not to eat more than a scant amount so that her husband and sons can eat; she is also convinced that women who speak in public embarrass their families.

Case B:  The Ghetto Youth (adapted from Jon Elster).  A teenager in a violent neighborhood claims he *does not want* to pursue higher education because “books are for chumps.”

Case C:  The Voluntary Ascetic.  An urban professional, after years of exposure to varied lifestyles, freely chooses a life of radical simplicity and donates her fortune to charity.

On the historical view, A and B manifest autonomy deficits because their preferences were formed in response to resource deprivation, gender hierarchy, or peer violence—factors that systematically curtailed the agent’s exposure to live alternatives and punished deviance.  In contrast, C’s preference, though similar in content to the peasant wife’s dietary self-denial, was cultivated under conditions of choice, deliberation, and social respect.  Thus the historical lens cleanly separates autonomy from both endorsement and content.

Why does history matter morally?  Two overlapping answers emerge.

(i)  Relational Justice:  Preferences produced by oppressive structures implicate *others* in the agent’s psychology; they are not fully “hers” because they carry the imprint of domination.  The injustice is social, not merely psychological.

(ii)  Counterfactual Competence:  Autonomy involves the agent’s capacity to assess, revise, and own her ends.  If that capacity was itself bent out of shape by formative constraints, present endorsement is epistemically unreliable.  The historical test functions like a quality-control check on the authenticity of desire.

This view, however, confronts three major objections.

1.  Paternalism Redux:  To declare a preference heteronomous because of its causal history seems to license third parties to override the agent’s choices “for her own good.”

2.  Epistemic Access:  How can we *know* whether a given preference stems from oppressive adaptation or genuine self-authorization?  Psychological histories are opaque.

3.  Infinite Regress:  If a preference’s autonomy depends on its lineage, must not the preferences that shaped the lineage be scrutinized, and so on indefinitely?

Section IV refines the historical account to answer these challenges.

IV.  The Relational-Historical Account: Autonomy as Critically Sustained Agency

A.  Core Proposal  

A preference P of agent A is autonomy-deficient to degree d if and only if:

(H) Formation:  P originated as a non-voluntary adjustment to constraints C that (i) were imposed by social structures that unjustly limited A’s feasible set, and (ii) would be repudiated by A under conditions of equal respect and information.

(R) Reflection:  Because C persists (or its psychological residues persist), A currently lacks adequate epistemic and social resources to subject P to sustained critical scrutiny.  

Together, H and R capture both backward-looking and present competencies.  R is crucial: an agent whose oppressive upbringing left her with a suspect preference may, through later education and dialogue, achieve critical distance and reaffirm the preference.  In that event, the autonomy deficit can *diminish* or vanish.  Hence the view is non-fatalistic.

B.  Reply to Paternalism

The account does not authorize intervention merely because a preference is adaptive; it licenses *empowerment*, not substitution.  The remedy for heteronomous history is to expand the agent’s opportunity and deliberative horizon—education, exposure to alternatives, legal rights—so that she herself can reconsider.  Only if the preference directly violates the rights of others (e.g., a slave who “prefers” slavery for everyone) may coercive override be justified on independent grounds.

C.  Epistemic Accessibility

True, we rarely possess certitude about causal histories.  Still, we often glean *converging evidence*: demographic patterns, testimonial reports, developmental psychology, sociological data.  If nearly all women in a region who lack schooling “prefer” child marriage while those given schooling exhibit diverse preferences, an inference to adaptive formation is warranted.  Moreover, the relational-historical account yields policy guidance that is relatively insensitive to error: where we suspect adaptive preference, the recommended response (broaden opportunities, supply information, dismantle unjust constraints) is beneficial even if the initial diagnosis was uncertain.

D.  Regress Avoidance

The regress dissolves once we note that autonomy is a *scalar* property.  The question is not whether some initial preference was *absolutely* uncaused—an impossible standard—but whether the lineage includes significant episodes of domination that the agent has not had a fair chance to reassess.  Each cycle of critical reflection can repair earlier deficits, so the chain does not run ad infinitum.

E.  Comparative Advantages

1.  It honors the intuitive pull of content critique without conflating autonomy and welfare: preferences hostile to flourishing are flagged as suspect when—and because—they plausibly owe their existence to oppressive history.

2.  It preserves endorsement as a *current* requirement: agents can reclaim autonomy over partly adaptive preferences by critical reaffirmation under improved conditions.

3.  It foregrounds power relations, a dimension muted in both procedural and substantive rivals.

V.  Implications and Concluding Thoughts

The account illuminates three practical domains.

1.  Development Policy:  When designing micro-credit, education, or health programs, the goal should be not to impose external ideals but to dismantle the background constraints that generate adaptive acquiescence.  Measuring “preference change” is less important than securing the conditions under which any preference, including the status quo, could be autonomously re-endorsed or revised.

2.  Legal Consent:  In contract, medical ethics, and sexual consent, the presence of ongoing structural coercion can taint apparently voluntary agreements.  Our view justifies enhanced safeguards (cooling-off periods, counseling, transparency) rather than categorical bans, thus balancing respect for agency with concern about autonomy deficits.

3.  Moral Responsibility:  Agents whose preferences stem from adaptive self-subordination may still be morally responsible for their actions, but blame should be mitigated to the extent that oppressive histories narrow their evaluative horizons.  This nuance supports restorative, rather than retributive, approaches to wrongdoing in marginalized contexts.

To conclude, adaptive preferences are less than fully autonomous chiefly because of *how* they are formed and *why* they persist—not because of their surface content nor solely because the agent presently embraces them.  A relational-historical account captures this fact by locating autonomy, and its deficits, at the intersection of personal psychology and social power.  It allows us to take individuals’ avowals seriously while refusing to treat endorsement as the last word.  And it recommends remedies aimed at expanding, rather than overriding, the agent’s own capacity for critical self-revision.  In the end, respecting autonomy requires more than listening to what people say they want; it demands attention to the fences that shape what they are able to imagine wanting at all.

Adaptive preferences are those we come to hold because our feasible set shrank: faced with limited or oppressive options, we reshape what we want so that our actual choices look attractive and psychologically bearable. Sen’s “happy slave,” the single‐option worker who hails her 18-hour shift as fulfilling, or the village girl who praises early marriage because nothing else is realistically available, are familiar examples. Though such agents avow their preferences sincerely, many philosophers sense that something about those preferences is “less than fully autonomous.” The task is to say what, exactly, is missing.

Three families of accounts dominate the literature:

1. Subjectivist or endorsement accounts, typified by Harry Frankfurt, locate autonomy in the agent’s higher-order identification with her first-order desires.

2. Content-based or substantive accounts locate autonomy in what is preferred—roughly, the preference fails because it targets an unworthy object (servitude, mutilation, subordination, etc.).

3. Historical or procedural accounts hold that autonomy turns on how the preference was formed—whether its etiology involves manipulation, coercion, or oppressive socialization.

My thesis is threefold.

A. Purely subjectivist models misdiagnose adaptive preferences because they treat wholehearted endorsement as sufficient for autonomy and therefore mistake the very success of oppressive socialization for evidence of freedom.

B. Pure content-based models identify genuine normative failings—oppressive preferences often do target bad or stunting ends—but they blur together autonomy with morality, cannot explain adaptive preferences that fix on seemingly innocuous ends (e.g., learning to love cabbage because meat is unavailable), and risk an objectionable perfectionism.

C. A refined historical account, enriched with a relational analysis of power, best captures the autonomy deficit. A preference is non-autonomous when its formation process systematically bypassed the agent’s critical capacities by capitalizing on her dependence or vulnerability. What matters is not simply that the preference arose under constraints—after all, all preferences do—but that it was shaped by social mechanisms aimed at adjusting what the agent can imagine, evaluate, and eventually endorse. The hallmark of oppression is that it colonizes the very procedures through which endorsement would normally secure autonomy.

The remainder of the essay defends these claims. First I frame adaptive preference formation more precisely. Then I evaluate the three accounts in turn, showing how each handles key cases. I close by articulating a relational-historical model that diagnoses the autonomy deficit without collapsing into moral perfectionism, and I answer several objections.

1. What Is an Adaptive Preference?

Jon Elster introduced the phrase by reference to Aesop’s fox: unable to reach the grapes, the fox devalues them (“they’re probably sour anyway”). Psychological research confirms the robustness of “preference change under scarcity”: dissonance reduction, focalism, and hedonic adaptation are normal human strategies. So mere adaptivity cannot be the problem. Indeed, agents often adapt autonomously—think of the mountaineer who, after injury, discovers the joys of birdwatching.

What distinguishes the troubling cases is that (i) the constraints are themselves unjust, typically products of social power, and (ii) the resulting preference tends to stabilize and legitimate the unjust structure. Adaptive preferences under oppression therefore have a dual function: they are coping mechanisms and ideological mechanisms. Any plausible autonomy analysis must register this duality.

2. Subjectivist Endorsement Accounts: Why Wholeheartedness Is Not Enough

Frankfurt’s hierarchical model says that I act freely when my first-order desire (say, to scrub the floor) is one I want to have. Higher-order endorsement distinguishes the willing addict from the unwilling one, the freedom fighter from the brainwashed conscript. If a village girl sincerely wants early marriage and wants to want it, Frankfurt seems bound to call her preference autonomous.

Advocates reply that Frankfurtian endorsement must be procedurally robust: the higher-order desire cannot itself be the product of bypassing manipulation. Frankfurt himself gestures at “decisive identification,” but he provides no machinery to detect illegitimate formation. The adaptive preference problem presses precisely on this lacuna.

Consider three counterexamples.

Case 1: The Happy Slave. Years of indoctrination make the slave wholeheartedly endorse servitude. Because indoctrination engineered the higher-order endorsement, the account needs an etiological condition—but acknowledging that shows subjectivism alone is insufficient.

Case 2: Internalized Misogyny. A woman in a patriarchal community not only wants to serve her husband but takes pride in wanting so. The preference sits coherently within her hierarchy of desires. Yet intuitively her autonomy is compromised, and the compromise traces to a socialization process that restricted what she could imagine a woman could decently want.

Case 3: The Contented Sweatshop Worker. He values 18-hour shifts because, given systemic poverty, the alternative is starvation. He identifies with his work ethic; adaptation spares him bitterness. Still, the authenticity of endorsement looks hollow, because the options were coercively narrowed.

These cases reveal a systemic vulnerability: the more thorough the oppressive formation, the more subjectivism certifies the result as autonomous.

3. Content-Based Accounts: The Lure and Limits of Substantive Independence

Some philosophers, influenced by perfectionist liberals like Raz or capability theorists like Nussbaum, hold that autonomy includes an objective element. If a preference favors servility, genital cutting, or self-destruction, then—whatever the agent thinks—something has gone wrong. The content is inconsistent with self-authoring agency.

This view has four advantages:

• It explains why autonomous agents care about certain goods (bodily integrity, practical reasoning, affiliation).

• It nails the intuition that preferences endorsing subordination are defective.

• It can criticize adaptive preferences even when the agent endorses them.

• It dovetails with political projects aimed at expanding capabilities.

Yet it pays three prices.

First, it risks conflating moral badness with autonomy deficit. Suppose Jan adapts to rationing by learning to love cabbage. Nothing morally objectionable about loving cabbage, but did Jan’s preference formation involve the same autonomy loss as the happy slave’s? A purely content-based test says no, so it cannot explain why we hesitate to treat her preference as fully hers when it originated in severe shortage.

Second, content tests court paternalism. To declare early marriage autonomy‐reducing because it is bad per se invites the charge that we are imposing external values and failing to respect cultural difference.

Third, content focus misses an explanatory datum: what makes adaptive preferences suspect is not just their objects but the fact that they emerged through social mechanisms designed to limit perceived alternatives. Two agents could both endorse a life of domesticity; if one had a real range of live options and the other did not, our verdict should differ.

4. Historical Accounts: Etiology, Bypassing, and Social Power

Historical or procedural theories claim that autonomy hinges on how the desire was produced. Robert Young, Ben Colburn, and Marina Oshana emphasize whether the desire was formed in a way that “bypassed” the agent’s critical faculties or emerged through pressured socialization. Relational theorists (Mackenzie, Stoljar, Friedman) tie bypassing to power: oppressive norms get internalized precisely because agents are dependent on the very relationships that convey them.

The historical approach can explain all three earlier cases:

Happy Slave: The preference is non-autonomous because systematic indoctrination bypassed the slave’s critical reflection.

Internalized Misogyny: The endorsement arose within a patriarchal culture that narrowed her horizon of possibility; alternative identities were socially disabled.

Contented Sweatshop Worker: Severe material coercion left acceptance of drudgery the only psychologically sustainable path; preference formation was reactive rather than deliberative.

Key virtue: the account explains why wholehearted endorsement is not decisive and why innocuous-looking preferences may still be suspect if they trace to unjust constraints.

Key challenge: All preferences have histories. Which features mark some as autonomy defeating? Here is where the notion of “relational bypassing” earns its keep.

5. Relational Bypassing: A Diagnostic Criterion

A preference is autonomy-defective when:

i. Dependence: It is shaped in a context where the agent’s access to valued goods (food, safety, recognition, love) depends on conforming to the preference.

ii. Constraint on Imagination: The social process restricts the agent’s ability to entertain alternative conceptions of the good life, either by informational deprivation or by sanctioning deviation.

iii. Immunization: The process inoculates the preference against future critical scrutiny, for example by attaching shame to dissent or valorizing self-sacrifice.

When (i)–(iii) jointly obtain, the agent’s critical faculties are not merely influenced (which is normal) but colonized. The resulting preference stabilizes the oppressive structure, feeding a loop in which domination reproduces itself via the very subjectivities it manufactures.

6. Objections and Replies

Objection A: “Many ordinary preferences (e.g., national tastes in food, fashion, language) fit criteria (i)–(iii). Does your account imply that most preferences are non-autonomous?”

Reply: The question is degree, not all-or-nothing. A relational-historical view yields a scalar autonomy metric. Mild dependence plus porous imagination plus easy revisability constitutes a low deficit. Oppressive contexts crank up all three dimensions: dependence is existential, alternatives are absent or punished, and dissent is pathologized. Adaptive preferences under oppression cluster at the high-deficit end.

Objection B: “Your account still smuggles in substantive value: it presumes that domination and imagination- restriction are bad. Isn’t this a covert perfectionism?”

Reply: The account presupposes only thin normative premises: autonomy requires that agents exercise critical reflection under conditions of adequate information and some freedom from coercive dependence. These are procedural, not perfectionist, conditions. One need not judge the content of the eventual choice; one need only care that the path to that choice remained open.

Objection C: “Sometimes adaptation is the best an agent can do; criticizing her preferences adds insult to injury.”

Reply: A relational-historical analysis targets the social conditions that produced the deficit, not the agent. Saying that the preference is non-autonomous does not blame the agent; it diagnoses a form of injustice that burdens her with coping strategies. Recognizing the deficit motivates reform: expand the option set, protect dissent, supply counter-narratives.

7. Why the Historical-Relational Account Outperforms Rivals

a. It isolates the autonomy dimension: by focusing on bypassing mechanisms, it avoids conflating autonomy with moral virtue or happiness.

b. It accommodates benign adaptation: if adaptation occurs without systematic bypassing (injured mountaineer discovers birdwatching through reflective exploration), autonomy is preserved.

c. It explains the political function of adaptive preferences: oppressive systems invest heavily in shaping subjectivity precisely because that secures stable compliance. The historical view makes sense of this fact; endorsement and content views do not.

d. It fits empirical data: psychological studies show that preference change under scarcity is mediated by threat to agency and sense of control. Interventions that restore perceived control (e.g., providing information, social support) reverse adaptive downgrading. Thus procedural conditions, not mere content or endorsement, are causal levers.

8. Two Illustrative Cases

Case A: Early Marriage in Rural Rajasthan

Girls aged 13–15 often express enthusiastic approval of early marriage, citing family honor and personal safety. Survey work reveals that many have never met an unmarried adult woman, schooling is logistically and culturally foreclosed, and dissent invites social ostracism. The endorsement is wholehearted; the content (marriage) is not prima facie evil. Still, autonomy is compromised because (i) dependence on family protection is total, (ii) alternative life plans are literally unimaginable, and (iii) honor norms immunize the preference from criticism (“a good girl never questions marriage”).

Case B: Post-Incarceration Job Aspirations

Former prisoners frequently report preferring low-paying manual labor “because it’s honest work.” Though honest work is unobjectionable, qualitative interviews show that the preference often arises after repeated rejections, discriminatory hiring, and parole requirements that threaten reincarceration if work is not secured quickly. The man adapts his career aspirations downward to avoid the psychic toll of futile striving. His preference is understandable, morally innocent, yet not fully autonomous in the sense that the labor market’s constraints and surveillance coerce its formation.

Content-based views must call Case B autonomous; endorsement views must call Case A autonomous. Historical-relational views diagnose both deficits and can say exactly why they differ in degree.

9. Policy and Ethical Implications

The relational-historical diagnosis suggests interventions:

• Expand capabilities: reduce dependence by providing material resources (micro-credit, social safety nets).

• Multiply counter-narratives: ensure access to dissenting viewpoints (media pluralism, education).

• Protect exit and voice: legal rights that make alternative life paths feasible.

The goal is not to induce agents to prefer some predetermined content but to reopen the procedural space in which preferences can form and reform.

10. Conclusion

Adaptive preferences appear less than fully autonomous because they are the sediment of unjust constraint. Subjectivist endorsement accounts mistake internalized domination for authenticity; content-based accounts rightly condemn many objects of adaptive desire but conflate autonomy with moral worth and overlook innocuous yet non-autonomous adaptation. A historical-relational approach, focusing on the etiological role of dependence, imagination constraint, and immunization, best captures what is missing: the agent’s critical standpoint has been colonized.

Because autonomy is fundamentally a relational achievement, sustained only where social and material conditions leave room for genuine self-direction, oppressive contexts convert psychological resilience into a political obstacle by molding what agents can want. Recognizing this dynamic clarifies both the philosophical puzzle of adaptive preferences and the practical urgency of dismantling the structures that make them necessary.

1. Introduction: the puzzle of wanting what confines us  

A factory worker in a garment sweatshop insists she prefers the fourteen-hour shift because “I am lucky to have any job at all.” A wife in a rigidly patriarchal household says she prefers to eat only after her husband and sons are finished: “It is simply right that men be served first.” A teenage girl raised in a refugee camp claims she does not want to continue her education: “School is for people with opportunities; I should help Mother at home.”  These are paradigmatic adaptive preferences—attitudes that have adjusted to a narrow, often unjust, range of feasible options.  They raise a distinctive autonomy puzzle.  On the one hand, the agents sincerely affirm these preferences; on the other, something seems amiss in treating them as fully self-governing choices.  If autonomy is the ability to determine one’s practical identity and life path, how can wanting the yoke of one’s own oppression count as autonomous?

The philosophical literature offers three broad explanatory strategies.  Subjectivist or “structural” accounts, exemplified by Frankfurt’s hierarchical theory, look solely to the agent’s own patterns of desire and endorsement.  Content-based or “substantive” accounts evaluate the moral quality of what is preferred; some desires, because of what they aim at, are ipso facto autonomy-undermining.  Historical or relational accounts focus on the processes by which the preference was formed, asking whether it arose from manipulation, coercion, or systemic injustice.  

I shall argue that:  

Thesis.  The autonomy deficit of oppressive adaptive preferences is best explained by a historical-relational account: such preferences are non-autonomous when (i) they result from socialization that structurally deprives the agent of epistemic and practical opportunities to question the constraints shaping them and (ii) the agent has not subsequently had a fair chance to re-evaluate them in conditions of expanded freedom.  Subjectivist endorsement is neither sufficient nor necessary for autonomy; content-based criteria risk paternalism and false negatives.  A historically relational test captures why, yet also when, an adaptive preference can eventually become genuinely one’s own.  

The argument proceeds as follows.  Section 2 clarifies autonomy and the concept of adaptation.  Sections 3 and 4 critique subjectivist and content-based accounts, respectively, using concrete cases.  Section 5 develops the historical-relational alternative and shows how it resolves the puzzle while avoiding paternalistic overreach.  Section 6 replies to two important objections: the “rational accommodator” objection and the “inescapable history” objection.  A brief conclusion draws policy implications for empowerment and social justice.

2. Autonomy and adaptive preference: setting the conceptual stage  

2.1 Autonomy: procedural, substantive, relational  

Autonomy has long been parsed along three axes.  A procedurally autonomous choice issues from an internal psychological structure that is reflectively endorsed (Frankfurt, Dworkin).  A substantively autonomous choice must also meet certain content standards—e.g., respect for one’s own moral worth (Korsgaard, Nussbaum).  Finally, a relational account insists that autonomy is exercised within social power relations; distorted socialization and dependency can invalidate even procedurally sound, morally acceptable preferences (Oshana, Benson, Christman).

2.2 Adaptive preferences  

Sen coined the term to explain why the oppressed often report high levels of life satisfaction.  But adaptation is not merely reporting happiness; it is a dynamic of preference formation: when an agent’s feasible option set shrinks, preferences shift toward what remains available, thereby reducing cognitive dissonance between desire and possibility.  The result can be epistemically and emotionally protective, yet it risks locking an agent into an unjust status quo.  

Importantly, not every adaptation is autonomy-defeating.  Preferring black coffee after learning you are lactose-intolerant seems perfectly benign.  What concerns us is adaptive preference under oppression—where constraints stem from unjust power structures that the agent has no reasonable moral obligation to accept.

3. The limits of subjectivist endorsement  

3.1 Frankfurt’s hierarchical model  

For Frankfurt, an agent is autonomous—or, in his terminology, has “free will”—when her first-order desires are aligned with her higher-order volitions.  If I not only want to smoke but also want to want to smoke, my smoking is an expression of self-governance.  Applied to adaptive preferences, the subjectivist would say: as long as the sweatshop worker reflectively endorses her preference for fourteen-hour shifts, her choice is autonomous.

3.2 Why endorsement is not enough  

a) Self-subordination can be wholehearted.  Empirical studies of internalized sexism and racism show that members of subordinated groups can—and often do—wholeheartedly endorse their own subordination.  The “happy housewife” of Betty Friedan’s critique passes Frankfurt’s hierarchical test, yet her preference is precisely what critics call adaptive and autonomy-compromised.  

b) Endorsement can be engineered.  Suppose a totalitarian regime subjects citizens to pervasive propaganda until they sincerely endorse the regime’s ideology.  Even if the citizens now wholeheartedly prefer their chains, we hesitate to call them autonomous, because their endorsement itself is the product of manipulation.

c) Frankfurt’s regress problem.  One might posit higher-order endorsements of the second-order volitions, but unless we eventually appeal to how those desires formed, the account becomes either viciously regressive or arbitrary.  A purely structural view cannot discriminate between free endorsement and endorsement produced by oppressive socialization.

4. The ambitions—and perils—of content-based criteria  

4.1 Substantive theories  

Nussbaum’s capabilities approach proposes a list of basic functionings (nutrition, bodily integrity, practical reason, etc.).  A preference that rejects significant capability—say, a girl who prefers not to be educated—counts as “incomplete” or “corrupted.”  Similarly, Raz claims that autonomy requires an adequate range of valuable options; if the content of one’s choice undermines one’s agency or well-being, autonomy is absent.

4.2 The paternalism worry  

Content criteria can flag the most repugnant adaptive preferences, but at the cost of overriding individuals whose life plans genuinely differ from dominant values.  Consider the Buddhist monk who freely embraces poverty and celibacy.  On a crude capability threshold (income, sexual expression) his preference looks disqualifying, yet few would deny the monk’s autonomy.  Content-based accounts risk conflating disagreement with deficiency.

4.3 False negatives and false positives  

Some oppressive preferences bear morally unproblematic content.  A woman might adapt by preferring embroidery over soccer because sports facilities are male-only.  The content—needlework—is innocuous, yet the preference feels autonomy-deflated given its origin.  Conversely, a saboteur who sincerely prefers to undermine an unjust state pursues morally excellent ends; yet if her preference was instilled via cultish brainwashing, autonomy is missing.  Content alone cannot reliably track autonomy.

5. A historical-relational explanation  

5.1 Core idea  

What undermines autonomy is not the structure of desires nor their moral valence but the history of their formation within oppressive constraints.  Autonomy requires that one’s preferences be “practically available to critical reflection under conditions that were not themselves coercively limited or epistemically distorted by domination” (paraphrasing Christman).  The question shifts from “Do you endorse this?” or “Is this good for you?” to “Did you ever have a fair chance not to want this?”

5.2 Two historical conditions for autonomy  

Condition A:  Non-domination at the formative stage.  The processes that shaped the preference must be free from coercion, manipulation, and severe epistemic deprivation.  This includes structural phenomena: gendered division of labor, racist stereotypes, economic dependency.  Direct coercion is not needed; pervasive socialization that systematically discredits alternative identities can suffice.

Condition B:  Opportunity for critical reappraisal.  Even if a preference originates under oppression, it can become autonomous if the agent subsequently encounters new information, alternative life paths, and enjoys the social and psychological safety to scrutinize her commitments.  Autonomy is thus temporally open-ended; emancipation can retroactively validate a preference.

5.3 The explanatory payoff  

a) Why wholehearted yet subservient preferences lack autonomy: they violate Condition A; endorsement itself is a product of domination.  

b) Why monks can freely choose austerity: their preference, though restrictive in content, is typically formed in communities where entry is voluntary and critical exit is possible.  Condition A is met; so is Condition B, because novices are exposed to the outside world before taking vows.

c) Why mundane adaptations (black coffee) remain autonomous: lactose intolerance is a natural, not oppressive, constraint; the history is not one of domination.

5.4 Illustrative case: FGM acceptance  

In many communities, young women express pride in having undergone female genital cutting, describing it as a virtue and marriage prerequisite.  A subjectivist must (uncomfortably) deem their preference autonomous.  A content theorist deems it non-autonomous because it violates bodily integrity.  The historical-relational view explains both their endorsement and its defect.  The preference was inculcated through socialization that withholds credible information about the harms of FGM, stigmatizes “uncut” women, and threatens social death for dissenters—violating Condition A.  Most have never encountered real opportunities or safety to reconsider—violating Condition B.  The verdict of non-autonomy follows without appealing to moralistic paternalism.

6. Replies to two objections  

6.1 Objection 1: the rational accommodator  

Sometimes adapting is the most rational way to cope with immovable constraints.  The factory worker’s preference for the fourteen-hour shift keeps her children fed.  Why deny her autonomy merely because she clears an unjustly low bar of opportunities?

Response.  The historical account does not conflate practical rationality with autonomy.  One can rationally navigate injustice yet suffer an autonomy deficit precisely because injustice constrained the space of deliberation from the start.  Not every constrained choice is non-autonomous; the critical point is whether the preference itself has become aligned with the constraint in a way the agent never had fair reason or opportunity to resist.  If the worker privately despises the hours but accepts them as a necessary evil, her preference is not adaptive; she remains lucidly critical, and her agency survives.  If, however, she has come to believe such long hours are inherently fitting for people “like her,” the constraint has colonized her self-conception.  It is this colonization, not the rational accommodation, that our criterion marks as autonomy-eroding.

6.2 Objection 2: inescapable histories  

If every preference has some history, and all histories involve social influence, won’t almost every preference fail Condition A?  Does the historical account demand impossible purity?

Response.  The criterion is not influence-free genesis but non-dominating influence.  Socialization is inevitable; domination is not.  Influence becomes autonomy-defeating when (i) it systematically aims to entrench agents’ subordination and (ii) it forecloses their later ability to scrutinize and revise the induced preference.  Many ordinary cultural transmissions—say, my love for local cuisine—are influence-saturated yet non-dominating because they can be reconsidered without penalty and because alternatives are visible.  The standard is demanding only where justice demands it.

7. Synthesis: a dynamic, relational autonomy metric  

The discussion suggests a three-step diagnostic for adaptive preferences in contexts of oppression:  

1. Identify the constraining structure: Is the option set limited by unjust social power (patriarchal norms, racial caste, economic exploitation)?  

2. Trace the formation process: Were the agent’s epistemic resources and social support sufficiently robust to explore alternatives without fear or severe cost?  

3. Check for critical moments: Has the agent since encountered, in a psychologically and materially safe environment, reasons and role models that could prompt re-evaluation?  

Only when the answer to 1 is “yes” and at least one of 2 or 3 is “no” do we have a prima facie autonomy deficit.  The view is compatible with respecting later wholehearted endorsements that survive open scrutiny, thereby limiting paternalistic intervention.

8. Policy and moral implications  

Understanding adaptive preferences through a historical-relational lens reframes practical debates.  It shifts the focus from overriding individuals’ current choices to altering the background structures that warp preference formation.  Empowerment policies—expanding education, guaranteeing exit options, protecting dissent, providing economic security—are autonomy-enhancing not because they coerce better choices but because they widen the historical pathways through which genuine self-determination can emerge.  Development economists, for example, have begun using “preference revelation” programs: providing young women with information about wages and safety in different occupations.  If, after exposure, they still prefer domestic service, that preference deserves respect; if many revise their aspirations, the prior endorsements were adaptive.

9. Conclusion  

Why are adaptive preferences under oppression less than fully autonomous?  Because they bear the mark of histories in which power silenced curiosity, choked alternatives, and colonized self-conceptions.  Subjectivist endorsement can coexist with this colonization; content-based moralism can misidentify it.  A historical-relational account isolates the core deficiency—the unjust genesis and insulation of the preference—while preserving room for cultural pluralism and individual diversity.  Autonomy, on this view, is not a snapshot of internal harmony or moral correctness but a trajectory of preference formation within a social space of equals.  When that space is constricted by domination, adaptation masquerades as agency.  The task of philosophy—and of politics—is to tell the difference, and to help build the conditions under which masquerade is no longer a rational strategy but an unnecessary relic of a less just world.

1. Setting the Problem  

In 1964 James Scott noticed that colonized peasants “learn to want what they can get.” Fifty years later the label “adaptive preferences” has become standard for this apparently perverse phenomenon: when circumstances are hard enough, people sometimes reshape their desires to fit the narrow range of goods they can realistically hope to secure. The vineyard-worker in Aesop who declares the unreachable grapes “sour,” the woman in a conservative village who declares that higher education is “unfeminine,” the imprisoned “happy slave” who proclaims that bondage suits his nature—all are canonical cases.

Why worry? Ordinary prudence often counsels adaptation; after an accident, preferring a wheelchair to a mountain bike can be fully rational. The political philosopher’s specific worry is autonomy. Something feels amiss—especially where preferences track oppressive constraints rather than brute facts of nature—yet spelling out exactly what goes missing has proven surprisingly hard. Three large families of answers dominate the literature:

• Subjectivist or endorsement accounts (e.g., Frankfurt, Dworkin, Bratman): a preference is autonomous just in case the agent reflectively identifies with it.

• Content-based or substantive accounts (e.g., Nussbaum’s capabilities approach, Raz’s perfectionism): certain things are objectively bad to prefer, so preferring them is non-autonomous.

• Historical or procedural accounts (e.g., Elster, Oshana, Benson, Khader): the pedigree of a preference matters; if it was shaped by illegitimate social forces, it is not fully one’s own.

I will defend the thesis that a suitably refined historical account best explains the autonomy deficit of adaptive preferences in oppressive contexts. Subjectivist endorsement is too weak because reflective identification itself can be sculpted by domination; content-based theories are too strong because they conflate autonomy with moral correctness. A historical view can avoid both pitfalls if it focuses on the freedom-undermining features of the formative process: coercion, deprivation of information, and systematically limited imaginative horizons. I conclude by proposing a hybrid “counterfactual-historical” test that marks the right boundary between permissible prudential adaptation and autonomy-eroding resignation.

2. What Autonomy Requires  

Autonomy is a family resemblance concept, but most accounts share three elements:

a) Psychological ownership: an autonomous preference must be authentically mine.  
b) Independence: it must be formed and sustained free from controlling influences.  
c) Competence: I must possess the cognitive capacity to grasp relevant reasons.

Adaptive preferences seem to threaten (a) and (b): they feel alien—“not really what she would want if circumstances were different”—and they reflect external domination. The puzzle is to articulate these misgivings without making autonomy impossible for everyone lacking an ideal upbringing.

3. The Subjectivist Strategy and Its Limits  

Harry Frankfurt’s hierarchical model is the locus classicus. A desire is autonomous when the agent endorses it from a higher-order perspective: she wants to want it. If Aisha endorses her preference to undergo female genital cutting, then, on Frankfurt’s view, that preference is authentically hers.

3.1 The Happy Endorsement Problem  
Oppression can penetrate the second-order layer itself. Members of subordinated groups are often socialized to endorse exactly those first-order desires that keep them compliant. Empirical psychology names the mechanism “normative internalization.” The phenomenon is precisely what we mean by “adaptive.” So the Frankfurtian test risks calling the most troubling cases fully autonomous.

3.2 Epistemic Distortion  
One might reply that Frankfurtian endorsement must be informed and reflectively stable. Yet the required epistemic conditions silently smuggle in historical considerations: Why is her information limited? Why has her horizon of imaginative alternatives narrowed? Once we ask those questions, we have already left the purely subjectivist domain and entered a historical one.

3.3 The Regress Problem  
If oppressive conditions can shape first-order and second-order desires, then a regress looms: do we now need a third-order endorsement, and so on ad infinitum? Frankfurt avoided the regress by stipulating that identification bottoms out in wholeheartedness, but wholeheartedness can itself be manufactured by domination. The subjectivist lacks a principled way to stop the slide.

In short, endorsement is a necessary condition for autonomy—without it the agent is alienated from her preferences—but not sufficient in contexts of systematic power imbalance.

4. Content-Based Theories: Moralism in Disguise?  

Martha Nussbaum has argued that some preferences are “beyond the pale” because they violate objective conditions of human flourishing (bodily integrity, practical reason, affiliation, etc.). If a woman prefers beatings to freedom of movement, we can simply declare the preference non-autonomous because its content contradicts human dignity.

4.1 The Paternalism Objection  
The substantive strategy risks collapsing autonomy into moral rightness. Suppose a devout monk autonomously chooses celibacy. Many liberals think celibacy is a legitimate life plan even though it sacrifices one of Nussbaum’s capabilities (sexual satisfaction). More dramatically, some people autonomously choose hazardous sports, extreme fasting, or vow poverty. Content-based theories over-inclusive: they mark these choices as deficient when no oppression is in sight.

4.2 Adaptive vs. Ill-Chosen  
To capture the distinctive wrongness of adaptive preferences, we need to differentiate between autonomy and prudence. Climbing Everest might be foolish, but if the choice is made under conditions of information and expressive freedom, it is quintessentially autonomous. Content-based theories fail to honor that distinction.

4.3 The Missing Mechanism  
Finally, content-based accounts do not explain how oppression produces the problematic preferences. They merely say “the preference is bad”; they do not illuminate why it is not quite the agent’s own.

Therefore, while moral quality matters for policy—states are justified in discouraging genital cutting even if chosen—it does not by itself identify the autonomy deficit.

5. Historical Accounts: The Promising Middle Path  

Historical theorists claim that autonomy depends on how, not merely on what, we prefer. A preference is non-autonomous if it bears the wrong causal pedigree—if it was produced by manipulation, coercion, or deprivation. This orientation directly targets the phenomenon of adaptation to constraint.

5.1 The Causal Story of Oppression  
Oppression typically narrows option sets (material constraint), restricts information flow (epistemic constraint), and penalizes deviance (social sanction). Over time, individuals left with few live possibilities begin to prefer the feasible. That adaptive mechanism is perfectly rational as survival strategy, but its rationality is derivative—it flows from coercive social facts. The historical account highlights precisely those facts, explaining why the resulting preferences feel externally imposed.

5.2 Counterfactual Dependence  
An intuitive test is the “free-world counterfactual”: Would the agent still prefer X if she had grown up with adequate resources, information, and respect? If likely not, the preference is historically tainted. This is Elster’s famous “flower in an oxygen-poor environment” analogy: the bloom is stunted not because it now wants to be small but because the soil was robbed of nutrients.

5.3 From History to Norms  
Skeptics worry that causal etiology alone cannot yield a normative verdict; after all, every preference has a cause. The reply is to specify regulating norms of formation:  
(a) Non-coercion: preferences induced by threats lack autonomy.  
(b) Adequate information: formation under ignorance or false belief undermines ownership.  
(c) Social imagination: the agent must have enjoyed real opportunities to sample or vividly envision alternatives.  
These are process-based, not content-based, constraints. They do the normative work without moralizing the outcome.

5.4 Prudential vs. Oppressive Adaptation  
Historical criteria also separate legitimate adaptation (to disability, aging, personal temperament) from adaptive resignation. When a climber who lost her legs learns to love wheelchair tennis, no oppressive force prevented her from keeping up-to-date information, imaginative exploration, and social respect. By contrast, when a caste-bound Dalit “chooses” not to apply to university because “people like me don’t belong there,” all three historical criteria are violated.

6. Objections to the Historical Account  

6.1 Verification Worries  
How can we know the causal history of another’s desire? Autonomy is a practical concept; if assessment required detective-level knowledge of childhood socialization, it would be useless. Two replies: (i) many oppressive contexts leave public, structural traces—severe option deprivation, education gaps, sanctions—so inference is often possible; (ii) the aim is not courtroom certainty but moral guidance about when intervention is justified. Probabilistic evidence often suffices.

6.2 The Filtering Problem  
Everyone’s preferences are causally influenced by culture. If the historical test is too demanding, no one is fully autonomous. The solution is to calibrate the criteria to domination, not mere influence. Influence per se is inescapable and often autonomy-enhancing (learning a language). What defeats autonomy is influence that systematically disables critical reflection or viable exit. The distinction tracks interpersonal power, not mere social shaping.

6.3 Respecting Present-Time Agency  
Does labeling someone’s preference “non-autonomous” insult her agency? Two thoughts. First, autonomy is scalar; calling a preference historically tainted does not strip the person of all agency. Second, critique aims at structural reform, not personal condemnation. Blaming the victim for her preference would indeed be disrespectful, but diagnosing oppressive formation is a way of directing responsibility upward, toward institutions that manufactured her limited horizon.

7. A Hybrid Proposal: Counterfactual Historical Endorsement  

We can now articulate a refined account in three clauses:

(i) Reflective Identification: The agent endorses the preference at time t. (Subjectivist element.)

(ii) Procedural Pedigree: The preference was not formed or sustained by coercion, information deprivation, or imaginative foreclosure. (Historical element.)

(iii) Robust Counterfactual Endurance: In a plausible nearby world where those procedural defects are absent, the agent would still endorse the preference after critical reflection. (Bridges historical and subjectivist conditions.)

Clause (iii) handles the remaining worry that people can presently reflect yet still be unable to envisage alternatives. It also captures the slogan “autonomy is choosing under conditions of freedom even if those conditions are hypothetical.” Notice that content plays no direct role; nothing prevents an agent, after liberated reflection, from endorsing celibacy or even risk-laden adventure. Yet the account condemns the caste-based resignation because the preference would predictably dissolve once the oppressive background is lifted.

8. Policy Implications  

Why does the theoretical account matter? Consider three practical arenas:

1. Development Economics. Should aid agencies override local women’s stated preferences for large families? The hybrid view implies caution: investigate whether the preference survives exposure to alternative life plans, schooling, and reduced child mortality. If it does, respect it; if not, design empowerment programs that widen horizons before ascribing “true” preference.

2. Legal Regulation of Bodily Harm. Should a state criminalize female genital cutting even when adult women request it? The historical account says YES when the requesting environment systematically withholds information about sexual function or penalizes dissent, and MAYBE NOT in the rare diasporic case where informed, uncoerced adults with genuine exit options freely choose the practice.

3. Workplace Choices under Neoliberalism. Gig-economy workers often declare they “love flexibility.” Are these adaptive? We must ask: Are alternative forms of secure employment realistically available? Is information about long-term income volatility transparent? If not, their professed “love” may signal historical taint, justifying labor protections.

9. Comparative Merits Recap  

Subjectivist endorsement Secures psychological ownership but ignores structurally induced endorsements.  
Content-based moralism Flags some oppression, but at the cost of paternalism and autonomy/morality conflation.  
Historical proceduralism Explains oppression’s distinctive damage, avoids over-inclusiveness, and preserves room for plural life plans.  

Therefore, as advertised, the historical family, fortified with a counterfactual endorsement clause, best captures why adaptive preferences are less than fully autonomous.

10. Conclusion  

Adaptive preferences dramatize a tension at the heart of liberal philosophy: respect for self-determination versus the reality that social power shapes the very selves who determine. A purely internal (subjectivist) answer underestimates domination’s reach; a purely external (content-based) answer overestimates the authority of philosophers to dictate the good life. By attending to history—how preferences come to be—and asking whether agents could own them under conditions of freedom, we strike the balance that autonomy theory requires. The result is both normatively sensitive to injustice and protective of the dizzying plurality of human aspirations that genuine autonomy allows.

Adaptive Preference and the Anatomy of Autonomy  
                               — Why the History of a Preference Matters Most —


1. Setting the Problem  

Agents often come to want exactly what they can get. A woman in a patriarchal village declares that she positively wants an arranged early marriage; a child soldier professes loyalty to his militia; a chronically under-employed worker claims to “love the simple life.”  Such wishes are adaptive: they arise in response to tight, often unjust, constraints on the agent’s feasible set.  Intuitively these preferences are “less than fully autonomous.”  Yet the standard philosophical theories of autonomy give different diagnoses of what, exactly, is missing.  Subjectivist accounts ground autonomy in wholehearted endorsement of one’s desires (Frankfurt, Hierarchy of Desires).  Content-based accounts locate autonomy in what is chosen rather than in who does the choosing, judging some preferences heteronomous because they aim at morally defective goods.  Historical or procedural accounts trace autonomy to the etiology of a preference—whether it was arrived at through the exercise of the agent’s own capacities, or implanted by forces that bypass those capacities.

My thesis is threefold:  

(a) Adaptive preference per se is not an autonomy defect.  The deficit arises only when the adaptation occurs through procedures that bypass, disable, or distort the agent’s evaluative capacities.  

(b) Subjectivist and content-based accounts, taken on their own, systematically misclassify key cases because they abstract, respectively, from history and from agency.  

(c) A historically informed, procedural‐relational account best captures why the preferences that form under oppression fail to be fully one’s own.  The historical dimension explains both how oppression works—by shaping options and molding desires—and why merely satisfying the resulting preferences does not respect persons.


2. Clarifying Concepts  

2.1 Adaptive Preference.  A preference is adaptive when (i) the agent’s feasible set is narrowed by externally imposed constraints, and (ii) her preference ranking adjusts in ways that make the constrained options appear positively desirable.  The adjustment can be conscious rationalization (“sour grapes”) or non-conscious habituation (“learning to desire what one repeatedly does”).  

2.2 Autonomy.  I treat autonomy as self-rule in the practical sphere: an action or preference is autonomous when it is the product of the agent’s own reflectively endorsed evaluative standpoint, formed and revised through unimpaired exercises of her rational and affective capacities, free from illegitimate control by others.  This “procedural agency” view deliberately separates autonomy from moral rightness; morally vicious yet self-chosen ends are, in principle, possible.

2.3 Oppression.  I reserve the term for social structures that systematically limit an identifiable group’s options and shape their self-conceptions in ways that stabilize the limitation.  Oppression therefore operates both externally (via coercion, material deprivation) and internally (via ideology, socialization).


3. Three Diagnoses of the Deficit  

3.1 Subjectivist (Hierarchical) Accounts  

Frankfurt’s model distinguishes first-order desires (D) from second-order volitions (D*).  An agent acts autonomously when she acts on D while wholeheartedly endorsing D with D*.  Applied to adaptive preference, the model assays autonomy by asking: Does the oppressed woman reflectively endorse her desire for early marriage?  If she does, Frankfurt must count her preference as autonomous.  

Problem 1 –  The Implanted Endorsement.  Oppressive socialization can generate second-order endorsements themselves—internalized without critical scrutiny.  The model lacks resources to say why such “adjusted” endorsement is defective.  

Problem 2 –  Counterfactual Ignorance.  Endorsement is measured against the agent’s actual psychological repertoire, not against what she could have endorsed in a less restrictive environment.  The account is thus blind to the device of limiting possibilities first, then eliciting wholehearted approval of what remains.

Therefore, Frankfurtian endorsement is insufficient: it does not track the etiology of the preference and so misclassifies many adaptive cases as autonomous.

3.2 Content-Based Accounts  

Content theorists argue that certain preferences (e.g., to be enslaved, to self-mutilate) are autonomy-undermining because their objects are inherently inimical to agency or personhood.  Hence a woman’s preference for genital cutting or permanent subordination is non-autonomous regardless of how she arrived at it.  

Strength –  Captures the intuition that some preferences are “false” to any person’s good.  

Weakness 1 –  Over-inclusive.  A martyr’s preference to endure torture for her faith is also self-harmful, yet plausibly autonomous.  

Weakness 2 –  Under-inclusive.  Suppose a village woman adapts by taking genuine delight in sewing rather than going to school.  The activity is innocuous in content, yet her preference still seems suspect if it is the result of gendered constraint.  Content theory cannot explain what is wrong.  

Weakness 3 –  Paternalistic Slippage.  By coding certain ends as inherently autonomy-incompatible, the account risks substituting the theorist’s conception of the good for the agent’s, ignoring pluralism.

Thus, while content matters ethically, it is a blunt instrument for diagnosing autonomy deficits intrinsic to adaptive preference.

3.3 Historical (Procedural) Accounts  

On these views an attitude is autonomous if the process that produced it respected the agent’s capacities for critical reflection.  Christman’s “bypassing” condition: a preference is non-autonomous if it was caused in a way that bypassed the agent’s capacities for self-reflection, such as hypnosis or coercive brainwashing.  Mele adds the “manipulation” constraint: if the causal chain involved deceptive or coercive socialization that the agent could not resist, autonomy is undermined.

Adaptive preference under oppression typically involves a long, subtle history: institutional deprivation curtails information; social norms punish dissent; credible alternatives are rendered invisible.  The formation pathway thereby bypasses robust exercises of reflection—though not through momentary coercion but through a standing social ecology that steers evaluative development.  The historical view, especially in its relational extensions (Mackenzie, Oshana), seems tailor-made for these cases.

Potential Worry –  Etiological Perfectionism.  Must every preference trace back to perfectly undistorted formative influences to count as autonomous?  That bar is implausibly high; all socialization shapes us.  The historical theorist needs a principled threshold distinguishing legitimate from autonomy-undermining influence.

I shall argue that a modification—focusing on “systematic, status-undermining bypassing”—solves this worry and gives the best account of the adaptive preference deficit.


4. Testing the Theories: Three Cases  

Case A: Prisoner’s Garden.  A political prisoner in solitary for ten years comes to cherish his cramped prison garden as the highest good.  Upon release he has the option to cultivate vast public gardens but prefers the familiar small plot.  

•  Subjectivist verdict: autonomous (wholehearted).  
•  Content verdict: benign content ⇒ autonomous.  
•  Historical verdict: suspect, since preference formed under severe constraint—but note, constraint was not imposed with the aim of shaping gardening preferences.  Intuitively, the preference seems largely innocuous, perhaps even self-nurturing.  

Lesson: adaptive preference is not automatically non-autonomous; only certain kinds of constraint matter.

Case B: Early Marriage Norm.  Girls in a rural region internalize the belief that marrying at 14 is honorable and that continued schooling is shameful.  They eagerly seek marriage proposals.  The practice is enforced by economic dependency, threat of social ostracism, and moralistic indoctrination.  

•  Subjectivist: wholehearted endorsement ⇒ autonomy (bad result).  
•  Content: arguably non-autonomous because the end (lifelong subordination) is incompatible with flourishing—yet we earlier saw martyrdom counterexample.  
•  Historical: preference produced by a social system that systematically forestalls awareness of alternatives, punishes dissent, and positions the girls as subordinate.  Their reflective faculties are sculpted to endorse the very regime that constrains them.  Autonomy deficit explained.

Case C: Minimalist Worker.  An under-employed gig worker embraces “voluntary simplicity,” declaring that consumer culture is hollow.  He is aware of higher-paying jobs but also of exploitative labor conditions.  He chooses minimalism partly in protest, partly to avoid burnout.  

Our intuitions hover: perhaps his preference is autonomous despite being shaped by economic precarity.  The historical perspective can accommodate the mixed verdict: the worker’s preference arises through critical evaluation of constraints rather than their uncritical internalization; hence it may clear the autonomy threshold.

The comparative test suggests that a qualified historical account tracks our nuanced judgments better than its rivals.


5. Why Subjectivist and Content Accounts Fail Systematically  

5.1 The “Trajectory” Blind Spot  

Subjectivism mistakes present-tense endorsement as sufficient because it collapses autonomy into synchronic endorsement.  But adaptive preference shows that autonomy is a diachronic achievement: what matters is how the preference came to be.  The hierarchical model’s failure to see that second-order volitions themselves can be products of oppressive filtering leaves it helpless against deep socialization.

5.2 The “Substantive Goods” Overreach  

Content theory confuses autonomy with well-being.  While it is true that deeply self-destructive ends can signal autonomy failure, the correlation is imperfect.  Some autonomy-robust agents choose harmful ends (Kant’s misanthrope who commits suicide from principle), while some adaptive preferences target benign goods but remain heteronomous because they are acceptances of unjust constraint rather than exercises of self-rule.

Thus both theories misfire for principled reasons.


6. Refining the Historical Account: Bypassing plus Status Considerations  

Merely adding history is not enough; we must say which historical features matter.  I propose:

A preference P of agent S is non-autonomous if and only if  
(i) P was formed through a process that systematically bypassed S’s critical capacities, where  
(ii) the bypassing occurred in virtue of S’s social status (gender, caste, race, etc.) in a structure aimed at securing compliance, and  
(iii) S lacks reasonable opportunities—temporally extended, materially supported, risk-manageable—to revisit or repudiate P.

Condition (i) captures the procedural concern.  
Condition (ii) embeds it in a relational context: it is not accidental tutelage but status-based domination that corrodes autonomy.  
Condition (iii) prevents etiological perfectionism: a once-bypassed preference can regain autonomy if the agent later has—and uses—adequate space for critical uptake.

This three-part test explains our earlier cases.  The prisoner, once free, has ample opportunity to reflect and revise; if he persists in loving his small garden, the preference becomes his own.  The village girls lack such opportunities; social costs of revision are prohibitive.  The gig worker has partial opportunities, hence a mixed verdict.

Importantly, the test avoids paternalism: intervention is justified not because the preference’s content offends our sensibilities but because the agent is denied fair conditions for self-rule.


7. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: Infinite Regress of Social Influence.  All preferences result from socialization; your view makes autonomy impossible.  

Reply: Social influence per se is not bypassing.  Bypassing is influence that disables or forecloses the very capacities through which agents normally filter influence.  Ordinary conversational persuasion engages these capacities; coercive indoctrination, psychological terror, or deprivation that prevents consideration of alternatives bypasses them.  The autonomy threshold is therefore demanding yet attainable.

Objection 2: Epistemic Uncertainty.  How can an external assessor know the preference’s history without intrusive speculation?  

Reply: In policy contexts we rarely need a metaphysical verdict of non-autonomy; what we need are defeasible indicators: severe, status-based constraint on options; evidence of punitive enforcement; lack of credible information channels.  These proxies track the likelihood of bypassing closely enough for legal and moral decision-making (e.g., in asylum or medical consent cases).

Objection 3: Respect for Agency.  Declaring adaptive preferences non-autonomous risks disrespecting agents who genuinely value their culture’s practices.  

Reply: The historical account embeds a procedural respect test: if the agent can and does critically affirm the practice under conditions allowing dissent without sanction, her choice stands—even if outsiders deplore it.  Only when opportunity for critical engagement is structurally denied do we classify the preference as heteronomous.

Objection 4:  Feminist Critique—Relational Autonomy Already Contains This Story.  

Reply: I agree; my proposal foregrounds the historical mechanism that relational theories emphasize.  What I add is a sharper “bypass plus status” criterion that specifies exactly how oppressive relations undermine autonomy, thereby operationalizing relational autonomy for normative assessment.


8. Normative Implications  

8.1 Policy.  Development agencies should not aim at eradicating adaptive preferences directly (which risks cultural imperialism), but at dismantling the formative constraints: broadening education, offering material alternatives, protecting dissent.  Once conditions for critical reflection exist, agents can own or reject their traditional preferences autonomously.

8.2 Consent Doctrine.  In medical ethics, consent procured from members of oppressed groups regarding culturally sanctioned harmful practices (e.g., FGM) should be scrutinized procedurally: Was the endorsement insulated from threats of ostracism?  Were genuine alternatives presented?

8.3 Positive Freedom.  The account supports a robust, agency-enhancing notion of freedom: political liberation requires not only removing coercion but also furnishing the social conditions under which preferences can form autonomously.


9. Concluding Synthesis  

Adaptive preferences dramatize a tension in liberal thought: if we honor subjective endorsement alone, we risk ratifying oppression; if we impose objective goods, we risk paternalism.  The solution lies in history: preferences stamped into persons by social mechanisms that trade on their subordinate status, that foreclose genuine critical uptake, are not fully their own.  By contrast, preferences that survive after constraints are lifted—indeed, preferences that emerge through the critical contest of reasons—warrant respect, whatever their content.

The historically grounded procedural view outperforms the subjectivist and content-based alternatives because it

• accounts for why wholehearted yet oppressed agents still lack self-rule (diagnosis),  
• preserves room for cultural pluralism once oppressive constraints are removed (respect), and  
• guides reform by targeting the social pathways of preference formation (action).

Therefore, what makes an adaptive preference less than fully autonomous is neither its current endorsement nor its substantive object, but rather the tainted genealogy through which oppressive structures infiltrate and truncate the agent’s capacity to shape her own will.  Autonomy demands a history worthy of a self-governing person; where that history is missing, liberation must begin.

1. Introduction: what is at stake

When we utter a sentence of the form ‘A finds φ Adj’—for example, ‘Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty’ or ‘She finds lying wrong’—we are attributing to the subject A a certain mental state toward the object φ.  Contemporary expressivists about value and taste suggest that that state is not a neutral representation of how things are in the world, but rather an affect-laden stance akin to liking, detesting, approving, or blaming.  If that diagnosis is correct, the semantics of the ‘find’-construction provides an unusually direct linguistic window on the kind of attitude evaluative discourse expresses.  The question, then, is what evidence there is—linguistic, behavioural, inferential, phenomenological—that the relevant ‘find’ state is indeed non-cognitive and specifically affective.

My thesis is that a convergent battery of diagnostics supports exactly that conclusion.  The ‘evaluative find’ (henceforth findE) behaves in syntax and discourse like a mental attitude of liking, enjoyment, or valuing, not like a belief or piece of knowledge.  At least six kinds of evidence point the same way:

1. Selectional restrictions: findE can embed only predicates that already display canonical marks of subjectivity; descriptive adjectives and nouns are systematically excluded.

2. Challenge patterns: findE assertions resist evidential, truth-conditional and calibration challenges appropriate for beliefs, but invite challenges that target emotional sensibility and taste.

3. Inference profile: findE is non-factive and does not license the inferential bridge from ‘S finds φ Adj’ to ‘Adj(φ)’.  Nor does it embed under ‘believe’ or ‘know’ in the way cognitive states do.

4. Adverbial and intensifier compatibility: the adverbs that comfortably modify findE are paradigmatically affective (‘deeply’, ‘personally’, ‘utterly’) whereas evidential or veracity adverbs (‘factually’, ‘verifiably’, ‘objectively’) clash.

5. Temporal-volitional behaviour: findE patterns with desire-like states that can shift, persist, or be cultivated, and it is the target of characteristic volitional constructions (‘I wish I still found olives delicious’; ‘Try to find the exercise fun’).

6. Moorean infelicity: first-person findE displays the same ‘pragmatic self-defeat’ phenomena that classically motivate non-cognitivism; denying one’s own findE state while asserting the corresponding value claim yields palpable oddness.

After laying out these six strands (§2-§7), I turn (§8) to alternative cognitive accounts that treat findE as ascribing belief about a ‘response-dependent’ property (e.g., tastiness-for-A) and argue that they cannot accommodate the full set of data without special pleading.  I conclude (§9) by sketching why the best explanation of the entire pattern is that findE attributes an affective, non-representational stance belonging to the same natural kind as loving, detesting, admiring, and loathing.

2. Selectional restrictions

Perhaps the cleanest surface clue is distributional: findE selects complements that are themselves semantically marked for subjectivity.  The contrast is familiar:

(1a)   Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty / delicious / delightful / revolting.  
(1b) *Holmes finds Saltimbocca vegetarian / made-of-veal / served-at-room-temperature.

(2a)   She finds lying wrong / cruel / reprehensible / admirable.  
(2b) *She finds lying widespread / illegal-in-Norway / rare-in-monkeys.

Where selection is graded, the pattern aligns perfectly with scale of subjectivity.  ‘Light’ adjectives like ‘salty’, ‘sweet’, ‘boring’, which straddle evaluative and descriptive uses, are acceptable precisely on the evaluative reading; their purely sensory-descriptive reads are disallowed: ‘Holmes finds the broth salty’ is felicitous only if ‘salty’ conveys a hedonic reaction (‘too salty for his taste’), not if it merely records NaCl level.

Such selectional behaviour is unprecedented among garden-variety cognitive attitude verbs (‘believe’, ‘think’, ‘suppose’, ‘guess’), which embed any truth-conditional content.  The restriction is instead the mark of verbs whose complement denotes a psychological experience rather than a proposition: ‘consider-ADJ’, ‘experience-as-ADJ’, ‘regard-as-ADJ’, ‘judge-ADJ’, etc.  In Kratzer’s semantics, these verbs combine with a predicate of individuals and return a property of experiencers; no proposition is ever formed.  That compositional fact makes it near-impossible to treat findE as encoding a belief relation to a truth-evaluable proposition.

3. Challenge patterns

Consider the canonical ‘belief’ challenges:

Cognitive challenge 1:  ‘Is that really true?’  
Cognitive challenge 2:  ‘What evidence do you have?’  
Cognitive challenge 3:  ‘Are you sure, or could you be mistaken?’

Now contrast two dialogues:

Belief case  
A:  ‘Pluto is no longer a planet.’  
B:  ‘Really?  What evidence do you have?’

FindE case  
A:  ‘I find durian disgusting.’  
B: ??‘Really?  What evidence do you have?’  
Better: ‘Really?  Have you actually tried ripe durian?’  
         ‘Oh come on, keep an open mind—lots of people love it.’

Challenges to findE characteristically target the speaker’s palate, experience, or openness, not epistemic credentials.  The discourse presupposes that the correct ‘cure’ for an erroneous findE is taste-acquisition or affect-modulation, never additional information.

Further, disagreement about findE complements takes the ‘faultless’ form familiar from predicates of personal taste:

A:  ‘Durian is delicious!’  
B:  ‘No, it’s disgusting.’
