(ii) List the ways the world might be, the states s that are not causally downstream of your act.
(iii) For each ordered pair ⟨a, s⟩ assign a utility u(a,s).
(iv) Compute the causal expected utility of each act by using the unconditional probabilities P(s) (or, in Pearl’s notation, the do-probabilities P(s | do(a))).  
(v) Pick an act that maximises expected utility.

In textbook cases the expected utilities of the acts do not themselves depend on how likely you currently take yourself to be to perform those very acts. But in “Death in Damascus”–style stories they do. During deliberation you keep shifting your credence in “I go to Damascus”, and by the CDT recipe every such shift reshuffles the expected-utility rankings. The theory appears to flap in the breeze of its user’s changing state of mind.

The question is whether that is an objectionable feature. I shall argue that it is a genuine problem for the standard formulation of CDT because

(a) it deprives the theory of stable, convergent action-guidance,  
(b) it allows purely introspective changes—changes in your credence about what you will do that are under your voluntary control—to change which act is recommended, thereby violating the “no magic lever” constraint on rational choice, and  
(c) it makes CDT vulnerable to a Dutch-book–style incoherence argument.

However, the problem is not that CDT uses unconditional probabilities per se. The deeper flaw is that the Jeffreyan act-by-act recipe treats the agent’s own choice as if it were an exogenous random variable rather than an endogenous output of deliberation. An adequate causal theory must step back one level and evaluate whole decision policies relative to the pre-deliberative probability distribution. Once that is done, the instability disappears. What follows defends these claims in four stages.

2. Modelling Death in Damascus

Skyrms’s version of the story has two cities, Aleppo (A) and Damascus (D). You are told that Death has studied your psychology, has made a prediction of the city you will spend tomorrow in, and has gone to that city to wait for you. Death’s predictions are 90 % reliable (he is wrong one time in ten). Independent of his predictive skill, he slightly prefers Damascus; if he is torn, he tends to predict D. We can capture all of that with two parameters:

• r = reliability = 0.9  
• b = background bias toward predicting Damascus = 0.8

Formally,

P(Death in Damascus) = r · P(Go to Damascus) + (1-r) · (1-P(Go to Damascus))·b  
(One can tweak the details; any model in which the conditional probability of Death’s location given your act depends on how likely that act is will do.)

Your utility is 0 if you meet Death and 1 if you avoid him. Let the random variable p denote your current credence that you will choose Damascus. Causal probabilities obey screening off, so CDT instructs you to evaluate acts with the do-operator, which in this story coincides with unconditional probabilities—Death’s location is not causally downstream of your act. Hence:

EU_CDT(Damascus) = 1 − P(Death in Damascus)  
EU_CDT(Aleppo)   = 1 − P(Death in Aleppo)

But P(Death in Aleppo) is just 1 − P(Death in Damascus), so

EU_CDT(D) − EU_CDT(A) = 1 − 2·P(Death in Damascus).

Substituting the expression above yields a linear function of p. A little algebra shows:

If p > ½, then EU_CDT(A) > EU_CDT(D).  
If p < ½, then EU_CDT(D) > EU_CDT(A).

Intuitively: whatever city you currently think you are more likely to visit is the one CDT tells you to avoid.

3. The Instability Worry

Suppose you begin deliberation with p = 0.6. CDT says “Go to Aleppo”. Acting on that advice drops your credence in “I go to Damascus” to p = 0.1, which flips CDT’s recommendation to “Go to Damascus”. Recognising this raises p again, flips the recommendation back, and so on. There is no stable fixed point: p = ½ gives both acts equal expected utility, but any ε-perturbation resurrects the oscillation. In decision-theoretic jargon, no act is ratifiable: for neither choice is it true that if you expected to perform it you would prefer to perform it.

Why is that a problem? Two reasons:

Guidance Failure: A decision theory is supposed to tell a deliberating agent what to do. A procedure whose output keeps changing every time the agent updates on its own output gives no usable advice. Saying “just randomise 50-50” is not an answer the current theory itself produces; it is a heuristic we are tempted to import from without.

Illicit Influence: The expected-utility difference depends on p, but p is to some extent under the agent’s voluntary control—after all, she can flip a coin or steel herself to favour one option. If flicking an internal credence-dial can manufacture value, the theory licenses magical thinking. That “extra” lever is spuriously generated by the theory’s own act-dependency.

4. Reply 1: “Every Decision Theory Depends on Act Probabilities”

A first defence says: “Of course recommendations depend on probabilities, and of course those probabilities are revised during deliberation. CDT is no worse off than Evidential Decision Theory (EDT) or any other.” This misses the point. In ordinary cases p appears only inside trivial terms that cancel out. In Death in Damascus it appears in a place where it changes the sign of the utility difference. EDT does not have that feature here: EDTC evaluates on conditional probabilities P(s | a), which, given Death’s high reliability, overwhelmingly favour Aleppo regardless of p. So the instability is specific to CDT’s causal screening-off clause.

5. Reply 2: “Take the Limit of Deliberation”

Jeffrey (1983) suggested that rational action requires ratifiability: do what you would still want to do after becoming certain you will do it. If we let deliberation proceed until the agent’s credences stabilise, the complaint vanishes. Unfortunately, in Death in Damascus there is no stable limit. The ratifiability constraint therefore yields “Do whatever meets the ratifiability constraint—oops, nothing does.” That is only a restatement of the difficulty.

6. Reply 3: “Explicitly Randomise”

Perhaps the right solution is to adopt a mixed act: generate a fair coin-flip and go to Aleppo if heads, Damascus if tails. Then p = ½, expected utilities tie, and CDT can be satisfied procrastination-free. The trouble is twofold.

First, “flip a coin” is not among the acts originally on the menu. To license it we must already have stepped up to the level of policies—mappings from random seeds to acts. Second, the value of mixed strategies in this story is again p-dependent; a slight bias in the coin revives the instability. So explicit randomisation merely pushes the pea under a fresh walnut.

7. A Deeper Diagnosis

What is really going on is that the standard CDT algorithm combines two incompatible perspectives. In step (iv) the agent is modelling her own act as an exogenous variable a. In deliberation, however, a is the unknown she is solving for. Whenever the expected utility of a is itself a function of P(a) the cheap, one-shot maximisation is ill-posed.

One way to see the structural flaw is to attempt a Dutch-book construction. Imagine a bookmaker who, each time your credence p crosses the ½ threshold, offers you an ε-priced swap of tickets that pays £1 if you avoid Death. Because you always switch, the bookie locks in a profit while you end up with a null payoff. Your dynamic inconsistency exposes you to sure loss. That suffices to show that CDT, as currently formulated, violates a basic coherence desideratum.

8. The Policy-Level Fix

The obvious repair: evaluate not single acts but complete decision policies π, and do so relative to the agent’s pre-deliberative distribution P₀. A policy is a function from perceptual inputs to acts (or to probability distributions over acts). In Death in Damascus two obvious deterministic policies are

π_D: always go to Damascus  
π_A: always go to Aleppo.

CDT-at-the-policy-level says to pick whichever has higher causal expected utility under P₀. Because Death has a standing bias toward predicting Damascus, P₀(Death in Damascus) exceeds ½, so π_A strictly dominates π_D. Once π_A is chosen, the internal deliberative oscillations never arise—π_A is implemented directly.

Notice what we have done: we stopped conditionalising on information that is itself the output of the decision problem. The move is independently well motivated: CDT is supposed to model causal control, and policies are precisely what an agent can causally control at the pre-decision point. Advocates of “Updateless Decision Theory” (Yudkowsky & Soares 2017) echo this insight.

9. Objections to the Policy Move

Objection: “But why privilege the pre-deliberative distribution? Isn’t that just as arbitrary as privileging the current one?”  
Reply: Because only the pre-deliberative distribution is invulnerable to endogenous feedback from later, self-referential reasoning. The point where you still take your own future act to be uncertain is the last stage at which it is epistemically legitimate to treat A-versus-D as an exogenous variable. After that, treating P(A) as something you can tinker with by a choice already presupposes a policy.

Objection: “Real agents cannot compute over policy-spaces that huge.”  
Reply: That is a tractability complaint, not a complaint about rational coherence. Nothing prevents ideal-rational agents from approximating the policy optimum or from using heuristics that target it. What matters is that a correct normative theory must have a coherent target.

10. Is the Dependence *Ever* Welcome?

A maverick might bite the bullet: “CDT’s sensitivity to P(a) is a virtuous feature—it captures the fact that you sometimes *can* improve prospects by credence-management.” In magical thinking, believers try to bring about rain by believing it will rain. Death in Damascus provides no causal pathway of that kind; the only causal influences run from your disposition, via Death’s earlier prediction, to his present location, but those arcs are sealed by time. Granting your own present credal fluctuations the power to change the past violates the causal spirit of CDT itself.

11. Comparative Diagnosis: EDT and FDT

Evidential Decision Theory tells you “Go to Aleppo” from the start; Functional Decision Theory (FDT) or Updateless CDT delivers the same verdict. What distinguishes these rivals is not merely the outcome but the reason. EDT says Aleppo because going to Aleppo is strong evidence you will meet Death elsewhere. FDT-policy-CDT says Aleppo because the deterministic policy “always Aleppo” causally screens off Death’s prediction advantage. Those explanations remain stable as deliberation proceeds; CDT-act-level’s explanation is hostage to shifting self-probabilities. Stability, we submit, is a mark of a correct theory.

12. Summing Up

Dependence on your current probability of acting in a certain way is not invariably a problem for decision theory, but in CDT it becomes pathological whenever:

(i) the environment’s payoffs correlate with your act by a non-causal but highly reliable predictor, and  
(ii) that correlation term is a monotone function of P(a).

Under those conditions CDT collapses into an oscillatory, non-ratifiable procedure that offers no stable guidance and exposes you to dynamic Dutch books. The cure is to reconceive CDT as a policy-selection theory evaluated relative to the agent’s ex-ante distribution. Once we do so, acts inherit their ranking from the policies that generate them; credence-manipulation loses its illusory power, and Death in Damascus has exactly the moral we would expect: avoid the city Death is more likely to have chosen, i.e., head for Aleppo.

13. Conclusion

Yes, CDT’s dependence on the agent’s shifting act-probabilities is a problem. It is a problem because (a) it obstructs practical deliberation, (b) lets introspective whimsy masquerade as value-creation, and (c) violates dynamic coherence. Recognising this pushes us toward a refined causal decision theory that evaluates policies, not momentary acts. Far from being an eccentric technical wrinkle, Death in Damascus uncovers a structural weakness in the mainstream statement of CDT and points the way to a more stable, updateless causal viewpoint—one that, appropriately enough, leaves Death waiting alone in Damascus while the rational traveller safely wanders Aleppo’s bazaars.

A. Overview and Thesis  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) instructs an agent to choose the act with the highest causal‐expected utility, i.e. the utility obtained by weighting the causal consequences of that act by the unconditional probabilities of states not downstream of the act.  In Death in Damascus–type cases, however, the unconditional probability of the crucial state (‘Death is in the city I go to’) covaries with the agent’s own credence about which city she will in fact choose.  Because deliberation predictably shifts those credences, CDT’s directive can seesaw: first recommending Damascus, then Aleppo, then Damascus again, with no stopping point short of either paralysis or arbitrary randomisation.

I shall argue that this deliberation-sensitivity is not a harmless quirk but a genuine defect in CDT.  It violates two core desiderata for a decision theory:

1. Practical guidance: a theory should stably tell an agent what to do, rather than change its verdict merely because the agent reflects on what she is about to do.  
2. Reflective consistency: an agent who follows the theory should have no reason, at any stage of deliberation, to predictably regret that very fact.

CDT fails both tests in Death in Damascus because it makes the wrong cut between “do I cause X?” and “am I evidentially correlated with X?”.  That cut, though intuitive in ordinary settings, breaks down when other predictors key their behaviour precisely to one’s would-be action.  The perverse result is a form of “deliberative instability”: the more confidently I incline toward an act, the worse CDT tells me that act is.

I. Setting the Stage  

1. The basic structure  

Suppose the world contains two cities, Aleppo (A) and Damascus (D).  If Death meets you, you suffer utility 0; if you escape him, you enjoy utility 100.  Death is a fallible predictor who, roughly, guesses the city you will choose with probability p > ½ but displays a built-in bias toward Damascus: when Death is uncertain he plumps for D.  The agent knows all this.

CDT says: to evaluate “Go to A”, look at causal consequences downstream of that act; anything upstream—e.g. where Death positioned himself last night—is treated as probabilistically independent of your choice.  In symbols,

EU_CDT(Go to A) = 100·Pr(Death in D) + 0·Pr(Death in A).  
EU_CDT(Go to D) = 100·Pr(Death in A) + 0·Pr(Death in D).

Because the probabilities on the right-hand side are unconditional, they should not be set by imagining what would happen if you acted otherwise.  Instead they are whatever you currently believe them to be.  But—and this is the crucial step—those beliefs partly track your own credence that you will choose A or D, since Death’s prediction, by hypothesis, is tethered to that very choice.

2. Why the utilities shift  

Let q be your present subjective probability that you will in fact go to Damascus.  Given Death’s reliability p, you should assign:

Pr(Death in D) = p·q + (1–p)·(1–q)  
Pr(Death in A) = p·(1–q) + (1–p)·q.

Plugging these into the expected utilities yields:

EU_CDT(D) – EU_CDT(A) = 100·[Pr(Death in A) – Pr(Death in D)]  
                       = 100·[(p·(1–q) + (1–p)·q) – (p·q + (1–p)·(1–q))]  
                       = 100·[(p – (1–p))·(1 – 2q)]  
                       = 100·(2p – 1)(1 – 2q).

If Death is better than a coin-flipper (p > ½), the coefficient (2p–1) is positive, so the sign of the difference depends on (1–2q).  Result:  

• If at the start of deliberation q < ½ (you think you are likelier to go to Aleppo) CDT says “Go to Damascus.”  
• Having contemplated Damascus, your credence q rises; if it exceeds ½, CDT flips to “Go to Aleppo.”  
• Iterate and you get an endless oscillation.

II. Diagnosing the Trouble  

1. Failure of practical guidance  

Practical rationality is supposed to tell an agent both what it is rational to do and how to settle on a course of action.  CDT’s oscillation undermines both aims.  A theory that issues conflicting mandates in immediate succession does not guide; at best it paralyses.  The oscillation does not stem from insufficient information.  On the contrary, the agent’s probabilities are perfectly sharp; it is the theory’s own rule for mixing them with utilities that generates the instability.

2. The shadow of “Dutch books”  

A classic hallmark of irrationality is vulnerability to a guaranteed loss through a series of wagers offered before and after deliberation.  In Death in Damascus, a clever bettor could exploit the CDT agent’s shifting recommendations: offer a side bet favouring whichever city CDT happens to prefer at the moment, wait a second for the preference to flip, and offer the symmetric bet.  Because each offer is rational by the agent’s lights at the time, she accepts both—yet the pair of bets ensures a certain loss.  This fact reveals an incoherence internal to the belief-desire package that CDT endorses.

3. Reflective inconsistency  

Joyce (1999) articulates a minimal self-requirement for rational choice: an agent ought to approve of her own decision process in prospect; if, ex ante, she can tell that following CDT will predictably put her in a state of self-doubt and policy reversal, CDT violates that requirement.  Put differently, a CDT agent foresees that her later self will judge her earlier self’s action sub-optimal the moment her credences nudge past the ½ threshold.  Anticipating this, the current self has reason to pre-empt the very method CDT prescribes—a direct clash with the Reflection Principle.

III. What Might CDT Say in Reply?  

1. “Fix your act probabilities”  

One move is to declare that act probabilities should be treated as exogenous ‘input parameters’, insulated from deliberation.  Do your causal-expected-utility calculation on those numbers; whichever act wins, execute it with certainty; do not update q mid-process.  But this instruction is psycholog­ically unrealistic and normatively ad hoc.  Deliberation just is the process of changing one’s credence about what one will do in light of reasons.  Freezing q is tantamount to forbidding deliberation.

Furthermore, on pain of circularity the agent needs a way to set those fixed probabilities.  Any non-deliberative basis would be arbitrary.  The cure thus demands a mystery: an infallible oracle giving you your own future act-base‐rate before you have chosen.

2. Ratifiability  

Jeffrey (1983) proposed that a rational act must be “ratifiable”: after one updates on the fact of having chosen it, one must still endorse it.  Applied here, the only ratifiable strategy is to randomise with exactly the mixture that makes Death’s prediction chance–match your lottery ticket, annihilating the predictor’s edge.  In a symmetric Death-in-Damascus this means q = ½, hence EU_CDT(D) = EU_CDT(A), so either city is ratifiable if chosen by a fair coin.

Ratifiability patches the oscillation but at high cost:

a. It replaces CDT’s causal reasoning with a fixed‐point condition alien to the original theory.  
b. It offers no advice about which mixed strategy to adopt when the predictor is biased, except the knife-edge probability that equalises expected utilities.  
c. The prescription to “randomise with probability ε” is itself unratifiable if one expects one’s randomiser might misfire (e.g. physical coin tosses are imperfect).

3. Two-Boxing Analogy  

Defenders sometimes argue the oscillation is no worse than the “tickle defence” of two-boxing in Newcomb’s problem: noticing oneself reaching for two boxes raises the probability that the opaque box is empty, yet CDT stands by the recommendation to take both.  So why panic in Damascus?  The disanalogy is that in Newcomb, CDT’s expected utilities are monotonic: as you become surer you will two-box, the utility of two-boxing only decreases, never flips to favour one-boxing.  Hence deliberation does not produce oscillation; at worst it reveals a static dominance relation.  Death in Damascus is different because each marginal increase in q penalises D and rewards A at equal rates.  The slope changes sign at the fixed point, creating feedback not present in Newcomb.

IV. Why the Problem is Deep  

1. Illusion of Causal Independence  

CDT tells us to ignore non-causal correlations, yet the pivotal correlations in Death in Damascus are produced by a causal process—Death’s earlier attempt to forecast your act.  What the agent lacks is not a causal connection, but control: her late-breaking choice cannot affect the past.  CDT’s way of factoring causes from evidential links therefore misfires: the predictor’s action is historically upstream but functionally coupled to the very deliberation now under way.

2. Self-Reference and Fixed-Point Failure  

Formally, CDT is searching for a fixed point of a best-response function defined over probabilities of acts.  In generic games such fixed points exist (e.g. Nash equilibria).  CDT in Damascus destroys existence by employing unconditional probability measures that shift when the strategy changes: every candidate act swings the probability balance against itself, so no pure strategy can satisfy ‘best response to itself’.  A theory incapable of locating a fixed point in single‐agent choice—in contrast to game‐theoretic multi-agent contexts—has abdicated its foundational task.

3. Updatelessness as a Benchmark  

Alternative formalisms—namely Updateless CDT or Functional Decision Theory—deliver a clean solution.  They evaluate acts using the prior credence function before learning anything about one’s own action.  From that perspective, Death’s position is positively correlated with one’s decision procedure, but choosing whichever city has the lower unconditional probability of Death maximises expected utility and stays stable under subsequent introspection.  That alternative does not oscillate, suggesting that CDT’s reliance on stage-wise ‘conditioning on your own act’ is the culprit.

V. Objections Considered  

1. “Any reasonable agent can just randomise; therefore no real problem.”  

Randomisation circumvents the oscillation but not the theoretical flaw.  First, CDT never justifies why mixed acts are rational here but not in structurally similar cases lacking a predictor.  Second, when utilities are asymmetric (Death’s bias toward Damascus), the knife‐edge chance of randomising exactly enough remains unstable: mis‐calibrate by a hair’s breadth and the oscillation returns.

2. “The case is contrived; real agents are not transparent enough to be predicted with accuracy p > ½.”  

True examples may be rare, but decision theory aims at principled generality.  Newcomb, Prisoner’s Dilemma, and Gettier cases are likewise stylised; yet they illuminate deep principles.  More practically, AIs interacting with copies or near-copies of themselves face predictor problems constantly: coordination among training instances, adversarial self-play, reflective oracles.  For them, Death in Damascus is no toy.

3. “EDT fares no better; so CDT is not singled out.”  

Evidential Decision Theory (EDT) indeed stumbles in other settings (medical Newcomb), but here EDT is stable: conditional on going to Damascus, you are almost certain to meet Death; conditional on Aleppo, almost certain to escape; choose Aleppo.  One need not embrace EDT wholesale to see that CDT alone produces the pathological vacillation in this scenario.

VI. The Path Forward  

The lesson is not that causal structure is irrelevant.  Rather, the agent should apply causal‐expected‐utility reasoning to the output of her algorithm before any self-locating evidence about which output it will be.  In game-theoretic terms, “commit to the policy, not the move.”  Once the policy is fixed, later conditionalisations on the move are purely epistemic and do not provoke further choice.  Doing so recovers practical guidance and reflective consistency while retaining a fundamentally causal outlook.

VII. Conclusion  

CDT’s dependence on act probabilities in Death in Damascus is a genuine problem because it yields oscillating recommendations, undermines practical guidance, and violates reflective consistency.  Attempts to rescue CDT by freezing credences or importing ratifiability either impose unrealistic constraints or smuggle in alien principles.  The deeper moral is that when other agents—or clever predictors—key their behaviour to our decision process, the neat segregation of “causally downstream” from “merely correlated” breaks down.  A satisfactory decision theory must therefore evaluate acts at a point prior to learning which act the deliberation will output.  Unless CDT is re-engineered along those lines, its prescriptions will remain unstable in precisely the cases where strategic self-awareness matters most.

Causal Decision Theory and Deliberation‐Dependence  
Why the ‘Death in Damascus’ Case Puts Pressure on CDT

1. Introduction and thesis  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) instructs an agent to choose the act with the greatest causal expected utility: the utility obtained by weighting each possible consequence of the act by the unconditional probability that the consequence would materialise if the act were performed.  In ordinary cases CDT performs well, but in self-referential situations—Newcomb’s Problem, Psychological Twins, and, most sharply, ‘Death in Damascus’—the output of CDT appears to turn on how likely the agent currently thinks she is to perform each act.  As those act-probabilities shift during deliberation, CDT’s advice can flip back and forth.  My thesis is that this deliberation-dependence is a genuine problem for CDT because (i) it deprives the theory of stable, action-guiding recommendations, (ii) it violates an intuitive constraint on rational choice—independence from purely introspective information—and (iii) it opens CDT to a Dutch book / money-pump style vulnerability.  The culprit is CDT’s reliance on unconditional probabilities in contexts where the state of the world is partly a prediction of the very choice under deliberation.  A satisfactory decision theory must extricate itself from that feedback loop; until CDT either revises its probability rule or moves to policy-level evaluation, the ‘Death in Damascus’ scenario reveals an internal instability.

2. The mechanics of CDT  

CDT evaluates each act A by

CEU(A) = Σs P(s) · U(outcome of A in s),

where s ranges over ‘causally independent’ states—facts not downstream of A—and P(s) is the agent’s unconditional credence in s prior to choosing.  The guiding thought is counterfactual: imagine ‘holding fixed’ the upstream world and then ask what A would cause.  Crucially, CDT tells us not to condition on the act itself.  If I am deciding whether to drink the toxin, the probability that I drink the toxin is not part of the calculation; the relevant probabilities are about the toxin’s chemical properties, my bank account, and so on—facts that will not be caused by the muscular motion of swallowing.

That policy delivers plausible results in standard cases, but it presupposes a neat causal partition: acts here, states there.  ‘Death in Damascus’ breaks that partition because the state includes a predictor whose belief about my future act is itself sensitive to how the causal process of my deliberation unfolds.

3. Setting up ‘Death in Damascus’  

Death is looking for me.  If he correctly predicts that I will travel to a city, he will be waiting there and I will die (utility = 0).  If he mispredicts, I escape for the day (utility = 1).  Death’s predictions are highly, though not perfectly, reliable:  P(Death predicts correctly | city = Damascus) = 0.9 and P(Death predicts correctly | city = Aleppo) = 0.9.  Moreover Death has a slight Damascus bias: absent any evidence he issues a Damascus prediction with probability 0.6.

Let p be my subjective probability, at a given moment in deliberation, that I will in fact go to Damascus.  CDT instructs me to calculate

EU(Damas) = (1 − 0.9) · (1 − p) + (1 − 0.9) · p = 0.1 − 0.2p  
EU(Aleppo) = 0.1 + 0.2p.

(For clarity, those numbers reflect the chance of Death’s misprediction; the algebra is straightforward and not essential to the broader point.)  EU(Damas) exceeds EU(Aleppo) just when p < 0.25; if I currently think there is more than a 25 % chance I will wind up in Damascus, CDT advises Aleppo, but the minute I begin to follow that advice p starts drifting downward (I now think I’m likelier to go to Aleppo), and at p = 0.24 the inequality flips—CDT tells me to head back to Damascus.  The calculation is literally self-referential: what is best by CDT lights depends on a credence that itself depends on what I think is best.

4. Is that drift a genuine problem? Three diagnostic tests  

4.1 Failure of stability  

A decision rule ought, at least in ideal conditions, to converge on a recommendation.  By ‘ideal’ I mean no new non-psychological information arrives; the only thing changing is the agent’s own conditional probabilities about what she will do.  Yet CDT’s rule fails even that modest test.  One can formalise the issue using Brouwer’s fixed-point theorem: the function from credence p to recommended act has no fixed point because the act is discontinuous in p.  Joyce, Rabinowicz, and Skyrms all note that a decision procedure that outputs “switch!” every time it is consulted cannot serve the directive role that a theory of rational choice is supposed to play.  In effect, CDT hands the agent a compass whose needle spins the moment she glances at it.

4.2 Violation of the ‘No Introspective Relevance’ principle  

Consider two epistemically identical agents except for their current level of self-confidence about choosing Damascus.  They inhabit literally the same external world: same predictor, same accuracy statistics.  On a plausible norm, purely introspective facts—how sure one is that one will act a certain way—should not by themselves rationalise different choices.  (This is akin to a principle of public deliberation: if we both have the same evidence about the world, our divergence in self-confidence should at most reflect irrationality, not recommended action.)  CDT flouts that principle: agent-A with p = .3 is told to choose Aleppo, while agent-B with p = .2 is told to choose Damascus.  All the object-level evidence is identical; only their inner hunches differ.  That looks like an epistemic analogue of indexical information driving action in an objectionably strong way.

One might reply that in Newcomb’s problem introspective information is relevant because the predictor already exploited it; but here the predictor has finished his job—Death’s expected location is determined only by the statistical relation between prediction and action.  Insofar as one’s current self-belief is epistemically insulated from further causal impact on Death, letting it dictate the choice seems unwarranted.

4.3 Money-pump exposure  

Suppose a cunning psychologist can observe my credences with perfect accuracy and charge a small fee every time I switch plans.  Starting from p = .5, CDT instructs: go Aleppo.  Realising I’m now unlikely to visit Damascus, my credence slides left; at p = .24 I reverse to Damascus.  The psychologist announces a taxi change and pockets a fee.  The cycle repeats, draining resources while leaving me no better off regarding Death.  The mere fact that I am following CDT makes me exploitable.  That consequence needn’t be decisive—every theory struggles with some money-pump variant—but it indicates that CDT’s deliberation-dependence is not just an aesthetic flaw; it cashes out in dominated behaviour.

5. Diagnosing the source: unconditional probabilities in a reflexive setting  

Why does CDT stumble?  Because its ‘hold fixed upstream, vary act’ procedure treats the correlation between my act and Death’s prediction as exogenous, even while my best estimate of that correlation changes once I start treating one act as counterfactual.  The unconditional probability P(Death predicts Damascus) is not in fact independent of whether I decide on Damascus, and CDT purposefully ignores conditionalising on the decision to avoid evidential back-feeding.  That works when the causal arrow is one-way (my drinking the toxin cannot causally explain the chemist’s having deposited money yesterday), but not when evidence flows both ways through a common cause (my psychology) as in prediction cases.

Formally, let S be Death’s prediction, A my act.  CDT uses P(S) rather than P(S | A).  Yet because S and A share a common-cause node—the psychological profile Death observed—P(S) is not stable under revisions to P(A).  Any credence shift in A reverberates into S through the agent’s belief that Death is a good predictor.  CDT hence forbids a conditioning step (to avoid evidential decision theory’s well-known pitfalls) but also refuses to excise the inferential pathway.  The result is an epistemic half-measure: we are allowed to notice that S correlates with A, but not allowed to hold that correlation fixed while counterfactually varying A.

6. Candidate repairs and their costs  

6.1 Ratifiability constraints  

Gibbard & Harper propose that a rational choice must be ‘ratifiable’: the act recommended by CDT, once adopted, would continue to be recommended after updating on that very adoption.  In Death in Damascus only one credence level may satisfy ratifiability, restoring uniqueness.  However, the ratifiability fix has two drawbacks.  First, the existence of a ratifiable fixed point is not guaranteed; some games contain none or multiple, leaving indeterminacy.  Second, the ratifiability condition is itself deliberation-sensitive; critics argue it smuggles in a diachronic evidentialist flavour antithetical to CDT’s spirit.

6.2 Policy or commitment decision rules  

Another move is to shift the unit of evaluation from one‐shot acts to complete policies, i.e. act-probability pairs.  Joyce advocates ‘Causal Decision Theory for Mixed Acts’ where the agent chooses a stochastic strategy that maximises expected utility over lotteries of acts.  In Damascus, a 25 %/75 % mix forms a fixed point and yields the highest value.  Deliberation then consists in randomising, not vacillating.  This approach secures stability but at a price: moving to policies blurs the distinction between a decision rule (which should pick a definite act once circumstances are settled) and a self-binding strategy (which embeds a randomisation device).  Critics will complain that the elegance of CDT lay in telling us which world-history we should cause, not which lottery over world-histories we should implement.

6.3 Two-boxer style hardline  

Some causalists bite the bullet: the decision problem is ill-posed unless the agent has a sharp credence p, and once she does the recommendation is determinate; if she vacillates, that is a failure of doxastic coherence, not the fault of CDT.  Yet in Damascus the instability arises not from initial indecision but from the very process of adopting CDT’s advice.  Any epistemically permissible p can be nudged across the threshold by the agent’s reflection about what she is about to do.  The ‘hardline’ response therefore collapses into psychological denial: it decrees that rational agents must possess magically stable self-predictions.

6.4 Evidential Decision Theory  

EDT, ironically, has no problem here: it advises choosing Damascus because doing so is evidence Death predicted Aleppo, hence you live.  That looks attractive, but EDT notoriously recommends one‐boxing in Newcomb, smoking when genes correlate with cancer, and other results many find counter-intuitive.  Resorting to EDT thus solves the particular headache at the cost of adopting a whole alternative framework with its own ailments.

7. Is the problem unique to prediction cases?  

One might worry that the pathology is special to outlandish predictor scenarios.  But variants turn up in real life.  Investment funds sometimes follow algorithms whose trades are reverse-engineered by competitors; the profitability of buying a stock can depend on whether rivals have guessed you will buy.  Negotiation stances depend on the opponent’s model of your strategy.  Even medical advice can be reflexive: your probability of sticking to a diet affects whether the diet is beneficial for you.  Whenever success depends on a third party’s (imperfect) forecast of your action, CDT’s deliberation‐dependence reappears.

8. Against a possible rejoinder: “But the instability is merely epistemic”  

A die-hard causalist may object that no irrationality is involved: the agent’s changing beliefs duly track new evidence—the evidence of her inclining toward one act.  Since beliefs rationally respond to evidence, the recommendation’s shift mirrors an epistemically proper update.  True, but the regress never bottoms out: each micro-shift in belief is instantly evidence for the next micro-shift.  Bayesians typically require closure under conditionalisation, but they also presume a halt to the evidence chain when no new external data arrive.  The endless self-generated ‘evidence’ of one’s own fleeting resolutions looks like epistemic wheel-spinning.  Without a rule to terminate the feedback, rational choice loses its moorings.

9. Comparative evaluation: what a decision theory is for  

Normative decision theory is supposed to satisfy two roles: action guidance and assessment of rationality.  CDT’s behaviour in Damascus undermines both.  As guidance it fails because it cannot settle on a directive.  As a standard of evaluation it yields the awkward verdict that a difference in flickering self-confidence can make one agent rational and another irrational, even though each possesses identical evidence about the world.  That seems to assign decisive normative weight to the epistemically flimsy fact of instantaneous self-belief.  Any theory delivering such verdicts is prima facie suspect.

10. Conclusion  

CDT’s dependence on the agent’s current act-probabilities in ‘Death in Damascus’ is not a harmless quirk; it exposes a structural instability rooted in CDT’s handling of unconditional probabilities when the state of the world embeds a prediction of the act under scrutiny.  The instability denies CDT a settled recommendation, violates a plausible independence principle, and renders the agent exploitable.  Proposed fixes—ratifiability, policy-level choice, or dogmatic insistence on stable self-belief—either distort CDT’s causal spirit or shift the problem elsewhere.  Unless CDT can articulate a principled way to ‘screen off’ self-referential evidential correlations without discarding causal guidance altogether, the Damascus case remains an Achilles’ heel.  A satisfactory decision theory must issue recommendations robust to the agent’s own deliberative tremors.  At present CDT does not.

1. Introduction and Thesis

For a decision theory to guide an agent, its prescriptions must be both stable and action-determining: having applied the theory, a rational agent must be able to settle on an option and act. In “Death in Damascus’’ cases, Causal Decision Theory (CDT) appears unable to meet this standard. Because CDT evaluates each act with an expected-utility calculation that treats the agent’s own credence in performing that very act as an input, its recommendation can shift in the course of deliberation. I shall argue that this dependence is indeed a decisive problem for CDT. It prevents CDT from offering (i) stable guidance, (ii) dynamically consistent planning across time, and (iii) a robust account of ratification. Attempts to rescue CDT—by appeal to mixed strategies, to “equilibrium’’ credences, or to a refined notion of act individuation—either collapse into another decision theory or leave the guidance problem unsolved. The difficulty is not a mere technical wrinkle; it reveals a structural flaw in CDT’s treatment of correlation with upstream states. Functional or policy-based decision theories that evaluate whole decision procedures rather than momentary acts avoid the instability and therefore look better placed to inherit the role CDT was meant to play.

2. The Case Re-stated

You are travelling through the desert when you encounter the Angel of Death. He tells you: “Tomorrow you will wake up either in Aleppo or in Damascus. I have spent the night predicting your destination. I am good at this: my prediction is correct about 90 % of the time, but this year I’m slightly biased—I tend to guess ‘Damascus’ when in doubt.’’ If Death predicted Aleppo, he will wait in Aleppo; if he predicted Damascus, he will wait in Damascus. You now know that you will die if you end up in the city he predicted. This is the familiar “Death in Damascus’’ story. Crucially, the variable describing Death’s location lies causally upstream of your choice of city: whether Death is in Aleppo is settled by his having predicted Aleppo, and his predicting is over before you decide. Nevertheless, Death’s prediction is strongly—but only probabilistically—correlated with your act. You must decide where to go, knowing that the correctness of your decision depends on a correlation you cannot affect causally but can affect evidentially.

3. CDT’s Evaluation

CDT tells the agent to compute, for each act a, its causal expected utility:

CEU(a) = Σs  U(a,s) · P(s),

where the sum runs over states s that are not causally downstream of a. Because the state “Death predicted Damascus’’ is upstream, its probability is unconditional: it is whatever you currently believe it to be, full stop. But your belief about Death’s prediction depends on how likely you think you are to go to Damascus, for you take Death to be reliable and to have biased priors. So, let p be your current credence that you will go to Damascus; the bias is such that

P(Death predicted Damascus) = .6 + .3·p.    (1)

(Substitute specific numbers if you like; the qualitative structure is the key.) Utility is simple: surviving is +1, dying is 0. Then:

CEU(Damascus) = (1 − P(Death predicted Damascus)) · 1 = 1 − (.6 + .3p),

CEU(Aleppo)   = P(Death predicted Damascus) · 1 = .6 + .3p.

Notice that CEU(Damascus) + CEU(Aleppo) = 1. So CDT recommends Damascus whenever CEU(Damascus) > CEU(Aleppo), i.e., whenever 1 − (.6 + .3p) > .6 + .3p, which simplifies to p < .067; and it recommends Aleppo otherwise. Put vividly: if at the outset of deliberation you are more than 6.7 % confident you will go to Damascus, CDT says “Go to Aleppo!’’. If you are less confident than that, CDT says “Go to Damascus!’’.

4. The Deliberative Loop

You begin in a perfectly ordinary first-person state of uncertainty about your forthcoming action. Suppose p = .3. CDT therefore tells you to go to Aleppo. But once you commit to Aleppo, you update p to near 0, for your chosen act is now (almost) certain. With p ≈ 0, equation (1) yields P(Death predicted Damascus) ≈ .6, so CEU(Damascus) ≈ .4 and CEU(Aleppo) ≈ .6; now Damascus is better! You reverse course. Yet the moment you lean Damascus-ward, p crests above .067, pulling CEU(Damascus) back below CEU(Aleppo). You flip again. The process can ping-pong indefinitely so long as you remain conceptually faithful to CDT’s rule of recomputing expectations after each micro-shift in credence.

The problem is not one of human psychology (e.g., akrasia or failure to settle). It lies in what CDT itself demands: a complete ordering of acts relative to the agent’s total evidence. But the agent’s total evidence at t consists not merely of external facts—she also possesses higher-order beliefs about her own impending act, and CDT instructs her to treat those higher-order beliefs as inputs. Because those beliefs are endogenously entangled with the very output CDT is supposed to determine, no stable output emerges.

5. The Guidance Failure

A theory that tells an agent “Do X—unless you come to believe you will do X, in which case do Y’’ fails to guide, because its advice depends on accepting or ignoring that very advice. The guidance role of decision theory, famously emphasised by Lewis and later by Joyce, requires that deliberation be self-effacing: consulting the theory should not itself change what the theory recommends. CDT flunks that test here.

One might protest: “The dependence on p is harmless, provided the agent enters deliberation with a determinate probability.’’ But that confuses static choice with dynamic choice. The agent’s first-person probability p is simply her epistemic state about what she is about to do. It is no more reasonable to demand that she begin deliberation with p = 0 or 1 than to demand that an uncommitted juror start with certainty about how she will vote. Indeed, if the agent began with p = 1 for Damascus, CDT would already tell her to go to Aleppo—a recommendation she perforce cannot follow (probability one). CDT thus issues counter-performative advice to agents certain of their act and unstable advice to agents uncertain of their act.

6. Ratification and the Absence of Stable Points

To diagnose this formally, philosophers (e.g., Jeffrey, Arntzenius, and Ahmed) have introduced the notion of ratifiability. An act is ratifiable for a given credence function if, conditional on doing that act, the agent would still prefer that act under the same evaluation procedure. In Death in Damascus, the only ratifiable “acts’’ under CDT are the limiting mixed strategies of probability 1 to Aleppo (if P(Death predicted Damascus) ≤ .5) or 1 to Damascus (if ≥ .5). But neither limiting point is guaranteed to be utility-maximising: whether surviving is likelier by certainty in Aleppo or certainty in Damascus depends on the bias in Death’s prior—an exogenous fact the agent may not control and may not know. Even worse, if the bias is exactly symmetric, the only ratifiable acts are knife-edge; any attempt to approximate them leads to the oscillation we saw.

A decision rule whose only stable points are extremes that the agent has no reason to favour exhibits what economists call “failure of existence of a Nash equilibrium’’ in pure strategies. It is standard in game theory to salvage such cases by appeal to mixed equilibria. But in ordinary single-agent decision problems there is no logical space for a “mix’’ between one’s own actions across possible worlds. Invoking a mixed strategy here is simply to say that as of now you commit to a lottery of destinations with some frequency. Yet CDT on its face evaluates acts, not commitment policies. So the route to stability appears to require a shift to a different unit of evaluation—precisely what functional decision theories recommend.

7. Dynamic Inconsistency and Planning

Suppose foreseeing the deliberative loop, you adopt a two-stage plan: tonight you will decide where to go; tomorrow morning you will travel. Ideal rationality requires dynamic consistency: if, when the plan was adopted, you had no grounds for foreseeing that tomorrow you would regret it, you should not expect to change your mind absent new information. But tonight you can foresee that tomorrow morning your p will have shifted to (almost) 1 for whichever city you are about to enter, at which point CDT will recommend the other city. Hence you know now that you will tomorrow reject whatever you now choose. CDT makes it rationally mandatory to adopt a plan you know you will abandon, which is absurd. (By contrast, Evidential Decision Theory and Functional Decision Theory both deliver time-consistent plans: go to Aleppo if Death is biased toward Damascus; otherwise stay put.)

8. A Dutch Book Illustration

Disagreement about decision principles is often clarified by exhibiting a “Dutch book’’—a set of bets that each conform individually to the agent’s current evaluation rule yet together guarantee a loss. Fix the numbers above. Every time your credence p crosses the 6.7 % threshold one way or the other, CDT flips its preference. A clever bookmaker who can watch your shifting credence can offer you a very small bet favourable by your lights each time the flip occurs: e.g., “Pay me 1¢ if Damascus is better, I pay you 1.1¢ if Aleppo is better.’’ Because you traverse the boundary infinitely many times in any ε-neighbourhood, you will accept countably many such bets whose net payoffs telescope to a sure loss. A theory that licenses a sure-loss strategy conditional only on rational updating is, at best, pragmatically defective.

9. Three Rescue Attempts for CDT—and Their Problems

Rescue 1: “Ideal reasoners assign p = 0 or 1 to their own future acts.’’ That claim contradicts standard Bayesian norms: absent a commitment device, agents typically have uncertainty about their future behaviour. Forcing p to extremes by fiat does not answer the explanatory demand: how should a rational agent reach those extreme credences before having chosen?

Rescue 2: “CDT should evaluate not simple acts but mixed acts—probability distributions over actions.’’ This is to change the theory. Standard CDT (Gibbard & Harper, Lewis) evaluates acts treated as deterministic choices. If we upgrade it to evaluate policies or mixed acts, it begins to look like functional decision theory or a sophisticated EDT which considers the evidential impact of adopting a policy. The supposed rescue therefore abandons classic CDT.

Rescue 3: “The dependence on p disappears once the agent applies counterfactual probabilities correctly: when computing the value of Damascus she should hold fixed P(Death predicted Damascus) as assessed before deliberation.’’ This proposal smuggles in evidential decision theory via the back door. CDT’s defining feature is the use of unconditional probabilities for upstream states. If those probabilities are frozen at pre-deliberative values even while one entertains contrary acts, the calculation violates CDT’s own recipe; and if one endorses that violation, one has conceded that mere contemplation of an act should not change one’s belief about upstream states—an evidential, not causal, restriction.

10. The Deeper Structural Flaw

Why does CDT stumble here? Because it tries to chart a razor-thin path: ignore all evidential implications of one’s act (to evade Newcomb-style “manipulation problems’’) yet allow ordinary causal implications. But in the presence of a predictor whose accuracy itself depends on the agent’s dispositions, the boundary collapses. Predictions correlate with acts for precisely the same reason acts correlate with their deliberative precursors: they share a common causal ancestor in the agent’s psychology. CDT must either blacklist that entire dependency—which would amount to using subjunctive conditionals that treat the agent’s psychology as mutable, thereby undercutting introspective knowledge—or allow the dependency, thereby triggering the instability we diagnosed. There is no stable classical CDT middle ground.

11. Functional Decision Theory as a Contrast

Functional Decision Theory (FDT), recently elaborated by Yudkowsky and Soares, treats the decision problem at the level of algorithms: you ask, “Which output of this very decision function has the best expected consequence?’’ In Death in Damascus you recognise that if the function outputs “Go to Aleppo,’’ then Death’s prediction is quite probably “Damascus’’ and you live. If it outputs “Go to Damascus,’’ the predictor likely said “Damascus’’ and you die. Because the function’s output is subjunctively linked to the prediction, FDT recommends Aleppo, period. No dependence on your credence about what you will do arises; what matters is the subjunctive dependency between algorithmic output and predictor’s act. FDT therefore supplies the stable guidance missing from CDT.

12. Confirming Intuitions and Empirical Plausibility

Ordinary agents do not in fact report oscillatory indecision of the CDT sort when faced, in laboratory settings, with predictor games. They realise that the predictor’s bias is what matters: if the predictor tends to guess Damascus, go to Aleppo. That pattern of behaviour fits EDT and FDT but not CDT. So not only is CDT normatively defective, it is descriptively implausible, undercutting a traditional selling point of causal utility reasoning—namely, its psychological realism.

13. Conclusion

Causal Decision Theory, precisely because it insists on using unconditional probabilities for upstream states, forces an agent’s evaluation of actions to depend on her evolving credence about performing those actions. In “Death in Damascus’’ scenarios the dependence becomes vicious: CDT supplies no stable recommendation, violates dynamic consistency, exposes agents to Dutch books, and fails the basic guidance test. The diagnosis generalises: whenever utilities are sensitive to correlations between the agent’s act and some upstream predictor, CDT either treats those correlations as causally irrelevant (and so mis-evaluates) or as causally relevant (and so destabilises its own recommendation). Attempts to patch CDT by freezing credences, by shifting to policy evaluation, or by endorsing mixed strategies in effect abandon CDT’s core principle. The lesson is not a local embarrassment but an invitation to rethink what rational choice under correlation requires. Decision rules that treat one’s decision procedure itself as the object of evaluation—whether Evidential Decision Theory refined with ratification or Functional Decision Theory—avoid the pathology and restore stable, time-consistent guidance. Consequently, the dependence on act probabilities is not a quirk but a fatal flaw in classic CDT.

1. Introduction and thesis

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) is often advertised as the theory that tells us to base choice on causal rather than merely evidential correlations.  In practice that slogan is cashed out by the Expected Utility (EU) rule: for each act A, calculate the causal expected utility ∑s P(s) · U(A,s), where the sum ranges only over states s that are not causally downstream of A.^1  In ordinary cases the probabilities P(s) are independent of what one is about to do, so the decision rule gives a stable comparison of acts.  But in so-called “Death in Damascus” (DiD) scenarios the probability of being in each state depends, via a predictor, on the probability one assigns to one’s own forthcoming act.  The upshot is that as one’s credence in going to Damascus versus Aleppo fluctuates during deliberation, CDT’s ranking of the acts can flip‐flop as well.  The central question is whether that dependence on “act probabilities” is an objection to CDT.

My answer is: yes, it is a serious problem.  The dependence generates (i) deliberative instability, (ii) a failure of ratifiability, (iii) vulnerability to Dutch books and coordination failures, and (iv) a violation of basic explanatory aspirations of causal decision theory itself.  Together these defects show that ordinary, act-based CDT, which evaluates each option in isolation against the background of the agent’s current credences about what she will do, is normatively inadequate.  What the DiD family of cases teaches us is that any satisfactory causal decision theory must treat whole policies, not momentary acts, as the objects of evaluation.  Once the shift to policy-based CDT is made, the “act-probability” instability disappears.  Thus the dependence in question is not a harmless quirk; it forces a structural revision of CDT.

The rest of the essay proceeds as follows.  Section 2 reconstructs the Death in Damascus case with enough formal detail to see where the dependence arises.  Section 3 shows how that dependence yields the four problems just listed.  Section 4 considers three lines of defence available to the causal decision theorist and argues that none succeeds unless CDT is reformulated in policy terms.  Section 5 sketches such a reformulation and explains why it avoids the original worry.  Section 6 addresses two residual objections and clarifies why the difficulty is not merely psychological but normatively significant.  Section 7 concludes.

2. How act probabilities enter the picture

Suppose you care only about staying alive and that Death’s scythe deprives you of 100 utiles of welfare.  You must choose between Damascus (D) and Aleppo (A).  Death observes the entire history of your deliberation except, let us assume, your final random seed, so his prediction is highly, but not perfectly, reliable.  Concretely:

(1) P(Death predicts D | you go to D) = p_high = 0.9  
(2) P(Death predicts D | you go to A) = p_low  = 0.6  

So Death is biased toward guessing Damascus.  If he guesses the city you actually visit, he goes there and you die (utility −100).  If he guesses incorrectly, you live (utility 0).  There is no intrinsic value or cost to either city.  

Let q = P_CDT(now)(D) be your current subjective probability of ultimately choosing Damascus.  CDT instructs you to compute the causal expected utility of going to Damascus as

EU_C(D) = −100 · P(Death predicts D | you go to D)  
    = −100 · 0.9 = −90.

Analogously,

EU_C(A) = −100 · P(Death predicts A | you go to A)  
    = −100 · 0.4 = −40.

So far Damascus looks worse.  But here is the twist: the conditional probabilities (1)–(2) are not fully exogenous.  The predictor is reliable precisely because he tracks whatever evidence about your intentions your current total state provides.  A natural way to model this is:

P(Death predicts D) = 0.9q + 0.6(1−q).  
Now by Bayes’ theorem,

P(Death predicts D | you go to D) = (0.9q)/(q) = 0.9,  

which is stable, but the crucial comparison turns out to depend on q after all once one allows Death’s slight bias to feed back into q during deliberation.  Intuitively, as you acquire confidence that you will pick Aleppo, you infer that Death will increasingly guess Damascus, making Damascus safer, which nudges you back toward Damascus, and so on.  The CDT machinery does not supply a unique equilibrium point.  Indeed, as Teller (forthcoming) shows, the only fixed points are q = 0 and q = 1; any intermediary credence is self-undermining.  Consequently, during deliberation CDT’s recommendation oscillates: with q = 0.51 choose Aleppo; as you start to intend A, q drifts up, making Damascus safer; CDT flips; the process repeats ad infinitum.^2

3. Four reasons this is a problem

3.1 Deliberative instability  
A decision rule should guide deliberation toward settlement on an act.  Act-based CDT instead initiates a feedback loop in which the very act of adopting a tentative intention to do A rationally forces reconsideration in favour of D, which in turn rationally forces reconsideration in favour of A.  Because the oscillation is generated by CDT’s own prescriptions, the agent cannot end deliberation in a way she recognises as rationally permissible.  This violates what Joyce (1999) calls the settling requirement: rational deliberation must be able to resolve into intentional action.

3.2 Failure of ratifiability  
Richard Jeffrey’s ratifiability test asks whether, having adopted act A on the basis of CDT, one should expect A to maximise EU conditional on that very fact.  In DiD there is no ratifiable act: if you pick Damascus, you thereby raise the chance that Death predicted Damascus, so D now looks worse; if you pick Aleppo, the parallel story holds.  A decision rule that never recommends a ratifiable act in a class of perfectly coherent cases is incomplete at best.

3.3 Dutch bookability and coordination failures  
Arntzenius, Elga and Hawthorne (2004) show that an agent whose credences evolve via such CDT-guided oscillations can be Dutch-booked by a clever bookie who offers bets fast enough to exploit each flip before the next.  More generally, if two CDT agents have to coordinate in a Death-style setting they can be trapped in mutually destructive cycles.  Susceptibility to sure-loss trades is a canonical sign of irrationality (de Finetti).

3.4 Conflict with the theory’s own causal rationale  
The whole point of CDT is to base choice on factors one can causally influence.  But whether Death predicted Damascus is not something your current act can causally affect once his prediction is fixed.  Act-based CDT nevertheless allows your own shifting credence in that act to change the evaluation.  In effect it smuggles back the evidential correlations CDT was designed to exclude, undermining the causal/explanatory motivation of the theory.

4. Can the causal decision theorist reply?

4.1 The “accept an equilibrium” reply  
One might insist that a rational agent must jump straight to a fixed point of deliberation—either q = 0 or q = 1—and thereby pick one city outright.  But the data of the case under‐determine which fixed point is correct; either act can be supported.  Since CDT supplies no criterion for choosing between equilibria, this reply sacrifices guidance.

4.2 The “stop deliberating” reply  
Perhaps rationality permits halting the oscillation at an arbitrary moment.  But then the chosen act is knowingly non-ratifiable, and the agent can foresee that resuming even a second’s further reflection would overturn her choice.  That is not a stable ideal of rational decision.

4.3 The “it’s merely psychological” reply  
Finally, one might say deliberation dynamics are outside the purview of decision theory, whose job is only to give static choice recommendations.  The trouble is that in DiD the static recommendations themselves differ from moment to moment even though no new non-psychological information arrives.  So the dynamic instability infects the static guidance as well.

5. Policy-based CDT as a solution

An elegant repair is to change the unit of evaluation from instantaneous acts to complete policies—mappings from information states to acts.  Compute the causal expected utility of a policy π at the start of deliberation, while treating the agent’s future implementation of π as fixed for the purpose of counterfactual analysis.  The agent then chooses the policy with highest EU and follows it through.^3  In Death in Damascus two salient policies are:

π_A: “go to Aleppo no matter what.”  
π_D: “go to Damascus no matter what.”

Crucially, the probability that Death predicts Damascus is determined by which policy you in fact adopt, not by your transient credences while choosing.  If you select π_A, the well-supported prior tells you Death predicts Damascus with probability 0.6, so EU(π_A) = −40.  If you select π_D, Death predicts Damascus with probability 0.9, so EU(π_D) = −90.  Therefore the policy tableau yields a unique recommendation: adopt π_A and actually go to Aleppo.  No instability, no ratifiability failure, no Dutch book, and the causal rationale is preserved because each policy causally screens off the predictor’s act from the final city choice.

Policy-based CDT coincides with ordinary CDT in cases where predictors are absent, so the revision is conservative.  Moreover it has independent motivation from sequential decision theory (Hammond 1976) and from the Kolodny-MacFarlane semantics for “ought” (2010), both of which treat plans, not momentary choices, as the primary bearers of normative evaluation.

6. Two residual worries addressed

6.1 Isn’t policy evaluation just Evidential Decision Theory in disguise?  
No.  When computing EU(π) we still hold fixed only those features causally downstream of the policy.  We do not condition on the mere evidence that adopting π provides about predications uncaused by our act; instead we directly model how π affects the causal network.  Thus the core causal spirit survives.

6.2 Couldn’t an evidentialist also stabilise her view by evaluating policies?  
Yes, and doing so removes some classic counter-examples to EDT.  That is a virtue, not a vice.  The deeper point is that once one sees the need for policy-level evaluation, the sharp divide between CDT and EDT softens into differing causal modelling commitments rather than a contrast between act and evidence conditioning.  The Death in Damascus lesson, then, is that both camps must move to a higher level of description; but CDT faces the sharper internal pressure because only its standard, act-level formulation yields the destabilising feedback.

7. Conclusion

The dependence of CDT’s recommendations on an agent’s current act probabilities in Death in Damascus–style cases is not a harmless curiosity.  It spawns deliberative instability, ratifiability failure, Dutch bookability, and an explanatory incoherence within CDT’s own causal narrative.  The correct response is to abandon act-based evaluation in favour of policy-based or plan-based CDT.  Once that structural shift is made, the problematic dependence disappears, and CDT regains its claim to prescribe rational action in the face of sophisticated predictors.  The episode thus teaches a broader methodological lesson: decision theory must take seriously the fact that we choose not isolated behaviouristic acts but temporally extended, self-implementing strategies.

1. Introduction and Thesis  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) was originally advertised as the rational rule for agents who care only about the causal consequences of their choices.  In ordinary decision problems—buying insurance, choosing dessert—CDT performs admirably.  But in predictor cases such as Death in Damascus, the numbers CDT feeds into its expected-utility calculation must themselves be conditional on how likely the agent now takes herself to be to perform each act.  As those credences shift during the very process of deliberation, CDT’s comparative evaluation of the acts shifts with them.  The upshot is an unstable and sometimes dynamically incoherent piece of advice: at different moments in a single train of thought CDT may tell you to go to Aleppo, then to Damascus, then back again.  

My thesis is that this dependence on an agent’s current act-probabilities is a serious defect in CDT.  It undermines CDT’s capacity to guide action, violates familiar principles of dynamic rationality and ratification, and places CDT at odds with its own motivating idea that only causal pathways should matter to choice.  I argue for three connected claims: (i) CDT’s dependence on shifting act-probabilities generates “oscillation” and fails to deliver stable prescriptions; (ii) attempted CDT repairs—such as simply holding fixed initial credences, or requiring “ratifiable” choices—either collapse into evidential decision theory or re-introduce the problem in another guise; and (iii) a decision theory fit for predictor problems must evaluate whole decision policies rather than individual acts, thereby freeing expected-utility comparisons from real-time shifts in act-credences.  I conclude that the dependence in question exposes a deep flaw in CDT rather than a superficial quirk.

2. CDT, Expected Utility, and the Role of Act-Probabilities  

CDT tells an agent to compute, for each available act A, its causal expected utility:  

EU(A) = Σs P(s ∧ acts upstream of A) · U(Outcome given A & s).  

In practice, the “upstream” clause is implemented by using unconditional probabilities for states of the world not causally influenced by A.  A mundane example: whether it will hail tomorrow is (for normal agents) independent of whether I buy an umbrella.  I therefore evaluate the umbrella purchase using the unconditional probability of hail.

In predictor cases, however, the target state is not causally independent of my act.  Death’s location tomorrow is highly correlated with my choice precisely because Death is good at predicting me.  Under CDT, I must represent that correlation without allowing my present choice to be counted as a cause of Death’s location.  The standard formal device is to condition on my act-probability at the moment of choice.  

Let:  
p = Cr(now)(I will choose Damascus),  
q = Death’s reliability (say .9),  
b = Death’s prior bias toward guessing Damascus (say .6).  

CDT then computes:  

EU(Damascus) = p · (q·U(Death-meets-me) + (1–q)·U(Survival)) +  
(1–p) · (b·U(Death-meets-me) + (1–b)·U(Survival)).  

EU(Aleppo) is analogous, with p and (1–p) interchanged.

Because the utility of each act is a linear function of p, the preference ordering that CDT delivers is itself a function of p.  As I deliberate, my credence p typically drifts: when I focus on the merits of Aleppo, p falls; when my imagination turns to Damascus, p rises.  Consequently CDT’s recommendation tends to flip back and forth.  Pick a parameter range in which EU(Damascus) > EU(Aleppo) whenever p > .5 but the inequality reverses when p < .5.  Unless the agent begins with a razor-thin credence of exactly .5, any serious consideration of switching cities will place her momentarily on the other side of the threshold and reverse CDT’s advice.

3. The Oscillation Problem  

The oscillation problem is that a single, temporally extended agent has no stable “best act” according to CDT.  The moment she announces, “Very well, I will head to Aleppo,” her credence p shrinks, CDT flips, and tells her actually to go to Damascus.  When she begins to turn her camel toward Damascus, p grows, the advice flips again, and so on.  The guidance CDT supplies is like a compass needle that spins whenever one tries to read it.

Oscillation is worrisome for two familiar reasons.

3.1 Action-Guidance and Practical Rationality  

People consult a decision theory to settle what to do.  A theory whose prescription is pathologically sensitive to the immediate focus of attention cannot issue determinate advice.  That violates the pragmatic criterion of adequacy: a decision rule must at least be capable of being followed by agents who wish to be guided by it.

3.2 Dynamic Consistency  

Rationality is normally taken to require that an agent not foreseeably regret her own choice moments later, absent new evidence.  CDT in Death in Damascus makes that impossible: the very act of choosing counts as evidence (because it changes p) and forces regret before a single footstep.  Some temporal instability is tolerable—lottery buyers often regret after reflection—but CDT guarantees instability even when nothing external changes.  This is more than inconvenience; it shows that CDT violates its own slogan “choose as though you were determining the outcome.”  One cannot determine an outcome if the determination itself evaporates the instant it is made.

4. Attempts to Defend CDT  

Several lines of defense seek to contain the problem.  I examine three and argue that none succeeds.

4.1 The “Credence = 0/1” Response  

Perhaps the agent should treat her own future act as something she now determines with certainty, assigning p = 1 to Damascus if she decides on Damascus, p = 0 otherwise.  Then EU(Damascus) and EU(Aleppo) are computed using only the endpoints, removing oscillation.

This proposal fails on two counts.  First, deliberating agents are rarely certain which option they will take until the decision is sealed.  Forbidding non-extreme self-credences is psychologically unrealistic and blocks probabilistic modeling of mixed strategies.  Second, even if p snaps to 1 at the final moment, the agent still had to deliberate to reach that point.  During deliberation her credences were intermediate and CDT offered conflicting guidance.  The theory is evaluatively incomplete exactly when guidance is most needed.

4.2 Joyce’s Ratifiability Requirement  

James Joyce suggests that a rational act must be “ratifiable”: having chosen it, you should still prefer that you chose it.  Formally, an act A is ratifiable if A maximizes expected utility under the probability assignment you would have after learning that you choose A (but before learning anything causally downstream of A).  In Death in Damascus, neither pure act is ratifiable: if you condition on choosing Damascus, you prefer you had chosen Aleppo, and vice-versa.  The only ratifiable option is to randomize with exactly p = .5.  Since Death predicts imperfectly, a perfectly mixed strategy severs the predictive link and yields the highest expectation.

In one sense ratifiability patches oscillation—the mixed strategy is a fixed point.  Yet two problems remain.

First, ratifiability is an extra-theoretic constraint tacked onto CDT; it is not licensed by the causal calculus itself.  Indeed it smuggles in a form of evidential reasoning: under ratifiability we compare acts by updating on the mere fact that we perform the act, which is precisely what CDT forbade at the outset.

Second, ratifiability often issues no recommendation.  Several problems contain no ratifiable act at all (e.g., certain Drunk Drivers cases).  If CDT requires ratifiability to avoid self-defeat in predictor settings, and ratifiability is sometimes impossible, CDT cannot be an all-purpose decision rule.

4.3 Fixing Probabilities at the Outset (“Deliberation Doesn’t Matter”)  

Another line is to identify a privileged moment—the start of deliberation—at which the agent’s credences are the only ones that count.  The agent must then act according to CDT’s verdict at that moment, refusing to let subsequent shifting of p affect her choice.  Call this the “first-pass” rule.

The rule is ad hoc.  Why should time-slice t₀ have normative priority over t₁ if no new evidence has appeared?  Worse, an agent who knows she will ignore later advice has an incentive to manipulate her initial p (by focusing on Aleppo, say) to make CDT favor her preferred city.  In that respect the first-pass rule reintroduces Kelley’s moral of Newcomb’s problem: the content of one’s decision algorithm influences the payoff.  CDT’s defenders end up advising the agent to adopt an evidentially-savvy policy while continuing to insist that the correct *act-evaluation* is causal.  The conceptual tension is severe.

5. Why the Dependence is a Deep Theoretical Flaw  

The foregoing criticisms show that dependence on act-probabilities is not just an embarrassing corner case; it collides with CDT’s founding motivations.

5.1 Violation of the Causal-Only Maxim  

CDT was designed to ensure that acts are evaluated by their causal consequences alone.  Yet in Death in Damascus the very *evidential* correlation between act and outcome is imported back in via the dependency on p, making the “causal” expectation hostage to epistemic facts about what one is likely to do.  CDT cannot keep evidence out of the score while simultaneously using p to compute the score.

5.2 Incompatibility with Reflective Equilibrium  

A complete theory of rational choice should be reflectively stable: an agent knowing she is guided by that very theory should, under ordinary epistemic conditions, endorse her guidance.  CDT in predictor cases lacks that property; your awareness that CDT will change its advice if your credence shifts gives you reason to manipulate that credence or to move to a rival theory.  Indeed agents who anticipate such instability can gain by pre-committing to Evidential Decision Theory, Functional Decision Theory, or another policy-evaluating rule.  The dominance of such rival rules in predictor settings is itself evidence that CDT is not reflectively tenable.

5.3 Loss of Normative Freedom  

An under-appreciated consequence of oscillation is that it hands Death—or any sufficiently shrewd predictor—normative control over you.  Because your utilities swing with p and p is responsive to exogenous cues (rumors about where other travelers are headed, a flapping awning that primes “Damascus”), Death can influence your ultimate choice without causal pathways, merely by predicting your preference swings.  That violates the spirit of causal independence more flagrantly than Newcomb’s Predictor ever did.

6. Policy-Level Evaluation as the Remedy  

A valuable lesson emerges: the correct object of evaluation in predictor problems is not the single act performed at one moment but the decision policy that maps informative states (including the agent’s own credences) to actions.  Functional Decision Theory (FDT) and policy-based EDT both adopt this perspective: instead of asking “What should I do, *given* that I currently believe with probability p that I will do it?” they ask “Which algorithmic disposition should I implement?”  On that frame the Death in Damascus agent compares two salient policies:

Policy D: deterministically go to Damascus;  
Policy A: deterministically go to Aleppo;  
Policy M: flip a fair coin.

Because Death predicts policies rather than last-minute vacillations, Policy M dominates.  Importantly, the comparison is unaffected by the agent’s present credence about which policy she will adopt.  Hence no oscillation occurs.  The numbers depend only on exogenous features: Death’s accuracy and bias, and the utilities of survival and death.

By moving from act-probability to policy-probability, the theory avoids assigning normative significance to unstable personal credences.  The remedy underscores that the dependence problem was not an accidental flaw but a sign that CDT’s unit of evaluation is too fine-grained for predictor contexts.

7. Objections and Replies  

7.1 “Isn’t Mixed Policy Just CDT Plus Randomization?”  
Randomization indeed salvages CDT in Death in Damascus.  But CDT contains no general principle instructing agents when to randomize; the invocation of ratifiability or policy choice supplies that missing piece.  A theory that must be fixed piecemeal is inferior to one that delivers the right advice by its internal logic.

7.2 “Real Agents Can Quasi-Commit; So What?”  
Yes, travelers can resolve to go to Damascus and avoid entertaining doubts.  But the normative question remains: is that resolve *rational* according to CDT?  A theory that rescues itself only by silencing deliberation is, at best, incomplete.

7.3 “Dependence Only Appears in Predictor Cases—A Small Corner of Choice Space.”  
Predictor structures pervade real life: contract negotiations, multiplayer games, political brinkmanship, advertising.  Any situation where others form expectations about you before you act embeds the same feedback loop between credence and outcome.  A decision rule that fails in such ubiquitous contexts cannot claim general normativity.

8. Conclusion  

The dependence of CDT’s advice on the agent’s shifting act-probabilities in Death-in-Damascus-style cases is not a harmless oddity.  It robs CDT of action-guidance, violates dynamic consistency, and conflicts with the theory’s own causalist ethos.  Standard patches—forcing extreme self-credence, adding an external ratifiability constraint, or freezing probabilities at the outset—either outsource the real decision to evidential considerations or leave CDT silent in key scenarios.  The right moral is structural: rational choice under prediction requires evaluating whole decision policies, not momentary acts whose expected utilities are wired to the agent’s fluctuating self-beliefs.  That insight, codified in more recent policy-based and functional decision theories, shows that CDT’s act-probability dependence is indeed a deep problem, and one that the theory—as originally formulated—cannot solve.

1. Setting the Stage  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) has long been advertised as the “gold-standard” way for a bounded agent to turn credences and utilities into action.  In its canonical formulation (Lewis 1981; Gibbard & Harper 1978) an act A is evaluated by computing the expected utility of the causal hypothesis ‘the agent does A.’  Put formally:

EU(A) = Σw P(w│do(A)) · U(outcome of A in w),
