where P(·│do(A)) is a counterfactual (or “causal”) credence that holds fixed everything not causally downstream of the act.  What happens upstream—the state of the distant past, the roll of dice that have already been cast, a predictor’s earlier guess—is treated as outside the agent’s control.

In Death in Damascus–style cases the upstream state crucial to the outcome is the city that Death predicted you would visit.  Because the predictor is very reliable, your credence that Death predicted ‘Damascus’ is highly correlated with your present credence that you will in fact go to Damascus.  That means your estimate of EU(Damascus) and EU(Aleppo) is sensitive to your current first-order probabilities P(Damascus) and P(Aleppo).  If during deliberation those credences shift—even for purely introspective reasons—your ranking of the acts can flip back and forth.  The question is whether this volatility constitutes a genuine defect in CDT.

I shall argue that it does.  The dependence on moment-by-moment act probabilities makes CDT dynamically unstable, generates Dutch-book vulnerabilities, and clashes with the deeper rational ideal that decision guidance should be “reflection-stable.”  After presenting the mechanics of the instability (sections 2-3), I consider two prominent repairs—ratifiability and causal policy selection—and explain why neither fully rescues orthodox CDT (sections 4-5).  I end by diagnosing the root cause (section 6): CDT’s atomistic focus on single acts prevents it from responding appropriately to information embodied in the very correlations that give predictors their power.  A satisfactory decision rule must take the whole policy, not the immediate act, as the unit of evaluation.

2. The Mechanics of the Case  

Here is a stripped-down numeric version (after Arntzenius 2008).  You have two live options:

  D: spend the night in Damascus  
  A: spend the night in Aleppo  

Death predicts your choice yesterday.  If he guesses correctly, he will be waiting in that city and you die (utility 0).  If he guesses incorrectly, you survive (utility 10).  Death’s tracker is 90 % reliable but slightly biased toward saying “Damascus.”  Concretely:

  P(Death predicted D │ you go D) = .9  
  P(Death predicted D │ you go A) = .1  

Normalising on those two possibilities we get:

  P(Death predicted D) = .9·P(D) + .1·P(A).

If you perform causal conditioning ‘do(D)’, you treat Death’s earlier prediction as independent of your act.  So, in CDT language,

  P_ca(Death predicted D │ do(D)) = P(Death predicted D).  
  P_ca(Death predicted D │ do(A)) = P(Death predicted D).

Hence:

  EU(D) = (1 – P(Death predicted D))·10 + P(Death predicted D)·0  
         = 10·(1 – (.9P(D) + .1P(A))).        (1)

  EU(A) = 10·(1 – (.9P(D) + .1P(A))).        (2)

At first blush those look equal, but remember: P(D) and P(A) are not exogenous constants.  They are the probabilities you yourself assign right now to choosing each act.  As you lean toward Damascus, P(D) increases, which raises the overall chance that Death predicted D; that in turn drags down EU(D) and, via the same term, raises EU(A).  A small incremental change in self-prediction therefore tilts the balance.

Put numbers on it.  Suppose at the start of deliberation you are 60-40 in favour of Damascus (P(D)=.6).  Then Death-predicted-D has chance .9·.6 + .1·.4 = .58.  Plugging into (1-2):

  EU(D│P(D)=.6) = 10·(1 – .58) = 4.2  
  EU(A│P(D)=.6) = 4.2   (a tie).

If, prompted by symmetry, you push your credence in Damascus down to .5, Death-predicted-D becomes .9·.5 + .1·.5 = .5, so EU(A) = EU(D) = 5.  Now both acts strictly dominate the earlier expected utility, so you might keep searching for a still better blend.  Indeed, calculus shows the maximal value of (1) is reached when P(D)=1/2, yielding EU=5.  That is produced by any act mix that exactly equalises your credence.  But you are a single-shot agent: eventually you must pick D or A with probability 1.  Crossing that 50-50 knife-edge in either direction immediately drops the expected utility of the city you are now favouring, making the other city preferable.  The result is an oscillation: nudge toward Damascus → makes Aleppo look better → nudge toward Aleppo → makes Damascus look better → …

The phenomenon generalises.  Whenever (i) the payoff difference between the states depends on whether an upstream predictor aligns with your act, and (ii) your subjective probability that the predictor aligns is a continuous function of your self-view about what you’ll do, then CDT’s expected-utility ranking is a continuous function of that self-view.  Unless the payoff function happens to be flat, there will be thresholds at which the ranking flips.  Deliberation—as a process of refining credences—can then send you ping-ponging across those thresholds.

3. Why Volatility Is a Problem  

A. Dynamic Inconsistency  

The first worry is pragmatic.  Decision deliberation is meant to guide action; yet CDT supplies guidance that is “path-dependent.”  At t1 you lean Damascus and CDT declares Aleppo best, so you resolve to go Aleppo.  Resolution updates P(A) to 1, which (because Death is likelier to have predicted A when you go A) reverses the ranking, prompting a new resolution.  The loop can persist indefinitely.

Sophisticated agents avoid cycles by insisting on dynamic consistency: once an act is judged rational at a given node of deliberation, later cognitive updates that are themselves completely foreseeable should not undermine that judgment unless new empirical information arrives.  CDT violates that norm here, for nothing external changes—only the agent’s second-order belief about her forthcoming behaviour.

B. Dutch Book Vulnerability  

Instability exposes an agent to a diachronic Dutch book.  A bookmaker who can observe your real-time credences can offer a bet favouring Aleppo when you are tipped Damascus and another bet favouring Damascus when you are tipped Aleppo.  Because each bet is accepted when it looks favourable by your own lights, you enter both sides of a parlay that guarantees a sure loss (see Ahmed 2014, ch. 4).  A decision rule that makes an agent exploitable purely through predictable fluctuations in self-confidence is normatively suspect.

C. The Reflection Principle  

From a more philosophical angle, the Reflection Principle (van Fraassen 1984) urges an ideally rational agent to view her future credences as additional data: if you expect that in five minutes you will believe Q with probability r, and you have no reason to think you’ll become irrational or be epistemically corrupted, you should already assign Q probability r.  CDT’s recommendation in Death in Damascus depends precisely on whether you anticipate believing P(D)=x or P(D)=y after the next twist in deliberation.  Resisting Reflection is not impossible, but it incurs a heavy theoretical burden.

D. The Sense of Lost Agency  

Finally, agents often report a phenomenological sense that CDT’s advice in predictor cases is self-undermining: “If I could just commit to Damascus (or Aleppo) without letting that fact leak through my credences, I would be fine—but CDT won’t let me.”  That is not decisive by itself, yet it indicates a mismatch between the heuristic role decision rules are supposed to play in actual cognition and the way CDT is forced to treat self-locating uncertainty.

4. First Repair Attempt: Ratifiability  

Jeffrey (1983) proposed that a rational act must be “ratifiable”: after you condition on the fact that you are going to perform it, you should still prefer it.  Formally, A is ratifiable iff EU( A │ I_do_A ) ≥ EU( B │ I_do_A ) for every alternative B.  In Death in Damascus, neither pure Damascus nor pure Aleppo is ratifiable, because knowing you will go there raises the probability that Death predicted that city, destroying its advantage.  Mixed strategies *are* ratifiable—specifically the 50-50 lottery is.  Thus a ratifiability-augmented CDT tells you to randomise with equal probability, which yields stable expected utility 5.

Does that solve the problem?  Two objections:

  (i) Implementation.  Private randomisation devices rarely exist, and if the predictor is reliable, he will foresee any pseudo-chance generator you construct.  True 50-50 self-randomisation is therefore unavailable.

  (ii) Mis-locating the value.  Even if you could secretly flip a coin, the ratifiability criterion searches among *acts* (here, lottery tickets) and selects the one whose *execution* would survive reflection.  Yet the intuitive reason to praise the coin flip is precisely that you were already disposed to obey its outcome.  If you would ignore the coin given an unfavourable result, ratifiability collapses.  The real work is being done by a higher-order policy: “Commit to obey whatever a truly random device says.”  Focusing on the single act misses that structure.

5. Second Repair Attempt: Causal Policy Selection  

More recently, CDT’s proponents have suggested shifting the unit of evaluation from single acts to whole *policies* (Joyce 2012; Spencer & Wells 2019).  The idea is to compute the causal expected utility of adopting a rule R mapping information states to acts, then choose the rule with maximal value.  In Death in Damascus, one salient rule is ‘Always go to Aleppo,’ another is ‘Always go to Damascus,’ and a third is ‘Go where Death is less likely to predict, given my evidence.’  Because the last rule produces the 50-50 mix, it again comes out top.

This manoeuvre avoids the earlier oscillation, because your second-order credence about which policy you will adopt is typically resolved *before* you ask the policy what to do in this particular instance.  Still, the fix is less a reform of CDT than an admission that single-act assessment is inadequate.  Moreover:

  • The policy space is huge; evaluating every mapping from evidence to acts soon becomes intractable.  
  • If policies are chosen by the same CDT machinery, the theory threatens an infinite regress: you need a meta-policy for choosing among policies.  
  • Most importantly, the step from act to policy is *ad hoc* unless grounded in a principled consideration of up-stream correlations.  Why stop at policies?  Some argue (e.g., Yudkowsky 2010; Garrabrant & Demski 2018) that only “updateless” choice over world-program pairs fully captures the relevant dependencies.

6. The Deeper Diagnosis  

The root pathology is not the algebraic dependence on P(D) per se.  Rational choice should accommodate true empirical correlations between our behaviour and earlier events.  The deeper issue is that CDT, as standardly interpreted, treats those correlations as *evidentially inert*.  When you contemplate going to Damascus, you do acknowledge that your doing so would be new *evidence* about the predictor’s accuracy (Bayesians cannot ignore that).  CDT, however, forbids you from letting that evidence influence your causal expectation, because the predictor’s choice is upstream of the do-operator.  The result is a mismatch between your epistemic and your causal conditionals.  During deliberation you oscillate precisely because you are pulled by the evidential reading (which says “going D is bad news about surviving”) and pushed by the causal reading (which says “you cannot affect Death’s prior choice”).  Small changes in subjective self-location modulate the tension, creating the observed instability.

One may put the point by saying that CDT is “act-locally causal but evidence-globally impotent.”  A more adequate theory should treat correlations that are predictably triggered by the cognitive act of deciding as decision-relevant causal channels in their own right—what philosophers of science call *inference to the best intervention*.  Functional Decision Theory (FDT) and some forms of Updateless Decision Theory attempt to do exactly that: they model decisions as the outputs of a stable algorithm whose code is recognizable by predictors.  The right counterfactual asks, “What happens in worlds where this very algorithm outputs D?”  Because the algorithm’s output is, in predictor cases, part of the common cause of both your act and Death’s location, a single evaluation yields a unique, reflection-stable recommendation (‘Go where the algorithm output maximises utility under that common-cause model’—here, Aleppo given the slight bias toward Damascus prediction).  Whether that renders CDT obsolete is still debated, but it makes vivid why the dependence on act probabilities is symptomatic of a deeper fissure.

7. Conclusion  

Yes—the dependence of CDT’s recommendations on the agent’s fluctuating credence in her own act is a problem, not a harmless mathematical quirk.  It undermines dynamic consistency, invites Dutch books, violates plausible reflection principles, and signals a failure to integrate information carried by predictive correlations.  Attempts to patch the theory via ratifiability or policy-level choice either shift the problem elsewhere or tacitly adopt a richer causal model than CDT itself sanctions.  A genuine cure requires a theory that allows the causal impact of one’s decision *as information*—a theory whose counterfactuals are sensitive to the functional role of deliberation.  Whether that cure is best delivered by FDT, UDT, or some yet-unnamed successor, the lesson of Death in Damascus is clear: ignoring how your present credences about your own acts infiltrate the world’s upstream causes is not a viable long-term strategy for a decision theory.

Deliberation, Ratification, and the Shadow of One’s Own Probabilities: Why ‘Death in Damascus’ Undermines Causal Decision Theory   

1. Introduction and Thesis  
Causal Decision Theory (CDT) tells an agent to pick the act whose causal expected utility is greatest: EU(A)=∑S P(S)·U(A,S), where the probability for any state S is unconditional on A whenever S is not causally downstream of A. In ordinary problems this works smoothly because an agent’s degree of belief about non-downstream states is fixed while she deliberates. In Death-in-Damascus cases, however, the crucial “state” is which city Death will appear in, and Death’s location depends on a prediction of the very act now under deliberation. As the agent’s credence in going to Damascus versus Aleppo shifts, so do the unconditional probabilities that Death will wait in either city, which shifts the computed utilities, which in turn can shift the agent’s inclinations. A feedback loop is created: the theory’s recommendation tracks an endogenous magnitude—the agent’s present act-probabilities.  

My thesis is that this dependence is a serious problem for CDT. It undermines action-guidance (the theory can give conflicting advice at different moments of the same rational deliberation), violates a plausible “ratification” constraint on rational choice (one should not wind up preferring to have chosen differently once one’s choice is settled), and reveals that CDT’s act-relative perspective misidentifies the proper locus of causal influence in predictor cases. Various repairs—appeal to mixed-strategy equilibria, adding ratifiability as a secondary principle, or insisting that nothing is amiss—either alter CDT’s core commitments or leave it unable to endorse any determinate act. The deeper lesson is that a satisfactory decision theory must evaluate policies from a stance prior to the fixation of act-probabilities, not acts from within a moving deliberational target; CDT, as standardly formulated, cannot do this.

2. How the Agent’s Own Probabilities Enter the Calculation  
Suppose travel and every outcome short of death has zero utility; surviving the day has utility 0, dying −10. Death’s rule is: he predicts where you will go; with accuracy .9 he guesses right, otherwise wrong; and he has a mild prior bias for guessing Damascus (he flips a biased coin that lands Damascus 2/3 of the time and Aleppo 1/3 before factoring in his information about you). Let p be your current subjective probability of going to Damascus. Standard Bayesian modeling of an imperfect predictor yields:

P(Death in Damascus) = .9·p + .1·(1−p) + (bias terms)  
P(Death in Aleppo)   = .9·(1−p) + .1·p.

(To keep numbers easy we can ignore the bias or fold it into the 2/3 versus 1/3 priors.) What matters is that both probabilities are affine functions of p. Therefore the causal expected utilities are:

EU(Damascus) = (−10)·P(Death in Damascus)  
EU(Aleppo)   = (−10)·P(Death in Aleppo).

Because the multiplier −10 is common, whichever act currently looks safer is whichever currently has the lower associated probability of Death’s presence, and that inequality depends directly on p. Shift p and the recommendation can flip.

3. The Instability Exposed  
Imagine you begin in a neutral mood: p = .5. Because of Death’s bias toward predicting Damascus, P(Death in Damascus) > P(Death in Aleppo), so CDT tells you, “Aleppo is causally safer.” But the moment you start to lean toward Aleppo your own probability p of choosing Damascus drops below .5. That changes P(Death in Aleppo): as the agent approaches certainty about Aleppo, the predictor does too, so Aleppo grows more dangerous and Damascus safer. CDT’s directive therefore reverses; it now tells you to head for Damascus. But the same feedback operates again. Unless the functions intersect exactly at a fixed point (unlikely without ad hoc parameter choices), deliberation never settles. Each infinitesimal update to your act-probabilities flips the sign of the causal advantage.  

This is not mere psychological vacillation; it is vacillation mandated by the normative theory. At every moment you are acting exactly as CDT directs, yet you can foresee that obeying the directive will immediately make it irrational, and so on ad infinitum. The dependence on p robs the theory of action-guidance.

4. Why Action-Guidance Matters  
A decision theory is supposed to help situated agents decide. Its prescriptions are delivered in real time to deliberating minds whose credences about their own future acts evolve in light of those very prescriptions. If following the theory predictably leaves one without a stable recommendation, the theory cannot serve its practical function.  

One might retort that, in the limit, an ideally rational agent would reach the fixed point where EU(Damascus)=EU(Aleppo) and hence be indifferent, so CDT is not self-undermining after all. But two replies follow. First, for generic parameter values there is no fixed point inside the unit interval; the functions cross only if the predictor’s bias exactly cancels his inaccuracy. Second, even where a fixed point exists, CDT tells the agent to be in that mixed state, not to perform a particular act. A real deliberator cannot simply choose to have credence .423 that she will go to Damascus; she must choose where to go. CDT therefore issues guidance only on the higher-order question, “What mixture of dispositions should I instill in myself?”—a question the one-shot traveler cannot implement.

5. Ratification to the Rescue?  
James Joyce and others have proposed adding a “ratification” test: an act is rational only if, were the agent certain she would do it, it would still maximize causal expected utility. This blocks recommendations that depend on p, because conditionalizing on the chosen act sets p = 1 (or 0), and in Death-in-Damascus either act then fares equally badly; so both acts pass or fail together, and oscillation ceases.  

Ratification solves the instability at a cost. It supplements CDT with a new normative principle not derivable from the causal calculus itself. Once we grant that augmentation, CDT loses its supposed virtue of providing simple, complete guidance from causal probabilities alone. Furthermore, ratification often advises “paradoxical” policies like deliberately randomizing, or refraining from introspection to avoid changing one’s own p, tactics that conflict with ordinary instrumental rationality. The patch therefore looks ad hoc: it glues stability onto CDT instead of showing that CDT never needed it.

6. Mixed-Strategy Equilibria  
A second repair says: in games with predictors the rational solution is a mixed strategy at which the opponent is indifferent; the fact that CDT points toward the mixed strategy is evidence of its adequacy, not its defect. For Death in Damascus, the Nash equilibrium is the probability p* that equalizes your causal risk in each city. A CDT-guided agent will keep adjusting until she is disposed to randomize with precisely p*, then take either city according to that lottery.  

This answer underestimates two problems. First, CDT does not recommend randomizing; it evaluates each pure act separately, using the current p as a parameter. The dynamics that lead toward the equilibrium lie outside the theory’s official prescription and rely on the informal psychology of the deliberator. Second, even if we build randomization into the option set, a one-person decision problem is not a two-person game. You are not trying to outsmart an adversary whose beliefs are held fixed while you mix; the predictor’s beliefs co-vary with yours. The mixed-strategy idea therefore imports game-theoretic machinery that sits uneasily beside CDT’s act-relative causal evaluation.

7. Is Dependence Really a Defect?  
A stalwart causal decision theorist might defend the status quo: “Of course my probabilities about Death’s location should change as my probabilities about going to Damascus change; that’s just honest Bayesianism. A correct decision theory must allow its inputs to be updated, even if that means real-time guidance is hard.” The reply is that there is a difference between (a) updating on new evidence about the external world, and (b) updating on nothing more than one’s shifting hunch about which act one will pick—hunches caused by the very calculation underway. Rational reflection should not be hostage to such self-made ‘evidence.’ The dependence violates what Richard Jeffrey dubbed the Principle of Reflection: one should not expect future probabilities, reached by sound reasoning alone, to differ systematically from current ones. Yet CDT encourages the agent to treat her own tentative inclinations as evidence about an external threat, which is epistemically perverse.

8. The Deeper Diagnosis: Wrong Locus of Causal Analysis  
Why does CDT stumble here? Because it evaluates acts in isolation from the policies or decision functions that generate them. Your choice of city is linked via the predictor to Death’s choice; the causal significance is not act→Death, but algorithm-that-produces-act→Death. CDT, focused on the skinny arrow from act to non-downstream states, misses that broader dependency. As a result it has to treat your transient subjective probability of Damascus as an independent variable, when in fact that probability is just the behavioral shadow of your underlying decision procedure.  

Updateless Decision Theory (Yudkowsky), Functional Decision Theory (Spohn, Joyce’s later work), and other “policy-selection” approaches remedy the problem by evaluating whole algorithms from the ex-ante stance prior to any self-locating update. From that vantage the predictor’s behavior is downstream of “whatever algorithm I am about to run,” not of the particular city chosen. Because the algorithm is causally upstream of both the city and Death’s prediction, the theory gives stable advice: pick whichever algorithm yields the best joint outcome across correlated worlds. In Death in Damascus, no algorithm can save you; every city choice is followed by Death. But at least the theory does not send you oscillating—it solemnly informs you that life expectancy is the same either way, so toss a coin if you must; nothing hangs on it.

9. Objections and Replies  
Objection 1: “CDT’s oscillation is purely theoretical. Real agents are psychologically limited; they will stop at the first preference and act. So no action-guidance is lost.”  
Reply: A decision theory aimed only at agents with arbitrary stopping rules forfeits its claim to normative authority. It is supposed to guide ideally rational deliberation, not exploit cognitive fatigue.

Objection 2: “Adding ratifiability is no ad hoc patch; it is latent in CDT’s spirit.”  
Reply: Ratifiability changes CDT’s evaluative target. Original CDT asks which act, given present unconditional probabilities, has the highest causal expected utility. Ratifiability says: ask that question under a hypothetical certainty of performing the act. That is a different function from the original one; supplying it shows that the old function was insufficient.

Objection 3: “Predictor cases are artificial. CDT works in real life.”  
Reply: Thought experiments are designed to stress-test principles. The same feedback arises in economic contexts where markets predict policy moves, in psychological contexts with accurate self-prediction, and in strategic settings with learning algorithms. A theory that fails in stylized cases offers no guarantee it will succeed when life approximates the same structure.

10. Consequences for the Axioms of CDT  
The dependence on p conflicts with two plausible structural norms for decision theory.  

a) Action-Guidance. A normatively adequate theory must give a stable recommendation for agents who deliberate by its lights. CDT does not.  

b) Ratification. One should not settle on an act then wish, by the theory’s own standards, that one had chosen differently. CDT’s dependence on p violates this because once p finally hits 1 (when you step toward Damascus) EU(Damascus) instantly falls below EU(Aleppo), and you judge your chosen act sub-optimal.  

Any decision principle that predictably condemns its adherents the moment they act is normatively self-defeating.

11. Broader Implications: Newcomb, Medical Newcomb, and Counterfactual Parasitism  
The Death-in-Damascus pathology generalizes. In Newcomb’s Problem, your credence that the opaque box is full depends on your credence that you will one-box, so CDT again yields deliberation-dependent utilities. In Smoking Lesion and Medical Newcomb variants, your credence about having the lesion shifts as you ponder whether to smoke. The same instability lurks whenever an evidential correlation runs through the agent’s own decision rule. The result strengthens the case for theories that treat such correlations as causally relevant at the policy level rather than evidential noise at the act level.

12. A Better Principle: Evaluate Policies Ex Ante  
Replace act-relative causal evaluation with policy-relative evaluation from an ex-ante perspective that precedes self-locating updates. Compute EU not of the act given current p, but of adopting decision procedure Π, integrating over the predictor’s response to Π. On that view your probability of Damascus is not an input; it is an output of Π and so does not vary independently inside the calculation. Stability is restored because the calculation no longer chases its own tail.

13. Concluding Verdict  
Yes—the dependence of CDT’s recommendations on the agent’s present act-probabilities is a profound problem. It strips the theory of action-guidance, violates the ratification requirement, and arises from CDT’s mislocation of causal dependence in predictor problems. Attempts to rescue CDT either change the theory (ratification), smuggle in external dynamics (mixed strategies), or accept indeterminacy. A deeper fix evaluates policies ex ante, as updateless or functional decision theories do. Until CDT is revised along those lines, Death-in-Damascus shows that its foundational prescription—maximize causal expected utility using unconditional probabilities—cannot be the last word on rational choice.

Deciding under uncertainty is supposed to be hard for the usual reasons—limited information about the world, computational limits, the sheer complexity of human values.  What should not, on the face of it, be difficult is determining which option is better once one has already fixed all of the non-causal facts relevant to a decision problem.  Causal Decision Theory (CDT) purports to do exactly that: for each act A, take the possible world-states S that are not causally downstream of A, weight the utility of the A-and-S conjunction by the unconditional probability of S, and pick the act with highest expected utility.  Yet in “Death in Damascus”-style stories a puzzling thing happens.  Which act CDT recommends—flee to Aleppo or hole up in Damascus—depends on your current, still-in-flux subjective probability that you will perform that very act.  When you start to lean toward Aleppo, CDT says “actually, given that tendency, Damascus comes out better.”  When you pull back toward Damascus, the same calculation flips and urges Aleppo.  The recommendation is fragile, buffeted about by the tiniest perturbations in credence that accompany ordinary deliberation.

Is that fragility a problem for CDT?  I shall argue that it is, but not simply because it feels weird.  Two deeper defects are exposed.  

1.  First, the dependence on act probabilities makes CDT dynamically unstable: a fully reflective agent can find no stable point at which her deliberation ends.  
2.  Second, the phenomenon reveals that CDT is sensitive to purely epistemic facts about what one is about to do, even though it claims to ignore such facts by focusing on the agent’s causal power.  Far from “screening off” non-causal correlations, CDT smuggles them in through the back door of act probabilities.  

Once those objections are laid bare, we can see why several proposed repairs—adopting ratification constraints, prohibiting self-locating updates during choice, or insisting on mixed strategies—fail to remove the underlying pathology.  What ultimately emerges is the need either to replace CDT with a decision rule that evaluates *policies* rather than momentary acts (for example Functional Decision Theory or Updateless Decision Theory) or, more modestly, to recognise that CDT must be supplemented by an independent principle ensuring *deliberative stability*.  The “Death in Damascus” case thus functions as a diagnostic probe: it shows that CDT’s standard recipe is missing a crucial ingredient.

I.  Setting up the puzzle

Suppose you have two options, go to Aleppo (A) or go to Damascus (D).  You know the figure of Death has a crystal ball whose predictions are right 90 % of the time.  Death also has a slight bias: if he is unsure he is more likely to guess Damascus.  If Death finds you, you die (utility −1000).  If you escape, you live (utility +1000).  There is no other intrinsic value in either city.  

Let p be your current unconditional subjective probability that you will go to Aleppo.  Since the options are exhaustive, probability of going to Damascus is 1 − p.  Because Death’s prediction accuracy is 0.9 and his bias favours Damascus, we can describe the relevant non-causally downstream states like this:

S1: Death predicted Aleppo.
S2: Death predicted Damascus.

Given p, Bayesian conditioning says  
P(S1) = 0.9 p + 0.1 (1 − p) = 0.1 + 0.8 p  
P(S2) = 1 − P(S1) = 0.9 − 0.8 p

The expected utilities, computed *causally* (i.e. we treat Death’s prediction as not downstream of your act) come out as

EU(A) = P(S1) · (−1000) + P(S2) · (+1000)  
EU(D) = P(S2) · (−1000) + P(S1) · (+1000)

Subtracting yields

EU(A) − EU(D) = 2000 · (P(S2) − P(S1))  
       = 2000 · ((0.9 − 0.8 p) − (0.1 + 0.8 p))  
       = 2000 · (0.8 − 1.6 p)

So CDT recommends Aleppo when p < 0.5 and Damascus when p > 0.5; it is indifferent when p = 0.5.  A rational deliberator who initially finds both cities equally salient (say p = 0.5) is pushed toward either extreme by the tiniest nudge.  If she momentarily imagines herself in Aleppo, her p dips below 0.5, CDT blares “Aleppo is safer!”, and p slides further downward.  The very same reasoning, starting with a momentary tilt toward Damascus, yields a runaway slide the other direction.  

What matters is that CDT’s advice at time t depends on the agent’s credence at t about what she will do, rather than on objective causal features of the world.  In a live deliberation those credences are in continual flux.  The result is an acausal feedback loop.

II.  Dynamic instability as a normative flaw

Why is that feedback loop a *problem* rather than an amusing quirk?  Consider the minimal requirements on a decision procedure:

A.  Convergence:  deliberation should (barring computational limits) settle on an act rather than oscillate indefinitely.  
B.  Self-endorsement:  at the moment of acting, the agent should not believe that some alternative, had it been chosen, would have had higher expected utility *in the same epistemic state*.  

CDT in “Death in Damascus” can violate both.  There is no guarantee of convergence because any small update in p flips the ranking.  More crucially, whichever city the agent eventually chooses (perhaps by an arbitrary tie-breaker), she is guaranteed to believe that, *given that very belief state*, the other act would have scored higher if only she had planned to perform it.  That is a violation of self-endorsement—sometimes called *instrumental instability*.

One might object that this is merely a psychological fact about deliberation, not a normative failure of CDT.  Normative theories aren’t required to guarantee our messy Bayesian brains will cleanly converge.  They only dictate what counts as rational given fully settled credences.  Yet the instability here *cannot* be swept away by positing some hypothetical “all-things-considered” credence distribution that magically stays fixed while we calculate utilities.  The *very act of calculation* provides new information: it reveals to us that we are leaning one way rather than another, and that information is relevant because Death is a predictor.  CDT, as classically formulated, provides no instructions about whether to treat that self-locating information as evidence.  In Newcomb cases, CDT insists that the content of the opaque box is not downstream of your act.  But here the predictor’s location *is* correlated with what act you are coming to perform.  CDT happily uses that correlation (via P(S1) and P(S2)) even though nothing causal flows from your present credence to the long-ago prediction.  The alleged pedigree of CDT—that it respects causal independence—is, in this context, unmasked as an illusion.

III.  The epistemic back-door

Notice how the dependence enters.  CDT tells you to compute P(S) unconditionally with respect to acts.  But conditioning on *acts* is not the same as conditioning on *credences about acts*.  Unfortunately the two collapse in Death-style problems because your credence that you will go to Aleppo is highly correlated with the truth of S1.  The predictor takes your own dispositions as evidence; you in turn take that correlation into account, and the vicious circle is complete.

What CDT should have insisted is: only causes licensed by the underlying causal graph may be used when updating probabilities.  Your momentary credence that you are leaning Aleppo-ward is *a downstream effect* of the world in which the predictor guessed Aleppo.  So, strictly, you should omit that piece of evidence when calculating the unconditional P(S).  In other words, CDT’s prescription secretly needs an epistemic qualifier: compute expectations in an epistemic state stripped of knowledge about how you are presently leaning.  But once that caveat is introduced, CDT ceases to be a simple mechanical rule.  It tells agents to ignore information that they in fact have, for reasons that cannot be reconstructed from the causal graph alone.  That is, again, a fatal flaw: the theory either issues an impossible demand (“before choosing, you must not know which way you are disposed to choose”) or self-contradictory advice (“given what you in fact believe, you should act on numbers derived from a hypothetical state in which you believed something else”).

IV.  Inadequate repairs

1.  Ratification (Jeffrey 1983).  Richard Jeffrey proposed that a rational act must be such that, were one to learn that one were performing it, one would still endorse it.  That condition blocks non-ratifiable options whose desirability depends on not knowing that one chooses them.  In Death in Damascus both Aleppo-conditional and Damascus-conditional prefer the other city, so neither act is ratifiable; a mixed „50-50 coin flip” is the lone ratifiable strategy.  Ratification therefore predicts indifference between pure acts and a slight preference for randomisation.

But two problems arise.  First, ratification merely punts the instability to a higher level: why suppose the randomisation device is not itself correlated with Death’s prediction?  If a flicker of thought about „tails means Aleppo” shifts your credence enough, the same oscillation re-appears.  Second, the ratification move is ad hoc.  It was introduced precisely to rescue CDT from such paradoxes; yet it sits uneasily with CDT’s causal motivation.  What causal reason have we to reject an act simply because knowing about it would change our mind?  Ratification imports an evidential concern (how your knowledge of choosing A would itself be evidence) into a theory that officially renounces such concerns.

2.  Commit to mixed strategies ex ante.  Some decision theorists say: „death predictors are less accurate when the agent uses genuine randomisation; therefore the uniquely rational response is 50-50.”  That proposal does yield convergence.  However, CDT does not compel it.  Expected utility maximisation over *acts*—not over probability distributions of acts—identifies mixed strategies only indirectly, by way of tie-breaking.  If an agent begins with p = 0.51, CDT unambiguously recommends Damascus; there is no instruction to search for a mixed strategy unless indifference is reached.  Hence the instability remains.

3.  Freeze act-probabilities during calculation.  You might declare a rule: „Fix your current p; compute EU’s; then act accordingly; do not, while calculating, allow p to drift.”  This dogma-level rule amounts to saying that deliberation must be *opaque to itself*.  That runs counter to the ideal of transparency in ideal rationality models, and it is at odds with CDT’s guiding rationale that rational agents should use *all* and only causally relevant information they possess.  Imposing deliberative opacity looks, again, like a patch rather than a principled extension.

V.  Toward policy selection

The deeper moral is that evaluating single-stage acts in isolation is too coarse-grained when predictors, simulations, or dependable correlations are in play.  What one really needs is to evaluate *algorithms* or *policies*—functional descriptions that fix the mapping from epistemic states to actions.  Functional Decision Theory (FDT) and Updateless Decision Theory (UDT) both proceed in that spirit.  Ask: „Which input-output map, if I were committed to it, would have the highest expected utility given the objective correlations in the world?”  In Death in Damascus, the policy „always go to Aleppo” and the policy „always go to Damascus” each screens off self-locating information, so their expected utilities can be stably computed; the better of the two (here, Aleppo) wins.  A policy-based approach thus regains both convergence and self-endorsement without invoking evidential considerations or forbidding introspection.

One might concede that policy selection works but insist it is an *add-on* rather than a replacement for CDT.  However, once policies are admitted, the original CDT prescription for single acts becomes inessential.  All work is done by the higher-level evaluation, which explicitly incorporates correlations that CDT mishandles.  The upshot is that CDT is either redundant or incorrect: redundant if bolted onto policy evaluation, incorrect if left alone.

VI.  Objections and replies

Objection 1:  „The instability arises only in contrived predictor stories.  Ordinary life contains no such entities, so CDT’s practical adequacy is untouched.”  
Reply:  Even in mundane settings our choices are predicted by other agents, market algorithms, or parts of our own brain we do not introspect.  Any reliable correlation between how one leans and outcomes can generate a milder version of the same instability.  If a negotiation opponent tends to anticipate your concessions, your deliberation may slide analogously.  The theoretical defect is therefore general.

Objection 2:  „What violates self-endorsement here is not CDT but Bayesianism: beliefs cannot be perfectly self-transparent.  A sophisticated agent maintains a ‚credal partition’ distinguishing object-level from deliberative facts.”  
Reply:  Distinguishing first-order from higher-order belief is helpful, but CDT needs instructions about which level to use in its expectation calculation.  Without that guidance CDT is under-determined.  Adding ad hoc instructions about ignoring or discounting certain higher-order beliefs merely reiterates my point that CDT as standardly formulated is incomplete.

Objection 3:  „Instability is rational; real agents frequently *should* be torn.  There is no guarantee that rational deliberation converges.”  
Reply:  Being torn is compatible with convergence failure, but normative theories traditionally require at least *conditional* prescriptions: “Given these credences, do A.”  CDT gives mutually inconsistent prescriptions as credences evolve in a perfectly ordinary, Bayesian-admissible way.  That is incoherence, not healthy ambivalence.

VII.  Distinguishing the causal, the evidential, and the deliberational

The above discussion suggests a three-way distinction that CDT conflates:

1.  Causal independence:  variable X is not downstream of act A in the objective causal graph.  
2.  Evidential independence:  learning that A will occur gives no information about X.  
3.  Deliberational independence:  the ongoing process by which one decides whether to do A is uncorrelated with X.

CDT officially cares only about (1); in practice it needs both (2) and (3) to hold or else the expected-utility calculation goes awry.  „Death in Damascus” is engineered so that (1) holds but (2) and (3) fail.  The dependence on act probabilities smuggles (3) back in.  Recognising this tri-partite structure is itself illuminating: once we allow that rational choice must be sensitive to deliberational dependencies, we realise that causal independence is not the full story.  Policies, not isolated acts, are the proper locus of evaluation because a policy can be deliberationally independent even when its constituent acts are not.

VIII.  Conclusion

Yes—the dependence of CDT’s recommendations on the agent’s shifting act-probabilities is a genuine problem.  It reveals that CDT:

(a) lacks a mechanism ensuring dynamic stability and self-endorsement;  
(b) covertly relies on evidential correlations it professes to avoid;  
(c) cannot, without ad hoc fixes, tell an agent how to bracket self-knowledge acquired during deliberation.

The best diagnosis is that CDT’s focus on one-shot acts is too fine-grained when reliable predictors are involved.  A satisfactory decision theory must evaluate policies or algorithms, thereby respecting both causal structure and deliberative self-knowledge.  Until CDT is revised along those lines—or replaced by a theory like Functional Decision Theory—it remains vulnerable to “Death in Damascus” and its many real-world cousins.

1. Introduction and Thesis

At first glance, the Death in Damascus story looks like a curiosity about omniscient grim reapers. Under the microscope, however, it exposes an unheralded structural feature of Causal Decision Theory (CDT): the value it assigns an act is a function of the agent’s own credence that she will perform that very act. Because those credences can and typically do shift during deliberation, CDT’s advice can oscillate in real time. My thesis is that this “self-reference” is not merely odd but normatively disabling. An adequate decision theory must satisfy two guidance requirements:

A. Deliberation invariance: once one has evaluated the options using the theory, further reflection should not predictably change what the theory itself recommends, on pain of paralyzing regress.

B. Choice autonomy: the theory should not make the rational permissibility of an act hinge on stochastic facts about how likely I currently think I am to do it, for those facts are not among the worldly features for which a rational agent should be penalized or rewarded.

Because CDT violates both conditions in Death-style cases, its dependence on act probabilities is indeed a serious problem. I defend that verdict in five steps. First, I reconstruct CDT’s mechanics and show exactly how the dependence arises (§2). Second, I demonstrate how it engineers instability and time-inconsistency (§3). Third, I rebut three prominent defences: (i) “fixed-point” solutions, (ii) the claim that the pathology is merely epistemic, and (iii) the suggestion that ratifiability repairs the theory (§4). Fourth, I locate the deeper lesson: by tethering value to one’s own intensional states, CDT mistakes deliberative evidence for causal information (§5). Fifth, I sketch what a correct successor theory would look like (§6). I conclude that the problem is substantive and forces a revision of CDT’s core recipe.

2. How CDT’s Self-Referential Valuations Arise

CDT tells us to pick the act with highest causal expected utility (CEU):

CEU(A) = Σs P(s |∅) · U(outcome of A in s),

where the sum ranges over states s that are not causally downstream of A; P is the agent’s unconditional credence distribution prior to choosing.

In ordinary problems—say, choosing chocolate or vanilla—my prior credence that I will choose chocolate does not appear in CEU(Chocolate) because “I choose chocolate” is downstream of the act and hence excluded from the states s. Death in Damascus is special because the predictor’s location of Death is determined by his prediction about where I shall be, and that prediction is formed before I act. Therefore, whether Death awaits in Damascus is not causally downstream of my eventual choice. It is fixed by the predictor’s prior belief about that eventual choice. Consequently:

CEU(Damascus) = P(Death in Damascus) · (-∞) + P(Death in Aleppo) · (0),
CEU(Aleppo)   = P(Death in Aleppo) · (-∞) + P(Death in Damascus) · (0).

Suppose I initially regard my probability of going to Damascus as p. If I know the predictor is 90 % reliable and has a built-in bias of 10 % toward guessing Damascus, standard Bayesian conditioning yields:

P(Death in Damascus) = 0.9p + 0.1(1-p) = 0.1 + 0.8p,
P(Death in Aleppo)   = 0.9(1-p) + 0.1p = 0.9 - 0.8p.

Plugging these into the CEUs, one obtains:

CEU(Damascus) ∝ –(0.1 + 0.8p),
CEU(Aleppo)   ∝ –(0.9 – 0.8p).

The ordering depends on p: if p < 0.5 CDT says “Damascus,” if p > 0.5 it says “Aleppo,” and if p = 0.5 it is indifferent. In deliberation I typically have no settled prior about what I’ll do; small evidential tremors shift p, which flips the recommendation, which in turn alters p, and so on. This is the dependence that fuels the instability.

3. Instability, Time-Inconsistency, and Paralysis

Imagine an agent, Elena, who begins torn: p = 0.5. She flips a mental coin and leans 51 % Damascus. Given that p now exceeds 0.5, CDT says “Aleppo!” Elena updates, so p = 0.49. CDT reverses: “Damascus!” Iterating produces an infinite sequence of switches with decreasing amplitudes that never settle at a decision.* Elena is rational by CDT’s own lights at each micro-stage, yet overall she is paralysed.

Two deeper pathologies follow.

3.1 Dynamic Dutch Books  
A bookie who can bet quickly during deliberation can institute a sequence of fair bets that, at each moment, Elena regards as expectation-neutral, yet which jointly guarantee her a loss. The genealogy of the loss traces to CDT’s non-invariant valuations: what was fair at t is unfavourable at t+1. This violates a minimal coherence norm.

3.2 Preference Reversal  
Suppose Elena somehow commits to Aleppo when her credence had inched above 0.5. After commitment she recognises—indeed she predicts—that once the ticket is bought, her credence she will go to Aleppo will hit 1, pushing P(Death in Aleppo) to 0.9 and making Aleppo far worse by her lights than Damascus would then have been. She knowingly locks herself into an option she expects to regret. CDT thereby counsels a plan that is time-inconsistent by its own standards.

A decision rule that systematically generates such cycles and preference reversals cannot serve as a practical guide.

4. Three Defences and Why They Fail

4.1 The Fixed-Point Gambit  
Skyrms (1990) suggests that rational deliberation must land on a fixed-point: a credence function P* and act A* such that A* maximises CEU relative to P* and P*(A*) = 1. Elena’s unsteady coin flips violate the rationality constraint; she should instead search for a fixed-point and move there directly. In Death in Damascus the only fixed-points are (Damascus, p=0) and (Aleppo, p=1): act with certainty. But these points are unreachable unless the agent can deterministically force herself, and CDT offers no argument why rationality requires that. Worse, which fixed-point is selected turns on arbitrary tremors in initial p; CDT becomes hostage to epistemic accidents. A theory of rational choice should not tell agents to make luck-based leaps.

4.2 “It’s Merely Epistemic”  
Another reply concedes instability but claims it is confined to belief, not to action: an agent may toggle credences yet still be free to choose either city. This is mistaken. As we saw, CEU slides linearly with p; each change in belief flips the ranking of acts. So the instability infects the normative verdict itself, not just the epistemic inputs.

4.3 Ratifiability to the Rescue?  
Jeffrey and later Arntzenius propose adding a ratifiability constraint: an act is rational only if, after learning that one is going to do it, one would still endorse it. Formally, choose A only if CEU(A | “I do A”) ≥ CEU(B | “I do A”) for all B. In Death in Damascus, however, no act is ratifiable. Conditional on “I go to Damascus,” the predictor’s accuracy fractions make death there highly probable, rendering Damascus irrational. Conditional on “I go to Aleppo,” mutatis mutandis. The ratifiability fix thus delivers an “empty set” of rational options, which does not guide choice. Even if modified to pick the least unratifiable act, the proposal again lets stochastic facts about my current credence dictate the choice. The ailment remains.

5. The Deeper Diagnosis: Mistaking Deliberative Evidence for Causal Relevance

Why does CDT stumble here but not in garden-variety cases? Because it misplaces the evidential role of one’s own decision process. That I am currently 0.6 confident I will go to Damascus is indeed excellent evidence about Death’s location, but it is not a causal feature of the world that rational choice should aim to affect. A normative theory should treat self-locating facts about deliberation the way it treats mood fluctuations or background music: as irrelevant to the objective ranking of plans.

CDT’s conditional exclusion of downstream states was supposed to enforce that irrelevance. Yet the Death case sneaks my credence back in because the predictor has used it as input. The root problem is that CDT bluntly divides the world into “causal descendants” and “everything else” irrespective of how the information about the latter is generated. When information is reflexively connected to my decision process, the partition collapses.

6. Toward a Remedy: Deliberation-Proof Decision Theory

A correct successor should satisfy:

(i) Deliberation invariance: changes in purely deliberative credences must not by themselves flip rankings.

(ii) Temporal coherence: acts chosen now remain best in ex ante and ex post perspectives.

Several proposals advance in that direction.

6.1 Evidential Decision Theory (EDT)  
EDT evaluates acts by conditionalizing on the act itself: EU(A) = Σs P(s | A)U(outcome). EDT decouples value from prior act probabilities; “I do A” is treated as certain. In Death in Damascus, EDT straightforwardly prefers Damascus because conditional on going to Damascus death is less likely (the predictor favours guessing it anyway). Critics worry about smoking lesion-type cases, but those involve genuine causal independence, unlike the reflexive link here.

6.2 Functional Decision Theory / Updateless CDT  
Newer approaches (Yudkowsky & Soares) advise agents to maximise expected utility from the perspective of the algorithm they implement, prior to learning the outcome of internal randomness. Because the algorithm’s code is fixed, its probability of outputting A is either 1 (deterministic) or defined by exogenous randomizers; internal vacillation is irrelevant. The theory therefore avoids the underspecification to which CDT succumbs.

6.3 Two-Level Theories  
A minimal repair keeps CDT at the execution level but requires agents to pre-commit, before introspecting about their own likelihoods, to whichever mixed strategy globally maximises expected value. In Death in Damascus that is the 50/50 mix: it equalises Death’s predictive edge and yields survival probability 0.5, strictly better than either pure act’s 0.1 or 0.9 death probability. Such two-level views preserve causal reasoning about exogenous states while filtering out self-referential noise.

Whether one endorses EDT, functionalism, or a two-level CDT, the moral is uniform: normatively relevant probabilities must be insulated from the very deliberation whose products they are meant to guide.

7. Objections and Replies

Objection 1: “But my act probability p is a genuine causal influence—it shapes Death’s prediction algorithmically.”  
Reply: The locus of control matters. Through deliberation I can alter p, but only by altering my choice. If the theory already tells me which choice to make, the extra dependence on how confident I feel adds no new lever; it only sows instability.

Objection 2: “If CDT is flawed here, so is any theory that uses prior beliefs. Vacillation is inevitable.”  
Reply: The argument targets a very specific feedback loop: the evaluation functional itself contains p. EDT and functional theories depend on posterior beliefs conditional on the act, or on algorithmic facts independent of p, so their valuations are constant across deliberation.

Objection 3: “Pragmatically, real agents settle; Elena’s psychology would converge to one side.”  
Reply: First, as the fixed-point analysis showed, where she settles is arbitrary, hence CDT violates symmetry. Second, rational norms apply counterfactually; if following a decision rule predictably yields cycles in idealised conditions, the rule is defective regardless of messy human limitations.

8. Conclusion

The dependence of CDT’s recommendations on the agent’s shifting act probabilities is more than a quirk; it undermines CDT’s claim to be a guide for rational choice. Because the dependence breeds deliberative instability, time-inconsistency, and susceptibility to Dutch books, CDT violates core criteria of guidance and autonomy. Attempts to rescue CDT by appeal to fixed-points, epistemic modesty, or ratifiability either fail or collapse into rival theories that insulate valuations from deliberative self-reference. The upshot is that decision theorists must either abandon the causal–evidential divide in its current form or enrich CDT with a layer that neutralises self-generated evidence. Death in Damascus is therefore lethal not merely to wanderers but to orthodox CDT itself.

Death, Deliberation, and Causal Decision Theory  
                                                   -------------------------------------------------

1. The Set-up

Causal Decision Theory (CDT), as originally formulated by Gibbard & Harper and by Lewis, tells an agent to evaluate each available act A by its expected utility

      EU(A) = Σs P(s | ⟨causal parents of A⟩) · U(A, s),

where the probability is unconditional on A itself (or on any event causally downstream of A).  In ordinary cases—buying a train ticket, lifting one’s arm—this delivers exactly the advice even commonsense deliberators would give themselves: perform the act whose causal consequences you antecedently expect to be best.

“Death in Damascus” (due to Bryson Brown, after a medieval fable) is not an ordinary case:

•  You must decide whether to spend the night in Damascus or in Aleppo.  
•  A supernatural entity “Death” predicted earlier today which city you will choose; he is highly reliable (say 90 %).  
•  Death goes to the city he predicted; if you arrive there too, you die.  Otherwise you survive unscathed.  
•  You also know Death has a mild bias toward expecting people to stay in Damascus: when he is unsure, he guesses Damascus.

Because Death’s prediction is (imperfectly) **correlated** with your act but not causally **influenced** by it—his prediction is already made—this is precisely the sort of case that pulls CDT and its rival, Evidential Decision Theory (EDT), apart.  And here a peculiar feature of standard CDT arises: the expected utility of each act depends on the agent’s *current credence* that she will perform it.  As that credence changes during deliberation, CDT’s recommendation flips back and forth.  The question is whether that dependence constitutes a *defect* in CDT or is merely a harmless reflection of the agent’s changing information.

2. Why EU(Damascus) and EU(Aleppo) Depend on q = P(Go-to-Damascus)

Let q be your present subjective probability of going to Damascus, given everything you know *except* your final, not-yet-chosen act.  Let r be Death’s reliability (0.9) and b (>½) measure his built-in tendency to guess Damascus when uncertain.  A simple model:

      P(Death predicted ‘Damascus’)   =  r·q + (1-r)·b,
      P(Death predicted ‘Aleppo’)     =  r·(1-q) + (1-r)·(1-b).

If you now *actually* go to Damascus, you die exactly when Death predicted ‘Damascus’.  Thus

      EU(Damascus) = (–1) · P(Death predicted ‘Damascus’) + 0 · P(Death predicted ‘Aleppo’) 
                   = –[r·q + (1-r)·b].

Analogously,

      EU(Aleppo) = –[r·(1-q) + (1-r)·(1-b)].

What matters is the **difference**

      Δ(q) = EU(Aleppo) – EU(Damascus)
           = –r(1-q) – (1-r)(1-b)  – [ –r·q – (1-r)b ]
           = r·(2q – 1) + (1-r)(2b – 1).

Suppose r = 0.9 and b = 0.6.  Then

      Δ(q) = 0.9(2q – 1) + 0.1(0.2) = 1.8q – 0.9 + 0.02 = 1.8q – 0.88.

•  If q < 0.488…, Δ < 0, so EU(Aleppo) < EU(Damascus): CDT recommends Damascus.  
•  If q > 0.488…, EU(Aleppo) > EU(Damascus): CDT recommends Aleppo.

Thus the dividing point is roughly “If you are more than 49 % confident you’ll end up in Damascus, go to Aleppo; otherwise, go to Damascus.”  If, like most deliberators, you *begin* neutrally inclined (q ≈ ½), you will form a slight preference for Aleppo.  But the moment you resolve to book a ticket north, q plunges below 0.49 and the preference reverses: now Damascus looks safer.  Switch back, and the calculus flips again.  CDT appears to generate an *oscillating recommendation* with no stable answer.

3. CDT’s Oscillation as a Philosophical Problem

To see why many philosophers take this to be a genuine flaw in CDT, consider what we reasonably expect from a theory of rational choice.

(1) Guidance.  A decision theory should deliver *actionable* advice.  A prescription that changes merely because I begin to act on it defeats the point.

(2) Deliberative stability.  It ought not be self-undermining.  An agent who follows it should not be forced into endless vacillation or into launching a random generator just to settle the matter.

(3) Insensitivity to epiphenomenal shifts.  As I lean mentally toward Aleppo, nothing in the causal structure of the world shifts—Death has already departed.  A theory whose recommendation flips solely because of my *leaning* seems to mistake evidential for causal relevance.

CDT’s dependence on q clashes with all three desiderata.  For the Death case the only fixed points are the extremes q = 0 and q = 1 (certain you’ll go to one city).  But if you could stably settle there, CDT would immediately tell you to do the opposite!  That is *deliberational incoherence*.

4. Can a Causal Decision Theorist Dismiss the Problem?

Four main lines of defence have been offered.

4.1  “Treat q As Epistemic, Not Psychological.”

Joyce and Arntzenius emphasise that q is supposed to be the agent’s *objective* unconditional credence, not a fickle psychological state.  It is fixed by background frequencies, by the known reliability r and bias b, and by broad facts about agents like you.  Your moment-to-moment “feeling” that you are leaning Aleppo-ward should not be inserted into the calculation.  Taken this way, q is unaffected by the micro-shifts of deliberation, so CDT gives a single verdict (here, probably Damascus because of Death’s bias).

Objection:  In many Newcomb-style or psychologised prediction cases the very *point* is that the agent knows she is an excellent predictor of herself.  If her introspective evidence that she is now 70 % disposed to choose Aleppo is not part of the probability calculus, CDT is ignoring information the agent in fact possesses.  Worse, CDT would outlaw *any* updating on one’s own emerging intentions, banishing a perfectly ordinary form of self-knowledge.

4.2  Ratifiability Constraints

Jeffrey and later Skyrms propose that a rational act must be *ratifiable*: it must maximise expected utility conditional on the agent’s knowledge that she will choose it.  Mathematically, one seeks a fixed point q* where the act chosen at q* is the act assumed in computing q*.  In the above numbers, the only ratifiable act is staying in Damascus, because assuming you choose Damascus (q = 1) makes Damascus ≥ Aleppo, while assuming Aleppo (q = 0) makes Damascus > Aleppo.  So CDT + ratifiability singles out Damascus and is *stable*.

Objection:  The ratifiable act can be strictly dominated in ex ante value.  The agent effectively reasons: “Because I anticipate choosing Damascus, that elevates the probability that Death is there; therefore Damascus has the higher EU; so I choose Damascus.”  Yet if by some miracle she ended up in Aleppo, she would survive with 90 % chance!  Many philosophers regard ratifiability as a patch that *sacrifices correctness for stability*.

4.3  Mixed Strategies

Perhaps the rational solution is to choose probabilistically: flip a coin weighted so as to *equalise* the expected utility of both pure acts, thereby making the predictor no better than chance.  In the toy model the optimal mix turns out to be exactly the unstable q ≈ 0.488.  But CDT was formulated for acts, not for *mixtures* of acts, and anyway the predictor is assumed to be better than random at reading even one’s subtle biases.  If mixing is physically implemented (hesitations, micro-tremors) the predictor will detect those too.

4.4  “One-Shot Policy Selection”

Miri’s “functional decision theory” and Yudkowsky’s “updateless CDT” recommend: ignore the actual introspective probability; instead choose the *policy* that would have had highest expected utility *before* Death made his prediction.  Back then it was still open whether you’d be predicted Damascus or Aleppo, so the policy “go where Death predicts I won’t be” had no way to break the correlation; symmetric policies tie.  The best full policy, given the bias b, is Damascus.  Yet this feels like resigning yourself to the predictor rather than *outsmarting* him.

5. Why the Dependence Really Is a Defect

I submit that the above defences leave CDT with a dilemma: either

(a) keep the original CDT calculus, permitting q to vary with deliberation, and lose deliberative stability; or  
(b) hold q fixed by decree (ratifiability, policy selection), at the cost of throwing away live information, endorsing dominated acts, and undermining the “causal” rationale for ignoring downstream facts in the first place.

The root of the trouble is that CDT’s prescription is *sensitive to correlations it recognises but treats as epistemic side-effects rather than as themselves decision-relevant*.  In Newcomb’s Problem this makes CDT two-box even though one-boxing systematically yields more money.  In Death in Damascus the same feature causes the whiplash: the agent keeps looking for a point where her *causal* influence is exerted, but there is none to be had; everything informative about Death’s location is evidential.  Because CDT insists on subtracting evidential impact from the calculation, the residual causal structure becomes *over-sensitive* to minuscule changes in the agent’s credence about her own act.

A principled decision theory should ground recommendations in determinants that are:

•  (i) stably knowable by the agent at the moment of choice, and  
•  (ii) not themselves outputs of the very deliberation they are supposed to guide.

CDT fails test (ii) in prediction cases.  The probability q is *generated* by that deliberation.  Basing advice on it is like advising a person walking toward a cliff to *lean whichever way she is currently least leaning*.  No stable leaning exists; the advice destroys its own basis.

6. The Broader Moral

CDT was designed for environments where acts have clear-cut downstream consequences and correlations without causation can safely be ignored.  Once we populate the world with accurate predictors, simulators, or agents deploying the same deterministic algorithm as ourselves, that design breaks down.  In such worlds our acts are “subjunctively entangled” with states that are not downstream yet are nevertheless *dependent* on our decision output—in the logical or mathematical sense that both are fixed by a common explanatory factor (our decision procedure).  CDT, tied to a purely *causal* dependence notion, cannot see this.

Hence the very feature queried—the EU’s dependence on act probabilities—*is* a diagnostic symptom: it betrays that CDT lacks the conceptual resources to handle logical dependence.  Attempts to mask the symptom (ratifiability, policy precedents) either capitulate to dominated outcomes or smuggle in evidential ingredients under another name.  A cleaner fix would be to replace CDT with a theory that evaluates acts or policies in light of *all dependences an ideal predictor would exploit*, causal or otherwise.  Functional Decision Theory and the growing literature on “logical decision theories” are precisely such attempts.

7. Conclusion

Yes, CDT’s dependence on the agent’s shifting act probabilities is a problem, not a superficial quirk.  It undermines the theory’s ability to give stable guidance, forces ad hoc patches, and ultimately exposes a deeper conceptual gap: a blindness to non-causal forms of dependence that matter in a world of predictors.  If we take Death in Damascus-type scenarios as legitimate tests of rational choice, the reasonable verdict is that classical CDT, unmodified, is inadequate.

Thesis.  In Death-in-Damascus–type cases Causal Decision Theory’s output turns on the very probabilities that the agent is in the act of determining.  That reflexivity makes the theory dynamically unstable: as one’s credence that one will go to Damascus rises, the expected utility of going to Aleppo rises, which in turn lowers one’s credence that one will go to Damascus, which in turn …  The deliberative loop need not converge, and even when it does the recommended act can flip merely because the agent becomes more self-confident.  A decision rule that yields such path-dependent and potentially indeterminate advice is defective in two ways.  First, it violates a plausible procedural norm—Deliberation Shouldn’t Undermine Decision—according to which a theory ought to deliver stable guidance across the course of ordinary reflection.  Second, it disconnects choice from the factors that actually matter causally to outcomes, thereby failing CDT’s own guiding insight.  Hence the dependence on current act probabilities is not a harmless bookkeeping quirk; it reveals an internal inconsistency that motivates either a revision of CDT’s machinery (e.g. through ratification‐style or policy-level reformulations) or its replacement by a different decision theory.

––––––––––
1.  Setting the stage: CDT and unconditional probabilities
––––––––––

According to standard CDT, an act A is to be evaluated by
EU(A) =  Σs  P(s) · U(A, s)
where the sum ranges over states s not causally downstream of A, P(s) is the agent’s unconditional credence in s, and U(A, s) is the utility that would result were A performed in s.  In most everyday situations the probabilities P(s) are exogenous to the present choice; whether I order tea or coffee does not alter the chance that tomorrow will be rainy.  But in Death in Damascus (and in Newcomb, Mechanical Blackmail, Psychological Twin Prisoner’s Dilemma, etc.) the state description “Death is in Damascus” is correlated with my act because Death is a predictor.  Importantly, CDT instructs us to evaluate using *unconditional* probabilities: we do *not* condition on the act; that would collapse CDT into Evidential Decision Theory (EDT).  Instead we hold fixed whatever probabilities of Death’s location we entered deliberation with.

This is where trouble starts.  Let

p := P(Go-to-Damascus).
q := P(Death predicts Damascus | background evidence).

Because Death is a reliable but imperfect predictor, q is close to p but not identical.  Let the utilities be:
• If I meet Death, utility = –1,000,000.
• If I avoid Death, utility = +0.

Suppose also that for aesthetic reasons I have a small preference ε > 0 for Damascus over Aleppo if Death is elsewhere.  Then the causal expected utility of Damascus is:

EU(Damascus) =  (1 – q)(ε)  +  q(–1,000,000),

and likewise for Aleppo with p replacing q.  Observe: EU(Damascus) is a decreasing function of q, and q tracks p, so EU(Damascus) is indirectly a decreasing function of *p*, my present credence that I will go to Damascus.  The more confident I become that I will go to Damascus, the worse the causal value of doing so becomes.

––––––––––
2.  The path-dependence phenomenon
––––––––––

Take an initial situation in which p = 0.6.  Because Death tends to guess Damascus, q = 0.65.  Then EU(Damascus) ≈ 0.35ε – 650,000, while EU(Aleppo) ≈ 0.65ε – 350,000.  Aleppo dominates.  On hearing this, a reflective agent lowers p; after all, she is now resolved to go to Aleppo.  Suppose p → 0.1.  That drags q down to, say, 0.15.  Now

EU(Damascus) ≈ 0.85ε – 150,000,
EU(Aleppo) ≈ 0.15ε – 850,000.

Damascus dominates.  But once the agent resolves on Damascus, p creeps back up, and the cycle can repeat.  CDT’s prescription therefore oscillates with the agent’s evolving self-beliefs.  In the limit we may find a fixed point p* at which both acts tie, but:

a) Convergence is not guaranteed.  
b) The limit, if it exists, can depend on arbitrary features of the deliberative path (how quickly p is updated, in what order considerations are entertained, etc.).  
c) Even if one settles on, say, p* = 0.5, it is hard to interpret “act-probability equilibrium” as a recommendation the agent can compliantly implement.  Nothing prevents a last-minute surge of confidence that pushes her off the knife edge again.

These facts show not merely that CDT can give shifting advice, but that its advice is *constitutively* entangled with a variable—credence in one’s own act—that the theory supplies no principled way of setting.

––––––––––
3.  Why procedural instability matters
––––––––––

One might respond: “Real agents eventually plump for something; why care if CDT twitches along the way?”  The answer is that a decision theory is supposed to *guide* deliberation.  A prescription that is itself hostage to how sure the agent already is about following it cannot play that guiding role.  Put differently, the theory violates the norm:

(DSD) Deliberation Shouldn’t Defeat: Merely engaging in rational reflection under the theory should not predictably cause the theory to withdraw or invert its recommendation.

The dependence on p ensures such self-subversion.  Compare: if a GPS updated its route in response to every mile you *consider* driving, you would never leave the driveway.

Dynamic instability also undermines learning.  Ordinarily an agent can gather new empirical data to refine P(s) without fearing that the very process of incorporating the data will alter which act maximises expected utility.  With act-probability dependence, by contrast, any fresh bit of introspection into one’s likely choice is “new data” that scrambles the ranking of acts.  The result is a form of preference reversibility reminiscent of money-pump scenarios.

Finally, CDT’s selling point is its focus on *causal* control.  But the causal features of the world—where Death is—do not in fact vary with my fleeting credence that I will go to Damascus.  When the theory says they do (because it uses unconditional probabilities that themselves shift with p), it mislocates the boundary between agent and environment that its own philosophy insists upon.

––––––––––
4.  Diagnosing the root of the problem
––––––––––

Two ingredients generate the feedback loop:

i) The instruction to use *unconditional* probabilities;  
ii) The fact that those unconditional probabilities are not independent of the act when the environment contains good predictors.

Item (ii) is not an exotic thought-experiment quirk; in a world awash with behavioural data and machine-learning predictors, our acts are routinely forecast.  So blaming (ii) is unpromising.  That leaves (i).

But (i) is what differentiates CDT from EDT.  Once we allow conditioning on the act, the theory collapses into evidentialism and endorses one-box in Newcomb, which causalists wish to avoid.  We seem stuck: keep (i) and we face reflexive instability; drop (i) and we abandon causalism.

––––––––––
5.  Proposed repairs and why they struggle
––––––––––

5.1 Ratificationism.  Jeffrey and others propose that a rational act must “ratify itself”: it must be such that, having chosen it, the agent would approve of having done so.  Formally, we look for an act A such that A maximises expected utility *under the new unconditional probabilities* one would have after firmly intending A.  Ratification replaces the unstable fixed-point in p with a more robust fixed-point in intentions.  Unfortunately, in Death in Damascus the ratification process tends to select *both* acts or *neither*.  If intending Damascus raises P(Death in Damascus), the act may fail to ratify; likewise for Aleppo.  Oscillation is curbed only at the cost of indeterminacy.

5.2 Policy selection.  Joyce and others suggest evaluating *entire policies*—mappings from observations to actions—by their causal expected utility.  Because the policy is chosen at the outset, the probability of its being implemented is 1, removing dependence on fragile interim credences.  In the Damascus story, a simple constant policy “always go to Aleppo” beats “always go to Damascus”, and the agent sticks to it.  This mitigates instability but at a price.  CDT was attractive partly because it respects the intuition that rational guidance should be available to agents who cannot pre-commit to policies (they may lack time or self-binding mechanisms).  Moreover, even policy CDT inherits a milder reflexivity: the value of a policy depends on the agent’s credence in adopting that very policy, rekindling the original problem at a higher level unless the theory imposes an external equilibrium-selection rule.

5.3 Stable causation approaches.  Spencer & Wells-Jensen (2020) propose that in predictor cases we should omit from the dependency graph edges that run from act to predictor’s belief *through the channel of prediction*, because the latter is not under the agent’s causal control *at the moment of choice*.  On that view, Death’s location is screened off from my act by earlier common causes; hence P(Death in Damascus) is exogenous after all, breaking the feedback.  Critics reply that this manoeuvre undercuts CDT’s canonical verdict in Newcomb: if Omega’s prediction is similarly not causally downstream, CDT should one-box, clashing with its traditional stance.

None of these repairs enjoys wide acceptance, suggesting that the dependence on act probabilities signals a deeper tension inside CDT.

––––––––––
6.  Objections and replies
––––––––––

Objection 1: “Any decision theory that cares about expected utility must consult act probabilities; CDT is not special.”  
Reply:  The charge is half-true: probabilities enter through the expectation operator.  What is distinctive to CDT is that the *same* expectation guides both the evaluation and, reflexively, the determination of those probabilities.  In contrast, EDT uses conditionalisation to sever the loop: an agent can regard P(Death in Damascus | Go-to-Damascus) as fixed while deciding whether to go.  Thus the instability is markedly more acute for CDT.

Objection 2: “Real agents can anchor p at an arbitrary value (e.g. 0.5) and decide from there.”  
Reply:  Arbitrary anchors are normatively unmotivated.  They amount to saying, “Choose according to CDT but first pick a number out of a hat that may well determine the outcome.”  A decision theory that needs a supplement of that kind is incomplete.

Objection 3: “The oscillation illustrates merely that rational agents face *indeterminate* choice; nothing irrational about that.”  
Reply:  Indeterminacy is tolerable only if the theory tells us what actions are “permissible” within it.  CDT pretends to be maximizing—*the* act with greatest expected utility—so handing us a non-singleton choice set is effectively an admission of failure to rank acts.  Furthermore, in Damascus both options cannot be jointly permissible; one leads, in expectation, to hundreds of thousands more deaths.

––––––––––
7.  Lessons for decision theory
––––––––––

We can draw four morals.

Lesson A.  A viable causal decision rule must insulate causal expectations from self-referential probability shifts—or else supply a principled equilibrium concept.  This is partly what motivates Functional Decision Theory (FDT) and derivatives: by evaluating the consequences of *the algorithm’s output* rather than the physical act, FDT achieves stable fixed-points in predictor scenarios.

Lesson B.  The Death-in-Damascus instability reveals that “expected utility maximization” is a two-place relation: it relates actions to probability measures.  A decision theory that leaves the measure unconstrained in predictor-enriched environments underspecifies its own choice function.

Lesson C.  Any defence of CDT must, at the least, augment it with a deliberation protocol—a rule for how act-probability credences should evolve in light of the theory’s advice.  Without that, CDT is a set of local gradients without an integral: no path-independent notion of best act.

Lesson D.  The thought-experiment undermines a rhetorical advantage CDT often claims against EDT, namely that only EDT is “irresponsibly introspective”.  In fact, CDT’s prescriptions are even more sensitive to the agent’s self-expectations.

––––––––––
8.  Conclusion
––––––––––

Dependence on current act probabilities is not a peripheral curiosity for Causal Decision Theory; it is a structural flaw.  It prevents CDT from giving determinate, stable guidance when the world contains reliable predictors correlated with our choices.  That instability violates procedural norms of rational deliberation and compromises CDT’s causal explanatory ambitions.  Attempts to patch the theory either abandon core causalism, re-import evidential reasoning under another label, or rely on ad hoc equilibrium selection rules.
