The upshot is that the Death-in-Damascus case, far from being a nuisance anomaly, exposes an internal tension that any adequate successor to CDT must resolve.

1. Introduction and Thesis

Imagine an agent—call her Leonora—who gives up a long-planned holiday because a stranger’s urgent medical expenses exhaust her disposable income. Leonora feels no special sympathy for the stranger and knows nothing of his personal story. What moves her is simply the recognition that, all things considered, the morally right thing to do is to divert the money. Many philosophers say that Leonora’s action, though right, lacks full moral worth. Because she acts from a de dicto desire “to do the morally right thing,” rather than from a concrete concern for the stranger’s welfare, they diagnose her as a moral fetishist, someone whose gaze is fixed on an abstract object—Rightness—as if it were a trinket. In their view, truly praiseworthy agents must be motivated by the very considerations that make an act right (the stranger’s need, his suffering, etc.), not by morality in the abstract.

I will argue, contra this widespread suspicion, that acting solely from the motive of duty can in principle suffice for moral worth. The key is to see that a de dicto desire to do the right thing, when it is the product of a suitably informed and competently exercised moral agency, already embodies appreciation for the concrete right-making features—even when those features are not what directly move the agent. Praiseworthiness does not require that the right-making considerations act as first-order motives; it requires that the agent’s deliberative structure exhibit (i) norm‐sensitive competence and (ii) a regard for morality that is itself properly grounded. When those conditions are met, the charge of fetishism loses its bite.

2. Mapping the Dialectic: De Dicto vs. De Re Motivation

We should begin by sharpening a distinction that has sometimes been left blurry. Suppose an act is right because it will relieve a child’s pain.

De re moral motive: The agent is moved by the child’s pain (or by sympathy, or benevolence).

De dicto moral motive: The agent is moved by the fact that relieving the child’s pain is morally required; she desires, in general, to do “the morally right thing,” and that desire explains her action.

Critics such as Stocker, Wolf, and Railton contend that agents who act from the de dicto motive display alienation. They fail to value what morality is “really about”—human flourishing, relationships, etc.—and so their psychology is morally deficient even if their actions align with duty.

Defenders, especially in the Kantian tradition, respond that a de dicto motive expresses respect for persons as such and is the only motive that guarantees reliability across contexts. But even many contemporary Kantians hedge: they allow that, in the best case, the motive of duty will be accompanied by appropriate sympathies and attachments. The question before us, however, is whether the duty motive alone can ever suffice.

3. An Initial Intuition in Favor of Sufficiency

Consider three types of morally right acts:

A. Cases where the right-making features are transparent and affectively potent (helping a crying child).

B. Cases where they are transparent but leave one cold (helping a disliked colleague).

C. Cases where they are opaque, complicated, or epistemically remote (paying fair taxes, refusing to engage in insider trading because “it’s wrong”).

Our intuitions about moral worth shift across these categories. B and especially C suggest that upright action often requires the abstract motive of duty, because the relevant concrete considerations either fail to engage sympathy or are not fully grasped. If agents in those contexts lacked a de dicto motive, moral performance would be fragile—left hostage to happenstance sentiment or incomplete knowledge.

4. The Structure of a Competent De Dicto Motive

For a de dicto desire to suffice, it must function within a larger competence that tracks moral reasons. That competence has two components.

4.1. Epistemic Competence

The agent must have reliable methods for ascertaining what morality requires. Leonora consulted trustworthy moral principles; she was not merely guessing. If she happened to do the right act for the wrong reasons (e.g., because she believed a horoscope that “morality favors generosity today”), she would lack moral worth. Thus praiseworthiness demands that the de dicto motive hook up to genuine right-makers via a reliable belief-forming process.

4.2. Rational-Evaluative Competence

The agent treats the requirement that p as sufficient reason to φ. That is, she has internalized the norm “If morality requires φ-ing, then φ.” This reveals a second-order evaluative stance: she values conformity to moral reasons as such. Importantly, that stance is itself grounded. She respects the moral law not as a fetishized object but because she judges that persons have equal dignity, that suffering counts morally, that promises are binding, etc. Those are precisely the concrete considerations critics worry about, and they are present—but at the justificatory, not the motivational, level.

5. Why the Alienation Charge Misses the Mark

5.1. Misunderstanding the Place of Appreciative Understanding

Critics mistake the phenomenology of moral action for its evaluative standing. True, someone who helps a child while feeling nothing might seem aloof. But moral worth is not a matter of warm feelings; it is a matter of being guided by the right reasons. If Leonora acts because morality requires helping, and her recognition of that requirement is grounded in an appreciation (at some level) of the child’s claims, then she is not alienated. Her concern travels through a de dicto filter but remains keyed to the child’s need.

5.2. The Respect Form of Valuing

Kant distinguished two modes of valuing persons: affective attachment (Liebe) and respect (Achtung). Respect is not a sentimental orientation; it is a principled acknowledgment of another’s authority as a source of reasons. Acting from duty exemplifies respect. Critics who demand affect mistake one legitimate mode of moral valuing for the only one.

6. The Charge of Moral Fetishism Reconsidered

The fetish analogy suggests an irrational fixation. But a de dicto motive need not be an inert, contentless preference for “rightness.” It is better understood as a regulative commitment: “I shall act only on reasons that survive moral scrutiny.” That commitment is instrumentally valuable (it secures reliability) and intrinsically valuable (it expresses one’s identity as a responsible agent). Nothing fetishistic in that.

To underscore the difference, compare:

Fetishist Freddy: “I thrill at the thought of Rightness. I want my ledger of acts to glitter with a metaphysical shine.”

Principled Priya: “I am committed to acting as morality demands, because I recognize others as bearers of claims on me.”

Both utter “I want to do what’s right.” Only Freddy’s attitude is fetishistic; Priya’s reveals respect.

7. Two Illustrative Examples

7.1. The Cataract Surgeon

In a crowded clinic, Dr. Sato restores sight via assembly-line cataract surgeries. She does not dwell on each patient’s story; time pressures preclude it. What fuels her relentless precision is a professional vow: to do what morality and medicine jointly require. Surely her conduct is morally worthy—indeed more reliable than if she required a surge of compassion for each patient.

7.2. The Dispassionate Rescuer

Lee dives into icy water to save a drowning stranger. He feels no warmth; he is terrified and numb. Still, a lifetime commitment to do his duty propels him. Retrospectively we praise Lee, not despite the absence of emotional concern but because, in that fraught moment, the abstract motive successfully overrode fear.

In both cases, de dicto motivation secures right action under conditions where affect, sympathy, or situational salience might falter.

8. Replying to Three Objections

8.1. The “Understanding” Objection

Objection: One cannot be credited for doing what’s right unless one understands why it’s right. De dicto agents lack that understanding; hence no credit.

Reply: Moral worth requires enough understanding to recognize the act as right on adequate grounds, not the kind of rich, affect-laden grasp critics presuppose. Dr. Sato understands that blindness is bad and restoring sight is required; she need not savor each patient’s narrative.

8.2. The “Coldness” Objection

Objection: Actions done from duty alone feel cold and are therefore less admirable.

Reply: (i) Evaluative standards are not identical with affective reactions, and (ii) our admiration often grows when someone acts rightly without affective help—when they overcome indifference or fear. We especially praise those whose moral commitment is strenuous.

8.3. The “Misidentification” Objection

Objection: A de dicto motive might latch onto the wrong acts if the agent’s moral theory is mistaken, undermining reliability.

Reply: True; but the requirement I stipulated—epistemic competence—screens off this worry. Where the agent’s methods are defective, moral worth fails. That is as it should be. The sufficiency claim is conditional on competent moral agency, not blind legalism.

9. A Positive Account of Praiseworthiness from Duty

Pulling the pieces together, dutiful action is praiseworthy when the following conditions obtain:

1. Rightness Condition: The act is in fact morally right.

2. Motivational Condition: The agent’s primary motive is a de dicto desire to do what is right.

3. Competence Condition: The agent has and exercises reliable capacities for identifying what is right— sensitivity to evidence, careful deliberation, openness to correction.

4. Valuational Condition: The agent’s de dicto desire is itself grounded in an appreciation, at the justificatory level, of the values that make right acts right (welfare, autonomy, etc.).

Under those conditions, the agent’s psychology manifests the two hallmarks of moral worth:

a. Reason-Responsiveness: She acts because of the right reasons (Condition 3).

b. Normative Identity: The act expresses her commitment to be governed by morality (Condition 4).

These hallmarks capture why we praise: they reveal a reliable, non-accidental responsiveness to what matters and an endorsement of morality’s authority.

10. Comparative Advantages over the De Re Requirement

10.1. Robustness Across Contexts

Empirical evidence on situationism shows that sympathy is finely tuned to salience and proximity. A robust de dicto motive supplies continuity: it motivates paying distant taxes, condemning casual racism, and protecting abstract rights that stir little feeling.

10.2. Moral Learning and Reform

Historically, moral progress (e.g., abolitionism) required agents to override entrenched sentiments. Those who relied on intuitions of sympathy often failed to grasp the injustice of pervasive practices. What mattered was a principled commitment to do what is right even when society’s feelings went the other way.

10.3. Impartiality

De re motives easily become partial: my sympathy attaches to those who look like me. A de dicto duty motive imposes impartial discipline.

11. Synthesis with Virtue Ethics

One might worry that my view sidelines virtues. Not so. Virtues are stable dispositions to respond well to reasons. The duty motive, under the competence and valuational conditions, is itself a virtue: practical conscientiousness. It partners with compassion and friendship but can stand on its own as a source of moral worth.

12. Limits of Sufficiency

I do not claim that de dicto motivation is always best. Rich moral agency often involves multiple strands—sympathy, special concern, aesthetic sensitivity. Nor do I deny that habitual reliance on duty alone can make personal relationships brittle. My claim is conditional: when concrete motives are absent, the duty motive can still ground full moral worth.

13. Conclusion

The suspicion of moral fetishism rests on a conflation. It mistakes the surface phenomenology of acting from duty—an affectively austere appearance—for inner alienation from moral values. Yet a properly structured de dicto motive already contains de re appreciation at the justificatory level and, crucially, manifests respect for persons as autonomous sources of reasons. When coupled with epistemic and rational competence, it tracks right-making features reliably and impartially. In such cases, acting from duty alone is not second-best; it is morally admirable in its own right. Leonora, Dr. Sato, and Lee deserve our praise not despite but because their conscientious commitment steered them where sympathy or inclination might not. Their actions reveal the deep moral virtue of principled agency—a virtue without which the fabric of our moral lives would fray.

1. Introduction and Thesis  

Can sheer dutifulness—acting from the de dicto desire “to do what is morally right”—suffice for moral worth? I shall argue that it can. More exactly:

Thesis: A de dicto motive of duty is sufficient for moral worth provided the agent’s desire to do what is right is (i) informed by a minimally accurate grasp of what rightness consists in, (ii) sensitive to the full range of concrete right-making considerations, and (iii) stably integrated into the agent’s practical agency. When these conditions obtain, acting “just because it is right” is praiseworthy not in spite of, but precisely because of, its abstract character: it manifests a second-order commitment to being guided by the normative authority of moral reasons as such.  

In defending this thesis I proceed as follows. Section 2 distinguishes three kinds of motivation and specifies what I mean by “acting solely from duty.” Section 3 reconstructs the two main objections—that a de dicto motive is (A) morally fetishistic (Smith) and (B) alienating or cold (Stocker, Wolf). Section 4 offers a positive account of why dutiful action can be worthy. Section 5 answers the fetishism and alienation charges. Section 6 clarifies the limits of the thesis: when sheer dutifulness fails. Section 7 closes by situating the view between Kantian and sentimentalist extremes.

2. Clarifying the Terrain  

2.1 De dicto, de re, and de se motivation  
• De re: I want, of Anna, that her welfare be advanced.  
• De se: I want, of myself, that I keep my promises.  
• De dicto: I want, of whatever acts are morally right, that I do them.  

The critics target the third. They admit it may often accompany de re concern (e.g., love of Anna), but claim that when it is the sole occurrent motive it cannot ground genuine moral worth.

2.2 “Solely from duty”  
“Solely” is ambiguous. I stipulate: the agent’s direct motivating desire is de dicto—no de re concern is occurrent at the moment of action—though she may harbor standing de re sentiments in the background. Among available motives, the de dicto one is causally sufficient.

2.3 Moral worth  
I use the term in the Kantian sense: an action has moral worth when it is praise-worthy in the specifically moral dimension—i.e., it exemplifies responsiveness to moral reasons. This need not coincide with maximal praiseworthiness all-things-considered.

3. The Objections Reconstructed  

A. Fetishism (Michael Smith). To desire rightness as such is compared to desiring a stamp’s being rare merely because it is rare: the agent fixates on a formal property and is blind to the substantive values (others’ welfare, fairness, etc.) that make acts right.

B. Alienation and Coldness (Michael Stocker, Susan Wolf). Morality aims at the flourishing of persons, love, fellowship. An agent who saves a friend “because it is right,” rather than out of friendship, seems estranged from the friend and displays a morally impoverished character.

Both objections share a core assumption: that a genuinely virtuous agent must respond to the concrete right-making considerations themselves, not to their abstract summary label.

4. A Positive Account of Dutiful Worth  

4.1 Second-order normative commitment  
What the critics overlook is the distinctive value of a second-order commitment to be guided by whatever reasons are, in fact, decisive. The de dicto desire “to do what is right” is not a contentless fetish; it encodes the higher-order judgment: “Whatever the balance of moral reasons requires, I shall do.” Such a disposition has three virtues.

(a) Reliability under moral uncertainty. De re motives—sympathy for Anna, love of art, aversion to suffering—are partial and can mislead. The second-order desire functions as a corrective compass when first-order sympathies conflict or are silent.

(b) Corrigibility. Because the de dicto motive is anchored in the property of rightness, it builds in an openness to revising one’s plans when new moral information arrives. It is explanatorily sensitive to the very features critics accuse it of ignoring.

(c) Integrity and impartiality. It integrates the agent’s practical identity around the authority of moral reasons, forestalling akrasia and biased selectivity.

4.2 An epistemic analogy  
Consider the epistemic virtue of loving truth. A scientist who cares “above all to believe whatever is true” manifests a second-order concern structurally analogous to caring “above all to do what is right.” We do not call her truth-fetishistic even if, in a given case, her proximate impetus to double-check an experiment is the abstract desire not to err rather than a meaningful personal attachment to those particular data points.

4.3 The contentfulness of rightness  
Rightness is not an empty label; it supervenes on concrete reason-giving features—welfare, fairness, autonomy, etc. A desire for rightness is therefore, via rational connections, a desire responsive to those features. If I want to drink water, I thereby want to drink H2O even if I do not occurrently represent it as H2O. Analogously, wanting “whatever is right” is wanting acts with the property that (say) they advance welfare and respect autonomy—even if I do not occurrently focus on each ground individually.

5. Answering the Objections  

5.1 Against fetishism  
Smith’s charge succeeds only if the agent treats rightness as a brute, inexplicable allure. But a duty-motivated agent typically sees rightness as authoritative because she endorses the normative reasons making the act right. Her psychological focus is second-order (“be guided by the decisive reasons”), not fetishistic first-order (“rightness, whatever that is, fascinates me”). The fetish case is possible, but not prototypical.

Example. Disaster triage. A medic with limited time may not have the emotional bandwidth to feel individual sympathy for each victim. Acting “because it is right to prioritize those likeliest to survive” is hardly fetishistic—it is a rational de dicto orientation that efficiently tracks the morally relevant factors (expected benefit, consent, etc.) without drowning in paralyzing sentiment.

5.2 Against alienation  
A friend saved “because it is right” may still feel genuinely valued. The right-making facts—her welfare, the promise I made—are the very facts constituting rightness in this context. My de dicto motive takes them up implicitly, even if I do not dwell on them verbally. Moreover, the coldness complaint conflates motivation at the moment of action with overall character. A person whose occurrent motive is duty can, over a lifespan, cultivate rich sympathetic bonds; in emergency contexts, duty simply becomes the motivational “fail-safe.”

Compare: I may attend a tedious departmental meeting out of duty to my colleagues. In doing so I manifest respect for them, not alienation from them. The same structure scales to higher-stakes morality.

5.3 Why not always replace duty with de re motives?  
Because practical life is messy. First-order sentiments are selective, fatigue-prone, and context-dependent. An agent who acts “just because it is right” exhibits a valuable kind of reliability and impartiality—especially where sentiment falters.

6. When Dutifulness Fails: Boundary Conditions  

The thesis is not that any desire to do the right is praiseworthy. Three failure modes matter.

F1. Normative incompetence. If one’s conception of rightness is grossly mistaken (e.g., a zealot’s racist code), the de dicto motive yields wrongful acts. Moral worth is absent.

F2. Formalism devoid of uptake. Suppose the agent treats rightness as a linguistic placeholder without tracking its grounds. She would not revise her plans in light of new reasons. This is genuine fetishism and lacks worth.

F3. Fragility. If the de dicto desire is situational—evoked only when convenient—it does not constitute a stable commitment and so confers at most minimal praise.

Thus my sufficiency claim is conditional: given reasonable moral competence, genuine uptake, and stability, sheer duty is enough.

7. Relation to Kant and to Sentimentalism  

Kant famously held that only the motive of duty confers moral worth. I accept his sufficiency claim but not his necessity claim. Love, sympathy, and care can also ground worthy action if they reliably track the moral reasons. Where I part company with many sentimentalists is in denying that concrete affect is always needed. A complete moral psychology will be pluralistic: sometimes love motivates, sometimes duty takes the helm, and often both cooperate.

8. Conclusion  

Acting “solely from duty” need not be fetishistic or alienating. When an agent’s abstract commitment to rightness is (i) epistemically informed, (ii) reason-responsive, and (iii) stably integrated, her action manifests a higher-order virtue: fidelity to the authority of moral reasons as such. That fidelity is itself a morally admirable trait, underwriting the praiseworthiness of sheer dutifulness.
