Duty without details?—How a purely de dicto motive can still ground moral worth

1. Orientation and thesis

Suppose Hannah helps a stranger only because she has formed the bare intention “do what morality requires.” She is not moved by sympathy, delight at the stranger’s flourishing, or horror at his prospective suffering. Philosophers from Hume to Susan Wolf have worried that such a “duty-first” agent displays “moral fetishism,” valuing morality as an abstract object rather than the concrete persons and goods that make moral demands weighty. I will argue, however, that a de dicto desire to do what is morally right can by itself suffice for moral worth. What makes such action praiseworthy is the agent’s successful exercise of a distinctive second-personal capacity: the capacity to treat the moral standpoint as supreme for the guidance of her will. When that capacity is competently exercised—accurately, reliably and out of self-legislated commitment—the agent manifests respect for persons (including herself) as free and equal rational beings. That manifestation, not the presence of any particular first-order sympathy, is what merits praise.

The argument unfolds in six steps:

(1) Clarifying the disputed contrast: de dicto vs. de re motives.  
(2) The charge of “moral fetishism” and why it appears worrying.  
(3) A Kantian reconstruction of moral worth: formal authority and autonomy.  
(4) Three sufficiency conditions for morally worthy dutiful action: epistemic, volitional, and structural.  
(5) Replies to four prominent objections: alienation, motivational impoverishment, insensitivity, and redundancy.  
(6) Why the sufficiency thesis matters: reliability, moral progress, and the division of moral labor.

2. De dicto vs. de re: carving the target correctly

Following Mark Schroeder, let us call a desire de re when its content is a particular state of affairs (that Anna’s headache stop); call it de dicto when its content is a proposition of the form “that whatever is morally right be done.” The dispute is not about whether agents should believe that the concrete right-making reasons obtain—that is obviously required—but whether their motivating desire must itself take those reasons as its content.

The critics’ “fetish” charge therefore targets not mere acceptance of moral reasons, but a motivational architecture in which the formal property of rightness, detached from any of its grounds, does the heavy lifting. My question is whether that architecture, by itself, can ground praiseworthiness.

3. Diagnosing the fetish worry

Two strands lie behind the charge:

(a) Phenomenological: A morally ideal agent, we are told, cares about children, beauty, justice, not the trophy of “rightness.” Solely de dicto motivation seems cold. Hume’s complaint that duty is “the last refuge” of a depleted heart echoes here.

(b) Explanatory: Rightness supervenes on substantive facts. If one acts only for the supervenient fact, one seems to ignore what actually explains why the act is warranted. Hence, one’s action looks “off-track”: the correct conclusion is reached, yet by latching on to the wrong premise.

These worries are powerful but not decisive. Their force rests on controversial assumptions about (i) what respect for persons requires and (ii) how moral cognition sustains agency.

4. A Kantian reprise: why form can matter more than matter

Kant’s notorious claim in the Groundwork that only actions “from duty” possess “authentic moral worth” is often caricatured as glorifying chilly zealots. Yet the text’s core insight is formal: what is morally admirable is not the affective color of an inclination but the will’s acknowledgement of the moral law’s authority. The moral law is the law one gives oneself as a rational being; so action from duty expresses autonomy—self-government under universally shareable principles. Respect for the law is not respect for an abstract fetish; it is respect for every rational agent as the co-author of that law.

On a contemporary rendering (Herman, Korsgaard, Markovits), the “desire to do what is right” is thus a second-order disposition to treat first-order reasons springing from others’ needs or claims as decisively normative. That disposition can do the normative work critics assign to sympathy or beneficence while adding something those motives lack: acknowledgment of the equal status of all claimants. I now formalize this thought.

5. Three conditions under which de dicto motivation suffices

S1. Epistemic competence: The agent must accurately identify what morality requires in the circumstances. (A merely lucky hit lacks worth.)

S2. Volitional control: The agent must be stably disposed to treat that requirement as decisive, overcoming contrary inclinations where necessary.

S3. Structural fit: The agent’s de dicto desire must relate correctly to first-order reasons. It must treat the property “being right” not as a brute magnet but as a summary representation of the underlying grounds. That is, the agent stands ready, on reflection, to endorse those grounds and to adjust her judgment of rightness if they shift.

If these are met, acting solely from the desire to do what is right is sufficient for praiseworthiness. Let me illustrate.

Case: Exhausted Dr. Lee

After twenty hours in a disaster ward Lee feels no warmth; she is numb. A child is wheeled in. She acts, not from felt sympathy—there is none left—but because “it is my duty as a physician to help.” Lee passes S1–S3: she correctly sees what morality (and her professional role) requires, she subordinates her exhaustion, and her abstract commitment tracks the deeper reason—the child’s welfare. Intuitively, we still praise Lee. The motive of duty saves moral life when sentiments flag.

6. Four objections met

Objection 1: Alienation—Lee helps but does not care; the child is used as a mere prop for Lee’s moral self-image.

Reply: Caring manifests in more than affect. To govern oneself by principles that secure others’ interests is itself a mode of respect. Indeed, Lee’s stance may be less ego-laden than someone who helps only when gripped by vivid sympathy.

Objection 2: Motivational impoverishment—De dicto desire lacks the richness required for fully human virtue.

Reply: Sufficiency is not exclusivity. I concede that the virtuous agent typically houses both de dicto and de re motives. My claim is only that when the former alone operates (perhaps due to emotional depletion), moral worth is not forfeited.

Objection 3: Insensitivity—Because “rightness” is an abstract label, the agent may fail to respond to the nuances of concrete cases.

Reply: Structural fit (S3) blocks this. A competent de dicto agent treats rightness as inferentially dependent on particulars. Indeed, focusing on the formal requirement may enhance, rather than blunt, sensitivity: she must consider every factor relevant to the permissibility of her act, not just those that trigger certain emotions.

Objection 4: Redundancy—If the agent must already grasp the substantive reasons to tell what’s right (S1), why not let those reasons motivate directly? The de dicto desire looks otiose.

Reply: Two points. (i) Psychological economy: in deliberation we often use higher-order summaries (“do the safe thing,” “do what’s kind”) that enable action under time constraints. (ii) Normative hierarchy: recognizing the authority of morality as such gives the agent a reason-filter—an algorithm for settling conflicts amongst competing first-order pulls. That filter is valuable in turbulent moral terrains.

7. Division of moral labor and the virtue of principle

There is also a social argument for the sufficiency thesis. A community of agents moved by sympathy alone will act unevenly: sympathetic attention is unevenly distributed. De dicto motivation, because it is impartial, can correct this. Think of institutional roles—judges, jurors, civil servants—where personal tenderness toward one party could corrupt fairness. Praiseworthiness here attaches precisely to the restraint of feeling in deference to an abstract requirement.

8. A note on vicious de dicto analogues

Am I licensing fanatics who pursue “rightness” as they misconceive it? No. Epistemic competence screens them out. Nor am I licensing servile conformity; volitional control demands that the agent wills the law for herself. A Nazi who “just follows orders” acts de dicto in a sense, but not under the right description: she takes the order, not morality, as final. Moral worth requires that the de dicto desire track the moral law, not any purported surrogate.

9. Why the debate matters

If we deny sufficiency, we risk devaluing a large share of ordinary moral life: the parent who musters fairness despite fatigue, the citizen who pays taxes without patriotic thrill, the introvert who gives to charity out of principle. Conversely, affirming sufficiency does not denigrate richer emotions; it simply secures a floor of praiseworthiness grounded in autonomy.

10. Conclusion

Acting solely from a desire to do what is right can be morally worthy because such action manifests a distinctive respect: respect for the moral law as the common will of free and equal agents. That respect is expressed whenever an agent, competently and self-critically, allows the abstract requirement of morality to govern her conduct. Far from fetishistic, the motive of duty is a structural commitment that integrates all particular reasons under a unifying principle and thereby secures impartiality, reliability, and recognition of others’ equal claims. Concrete sympathies make morality humane; the formal motive of duty makes it principled. When the former are absent or mislead, the latter can still speak for us—and when it does, we are right to applaud.

1. Introduction and Thesis

The worry about “duty‐fetishism” begins with an intuitive contrast. Imagine two bystanders who plunge into an icy river to save a drowning child. Alice acts because she is horrified by the child’s peril; Bob acts because, after a quick internal calculation, he thinks, “Rescuing that child is the morally right thing to do.” Many find Alice’s motive more attractive. On one popular interpretation, Bob’s abstract concern with “rightness” reveals a chilling detachment from the concrete value at stake—the child’s life—and therefore renders his act less than fully praiseworthy.  

My thesis is that this reaction is too quick. A de dicto desire “to do what is morally right” can ground moral worth. Indeed, in some circumstances it is the best, and occasionally the only, way to guarantee that an agent’s action is reliably and intelligibly connected to moral reasons. When such a desire is properly integrated into the agent’s deliberative life—serving as a second-order policy to comply with whatever considerations turn out to be morally relevant—it manifests three features that suffice for praise: (i) clear recognition of moral reasons as reasons, (ii) committed self‐governance in light of those reasons, and (iii) a stable disposition to act rightly across changes in affect, inclination, or local knowledge. Far from constituting fetishism, this structure embodies a form of respect for persons (including oneself) as rational agents.

To defend the thesis, I proceed as follows. Section 2 clarifies the de dicto / de re distinction. Section 3 catalogues the main objections: the fetishism charge (Stocker, Smith), the worry about moral alienation (Railton), and the “moral saint” complaint (Wolf). Section 4 argues positively for the sufficiency of a de dicto motive, drawing on cases of epistemic opacity, affective depletion, and value conflict. Section 5 shows why the agent so motivated earns praise. Section 6 answers the three objections. Section 7 situates the view in a broader Kantian framework while marking real departures from Kant. Section 8 concludes by diagnosing our lingering preference for Alice-type motivation and suggesting how the two forms of moral concern can—and should—coexist.

2. De dicto versus De re Moral Motivation

The terminology is borrowed from the philosophy of language. A de re desire is directed toward a particular property or state of affairs in the world: e.g. “I want that child to flourish.” A de dicto desire is formulated under a description: “I want whatever is morally right to occur” or “I want to do my moral duty.”

Important refinement: “doing what is morally right” must be understood dispositionally, not as a fetish for a mysterious property ‘Rightness™’. It is the commitment to act in accordance with whatever the correct moral principles on inspection demand—even when the agent cannot at the time identify the specific concrete grounds (welfare, justice, fidelity, etc.). The desire is therefore second-order: it directs the agent to be guided by the moral point of view, whatever it turns out to recommend. Provided we keep this function‐alist reading in view, we can bracket the worry that “rightness” is treated as an occult intrinsic good.

3. Three Standard Objections

3.1 The Fetishism Objection  
On Michael Smith’s influential version, an ideally virtuous agent is motivated by the features of an act that explain its rightness, not by its being right. To be moved by rightness is to focus on the wrong property—a kind of moral fetish akin to loving someone for her social security number.

3.2 The Alienation Objection  
Peter Railton and Bernard Williams emphasize the value of unmediated attachment. If motives always run through the abstract filter of “duty,” the agent becomes estranged from her particular projects and relationships, and hence from her own humanity.

3.3 The Moral Saint Objection  
Susan Wolf suggests that an agent guided exclusively by moral rightness risks crowding out the non-moral excellences and particular loves that render a life rich and admirable. Such a person may be praiseworthy in a thin sense yet repellent as a full human being.

All three objections depend on the assumption that a de dicto motive is motivationally exclusive and affect-insensitive. I will argue that this assumption is optional and in most real cases false.

4. Why a De dicto Motive Can Suffice

4.1 Epistemic Opacity  
Often we do not know the concrete grounds of rightness. A doctor in triage cannot trace every life-saving order to its justificatory basis. What she can keep fixed is the policy: “Do what duty (professional and moral) requires.” The de dicto desire functions as an epistemic placeholder linking action to justification. Without it, her decision pattern would float free of moral reasons; she would be guessing. That she acts from duty makes the relation intelligible and non-accidental, exactly the feature most theories of moral worth prize.

4.2 Affective Depletion  
Empathy, care, and fellow-feeling are finite psychological resources. Imagine another rescuer, Carla, who has just endured the fifth emergency of the day. She feels numb. Still, she tells herself, “The child’s life is in danger, and it is my duty to help.” Her abstract commitment sustains right action when the emotional energies that normally supply de re motivation are exhausted. Acting well under such strain is paradigmatically praiseworthy; duty is the scaffold that keeps the agent aligned with moral reasons precisely when more sentimental motives flag.

4.3 Conflict and Temptation  
Suppose Daniel promised his friend to attend her recital but is suddenly offered a lucrative contract elsewhere. His passion for music is weak; his desire for money strong. What rescues Daniel from defecting is the remembered principle “Promises must be kept.” A second-order de dicto aim to honor duty enables him to counteract a first-order desire. Again, the structure seems not pathological but exemplary.

5. What Makes the Dutiful Action Praiseworthy?

The three examples reveal a common structure. Praiseworthiness requires not merely causal connection to the right-making features but an agentive connection that reflects (i) practical recognition, (ii) self-governance, and (iii) reliability.

(i) Recognition: The agent explicitly takes moral considerations as reasons for her. A de dicto desire satisfies this: the agent wants her behavior to fall under whatever reasons are morally decisive. That is a sophisticated cognitive achievement, not a defect.

(ii) Self‐governance: The action issues from the agent’s settled practical identity—a policy she claims as her own. This is autonomy in a recognizably Kantian key. The will that bends itself to the moral law is praiseworthy as the expression of rational self-legislation.

(iii) Reliability: A desire for the right as such is content‐neutral across situations. Whereas sympathy may track sufferings selectively (the cute sufferer, the in-group member), a second-order policy is impartial and stable. Reliability is a mark of moral character; hence its presence is ground for praise.

6. Replies to the Objections

6.1 Answering Fetishism  
Smith’s fetish image gains force only if “rightness” is conceived as a detachable non-relational property. But on the policy reading, the desire is precisely to track the relational property “whatever is supported by the ensemble of concrete moral reasons.” In loving my partner, I may in the moment be unsure whether to tell a painful truth or protect her feelings. A standing commitment “to do right by her” is not fetishistic; it is rational humility in face of complexity.

Furthermore, de re and de dicto motives need not compete. Often the abstract policy feeds and structures the cultivation of more concrete motives. Knowing that alleviating suffering is (often) morally required, I train my sympathies. Far from displacing affection, the de dicto stance can incubate it.

6.2 Answering Alienation  
Railton and Williams rightly prize immediacy, yet they overlook how a de dicto motive can integrate rather than eclipse first-order attachments. The model is hierarchical: second-order duty governs the orchestration of one’s particular loves, setting limits when they conflict, otherwise leaving them intact. Consider the parent who recites to herself, “I must do right by my child,” before deciding to forgo an academic conference. Nothing in that self-reminder alienates her from parental attachment; it articulates it in the register of obligation, making explicit why the attachment has normative authority.

6.3 Answering the Moral Saint Complaint  
Wolf’s moral saint is a person who allows moral considerations to swamp every aspect of life. But de dicto motivation does not necessitate lexical priority of the moral over all other values. One can have a policy: “Act within the moral constraints, then pursue non-moral projects wholeheartedly.” Morality occupies a deontic veto position, not an all-consuming maximizer. Respecting moral side‐constraints leaves room—indeed, creates the secure space—for aesthetic and personal excellence.

7. Kant Revisited (With Modifications)

Kant famously privileges acting “from duty,” which for him means acting from respect for the moral law. Critics note that Kant sometimes speaks as though only de dicto motivation carries moral worth. I have argued for sufficiency, not necessity: de re motives like beneficence can equally ground praise when they appropriately track right-making features and manifest self-governance. This broader ecumenism departs from an austere Kantian reading but retains his insight that autonomy and stability matter.

Moreover, on my account the duty motive is empirically pluralistic about the correct moral theory. An Aristotelian may have a second-order policy to act in accordance with phronēsis; a utilitarian, to maximize well-being. The structure, not the content, is what carries the justificatory weight. This ecumenical stance fits better with epistemic humility than the categorical-imperative-centric reading of Kant.

8. Why We Prefer Alice—and Why We Should Still Praise Bob

Our partiality for Alice’s affective motive is rooted in two psychological facts:

(1) Epistemic window dressing: Her compassion offers a transparent causal story we can empathically rehearse (“I, too, feel horror at the child’s danger”). Bob’s deliberation is invisible; abstract respect seems bloodless. But absence of emotional display is not absence of moral concern.

(2) Social signaling: Warmth is reassuring, while explicit appeals to duty sometimes connote judgmentalism. Yet these pragmatic connotations do not bear on moral worth.

Recognizing that de dicto motivation can suffice should not lead us to denigrate de re motives. The healthiest moral psychology includes both: affection supplies energy and local acuity; the standing commitment to duty supplies guidance, discipline, and reach. Together they form what Rawls called “the two moral powers”: the capacity for a conception of the good (grounded in attachments) and the capacity for a sense of justice (a de dicto policy). A mature moral agent harmonizes them.

9. Conclusion

Acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can indeed suffice for morally worthy conduct, provided the desire functions as a second-order commitment that secures recognition of and responsiveness to moral reasons across contexts. Such duty-based action warrants praise because it (i) embodies rational acknowledgment of moral authority, (ii) manifests autonomous self-governance, and (iii) provides a reliable, impartial disposition to act rightly even under epistemic, affective, or motivational strain. The standard objections—fetishism, alienation, and saintliness—lose their force once we distinguish pathological from policy-based duty motives and appreciate how the latter integrates rather than displaces concrete moral concerns. The upshot is not that abstract duty should monopolize our motivational economy, but that we need not apologize for it. Sometimes, when our sympathies misfire, when we cannot discern the specific ground of rightness, or when temptation looms, the quiet voice that says “Do the right thing, whatever it is” is precisely the voice of virtue.

1. Introduction and Thesis  

Is a bare “desire to do what is right” enough to make an action morally worthy, or must a praiseworthy agent also be moved by the first-order considerations that make the act right—for example, by compassion for the beneficiary? I shall argue for a qualified “yes.” Acting solely from a de dicto desire to do what is morally right can suffice for moral worth provided that (i) the agent’s de dicto motive is integrated with an adequate understanding of why the act is right and (ii) the agent would manifest the appropriate first-order concerns were she not impeded by circumstances internal or external to her agency. What makes such action praiseworthy is not the presence of a particular concrete motive but the agent’s competence to track and conform to moral reasons across contexts. In short, moral worth supervenes on reliable responsiveness to right-making features, and a de dicto desire can implement that responsiveness just as well as first-order motives can.

The argument proceeds as follows. Section 2 clarifies the relevant distinctions: moral rightness vs. moral worth; de dicto vs. de re moral motivation; alienation and “moral fetishism.” Section 3 reconstructs the main objections to de dicto moral motivation. Section 4 shows why those objections overreach. Section 5 develops a competence theory of moral worth on which a de dicto desire can ground praiseworthiness. Section 6 responds to residual worries about coldness, over-intellectualism, and the value of the moral law. A brief conclusion summarizes the pay-offs.

2. Conceptual Ground-Clearing  

2.1 Moral rightness and moral worth  

An action can be morally right yet not creditable to the agent (e.g., the accidentally beneficent deed); conversely, one can act from excellent motives yet fail to do the right thing. “Moral worth,” as Kant first highlighted, is the property of an action that is not only right but redounds to the agent’s moral credit. Contemporary discussions typically reserve that label for cases in which the agent acts because the right-making reasons move her in the right way.

2.2 De re vs. de dicto moral motivation  

A de re moral motive is a desire directed at the very features that make the action right: helping because the other is in need, telling the truth because honesty respects autonomy, and so forth. A de dicto motive, by contrast, is an attitude toward the proposition that the action is morally right: one’s reason for acting is simply that this is what morality requires.

2.3 Alienation and moral fetishism  

Michael Smith and Jonathan Dancy, among others, charge that the purely de dicto agent exhibits “moral fetishism”: she is fascinated by morality as a formal property and thereby alienated from the concrete value of people and projects. Susan Wolf, Bernard Williams, and Michael Stocker raise related worries about motivational “schizophrenia”: the moral calculus crowds out personal concern and renders the agent cold or inauthentic.

3. The Standard Case Against De Dicto Sufficiency  

Three lines of argument dominate.

A. The Missing Value Argument  
1. Praiseworthy action should manifest appreciation of the considerations that make it right.  
2. A de dicto motive abstracts away from those considerations.  
3. Therefore, a purely de dicto motive cannot ground moral worth.

B. The Alienation Argument  
1. Morality is about promoting or respecting substantive values (welfare, autonomy, etc.).  
2. Valuing “morality” instead is to mislocate value; one loves the map, not the territory.  
3. Such mislocation is fetishistic and thus not praiseworthy.

C. The Practical Rationality Argument  
1. Rational agency requires sensitivity to the contents of reasons.  
2. A de dicto motive is too thin to explain why a particular act is required.  
3. Therefore, such an agent is irrational or at least imperfectly rational; moral worth demands better.

4. Diagnosing the Overreach  

4.1 Misreading the De Dicto Desire  

Critics tacitly assume a de dicto motive comes apart from appreciation of right-making reasons. Yet an agent can treat the moral law as a reliable indicator of those very reasons. The de dicto desire need not be “I want to do the right thing full stop” in the absence of any grasp of what makes it right; it can be “I want to do whatever the moral facts, constituted by people’s needs and rights, require.” If so, the agent’s motivational psychology is a two-stage mechanism: the higher-order desire to comply with morality triggers first-order recognition of concrete reasons. Nothing in the mere form of the desire precludes that.

4.2 Respect vs. Affection  

Kant distinguished acting from inclination and acting from respect. Respect is not cold indifference but a mode of valuing persons as ends. When I rescue a drowning stranger “because it is right,” I still engage the person’s plight; I simply frame my motivation in normative rather than sentimental terms. The critic’s inference from “no affection” to “no concern” equivocates between psychological warmth and moral regard.

4.3 The Reliability Test  

Suppose two agents each help the stranger: Clara because she cares, Dana because “it’s the right thing.” Clara helps when she happens to care; Dana helps whether or not she feels inclined. If reliability in responding to need is morally important, Dana’s motive may be superior. The fetishism argument overlooks the dimension of robustness across contexts.

5. A Competence Account of Moral Worth  

5.1 Competence Rather Than Content  

I propose that moral worth attaches to an action when it issues from a competence to track right-making reasons. Competence has two sub-components: (i) epistemic: the agent reliably forms correct beliefs about what is right; (ii) volitional: she is reliably motivated to act accordingly.

5.2 How a De Dicto Desire Can Realize the Competence  

A higher-order de dicto desire functions as a self-binding strategy: it directs attention to moral reasons and commits the will in advance to follow them. For many human agents, concrete sympathy is selective, but the moral-law desire is global. Its practical upshot is a plan: “In any circumstance, do what morality requires.” If the agent’s moral cognition is adequate, the plan ensures competent responsiveness. Therefore, de dicto motivation passes the reliability test.

5.3 Why the Competence Is Praiseworthy  

Three values ground the praiseworthiness of competence.

1. Non-accidentality: Worthwhile conduct should not be a fluke; competence internalizes the connection between reasons and action.  
2. Respect: To act because it is right is to give the moral law authority over one’s conduct; that expresses the equal status of all persons whose interests constitute the content of the law.  
3. Integrity: A higher-order plan unifies agency over time, enabling self-governance in the face of conflicting inclinations.

6. Replies to Residual Objections  

6.1 Coldness and the Huckleberry Finn Case  

Mark Twain’s Huck helps Jim escape despite believing it wrong; his compassion overrides his sense of duty. Does Huck show that affection is the true seat of moral worth? No. Huck’s act is indeed admirable, but the admirability stems from his implicit responsiveness to the right-making reason (Jim’s humanity). Compassion here compensates for defective moral cognition. In a cognitively sound agent, the duty motive would serve the same function. The case shows that affection can substitute for duty, not that duty is unnecessary or insufficient.

6.2 The Wrongful Obedience Worry  

De dicto agents, it is said, are hostage to mistaken moral principles; Nazis who acted “from duty” hardly deserve praise. True, but the problem lies in epistemic incompetence, not in the de dicto structure. A sympathy-only agent misled about who deserves compassion can do equal harm. Competence demands both correct judgment and appropriate motivation.

6.3 Fetishism Revisited  

Isn’t valuing morality for its own sake like collecting stamps—the object of value seems arbitrary? Not if morality is constitutively tied to reasons of universal importance. Respect for morality is respect for the network of properties that make actions right. To fetishize is to value a property detached from its grounding; the competent de dicto agent values morality precisely because it is a reliable marker of what has value.

6.4 Over-Intellectualism  

Finally, is the competence theory too demanding? Children and non-reflective adults do praiseworthy deeds without articulating moral laws. Note that a desire can be tacit; the competence can be sub-personal or habitual. What matters is the reliable function, not explicit deliberation.

7. Conclusion  

Moral worth does not require that the agent’s first-order motives mirror every right-making feature. What it requires is reliable responsiveness to those features. A de dicto desire to do what is right, properly integrated with adequate moral understanding, secures that responsiveness and therefore suffices for moral worth. Far from being fetishistic, such a motive embodies respect, integrity, and robustness—virtues that ground genuine praiseworthiness.

Duty without Fetish: A Defense of the De Dicto Motive

1. Introduction and Thesis  
Ought moral admiration be reserved only for people moved by concrete, “world-directed” concerns—empathy for a friend’s suffering, loyalty to a promise, love of justice? Many contemporary writers (e.g., Arpaly, Stocker, Wolf) answer affirmatively. They argue that an agent who acts from a merely abstract desire “to do the morally right thing” displays moral fetishism or alienation and therefore earns, at best, tepid praise. In reply, defenders of the de dicto motive (most prominently Markovits) have insisted that a pure concern with rightness can itself ground moral worth.

I defend a qualified version of this latter view. Acting solely from the de dicto desire to do what is morally right can be fully morally worthy, provided (i) the agent’s desire for rightness is non-instrumental and integrative—it governs their deliberation in a way that coordinates rather than suppresses first-order values—and (ii) the agent’s sensitivity to rightness is suitably reliable and non-accidental. In short, what makes dutiful action praiseworthy is that it expresses an agent-centered commitment to the normative authority of morality, a commitment that itself embodies respect for persons and goods, albeit at a higher level of abstraction. The charge of fetishism rests on a misunderstanding of how second-order concern with morality can nest, rather than compete, with first-order concerns.

2. Setting the Stage: De Dicto Versus De Re Motives  
A de re motive is directed at a particular right-making consideration: I give back your book because it is yours (respect for property). A de dicto motive, by contrast, is directed at the fact that a certain act is morally right: I return the book simply because it is the right thing to do. The central worry is that de dicto agents, focusing on the property of rightness, treat concrete values as mere buttons to be pressed for a higher, perhaps aesthetic, satisfaction: “Ah, another moral requirement fulfilled!” Hence “moral fetishism.”

Yet we must distinguish:

a. Abstractness of content (my desire aims at “rightness”)  
b. Abstractness of epistemic route (I form the judgment that φ is right by armchair theorizing rather than empathetic perception)  
c. Abstractness of emotional engagement (I feel no compassion, only cool resolve)

Opponents of the de dicto often conflate these. One can have motive-type (a) while avoiding the alienation said to attend (b) or (c).

3. Minimal Conditions on Moral Worth  
Any adequate account of moral worth should explain three phenomena:

(1) Responsiveness. Worthy action tracks moral reasons in a non-accidental way.  
(2) Guidance Control. The reason’s efficacy must flow through the agent’s own capacities, not bypass them (e.g., hypnotic compulsion).  
(3) Agential Expression. The motive should reveal something commendable about the person’s character or practical identity.

The de dicto motive can satisfy all three once we grasp its internal structure.

4. The Integrative De Dicto Desire  
Consider the following mental economy, which I call Integrative Dutifulness:

First-order layer: The agent has ordinary desires—pleasure, friendship, curiosity, etc.  
Second-order layer: The agent has a standing commitment to doing what is morally right. This commitment operates as a “constitution-constraining principle” (analogous to Rawlsian constitutional essentials): it instructs the agent to treat moral requirements as undefeated reasons.

Crucially, the second-order desire neither obliterates nor ignores first-order concerns. Rather, it governs them by a principle of conditional authority: let any first-order motive speak, unless and until it conflicts with moral rightness. In that event, the second-order desire vetoes. On ordinary occasions, the agent’s kindness or fidelity will coincide with morality, and she will act kindly or faithfully. But when conflict arises, she is prepared to sacrifice convenience, inclination, or even affection, because she endorses morality’s authority over the entire field of reasons.

This structure mirrors the constitutional supremacy of law over day-to-day political preferences. Just as fidelity to the constitution is praiseworthy in a judge, fidelity to morality-as-such is praiseworthy in an agent, precisely because it is the principled way of honoring each person’s equal moral standing.

5. Fetishism Reconsidered  
Why is this not fetishistic? Because the de dicto agent does not value the property of “being-right” as one might value possessing baseball cards. She values it as the property whereby acts express respect for persons. In Kantian language, she “recognizes the moral law as binding” and thus, implicitly, recognizes every rational being as legislator and end. De dicto desire is an allegiance to that law, which is nothing other than the system of reasons constituted by everyone’s claims.

An analogy: a scientist’s second-order desire “to believe what is scientifically justified” is not epistemic fetishism; it is a metacognitive orientation that integrates first-order curiosity, observation, and inference. Similarly, a de dicto moral orientation integrates first-order compassion, fairness, and fidelity by treating them as the content that fills out “rightness.”

6. Examples Doing Real Work  
(1) The Conscientious Juror. A juror, exhausted after weeks of testimony, is tempted to go home early. What keeps her in deliberation is not vivid sympathy for the defendant—whose face she can barely recall—but her vow “to do my civic duty.” She patiently weighs the evidence and helps avert a wrongful conviction. We praise her, not despite, but because of her abstract motive.

(2) The Neutral Aid Worker. An aid worker administers vaccines in a refugee camp. She does not share a common language or culture with the children. Her immediate emotional response is muted; what moves her is the recognition that these strangers are owed equal concern by morality. Her deed seems eminently praiseworthy. The absence of concrete-affective ties does not mar its moral worth.

(3) The Shopkeeper Revisited. Kant’s famous shopkeeper charges honest prices “from duty.” Critics protest that if he were moved only by duty, we would distrust him. But note: we distrust the shopkeeper only if we imagine his dutifulness as brittle, perhaps cynical. Suppose instead he has a settled, integrative de dicto commitment. Then we admire him for refusing to overcharge tourists even when no one is watching.

7. Reliability and Non-Accidentality  
Mere intention to do right is insufficient if the agent routinely misidentifies what rightness requires (the scrupulous fanatic). Moral worth arises when the de dicto disposition succeeds via reliable competence—call it “practical moral epistemology.” This mirrors intellectual worth: a desire for truth is admirable when coupled with reliable belief-forming methods. Thus requirement (ii) above: sensitivity must be competent, not lucky.

8. Dialectical Engagement: Answering Five Objections

Objection 1 (Stocker): De dicto motivation alienates friends, who rightly want to be loved for themselves.  
Reply: The integrative structure ensures that one’s friends are loved for themselves; the second-order desire merely guarantees that this love never violates another’s equal moral claim. My friend would resent me if I rescued her “only because morality demands it” when affection was available. But the presence of the de dicto motive does not preclude affection; it supplements it.

Objection 2 (Arpaly): Huckleberry Finn, motivated by sympathy but believing rescue wrong, is more praiseworthy than the de dicto racist who frees Jim “because abolition is right.”  
Reply: Two points. (a) Moral worth is multi-dimensional; Huck’s empathy displays a virtue the racist lacks. Yet the abolitionist’s act, considered in isolation, still manifests a commendable respect for rightness, especially given the social cost of dissenting from pro-slavery norms. (b) Where Huck’s conscience is corrupted by mis-education, his good-hearted response evidences a different virtue—responsiveness to pro tanto moral reasons he mistakenly classifies. Both cases reveal how diverse virtues can ground worth. They are not mutually exclusive counter-examples.

Objection 3: De dicto agents face moral overload and paralysis, constantly calculating the right.  
Reply: They need not. A settled disposition can function heuristically: absent defeaters, follow benevolent inclinations; when moral uncertainty looms, slow down. This is the same pattern responsible scientists or doctors exhibit in their domains.

Objection 4: The motive seems cold or joyless.  
Reply: Nothing in the de dicto desire entails emotional poverty. Respect for rightness can itself be affectively rich: pride in justice, satisfaction in integrity, indignation at wrong. Moreover, one can simultaneously experience neighbor-directed compassion.

Objection 5: The view collapses into a Kantian formalism disconnected from lived goods.  
Reply: On the contrary, the integrative model understands moral rightness as constituted by the very considerations opponents defend (welfare, autonomy, fidelity). The agent’s abstract desire simply anchors those considerations within a higher-order commitment to universality and impartiality.

9. Precision in Distinctions  
I have emphasized three distinctions often blurred in this debate:

(i) Motive-type versus affect-profile: A de dicto motive need not be affect-free.  
(ii) Content-level versus epistemic-method: Caring about rightness does not entail theorizing about it.  
(iii) Second-order governance versus first-order exclusion: A priority rule is not an eliminative rule.

Maintaining these distinctions dissolves much of the intuitive charge of fetishism.

10. Substantive Contribution: The Civic Analogy  
My proposal models the moral agent on a civic republican. A republican citizen esteems the constitution not for its parchment texture but because it institutionalizes equal liberty. Likewise, the de dicto motive esteems “moral rightness” because it institutionalizes equal moral status. This analogy clarifies two issues:

(a) Why the motive is non-fetishistic: what is loved is not a mysterious property but the public framework ensuring everyone’s claims are fairly adjudicated.  
(b) Why the motive is crucial in moments of conflict: just as constitutional fidelity tempers populist passions, duty tempers partiality.

11. Relation to Alternative Accounts  
Virtue ethics: The integrative de dicto motive is compatible with virtue. It acts as an architectonic virtue—not a rival—ensuring that courage, generosity, and fidelity operate within rightful bounds.

Scanlonian contractualism: To judge an act “right” is to see it as unrejectable by reasonable persons. A de dicto desire to do what is right therefore embodies universal concern, albeit indirectly.

Kant: My view vindicates Kant’s claim that only actions done from duty have “moral worth” but refines it: worth attaches because duty expresses respect for persons, not because of metaphysical formality.

12. Limits and Further Questions  
Two limits deserve acknowledgment. First, in certain intimate contexts (romantic love, parent-child bonding) we expect primary acknowledgment of concrete concern, with duty as back-up. Whether failure to manifest the favored “foreground” motive diminishes worth is an open question. Second, cultural and epistemic constraints affect the reliability of de dicto guidance. Future work might explore institutional supports (education, deliberative forums) that help duty fulfill its promise.

13. Conclusion  
Acting solely from the desire to do what is morally right can indeed confer full moral worth. When that desire (i) is non-instrumental and integrative, (ii) manifests reliable sensitivity to moral reasons, and (iii) expresses respect for persons through allegiance to morality’s authority, the resulting action exemplifies moral excellence rather than fetishism. The appearance of cold abstraction dissolves once we recognize that “rightness” is merely the systematic face of the very concrete values everyone already agrees matter. Far from alienating us from morality’s point, dutiful action secures it: it is the agent’s steadfast way of treating all persons—ourselves included—as ends whose claims set the terms of rightful action.

Approx. 2,050 words

1. Introduction and Statement of Thesis  

Most people who do the right thing do so for concrete reasons: they give to Oxfam because they see the misery of famine victims, or they return a lost wallet because they imagine the owner’s distress.  By contrast, the agent who says simply “I did it because it was the morally right thing to do” can sound chilly, even fetishistic.  Contemporary critics—from Michael Smith’s‐style “moral fetishism” charge, through Susan Wolf’s worry about “moral saints,” to Railton’s and Slote’s “alienation” concerns—argue that the motive of duty, understood as a de dicto desire to do whatever morality requires, cannot by itself ground moral worth.  They insist that praiseworthy agents must be moved by the concrete considerations that make their acts right, not by the bare idea of rightness.  

I shall defend the opposite view.  A de dicto desire to do whatever is morally required can, by itself, suffice for moral worth.  In such cases the source of praiseworthiness is the agent’s commitment to the authority of morality itself—a commitment that (i) embodies respect for others as rational equals, (ii) enables reliable responsiveness to right‐making considerations across situations, and (iii) displays a form of moral self‐governance that is necessary for full moral agency.  While concrete, de re concerns often enrich motivation, they are not conceptually or normatively required for an action to be morally worthy.  Indeed, an exclusive insistence on de re motivation smuggles in questionable empirical assumptions about human psychology and overlooks how moral learning, deliberative uncertainty, and structural injustice can make the abstract motive of duty the best—or even the only—uncompromised route to doing what is right.  

The argument proceeds in five stages.  Section 2 clarifies the distinction between de dicto and de re moral motivation and introduces a neglected middle category: higher‐order de dicto regulation of lower‐order de re motives.  Section 3 diagnoses the “moral fetishism” objection and shows why it relies on an implausibly narrow picture of moral psychology.  Section 4 develops a positive Kantian account of why the abstract motive of duty is itself valuable and not alienating.  Section 5 replies to three leading objections—that duty motivation is (A) motivationally anemic, (B) epistemically blind, and (C) emotionally impoverished—using historical examples and thought experiments to show how duty‐only motivation can in fact excel on each dimension.  Section 6 draws the upshot: moral worth attaches to the quality of volitional governance, not to the phenomenology of one’s concrete sentiments.

2. De dicto versus de re—and a Third Alternative  

The standard contrast is familiar.  

De re moral motivation: the agent acts from a desire concerning the very property that makes the act right (e.g., “I give money because it will relieve Julio’s suffering”).  

De dicto moral motivation: the agent acts from a desire that the act be morally right, without particular concern for the right‐making property (e.g., “I give because it’s the morally required thing to do”).  

Critics treat these as exhaustive, but there is a third, hybrid form:  

Higher‐order de dicto regulation: the agent is moved by concrete de re motives (empathy, fairness, charity) but is disposed to screen, endorse, or override those motives by reference to the de dicto desire to comply with morality.  Call this “regulated de re motivation.”  

The hybrid model shows that a de dicto desire can structure an agent’s motivational set without itself supplying a vivid first‐order sentiment.  This undermines the fetishism charge (which targets the picture of a lone, icy, de dicto motive) by revealing how, psychologically, the de dicto motive often functions as a governing commitment, not as a monotonous substitute for ordinary sentiments.  But for the purposes of the present essay I want to make the stronger claim: even when the de dicto desire operates alone—as it sometimes does—it can confer full moral worth.

3. What Exactly Is Moral Fetishism?

Smith’s complaint is that the duty‐fixated agent treats the property of being right as if it had an intrinsic magnetism, fetishizing an abstract quality while remaining indifferent to the human goods at stake.  But this diagnosis trades on an analogy to sexual fetishism that fails on three grounds.

First, the fetishist is captivated by an accidental property (e.g., a shoe) while ignoring the person; the dutiful agent is captivated by the property that makes the act obligatory—morality itself—not by an accidental feature.  Respecting morality is not a distraction from what matters morally; it is an explicit affirmation of it.

Second, fetishism is marked by compulsive affect; the duty‐motivated agent’s concern is principled and reflective.  The criticism confuses principled impartiality with pathological obsession.

Third, the charge presupposes that the de dicto desire crowds out de re concerns.  Empirically this is dubious.  One can be moved solely by duty in a given circumstance (because concrete sympathy is absent) without being globally indifferent to others’ welfare.  A surgeon exhausted after a 20‐hour shift may wash before operating “because it’s the right thing to do,” even though she presently feels no vivid concern for the next patient.  Nothing fetishistic here—just professional integrity in attenuating circumstances.

Thus the fetishism objection rests on caricature.  The duty‐only motive need not reflect indifference to concrete goods; it can reflect principled governance when other motives are silent, overwhelmed, or corrupted.

4. Why the Abstract Motive of Duty Is Morally Valuable

Kant’s groundwork provides the canonical defense: acting from duty displays respect for the moral law and hence for persons as ends in themselves.  Critics often recite this but miss three points.

4.1. Authority and Equal Status  

The de dicto desire implicitly acknowledges that no individual’s partial perspective, not even one’s own, has ultimate authority.  To act because something is morally required is to act under a law one gives to oneself in concert with all rational beings.  This expresses equal moral respect in a way that purely sentimental concern cannot, because sentiments track partiality (we feel more empathy for the near, the familiar, the lovable).  The duty motive therefore has an egalitarian meaning that ordinary de re motives lack.

4.2. Reliability Across Contexts  

A second virtue is diachronic and cross‐situational reliability.  Concrete motives are situation‐specific and easily hijacked by salience effects, framing, and prejudice.  The abstract commitment to do what morality requires can trigger right action in contexts where the relevant suffering is invisible, where no personal relationship cues special concern, or where unjust social norms dampen sympathetic imagination.  The 19th‐century abolitionist who refuses to keep slaves because “it is wrong, full stop,” despite having been raised in a culture that normalizes slavery, illustrates how de dicto motivation can outperform sentimental concern that has been socially conditioned to favor only certain victims.

4.3. Autonomy and Self‐Governance  

Finally, duty motivation realizes a distinctive form of practical freedom: the ability to act for reasons that one can endorse under critical reflection, independent of contingent drives.  This autonomy itself has moral value.  A world where agents saved drowning children solely because they happened to feel strong empathy would be welcome, but one where they saved children even when exhausted, resentful, or emotionally numb—because “it is the right thing to do”—exhibits a deeper kind of moral agency, one less hostage to vagaries of temperament.

5. Replies to Three Objections  

Objection A: Motivational Anemia (“duty alone won’t get you off the couch”).  
Reply: Empirical studies on “rule internalization” and “professional role morality” show that abstract normative commitments can reliably motivate costly actions—in soldiers who leap on grenades, in judges who recuse themselves despite personal loss, in whistle‐blowers who forgo lucrative careers.  These are not cases of warm concern for concrete victims; often the victims are faceless.  Yet the actions are morally heroic.  The claim that the abstract motive is too weak is a descriptive conjecture belied by real human behavior.

Objection B: Epistemic Blindness (“without de re concern you can’t see what morality demands”).  
Reply: The objection confuses the epistemic role of emotions with their motivational role.  Sympathy can be an evidential aid in recognizing that an act would relieve suffering, but once that fact is known, the motive of duty can supply the practical impetus.  Moreover, the duty motive can recruit epistemic tools—consultation, deliberation, moral theory—to determine rightness where emotions mislead.  Again, the abolitionist’s insight depended not on feeling the slave’s pain (many did not) but on grasping the contradiction in the institution relative to equal freedom.  Far from being blind, the duty motive can widen moral vision by checking partiality.

Objection C: Emotional Impoverishment (“duty motivation lacks the warm affect we admire”).  
Reply: Moral worth is not identical with moral beauty.  An agent can be praiseworthy without being charming.  We should separate (i) the aesthetic value of moral emotions from (ii) the ethical value of principled action.  In crisis contexts—triage medicine, disaster response—the agent’s emotional palette may be numb or stressed, yet her duty‐driven actions remain laudable.  Indeed we sometimes *prefer* such self‐disciplined agents; a judge who sentences a guilty friend may feel agony, but if empathy swayed her to acquit she would fail in her duty.  The cool motive can be more trustworthy.

6. Testing the Thesis: Historical and Hypothetical Cases  

Case 1: The “Quiet Rescuer” in Occupied France  
Yvonne Beauvais hid Jewish families though she felt no special affection for them and was terrified of reprisal.  Her diary: “One must do what God and Right demand.”  Post‐war reflections hail her as a righteous person, despite her admission that fear drowned out feelings of empathy.  Moral worth seems intact.

Case 2: The “Decolonizing Bureaucrat”  
Suppose a colonial officer in 1946 Britain reads a parliamentary report concluding that continued imperial rule violates basic self‐determination.  He has no emotional ties to Indian villagers but resigns, explaining, “I could not in conscience enforce a policy I now see as unjust.”  His act stems from duty, not sentiment, yet is clearly praiseworthy.

Case 3: The “Saturation Surgeon”  
An emergency surgeon, after twelve hours of amputations following an earthquake, feels nothing but exhaustion.  She scrubs for the next operation out of professional duty.  Her affective exhaustion is the very condition under which the duty motive shows its moral worth; it carries her through when compassion is temporarily spent.

These cases exhibit what we revere: steadfastness to principle amid fear, fatigue, or indifference.  If the critics were right, we would withhold praise; yet the intuitive verdict goes the other way.

7. Reconciling De Dicto and De Re: Two Modest Claims  

One need not deny the moral value of concrete motives.  My defense of duty motivation implies two more modest theses:

Integration Thesis: The most robustly virtuous characters harmonize de re sentiments under the governance of a de dicto commitment.  Thus de dicto motivation is at least necessary for fully developed virtue, even if not always alone sufficient for action.

Sufficiency Thesis: In any given action, the presence of de dicto motivation alone can secure moral worth when (a) the agent’s belief about what morality requires is true, and (b) the motivation issues in right action intentionally.  De re motives are optional bonuses, not requirements.

8. Conclusion  

The suspicion of an exclusive duty motive stems, I have argued, from conflating vivid sentiment with moral seriousness.  Abstract commitment to rightness is neither fetishistic nor alienating; it is an expression of respect for the equal authority of the moral law, a safeguard against partiality, and a source of autonomy.  When concrete sentiments fail—because bias, distance, fatigue, or social corruption dampens them—the motive of duty can stand alone and still render conduct fully praiseworthy.  Far from being a second‐best, it is often the mark of the highest moral agency.

1. Setting the Stage: What Is at Issue?

When Kant writes that only an act “from duty” has moral worth, he is commonly read as endorsing a distinctive motive: the agent acts because she recognizes that what she is about to do is morally required. That motive, call it the de dicto desire to do what is right (I shall abbreviate it DD-desire), is contrasted with a de re concern for the right-making features of the situation—e.g., another person’s pain, the unfairness of a distribution, the mendacity of a promise. Contemporary critics (most prominently Michael Smith, Jonathan Dancy, and Kieran Setiya) object that the DD-desire looks fetishistic: the dutiful agent seems weirdly focused on a property—rightness—as such, rather than the human needs or values that make the act right. A morally mature person, they insist, should be motivated directly by those values; someone who merely wants “to do the right thing” stands at one remove from what morality is really about and so fails to earn full moral credit.

My thesis is twofold.

(1) Contrary to the fetishism charge, a pure DD-desire can in principle suffice for moral worth.

(2) The key to its praiseworthiness lies not in its abstract content but in its functional role: it expresses the agent’s recognition of morality’s authority and her rational commitment to act accordingly. When that commitment is exercised competently—that is, when the agent identifies the right act because she competently traces how the concrete right-makers bear on her situation—the action is fully worthy of moral praise.

I proceed as follows. §2 clarifies the concepts of motive and moral worth. §3 develops a positive argument for the sufficiency of a DD-desire. §4 faces three central objections: fetishism, alienation, and motivational fragility. §5 introduces two illustrative examples—a conscientious lifeguard and a bigoted but self-reflective shopkeeper—to show how the account handles real-world cases. §6 locates the view in recent literature and draws out broader implications. I conclude in §7.

2. Clarifying the Terrain

2.1. Motive vs. Right-Maker  
Right-making considerations are facts in virtue of which an act is morally required or permitted: that rescuing a drowning child prevents grave harm, that repaying a debt keeps a promise, etc. Motives are psychological states that move an agent to act. A moralized psychology tends to map motives onto right-makers: caring about the child’s welfare leads one to rescue her. The DD-desire, by contrast, has the schematic content “act as morality requires,” leaving the right-makers unspecified.

2.2. Moral Worth  
We praise acts for two dimensions: (a) objective rightness (did the agent do what morality demands?) and (b) moral worth (was the act motivated in a morally appropriate way?). Kant’s paradigm is the honest shopkeeper who charges fair prices from self-interest (objectively right but not morally worthy) versus the shopkeeper who does so from duty (both right and worthy). Many contemporary theorists accept a two-tier structure though they reject Kant’s restrictive criterion.

2.3. De dicto vs. De re Desire  
The de dicto/de re distinction applies to the way a desire represents its object. Suppose Maggie desires to drink the liquid in the glass. De re: she desires of that very substance that she drink it; de dicto: she desires to drink “the refreshing beverage,” a description under which she conceives it. A desire to do what morality requires is de dicto in this sense: its object is whatever act fits the description “morally right.” Importantly, that does not prevent Maggie from consulting the world to see which concrete act matches the description.

3. The Positive Case for Dutiful Motivation

3.1. The Rational Agency Argument  
Step 1. Rational agency is guided by practical principles that are, at some level, content-general. To become an agent at all is to commit oneself to acting for reasons.  
Step 2. Morality, if authoritative, supplies reasons that are categorically binding. Recognizing that authority naturally gives rise to a standing policy: “Do what morality requires.”  
Step 3. A rational agent who forms and acts on that policy manifests a distinctive virtue—respect for the moral law. In a slogan: rational recognition of moral reasons is itself reason-giving.  
Step 4. Therefore, when such an agent acts from the DD-desire, she exhibits a virtuous form of practical rationality; the act therefore possesses moral worth.

3.2. Competence Condition  
The DD-desire confers worth only if it is exercised competently: the agent must identify what morality in fact requires and adjust her action accordingly. Compare: a physician motivated by concern for her patient’s health acts with professional worth only if she diagnoses correctly. Moral competence includes sensitivity to the concrete welfare, rights, and relationships that ground the moral requirement. If the agent reaches the right act by wishful thinking or lucky guess, her motive is epistemically defective and so diminished in worth. That caveat answers the worry that a bare schematic desire floats free of the right-makers; correct linkage is demanded.

3.3. The Expressivist Rationale  
On a familiar insight from Frankfurt and Moran, actions can express who one is: they manifest practical identity. Acting from the DD-desire expresses the identity of one who takes morality to be a supreme normative authority. That expressivist dimension grounds desert of praise: we honor agents who embody moral commitment in this deep sense.

4. Objections and Replies

4.1. The Fetishism Charge  
Critics liken the dutiful agent to a collector who values a postage stamp not for its artistry or its history but solely because it is “rare.” The content “doing the right thing” seems equally abstract and fetishistic. But the analogy misfires. A fetish object is valued for an accidental property without regard to what grounds that property. In the moral case, however, rightness is not an accidental label; it is systematically connected to the concrete features that make acts right. Valuing rightness therefore entails valuing an abstract property whose extension is fixed by those features. To fetishize X is to be indifferent to what makes something X; the dutiful agent, being committed to tracking rightness correctly, must care about those concrete grounds at the level of practical deliberation. Thus the DD-desire is not fetishistic provided it is operationalized via competent identification of right-makers.

4.2. The Alienation Worry  
Bernard Williams famously warns against a morality that “alienates” us from our projects and sentiments. Might the DD-desire crowd out the agent’s sympathy, love, and other humanly rich motives? Two points: (a) Sufficiency is not exclusivity. Saying the DD-desire can suffice for worth does not preclude additional motives. A father who saves his child “because it is morally required” acts praiseworthily even if he lacks affection—though we may fault him on other grounds. (b) In actual agents, the DD-desire typically integrates with first-order sentiments; it frames them rather than replaces them. Choosing to help a friend because it is right need not alienate me from her suffering; indeed, recognizing rightness often sharpens attention to those very sentiments. So alienation is neither necessary nor typical.

4.3. The Fragility Objection  
Because the DD-desire is second-order, it might seem motivationally fragile: in emotionally intense contexts, only direct concern for the victim’s pain will have sufficient oomph. Empirical evidence is mixed: some agents (Kantian principled resisters) do heroic deeds under severe stress. But more philosophically, sufficiency for worth does not entail superiority in reliability. Courage is praiseworthy even if rare; likewise a purely dutiful motive can be worthy even if many humans cannot sustain it.

5. Two Illustrative Cases

5.1. The Conscientious Lifeguard  
Sara is a professional lifeguard. During her shift she regularly scans the water, not from spontaneous bursts of empathy toward particular swimmers, but because she has internalized a policy: “Fulfill my moral-professional duty to keep patrons safe.” One afternoon she spots a child struggling and dives in. Her sole motivating thought is: “It’s my duty to rescue.” Is her act worthy? On the present account: yes. Her DD-desire is exercised competently (she perceives the concrete danger), it expresses respect for life and professional obligation, and it guides effective action. Intuitively, we praise Sara.

What if Sara had instead been moved by affection for that particular child’s laughter? That might seem warmer, but warmth is not the criterion of moral worth. The child’s welfare is secured in either case; the moral credit Sara earns stems from her steadfast commitment to duty.

5.2. The Bigoted but Self-Reflective Shopkeeper  
Call him Al. Al harbors racist antipathy that makes him averse to serving clients of a certain group. Over time he comes to acknowledge, resentfully, that such discrimination is morally wrong. Wanting “to do the morally right thing,” he suppresses his bigoted impulses and serves everyone equally. Al’s motive is purely dutiful; he feels no goodwill toward the disfavored group. Do we praise him? Common intuition: grudgingly yes. Moral progress sometimes begins with reluctant duty. My account validates that intuition: Al’s action has moral worth because the DD-desire successfully counters immoral inclinations. Worth is not maximal—he lacks the virtue of respect for persons at the emotional level—but it is genuine. Importantly, insisting that only de re concern for the customer’s dignity confers worth would condemn Al, thereby making moral improvement unduly demanding.

6. Situating the View in Contemporary Debate

6.1. Herman’s Patient and Korsgaard’s Reflexivity  
Barbara Herman argues that agents should be moved by the right-makers because practical reasoning is situated; attention to the concrete values keeps morality vivid. Christine Korsgaard replies that the kind of reflective endorsement that constitutes autonomy operates at the level of principle. My view aligns more with Korsgaard: respect for moral law as such expresses autonomy. Yet I incorporate Herman’s insight via the competence condition: only by attending to right-makers can an agent reliably execute the DD-desire.

6.2. Arpaly and Motivational Harmony  
Nomy Arpaly holds that moral worth accrues when an agent is responsive to moral reasons de re, whether or not she conceptualizes them as such. That allows Huck Finn’s rescue of Jim to be praiseworthy even though Huck misclassifies it as wrong. My account does not denigrate Huck; it simply offers an additional route to worth. There is no competition: responsiveness can be de re or de dicto. So we gain an inclusive account that captures a wider range of intuitions.

6.3. Hybrid, Not Monistic  
I resist the temptation to claim that only DD-motivation or only de re motivation suffices. Morality is pluralistic in the kinds of motivational grounding it tolerates. The sufficiency thesis is modest: DD-motivation is one legitimate ground of moral worth.

7. Conclusion

Acting from a desire to do what is morally right can indeed suffice for moral worth. The decisive factor is not the abstractness of the desire but (i) its expressive function—affirming morality’s authority—and (ii) the agent’s competence in linking that desire to the concrete right-making facts. When those two conditions obtain, the charge of fetishism collapses, alienation is optional rather than inherent, and the motivational pathway is robust enough to ground deserved praise.

In a moral landscape where agents vary widely—some sentimental, some principled, some conflicted—such inclusivity matters. A theory that demands perfectly virtuous sentiments for worth would exclude transitional agents laboring to overcome prejudice or weakness of will; conversely, a theory that valorizes only duty ignores the rich texture of human concern. Recognizing the sufficiency of the DD-desire supplements but does not eclipse other sources of moral worth. It reminds us that taking morality seriously, as morality, is itself a profound achievement of rational agency.

1. Introduction and Thesis

Suppose a nurse administers a painful injection to a child. She steels herself, reminding herself simply that it is morally required, even though the screams distress her. She does not, in that moment, feel sympathy for the child or think about the long‐range epidemiology of measles; what pushes her is a stark, “This is the right thing to do—so do it.” Is her motive adequate for moral worth? I shall defend a qualified Yes: a de dicto desire to do what is morally right can by itself ground praiseworthy action, provided (i) the agent is capable of identifying what is right on suitable grounds and (ii) the desire functions as an exercise of respect for the authority of morality rather than as a mere psychological quirk. On this view, moral worth lies not in the presence of warm fellow‐feeling but in the practical rational self‐governance that a duty‐centered motive expresses.

I proceed as follows. §2 distinguishes three kinds of moral motivation and locates the dispute. §3 sets out the “moral fetishism” objection, canvassing the arguments of Stocker, Smith, Wolf and Railton. §4 reconstructs Kant’s classic reply: when other motives conflict or go missing, the pure motive of duty displays the agent’s moral commitment. §5 develops a contemporary version of that reply. I argue that the de dicto desire to do the right thing (A) is not empty but imports the whole structure of first‐order moral reasons, (B) embodies a second‐order capacity that is uniquely valuable, and (C) meets the alienation worry once we attend to how it operates diachronically across cases. §6 addresses two further objections—coldness and epistemic luck—and §7 concludes.

2. Three Kinds of Moral Motivation

We need sharper distinctions than those usually offered.

1. Concrete de re desire: An affective or practical attraction toward the very features that make the act right—e.g., “because it relieves her suffering.”  
2. Abstract de dicto desire: A desire aimed at the property of rightness—“because it is morally right, whatever that turns out to be in this case.”  
3. Reflective (second‐order) endorsement: A standing commitment to regulate one’s will by what one judges right, regardless of what specific features ground that judgment.

The critics target (2), claiming that (1) or at least a combination of (1) and (3) is required for moral worth. Defenders of Kant hold that (2) together with (3) can suffice. My thesis is that (2) can carry the whole normative burden if it is understood as operating through (3).

3. The Fetishism and Alienation Objections

Michael Stocker’s “Schizophrenia of Modern Ethical Theories” inaugurates the worry: an honest friend who visits you only because it is his duty seems defective; we want him to come out of affection. Simon Keller’s dutiful husband, Susan Wolf’s moral saint, Mark Schroeder’s Huckleberry Finn in reverse—all aim to show that a purely duty‐oriented agent is missing the point of morality. The charge bifurcates:

(a) Fetishism: The agent fetishizes the abstract property of rightness, neglecting the substantive values that make the act right.  
(b) Alienation: By focusing on duty, the agent stands at a distance from her own projects and from the lives of others; her motive cannot intelligibly connect to what matters.

4. Kant’s Embryonic Reply

At crucial moments in the Groundwork, Kant insists that only actions “from duty” have moral worth. Commentators like Barbara Herman clarify that what matters is not coldness but rather the form of practical necessitation. If sympathy or prudence would have led one to the same act, we have no proof that the will is governed by respect for the moral law. This is not to denigrate sympathy; it is to say that respect for law shows its distinctive worth precisely when the law alone moves us. The moral fetishism objection worries that this turns the law into an idol. Kant’s deeper point is that the law is not one value among others: it is the formal principle that binds values into reasons for all rational beings.

5. A Contemporary Defense

A. De dicto motivation imports de re reasons  
Think of the ancient astronomer who wants “to believe what is true.” That desire is de dicto, yet to pursue it he must acquaint himself with planets, telescopes, and mathematics. Likewise, to act on the desire to “do the right thing” I must expose myself to the facts that make actions right—needs, welfare, justice, autonomy. The de dicto desire therefore channels me toward the very features critics fear it neglects. It is a regulating motive that continually reopens inquiry into what rightness demands.

B. Second‐order governance as distinctive value  
Harry Frankfurt showed that agency involves a hierarchy of desires; moral worth, I submit, attaches to an agent’s capacity to govern first‐order impulses by reflective commitment. The de dicto desire does precisely this. It is content‐free enough to be portable across contexts, yet contentful enough—because “rightness” is not arbitrary—to anchor deliberation. An agent who acts from this desire therefore manifests a special kind of reliability: she will do what morality requires even when local sympathies mislead or desert her.

C. Meeting the alienation worry  
Railton’s alienation critique presumes a snapshot perspective: we imagine the agent’s motive in one episode. Take a diachronic view. Over a life, feelings are fickle. Sometimes anger, exhaustion, or depression erode empathy. At those times, the agent guided by duty alone still visits the hospital, still tells the painful truth, still refrains from cruelty. Far from alienating her from what matters, the motive of duty reconciles her day‐to‐day conduct with her deepest evaluative commitments. It is the cement of identity over time, not an external constraint.

6. Two Remaining Objections

i. “The dutiful agent is emotionally cold.”  
Reply: Nothing in having the de dicto motive precludes also having warm concern. My claim is about sufficiency, not exclusivity. Moreover, some emotional distance may be morally salutary. The nurse’s composure shields the child from panic. Coldness is blameworthy only when it signals indifference, not when it is the by‐product of impartial self‐command.

ii. “Epistemic luck: An agent could fetishize rightness yet blunder about.”  
True, one can fetishize without understanding. But moral worth requires competence: the agent must reliably track what is right. That condition is implicit in any plausible theory; mere good intentions coupled with consistent mistake generate excuse, not praise. The objection therefore targets a straw man.

7. Conclusion

Acting solely from the desire to do what is morally right can, and sometimes must, suffice for moral worth. What makes such action praiseworthy is not any sentimental resonance with the concrete values at stake but the agent’s exercise of reflective self‐governance—her respect for the moral law as law. Far from being a fetish, the de dicto motive is the lynchpin that integrates shifting first‐order motives into a stable moral identity.

1. Framing the Question  

In the contemporary debate about moral motivation, two pictures compete.  
Picture A: The morally admirable agent is moved by the very considerations that make an act right—hurt is bad, promises create expectations, generosity relieves need, and so on. Here motivation is de re: the agent wants, of those actions, the ones that relieve need, keep promises, respect persons, etc.  
Picture B: The admirable agent might instead be moved by the abstract thought that “this is the right thing to do.” Here the desire is de dicto: to perform whatever act, whichever one it is, that morality requires.

Many worry that Picture B amounts to “moral fetishism.” A person who acts only because “it is required” seems alienated both from the human beings benefitted and from the concrete values at stake. We praise the friend who visits you in hospital because she cares about you, it is said, not the one who drops by merely because “it’s the morally right thing to do.”

I shall defend the following thesis.  

Thesis: Acting solely from a de dicto desire to do what is morally right can by itself confer full moral worth, provided (i) the desire is integrated into the agent’s practical deliberation in a way that renders her reliably sensitive to the right-making features of actions, and (ii) the desire expresses a rational recognition of morality’s authority rather than a pathological need for moral correctness. Moral fetishism is therefore not the inevitable consequence of de dicto motivation; the decisive issue is how the abstract desire is embedded in the agent’s rational psychology.

2. Key Distinctions

2.1 De dicto vs. de re desires  
A de re desire “to help this wounded stranger” targets some determinate state of affairs; a de dicto desire “to do what morality requires” is schematic. But the two are not exclusive. The de dicto desire often functions at a higher, architects’ level: once I settle that assisting the stranger is demanded, the de re project specifies means and details.

2.2 Standing vs. occurrent motive  
One might possess a standing de dicto commitment yet act in the moment from compassion. Conversely, a person whose emotions are exhausted might fall back on the standing commitment. Moral worth attaches primarily to the motivational profile that actually moves the agent on the occasion.

2.3 Conative vs. cognitive fetishism  
It is one thing to value only the moral property (fetishism about what is valued); another to value ordinary things but need the moral property as a cognitive trigger (fetishism about what explains one’s action). Critics often conflate the two. My thesis only concerns the second: the agent’s entry point into deliberation.

3. Three Arguments for the Sufficiency of Duty as Motive

3.1 The Argument from Rational Authority  
Morality purports to speak with overriding normative force. An agent who recognizes and responds to that authority, exactly as such, manifests a distinctive form of rational excellence: she allows herself to be guided by what she has most reason to do, period. That responsiveness is what Kant called “good will.” Praiseworthiness tracks the exercise of a capacity that everyone ought to cultivate—the capacity to see and to do what must be done because it must be done. Whether the authority reaches the agent through de re or de dicto channels is secondary; what matters is the rational submission itself.

3.2 The Reliability Argument  
First-order motives (sympathy, friendship, aesthetic delight) are circumstantially fragile. Affection cools, attention wanders, biases intrude. A higher-order de dicto commitment functions as a stabiliser. An agent who acts from duty alone is disposed to act rightly across a wider range of cases—including those where concrete sentiment is absent or counter-motivating. Reliability with respect to moral reasons is itself an excellence we have good grounds to admire.

3.3 The Epistemic Argument  
To turn the de dicto desire into action the agent must ask: “Which act, here and now, is the right one?” That question forces her to track the very considerations the critic says she ignores.
