The epistemic route from abstract desire to concrete choice runs through the right-making features. Hence acting from duty need not involve motivational blindness to concrete values; the route might be purely instrumental, yet the resulting sensitivity is genuine.

4. Replies to the Alienation and Fetishism Objections

Objection 1: The hospital visitor who comes “because it is right” seems chilly; she fails to value the friend for her own sake.  
Reply: Two confusions lurk. (a) The alleged chilliness is a phenomenological datum, not a moral one. We welcome warmth, but moral worth concerns what reasons one responds to, not what emotional colour accompanies the action. (b) Even if the visitor’s occurrent desire is de dicto, she need not lack affection or appreciation; she may simply find, on this occasion, that duty provides the motivational edge needed to overcome competing pulls (fatigue, deadlines, social anxiety). Kant’s own examples—of the melancholy philanthropist who gives out of duty when compassion has withered—are precisely cases where duty preserves value that sentimentalist motives might forfeit.

Objection 2: De dicto motivation is a “moral fetish”; the agent fetishises the moral property the way a collector fetishises stamps, valuing them not for their historical significance but for their being stamps.  
Reply: The analogy misfires. The stamp fetishist’s desire bypasses the reasons stamps might matter (history, artistry). In contrast, the de dicto-motivated agent is committed to acting in accordance with whatever reasons there are. Her concern is not with a bare property but with the normative force that property signals. Unlike the fetishist, she stands ready to abandon any act once she learns it is not required. That flexibility is incompatible with fetishistic fixation.

Objection 3: De dicto action is heteronomous—one’s will is dictated by an external code rather than one’s own evaluative outlook.  
Reply: When the agent endorses the moral law as authoritative for her deliberation, the law is no longer external. It is integrated into her practical identity; she governs herself by reasons that she, upon reflection, recognises as decisive. Autonomy is preserved.

5. Why De Dicto Motivation Is (Often) More, Not Less, Praiseworthy

Suppose two drivers notice a child who has fallen in traffic. Alice swerves because the child’s distress horrifies her; Ben swerves because “saving the child is morally required.” Both succeed. Which is more praiseworthy?

Factors relevant to praise:

(a) Effort and cost. If Ben overrides strong self-regarding incentives (he risks injury) solely because of duty, the exertion of will displays greater commitment than Alice’s spontaneous empathic reaction.

(b) Scope of concern. Alice might respond similarly only to children whose vulnerability triggers her affection mechanisms. Ben is disposed to save any endangered person, including those who elicit no sympathy. That broader scope constitutes a deeper recognition of impartial moral reasons.

(c) Stability across contexts. Empathy is notoriously susceptible to distance, statistical abstraction, and prejudice; a duty-motive is not.

These considerations show that de dicto motivation is not the poor cousin of concrete concern. Depending on circumstances, it may reveal a morally superior responsiveness.

6. Two Clarifying Examples

Example 1: The Decisive Judge  
A judge must impose a sentence on an affable but corrupt official. The official’s charm naturally engenders sympathy. The judge sets aside these feelings and sentences strictly according to the law because “justice requires it.” We do not brand the judge a fetishist. Her abstract thought that “this is what justice demands” secures impartiality—exactly what we want from an upright judiciary.

Example 2: The Exhausted Parent  
A parent caring for a colicky infant at 3 a.m. may feel no warmth, only bone-deep weariness. Yet she gets up “because it is my duty as a parent.” Her motive is de dicto, but we would scarcely deny her praise. Indeed we often think such late-night ministrations are worthier than the daytime play that flows effortlessly from affection; perseverance in duty amidst depleted emotion reveals steadfast love through another channel.

Both examples undercut the empirical claim that de dicto motivation alienates the agent from concrete values. The judge cares about justice; the parent cares about the child. Their route to action travels through duty because alternative motivational paths are blocked or morally risky.

7. Limits and Residual Questions

I have argued that the duty motive can suffice for moral worth, but two limits merit notice.

Limit 1: Content ignorance. If the agent’s de dicto desire does not pass through an accurate representation of right-making features—say she uncritically obeys a moral authority figure—then praise is attenuated. Acting “because it is right” when one’s belief about rightness is the product of bias or dogma does not manifest the rational excellence I defended. The epistemic component matters.

Limit 2: Crowding-out. There is empirical evidence (e.g., in crowding-out studies on charitable giving) that emphasising duty sometimes dampens spontaneous concern. If de dicto emphasis systematically eclipses morally healthy sentiments, the agent’s character may be lopsided. While isolated dutiful acts can suffice for moral worth, a wholly sentiment-less life would fall short of the human good. Still, that is a structural, not an occasion-specific, criticism.

Conclusion

The fetishism charge rests on a misunderstanding of how abstract moral commitment operates within practical agency. A de dicto desire to do what is morally right can supply all that is needed for moral worth, provided it is (i) the operative motive, (ii) guided by an informed appreciation of the right-making features, and (iii) expressive of rational recognition of morality’s authority. In many real-world cases duty not only suffices but excels, securing impartiality, reliability, and steadfastness where more sentimental motives falter. Moral philosophy should therefore resist any simple preference for concrete over abstract motives and instead appraise how agents integrate the two within the architecture of their deliberative lives.

1. Introduction and Thesis

Can a person who cares only about “doing the right thing” act with full moral worth, even when no more concrete sentiment—compassion, friendship, love of beauty—animates her? Common‐sense moral psychology says no: someone who pulls a child from a raging river because “that is what morality requires,” without an ounce of fellow‐feeling, strikes us as cold, even repellent. Philosophers have echoed this reaction. Michael Stocker worries that obsession with “right‐making features” breeds moral schizophrenia; Berys Gaut calls it “moral fetishism;” Susan Wolf remarks that the “moral saint” seems deeply alienated from what actually makes life valuable. The shared suggestion is that a purely de dicto desire to do what is right​—​a desire aimed at the property of rightness as such​—​cannot confer genuine praiseworthiness.

My thesis cuts against this consensus: acting solely from the motive of duty can suffice for moral worth, and, under certain recognizable conditions, can be morally exemplary. The core of the case is that the de dicto desire to do what is right, far from being an empty abstraction, can itself be a substantive expression of respect for persons and of one’s own practical agency. When sincerely held, it manifests an appreciation of others as bearers of moral claims and of oneself as answerable to those claims. This “respectful agency” is valuable in its own right. Moreover, a purely dutiful motive need not exhibit the psychological defects critics allege; alienation and fetishism arise only when the motive of duty is malformed, not when it is operating properly. Finally, a commitment to rightness plays an indispensable architectonic role: it integrates and adjudicates competing concrete values, providing a stable and impartial standpoint that nothing else can fully supply. These points together show that the motive of duty can, without supplementation, ground praiseworthy action.

The argument proceeds in four stages. Section 2 clarifies the central concepts: de dicto vs. de re moral desire, moral worth, and praiseworthiness. Section 3 rebuts three leading objections​—​the fetishism charge, the alienation worry, and the “missing value” objection​—​showing that each either misdiagnoses the motivational structure of dutiful action or demands more than moral worth requires. Section 4 presents a positive account: a dutiful action has moral worth when it (i) is guided by a reliable capacity to discern rightness, (ii) springs from a standing commitment to treat persons with respect, and (iii) expresses autonomous authorship of one’s choices. Section 5 illustrates the view with concrete cases and highlights its explanatory advantages. Section 6 concludes by situating the account within broader debates between Kantian and virtue-ethical approaches.

2. Clarifying the Terrain

2.1 De dicto vs. de re moral motivation  
A de dicto moral desire is directed at an act under the description “an action that is morally right.” It is structurally second-order: the agent wants, of her available options, whichever one is right. By contrast, de re moral motivation tracks the particular features that make an action right (its promoting wellbeing, keeping a promise, etc.) without invoking the abstract property of rightness. The same action can of course be motivated both de dicto and de re; the present question isolates the first component.

2.2 Moral worth and praiseworthiness  
Kant draws a celebrated distinction between doing what is right and doing it “from duty.” Only the latter possesses moral worth and calls for esteem. Contemporary discourse often replaces “moral worth” with “praiseworthiness,” but retains the core idea: an action is praiseworthy insofar as it manifests the agent’s morally excellent dispositions. I shall follow this usage: to say that a motive suffices for moral worth is to say that when an agent acts from that motive (and the action is in fact right), she merits moral praise.

3. Three Objections Reassessed

3.1 The fetishism charge (Michael Smith, Berys Gaut)  
A fetishist, famously, is invested in an object because of one of its properties while ignoring its substantive features. Analogously, the de dicto moral agent is said to fetishize the property “rightness,” treating it as an “occult property stamped on actions,” divorced from the concrete values ethics is about. Two replies undermine this parallel.

First, the fetishism analogy overlooks the epistemic structure of moral deliberation. Except in toy cases, agents are uncertain about which particular consideration—welfare, fairness, promise-keeping—ultimately justifies a given act. A standing desire to do what is right functions as an epistemic heuristic: it directs practical attention toward whichever reasons, once fully assessed, turn out to be decisive. That is not fetishistic; it is a rational strategy for dealing with uncertainty.

Second, the fetishism worry presupposes that the de dicto desire crowds out other motivations. But the claim under dispute is only that the de dicto motive can be sufficient, not that it must be the only motive. Even when it is the sole conscious motive, an agent’s cognitive access to rightness requires that she understand at least some concrete moral reasons. Otherwise she could not identify an action as right in the first place. The abstract desire is thus necessarily connected to substantive value, undermining the fetishism comparison.

3.2 The alienation worry (Stocker, Wolf)  
On this view, a person moved solely by duty is estranged from personal projects and affections that give human life its texture; she is “too morally buttoned-up” to be an attractive character. Two points blunt the force of this critique.

Alienation from value vs. alienation from the agent. What Wolf and Stocker document are cases where dutiful motivation alienates the agent from her own desires (she helps a friend because it is right, not because she cares). That may indeed make the agent less lovable, but it does not show that her action lacks moral worth. The question before us is narrower: are we entitled to praise her morally? The fact that she sets aside her private attachments for the sake of duty can itself ground moral admiration, even if it limits her personal flourishing.

Second, the charge presupposes that a robust moral life and rich personal attachments cannot coexist. But history brims with counterexamples: consider the abolitionists who, moved by the moral law alone, repudiated prevailing sentiments. Their lives were not emotionally impoverished; rather, their de dicto commitment to rightness structured and deepened their other attachments by preventing complicity in injustice. Alienation is not a necessary consequence of dutiful motivation; it is, at most, a contingent possibility.

3.3 The missing-value objection  
A final critique says that an act motivated only by respect for rightness fails to register what is actually valuable in the world. The rescuer who saves a child “because it is right” supposedly misses the point: the child’s life is what matters, not the abstract property of rightness. This objection conflates motivational focus with evaluative recognition. To intend to do what is right just is to intend an action whose right-making features one believes to obtain. One cannot form the de dicto intention without also representing those features. The difference is merely which representation moves the will. The rescuer need not be oblivious to the child’s life; she simply channels her motivational energy through the practical judgment that saving the child is morally required. No evaluative blindness ensues.

4. A Positive Account: Respectful Agency

Having cleared the ground, we can state a sufficiency thesis:

A right action performed solely from the motive of duty possesses moral worth when the agent’s de dicto desire embodies (i) reliability in tracking rightness, (ii) respect for persons as ends, and (iii) autonomous authorship.

4.1 Reliability condition  
Moral worth presupposes that the agent is not merely lucky. Her de dicto desire must be guided by a reliable cognitive capacity—practical wisdom, conscience, or reflective equilibrium—that tends to identify right action in varied circumstances. Without this, the action is akin to a fortunate accident; praise attaches to competence, not chance.

4.2 Respect condition  
Why is the abstract concern with rightness valuable? Because the property “being morally right” is not a metaphysical curiosity but the normative shadow of a deeper moral reality: the status of persons as bearers of claims. A desire to act rightly is, when properly formed, a desire to stand in the relations of respect that persons are owed. Kant called this the “recognition of the authority of the moral law.” Such recognition is itself a mode of valuing persons, one uniquely suited to pluralistic contexts where we cannot always be moved by affection or fellow-feeling. The dutiful motive therefore instantiates moral value rather than bypassing it.

4.3 Autonomy condition  
Finally, moral worth attaches to actions that agents author. A purely instinctive impulse, or an act performed under hypnosis, though causally connected to rightness, would not be praiseworthy. The de dicto desire to obey morality is paradigmatically an exercise of self-legislation: the agent treats the moral standard as one she endorses, not merely as an external pressure. Praiseworthiness attaches to this self-governing stance.

Notice that these conditions do not smuggle concrete motives back in. The agent could entirely lack sympathetic feelings or personal attachments; as long as she meets reliability, respect, and autonomy, her action earns moral praise. Yet the account also explains why many purely dutiful agents will in fact cultivate emotions like sympathy: these feelings assist reliability and deepen their grasp of respect. The view thus harmonizes with common intuition while affirming the sufficiency of duty.

5. Illustrative Cases

5.1 The Flooded Hospital  
Dr. Hayes must decide whether to stay at her flooded hospital to care for patients or flee to ensure her own safety. Exhausted and numb, she feels no compassion; what moves her is the firm judgment, “It would be wrong to abandon them.” She stays. Dr. Hayes satisfies all three conditions. Her medical training and moral reflection supply reliability; her choice stems from respect for vulnerable persons; and she acts autonomously, having considered alternatives. Intuition says her conduct is praiseworthy despite the absence of warm feelings. The sufficiency thesis captures this.

5.2 The Chilly Bystander  
Sam, walking by a pond, sees a child drowning. He feels no empathy but recalls that morality requires one to rescue at small cost. He wades in and saves the child. Critics might deride Sam as cold, yet most of us would still praise him—certainly more than the onlooker who walks by for fear of muddy shoes. What matters morally is that Sam responded to the child’s claim on him, albeit under the description “morally required.” Again, sufficiency holds.

5.3 The Bigoted Reformer  
Consider instead Clara, raised with racist attitudes. She endorses the maxim “always do what is right,” but her empirical beliefs are corrupt: she mistakenly judges segregation right. She campaigns to maintain Jim Crow. Clara fails the reliability condition; hence her dutiful motive confers no moral worth. The view explains why de dicto desire is not automatically praiseworthy—properly functioning moral cognition is essential.

6. Positioning the View

6.1 Relation to virtue ethics  
Virtue ethicists insist that acting rightly requires being motivated by the right reasons in the right way. I agree—my autonomy and respect conditions echo this. Where we differ is over whether concrete affective motives are necessary. The sufficiency thesis says no: what counts is the quality of practical judgment and the stance of respect, not the phenomenology of compassion. Virtue ethics is right to valorize traits like generosity; it errs in treating them as the only route to moral worth.

6.2 Kantian lineage  
The account draws openly on Kant’s notion of respect for the moral law, but it revises Kant in two ways. First, it refrains from marginalizing empirical feelings; they can play a constructive role in reliability. Second, it treats the duty motive as one valuable form of moral motivation among several, rather than the sole locus of worth. Still, the Kantian thesis that respect for law can alone ground moral worth is vindicated.

6.3 Practical implications  
Recognizing the sufficiency of duty has social importance. In institutional contexts—judges, police, civil servants—we often need agents to act on principle precisely when sympathy is unreliable or dangerous. A culture that disparages the motive of duty risks undermining these roles. Conversely, acknowledging the moral worth of principle fortifies integrity in complex pluralistic societies.

7. Conclusion

The debate over duty’s sufficiency is, at bottom, a debate about what we honor in moral agency. Critics focus on the warmth of the agent’s heart; defenders of duty emphasize the clarity of her conscience. I have argued that the latter orientation is enough for moral praise, provided it is competently and autonomously exercised in a spirit of respect. The de dicto desire to do what is morally right is neither fetishistic nor alienating when properly formed; it is a distinctive expression of the value that persons, including oneself, matter. An agent who acts from this motive shows herself answerable to the moral community and worthy of our esteem.

1. Introduction: The Charge of “Moral Fetishism”  
The thought that moral worth requires more than a bare concern to “do the right thing” is intuitive and widespread. We admire the Samaritan who helps because the injured stranger is in pain, not—so the worry goes—because she is checking off a box labelled Right Action.  Philosophers (Williams, Stocker, Smith, Arpaly, Markovits, and others) have developed this worry into the charge of moral fetishism: the dutiful agent is fixated on an abstract property (rightness) and thereby estranges herself from the concrete values that make actions right.  But is that charge inevitably correct?  Must an agent motivated only by a de dicto desire to do what is morally right lack the moral worth we praise?  

I shall defend three claims:

1. A de dicto desire to do what is morally right can be sufficient for moral worth, provided it is suitably integrated into the agent’s overall motivational psychology.  
2. What makes such action praiseworthy is not the presence of any particular first-order, de re concern (for pain relief, flourishing, justice, etc.) but the quality of the agent’s will—specifically, her reliable responsiveness to the reasons that morally matter.  
3. The fetishism worry conflates two importantly different phenomena: (a) motivational structure (whether the agent’s highest-order desire is de dicto or de re) and (b) deliberative competence (whether the agent can recognize and appropriately respond to right-making features).  When these are separated, we see that the alienation critique targets only certain deficient versions of de dicto motivation, not the form itself.

If this argument succeeds, then acting solely from duty can be fully morally worthy, though—as I concede at the end—there may be dimensions of admiration (e.g., warmth, grace) that distinguish the person who helps from affection from the person who helps from principle.

2. Setting the Table: Distinctions We Need  

Distinction 1: De dicto vs. de re moral motivation  
• De re (of the thing) concern: a desire directed at the concrete right-making factor itself—e.g., “I want to alleviate that child’s suffering.”  
• De dicto (of the description) concern: “I want, whatever it is, to do what is morally right.”  

Distinction 2: Occurrent vs. standing motive  
One might have a standing de dicto commitment while deliberating occurrently about the child’s pain.  The fetishism charge typically targets the case where the de dicto desire is the sole occurrent motive.  

Distinction 3: Guidance vs. production  
A desire can guide deliberation (set the standard) even if it is not what moves the body to act; conversely, it can produce action without sophisticated guidance.  Confusing these roles makes the fetish charge look stronger than it is.  

Distinction 4: Worth vs. optimal worth  
An action can meet a threshold of praiseworthiness without incarnating the most admirable motive possible.  The fetishist objector often slides from “not optimally virtuous” to “not morally worthy at all.”  

With these distinctions in hand, the dialectic can proceed more cleanly.

3. A Kantian Point Rehabilitated  
Kant famously argued that only actions done from duty have moral worth.  Many find the view extreme, but its core insight remains potent: moral worth tracks the agent’s recognition of obligating reasons and her reliable commitment to act on them.  Kant’s own account is richer than the familiar caricature.  He denies neither sympathy nor love any value; he only insists that their moral worth is contingent unless undergirded by the regulative idea of duty.  If my kindness evaporates when I am in a foul mood, the underlying good will is revealed to be fragile.  A de dicto commitment to do right, by contrast, is structurally aimed at stability and impartiality; it aspires to act “from the moral law.”

Notice how this line of thought already loosens the fetishism charge: the de dicto desire is not fixating on an empty property but on a norm that bundles together, in one place, all the concrete considerations that make acts right.  Saying “I want to do what morality demands” is (if morality is correctly understood) tantamount to saying “I want to respond appropriately to suffering, flourishing, autonomy, fairness, promise-keeping, etc., in whatever proportion they merit.”  The abstract label can function as a compressed representation of those concrete reasons, not a mysterious substitute for them.

An analogy: a conscientious physician might declare, “My professional aim is to promote the patient’s health.”  Is she thereby fetishising “health” as an abstract property?  That seems an odd complaint.  The general aim is what enables her to navigate an indefinite variety of particular symptoms, treatments, and trade-offs.  Likewise, “do what is right” can be a regulative commitment that efficiently encodes diverse moral data.

4. The Reliability Argument  
The first positive argument that a purely de dicto motive can suffice for moral worth is reliability under epistemic, motivational, and situational strain.

(A) Epistemic strain.  Some right-making features are invisible to untutored perception.  Exploitative labor practices in a distant supply chain, for instance, are not salient to my empathic concern the way a bleeding pedestrian is.  A standing commitment to do what is right motivates investigation: “Is buying this shirt permissible?”  The de dicto desire reaches outward for relevant facts even when no de re affect is triggered.

(B) Motivational strain.  My sympathies are subject to bias—toward the near, the similar, the cute.  The de dicto desire is by definition impartial.  It prompts me to override partiality where required.  Consider Milgram’s experiment: someone who refused to shock only because “this seems morally wrong” exemplified justified de dicto motivation even in the teeth of experimenter pressure.

(C) Situational strain.  When fatigued, anxious, or angered, our de re concerns wax and wane.  A higher-order de dicto commitment can supply resolve: I may not feel like paying the onerous tax bill, yet I do so because it is the right thing.  The resulting honesty is morally worthy even if no warm empathy motivates compliance.

Reliability is morally relevant because morality itself is demanding across contexts; a motive that tracks right-making considerations stably is therefore a legitimate basis for praise.

5. Objection 1: Understanding and Alienation  
Critics emphasize a worry about understanding: “If you rescue me solely ‘because it’s right,’ you don’t really grasp—or care about—my suffering; you treat me as an occasion for the exercise of moral purity.”  The reply invokes Distinctions 1 and 3.  To deliberate under the description “morally required” one must (if competent) understand at least the gist of why it is required.  In normal agents, the de dicto desire is not satisfied by zombie compliance; it is satisfied only by seeing that the action is right, which involves some recognition of relevant concrete features.  Just as a chess player who aims to make “the best move in the position” must appreciate, at least minimally, the threats and resources on the board, a morally dutiful agent must appreciate that you are in distress.

Moreover, accusations of alienation overlook the second-personal dimension of moral address.  If you ask, “Why did you help me?” and I say, “Because alleviating your suffering mattered,” that answer is intelligible.  But another fully intelligible answer is, “Because it would have been wrong not to.”  Indeed, that reply signals regard: it treats you as a bearer of moral claims that obligate me.  Conforming to duty is a way of taking the other’s standpoint seriously (to borrow Darwall’s phrasing).

6. Objection 2: Motivational Richness  
The critic may accept sufficiency but downgrade the value: “Yes, dutiful action has some worth, but it is less worthy than action from love or compassion.”  Two points:

First, there are contexts where de dicto duty is not merely second-best but superior.  Suppose a judge must sentence a defendant who elicits her sympathy.  The right sentence may be severe.  If the judge’s compassion sways her from the legally and morally correct outcome, her action lacks worth; if her impartial de dicto commitment to justice secures the appropriate sentence, that commitment is not a consolation prize.

Second, degrees of worth can co-exist in a pluralistic landscape.  A doctor moved by both duty and compassion might display the highest worth; a doctor moved solely by duty still merits praise; a doctor moved only by profit merits none.  The key claim defended here is sufficiency for genuine moral worth, not for maximal worth.

7. Objection 3: De dicto Motivation and Moral Epistemic Luck  
What if the agent’s conception of “morally right” is substantively mistaken yet she acts from duty?  A fanatical inquisitor burns heretics “because it is right.”  Surely that is not praiseworthy.  True.  But the problem is not that the motive is de dicto; it is that the agent’s moral epistemology is gravely defective.  Any account of moral worth must include a correctness or tracking condition: the agent’s motive must be appropriately connected to the actual right-making reasons.  Add that condition and the inquisitor case is dispatched.  Notice that the same issue arises for de re motives: someone might save a drowning dog out of love for canines while ignoring the drowning human beside it; we would withhold praise there, too, because the response fails to track morally decisive reasons.

8. A Neo-Kantian Synthesis: Quality of Will and Competence  
We are now positioned to articulate a general account.

Definition (Good Will Condition): An action has moral worth iff it issues from a will that (i) is stably disposed to act in conformity with moral reasons and (ii) does so because those reasons have normative authority for the agent.  

Definition (Competence Condition): A will is disposed as in (i) only if the agent exercises sufficient moral competence—sensitivity to, and grasp of, the considerations that in fact make actions right.  

On this model a purely de dicto desire satisfies (i) as long as, in tandem with the agent’s cognition, it tracks right-making features; it satisfies (ii) because the agent acts under the authority of morality.  No de re motive is required.  The model also explains why fetishistic caricatures fail: a “moral fetishist” who robotically recites “do right” yet cannot identify what rightness demands would flunk the competence condition.

9. A Concrete Case Study  
Laura faces a choice: return an erroneously received tax refund of $8,000 or keep the windfall.  No identifiable individual will be visibly hurt; the money would be absorbed into the Treasury.  Laura feels no sympathetic pangs—no child is weeping in front of her—but she does have a firm resolve to do what is right.  She deliberates, recalls that keeping money you are not entitled to is dishonest, that a fair tax system relies on truthfulness, and that her society’s public goods are at stake.  She returns the money.

Is Laura’s act morally worthy?  If one insists that only compassion or some other concrete affect confers worth, the answer must be no.  That seems implausible.  We would justly praise her integrity, especially given the temptation and anonymity.  What grounds our praise is precisely that she recognized moral reasons and acted from them.  The case shows how de dicto motivation can be laudable even when de re emotions are inert.

10. Why the Fetishism Worry Persists  
Part of what fuels the worry is an aesthetic preference: we like warmth, immediacy, the human touch.  A merely dutiful act can feel cold.  But moral worth and likability are distinct.  Stocker’s hospital visitor, who visits a friend solely from duty, may be less endearing than the visitor moved by love, yet her fidelity remains praiseworthy.  The aesthetic datum therefore does not underwrite the normative conclusion that de dicto motivation is insufficient for worth.

Another source of unease is a metaphysical vision of moral agency as rooted in sentiment (Humean tradition).  If reasons are motivationally inert absent desire, the de dicto motive can seem mysteriously self-propelling.  But on any plausible psychology, de dicto motives are desires too—albeit higher-order normative desires.  Modern empirical work on “principled” or “rule-based” moral motivation lends support: individuals scoring highly on principled moral identity measures display stable, cross-situational moral behaviour even when emotion is muted.

11. What About Virtue Ethics?  
Virtue ethicists prize finely-tuned concern for the concrete particulars.  Does the foregoing sideline the virtues?  Not necessarily.  We can treat the virtues as the traits that enable competent tracking of reasons.  Courage, compassion, and generosity provide epistemic and motivational sensitivity to right-making features; the de dicto commitment provides integrative governance.  The best moral psychology has both elements.  What I resist is the leap from “virtues add value” to “dutiful resolve alone never suffices.”

12. Degrees of Worth and the Plurality of Praise  
While sufficiency is my main thesis, a full moral phenomenology admits that some dutiful actions shine brighter than others.  Three scaling variables are salient:

(1) Epistemic depth: how fully the agent grasps the concrete reasons.  
(2) Motivational harmony: whether the de dicto motive conflicts with or is supported by de re motives.  
(3) Costliness: the sacrifice endured.  

Laura’s tax honesty scores high on (3), moderate on (2), moderate on (1); it is clearly praiseworthy.  A second agent, Sabrina, who loves public goods and feels vivid concern for fairness, would score even higher on (2) and (1).  There is room for gradation without denying Laura’s worth.

13. Conclusion  
Acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can suffice for moral worth.  The key is the integration of that de dicto desire within a competent, reason-responsive will.  The fetishism worry recedes once we distinguish motivational structure from deliberative competence: fetishism is a pathology of incompetence, not an inevitable feature of de dicto motivation.  A purely dutiful agent may lack certain graces of sentiment, but she possesses the central virtue of integrity—steadfast responsiveness to moral reasons—and that is enough to deserve praise.

1. Introduction and Thesis

Is an agent who saves a drowning child “just because it is the morally right thing to do,” yet who feels no particular warmth toward the child, worthy of praise? A broad tradition stretching from Aristotle to Michael Stocker and Susan Wolf says no. Such a rescuer, we are told, is a moral fetishist: she fixates on the abstract property of rightness while remaining alienated from the very features that make the act right (the child’s terror, the value of her life). I will argue that this verdict is too quick. A de dicto motive—“to do what is morally right”—can by itself be sufficient for moral worth, provided it is suitably integrated into the agent’s practical psychology. What makes such austere dutiful action praiseworthy is (i) the way it embodies a distinctively rational form of responsiveness to moral reasons, (ii) the way it secures impartial reliability across contexts, and (iii) the respect it pays to the moral law and, derivatively, to persons as bearers of that law. Although a purely dutiful agent may lack certain attractive traits (e.g., spontaneous sympathy), her actions are still worthy of moral admiration because they manifest self-governance under the authority of morality itself. In defending this thesis, I will (A) clarify the relevant motivational distinctions, (B) diagnose the standard “fetishism” objection, (C) show how a de dicto motive can nevertheless track the concrete right-making features, and (D) explain what kind of praise is appropriate.

2. Clarifying De dicto and De re Moral Motivation

Following Mark Schroeder, call a de re desire one that targets a specific property or object: “I want to relieve that child’s suffering.” A de dicto desire is more abstract: “I want to do what morality requires.” Two errors must be avoided. First, a de dicto desire is not necessarily content-less; it has the content of moral requirement, even if the agent cannot yet specify which act that is. Second, “solely motivated by duty” can mean either that the de dicto desire is the agent’s only first-order desire relevant to the act or that it is the decisive desire at the moment of action. For concreteness, assume the strongest version: the agent’s *only* relevant motivational state is the abstract desire to comply with moral duty.

A further distinction: we can assess (i) the *moral worth* of the action (roughly Kant’s Frage: does it express good will?) and (ii) the *attractiveness* of the agent’s character (would we like such a person as a friend?). The fetishism objection typically conflates these dimensions. I will concede that a merely dutiful agent may be less lovable than a compassionate one, yet maintain that her actions are fully morally worthy in Kant’s sense.

3. The Standard Objection: Moral Fetishism and Alienation

3.1 Stocker’s Schizophrenic Pleasures.   Stocker portrays a friend who visits you in the hospital “for duty’s sake” alone; you feel disappointed, as though she cared not for *you* but for an abstraction. The moral seems to be that friendship demands de re motives.

3.2 Wolf’s Moral Saints.   Wolf argues that agents whose every choice is driven by moral duty lack the variety of interests and affections constitutive of a rich human life; they are in that sense unattractive ideals.

3.3 Smith’s Fetishism charge.   Michael Smith worries that an agent motivated only by the de dicto desire to do right lacks sensitivity to the reasons that make something right; her motive is, as it were, pointed in the wrong direction.

Underlying all three is a transition from: “The agent’s motive is purely de dicto” to “The agent is insensitive to the right-making reasons,” and from there to “The action lacks moral worth.” The two transitions are not mandatory; the middle premise can be denied.

4. Why De dicto Motivation Need Not Be Insensitive

Imagine Anna, who faces three options: rescue the child (R), scroll her phone (P), or taunt the child (T). Anna possesses a single desire: to do what morality requires. She investigates which act is morally required, concludes it is R, and acts accordingly. Does Anna care about the child’s welfare? At the level of first-order desires, no. But at the level of *reasons-responsiveness* she is perfectly keyed to them: had she discovered that relieving the child’s terror *wasn’t* morally required (say, because someone else was already rescuing the child and interfering would worsen matters), she would not have leapt in.

Consider a thermostat. It has a higher-order aim: keep the room at 20 °C. It does not “care” about the specific chemical processes by which the heater reaches that temperature; nonetheless, it is exquisitely sensitive to them. Likewise, an agent whose highest-order desire is “comply with moral reasons” can track all the fine-grained right-making features via her *beliefs*. The de dicto desire supplies the motivational force; the beliefs supply the informational content. Together they solve the practical problem.

The fetishism charge presupposes that genuine sensitivity must be encoded in desire rather than belief. But that is a gratuitous restriction. We routinely explain action as the product of a general desire plus a context-specific belief: “He wants to stay healthy and therefore takes vitamin C because he believes it promotes immunity.” Why should morality be special?

5. The Positive Case for Praiseworthiness

5.1 Autonomy under Moral Law.   Kant’s central insight is that moral worth attaches to acts done from reverence for the law. What impresses us in Anna is her capacity to guide herself by a principle she recognizes as having unconditional authority. This is a triumph of *practical reason*: she does not merely happen to act rightly; she *makes it* the ground of her action. The kind of praise appropriate here is not warmth but esteem: respect for her self-legislation.

5.2 Reliability and Impartiality.   Concrete motives such as sympathy, though charming, are notoriously selective: we feel them more toward the near, the similar, the photogenic. A de dicto motive is impartial by construction; it commits the agent to *whoever* happens to need help, whether or not the situation tugs at her heartstrings. That reliability is itself a praiseworthy moral asset. If we imagine an “ice-hearted” but purely dutiful lifeguard, we may prefer him on a bad day to a warm-hearted but distractible one.

5.3 Respect for Persons as Ends.   Far from alienating the agent from concrete value, the de dicto motive can *express* respect for it. To treat the child’s welfare as a *moral requirement* is to take her interests with ultimate seriousness, elevating them to a categorical imperative. In Kantian language, the child’s rational nature legislates a claim on my will; acting from duty acknowledges that claim precisely as such. The alternative—acting merely from inclination—risks treating the child as an object of sentimental preference rather than as a rightful claimant.

6. Replies to Leading Objections

Objection 1: The Dutiful Agent Is Cold and Therefore Unlovely  
Reply: Lovability and moral worth are separate axes. We rightly cherish benevolent dispositions, but the question at hand is whether an action can *merit moral praise*. Even Hume distinguishes between the *agreeable* and the *virtuous*. The stoic who suppresses feelings but acts from reason may be less agreeable, yet virtuous nonetheless.

Objection 2: The Agent Would Act Well Only If Convinced It Is Morally Required; This Shows a Lack of Direct Concern  
Reply: True, but that conditionality is exactly what rational agency demands. We want agents whose actions vary with reasons, not with the ebb and flow of sentiment. The worry confuses motivational *structure* with motivational *content*. That my desire is “act as required” does not show indifference to persons; it shows reverence for the norm that protects them.

Objection 3: The Dutiful Agent Misses Something Ethically Important—E.g., the Virtue of Compassion  
Reply: I happily concede she lacks some virtues. Moral worth is not an all-or-nothing trophy; different traits warrant different kinds of praise. Pure duty secures the virtue of justice; compassion secures the virtue of benevolence. An agent can possess one without the other. The question was sufficiency, not exhaustiveness.

Objection 4: If Everyone Were Purely Dutiful, Human Life Would Be Bleak  
Reply: Perhaps, but that is a sociological worry. The claim that a motive suffices for moral worth does not imply it is optimal for human flourishing. Stoic sages might be rare but still exemplify a form of moral excellence.

7. A Refined Hybrid View?

One might grant my arguments yet insist that the *best* motivational profile integrates both de dicto and de re elements. I agree. There is no conflict in practice: the dutiful agent can cultivate sympathetic feelings as auxiliary motives. Kant himself encourages promoting helpful inclinations because they facilitate duty. But acknowledging the value of such hybridity is consistent with maintaining that duty alone crosses the threshold of moral worth.

8. An Illustrative Triad

Consider three rescuers:

Ben: Acts from spontaneous empathy for the child.  
Carol: Acts from mixed motives: empathy plus a sense of duty.  
Dana: Feels nothing particular but acts solely from the conviction that rescue is morally required.

How should we rank them?

Sympathy: Ben = Carol > Dana  
Reliability across impartial cases: Dana = Carol > Ben  
Moral worth (as responsiveness to the authority of morality): Carol = Dana > Ben

Thus Dana ties for first in the dimension that Kant—and the present question—focuses on, even though she performs worse on other admirable dimensions. This suggests that the fetishism objection stems from importing extra criteria (friendliness, warmth) into the assessment of *moral* worth.

9. Why the Fetishism Label Misfires

A fetish involves fixating on a property divorced from its normal context (e.g., a shoe independent of the person). But morality as such is not an accidental property; it *just is* the totality of right-making features, summarised under the normative concept “what ought to be done.” To desire to do the right thing is to orient one’s will toward *whatever* set of features turns out to have that property. Far from being an alien abstraction, “moral rightness” is a meta-level pointer that tracks the concrete values in a systematic way.

10. The Role of Moral Epistemology

A worry persists: what if the agent misidentifies the right action? Would her de dicto motive still confer worth? I follow Kant’s dictum that moral worth requires acting “for the sake of duty” *and* in a way that accords with duty. Thus mistaken duty (e.g., the well-meaning inquisitor) lacks worth not because the motive is de dicto but because the deed is wrong. Moral worth demands success under the aspect of duty plus the right kind of motive. That further underscores the importance of linking the de dicto desire with rational deliberation and evidence.

11. Comparative Cases: Epistemic and Aesthetic Duty

Our intuitions in non-moral domains support my view. A scientist who pursues truth *because it is true* rather than out of personal curiosity is praiseworthy. An art critic who judges paintings by the *standards of artistic excellence*, indifferent to personal taste, earns esteem. In neither case do we accuse the agent of “epistemic fetishism” or “aesthetic alienation.” We praise their principled commitment. Morality should be no different.

12. Conclusion

Acting solely from the desire to do what is morally right can indeed suffice for morally worthy conduct. The charge of fetishism misconstrues the relation between higher-order motives and first-order reasons. When properly understood, a de dicto motive is a rational device that (i) integrates all concrete right-making reasons under a unifying norm, (ii) secures impartial reliability, and (iii) expresses respect for the moral law and, thereby, for persons. Such dutiful action merits praise even if it lacks the warmth of fellow-feeling or the charm of partial affection. In the economy of moral evaluation, duty has its own noble currency, and it spends just fine.

1. Introduction and Thesis

Is an agent who acts solely from a de-dicto desire to “do the right thing”—rather than from the more concrete motives that make the act right—necessarily less praiseworthy or even morally suspect? I shall argue that the answer is No. A pure motive of duty can ground full moral worth, provided (i) that the de-dicto desire is not a bare abstraction but a practical commitment whose content is continually regulated by the best available moral reasons, and (ii) that the agent’s self-conscious allegiance to rightness expresses a distinct value—respect for persons as free and equal—that is not reducible to the first-order reasons that happen to apply in a given case. When these two conditions are met, dutiful action is not fetishistic but rather manifests the agent’s practical identity as a moral equalizer; it is praiseworthy because it exhibits a form of self-governance that ensures reliability, impartiality and responsiveness to moral reasons across contexts. 

2. Mapping the Dispute: De Dicto vs. De Re Motivation

Talk of “acting from duty” is ambiguous between two kinds of motivational content:

a. De re (object-directed) motive: wanting to relieve this child’s pain, to promote that person’s autonomy, etc.  
b. De dicto (description-directed) motive: wanting, of the available actions, to do the one that is morally required (or not morally forbidden).

Critics of the de-dicto motive argue that, when it is the exclusive driver, the agent’s psychology is improperly detached from the values that ground moral requirements. Their worry comes in two forms:

The Fetish Worry (e.g. Smith): The agent’s primary “object of concern” becomes the abstract property of rightness itself, as though morality were a shiny trinket rather than something about people’s lives.

The Alienation Worry (Williams, Stocker): If one saves a friend from drowning “because duty demands it” rather than out of friendship, one fails to show genuine concern for the friend; moral deliberation has intruded where personal concern ought to rule.

Both worries assume that right-respecting motivation is motivationally inert unless it is backed by first-order concern for the concrete values that underlie rightness. I shall contest that assumption.

3. A Kantian Precedent—and Its Misreadings

Kant notoriously held that actions possess moral worth only when they are done “from duty.” Contemporary critics often read him as valorizing sheer rule-obedience; yet Kant’s text depicts the moral motive as reverence for the moral law, which itself is a law of equal respect. On this reading, to act from duty is not to be moved by an empty label but to be moved by recognition that one’s maxim must be justified to every rational being. That recognition is not a psychological symptom of alienation but of moral self-legislation—an attitude specifically oriented to others’ equal autonomy. 

Barbara Herman’s distinction between “deliberative priority” and “motivating efficacy” helps here. Rightness has deliberative priority—entering as a filter on admissible maxims—but concrete reasons supply much of the motivational energy. Yet even if, per the stipulated case, no concrete sympathetic feeling is present, the respect-based motive itself signifies acknowledgement of every person’s claim to justification. That is a substantive attitude, not an empty fetish.

4. Two Conditions for Praiseworthy Dutiful Action

Condition 1: Normative Tracking

The de-dicto desire must be reliably and non-accidentally connected to correct moral verdicts. If the agent’s conception of “what is right” floats free of genuine reasons—say, it is fixed rigidly by an authority or tribal code—then even if she acts from that desire, her conformity to duty is at best lucky. Moral worth requires that the agent’s will exhibit practical wisdom: a sensitivity to the moral landscape.

Condition 2: Respect-Expressive Form

Dutiful action must manifest respect for persons as autonomous law-givers. This condition distinguishes the valuable form of de-dicto motivation from slavish rule-worship. The praiseworthy agent does not bow to morality as a foreign power; she identifies with it as the voice of her own and others’ reason. Thus her dutiful act is an expression of relational equality, not an object-directed fetish.

Meeting these conditions is sufficient (though not necessary) for moral worth irrespective of whether concrete sympathies are present.

5. Why the Two Conditions Matter

a. Reliability. De-re motives often map well onto right actions but can misfire in atypical cases. A parent’s intense love may motivate helping his child even when doing so violates serious duties to others. The de-dicto desire to do the right thing, if properly regulated, provides an impartial corrective that prevents such misfires.

b. Impartiality. Particularistic sentiments tend to be partial by nature. The de-dicto motive treats like cases alike; it is structurally egalitarian.

c. Integrity of Practical Identity. By centering one’s agency on the project of “getting morality right,” the agent forges a unifying commitment that can organize diverse subordinate motives without collapsing into obsessive moralistic neurosis.

6. Addressing the Fetish Worry

Michael Smith imagines an agent who is fascinated by “the property moral rightness.” He infers that such an agent values a metaphysical property rather than the features that make acts right. Yet if Condition 1 is satisfied, then “rightness” is precisely the formal status of being justified by the best balance of those very features. Valuing rightness is reflexive valuing of whatever reasons survive critical scrutiny. Far from valuing an irrelevant property, the agent values the whole set of morally relevant features under a unifying description.

An analogy: a scientist may desire “to believe what the evidence supports.” This is not a fetish for the property of evidential support but an attitude of epistemic conscientiousness. Likewise, the dutiful agent’s meta-desire is a form of moral conscientiousness.

7. Addressing the Alienation Worry

Bernard Williams’ famous case: Jim can save Pedro’s life but only because utilitarian morality requires it. Williams complains that Jim’s deliberation sidelines his personal concern. Yet note: The question is not whether first-order concern is absent, but whether its absence undermines moral worth. Suppose Jim has no warm feelings for Pedro (perhaps they’re strangers) but acts solely from the de-dicto motive. According to Williams, this reveals a chilling abstraction. According to my view, Jim’s act displays respect for Pedro’s status as a moral equal—indeed, it treats Pedro not merely as an object of sympathy (which might or might not arise) but as a co-legislator of the moral law. 

Moreover, the presence of a de-dicto motive need not exclude first-order sentiments. The agent who says “I saved you because it was the right thing to do” can also feel friendship or compassion; the abstract statement can be a shorthand for a deliberative structure, not a full psychological report. The alienation critique overreads the phenomenology of moral language.

8. Objection: The Empty Container Reply

Someone might concede my two conditions but protest that they covertly install de-re motivational content: sensitivity to reasons (Condition 1) and respect for persons (Condition 2) are concrete values; therefore, the agent is not “solely” de-dictally motivated after all.

Reply: Sensitivity and respect function as second-order dispositions governing how the de-dicto desire operates, rather than as first-order motives. The immediate desire is still “to do what is right.” What ensures its correctness is the background intellectual and affective architecture. Compare: The utilitarian may be moved by the de-dicto desire “to maximize utility,” yet she must possess competency at evaluating utility, or else her will is malformed. That does not show she is moved by each concrete welfare consideration as such; it shows only that her de-dicto motive is guided. Similarly, respect for persons enters as the constitutive ideal of rightness—it gives content to the de-dicto aim without replacing it.

9. Two Illustrative Cases

Case A: The Steadfast Judge

Judge Adams, known for her impeccable impartiality, must decide a case involving her childhood friend. She feels potent affection for the friend, who pleads for leniency. Nevertheless, Adams sentences strictly in accordance with just precedents, motivated by her pledge to uphold what is right. She consciously sets aside her personal feeling. Critics might call her cold, but most would agree her action is morally worthy, precisely because it manifests fidelity to law and to the equal rights of unknown litigants. Here, the de-dicto desire counteracts partial sympathetic motives; its worth is patent.

Case B: The Exhausted Samaritan

Rosa, a disaster-relief nurse, has been on duty for 36 hours, emotionally numb and physically drained. Her empathic reserves are depleted; she feels no warmth when yet another victim is wheeled in. What keeps her going is a disciplined commitment: “These people deserve care, and giving it is the right thing to do.” She proceeds to treat the patient conscientiously. Surely Rosa’s action is praiseworthy; to demand lively sympathy under such conditions would be heroic but not morally required. The dutiful motive suffices.

10. Positive Payoffs: Why Prize the Dutiful Agent?

First, reliability across contexts where natural sympathy fails (remote duties, justice in distribution, environmental duties to future generations).  

Second, humility: De-dicto motivation recognizes the limits of one’s emotional palette; it does not mistake the presence of feeling for the presence of obligation.  

Third, solidarity: By acting from an ideal that any rational being could share, the agent signals moral fellowship unmediated by special ties or sentiments.

11. Theoretical Integration: Moral Worth as a Function of Practical Rationality

We can generalize: An act has moral worth when it issues from a will whose governing maxim is suitably responsive to moral reasons under a practical identity that affirms others as equals. Whether the motivational content is de-re or de-dicto is, on this account, less important than whether the will is normatively guided and respect-expressive. Hence, the exclusive valorization of de-re motives is misguided; de-dicto motives can instantiate the same rational structure.

12. Revisiting the Critics

Stocker’s charge that modern moral theories “leave a moral vacuum” because they ignore motives rings true against a certain hyper-intellectualized moralism. But permitting de-dicto motives does not entail ignoring motives; it widens the palette. Similarly, Wolf’s “Moral Saints” worry—that agents obsessed with being morally perfect lose the capacity for personal flourishing—targets extremism. A healthy de-dicto motive need not crowd out non-moral projects; it sets a threshold of permissibility, after which plural ends can flourish.

13. Objection: The Redundancy Worry

Why not say that de-dicto desire is instrumentally useful but the real ground of praise is the agent’s capacity to track reasons (practical wisdom)? Then duty drops out as a superfluous layer.

Reply: The value of taking rightness itself as one’s explicit aim is that it renders one’s agency transparently accountable. It is constitutive of acting *as* a moral agent rather than as a coincidentally well-disposed empathizer. The public-regarding stance—“I do this because it is what anyone similarly situated ought to do”—has moral meaning beyond the bare fact of correctness. It acknowledges a common normative standpoint, which itself is worthy of praise.

14. Relations to Virtue Ethics and Rails of Care

Virtue ethicists might reply that dutiful action lacks “eudaimonic integration”: moral reasons appear as external impositions, not as expressions of the agent’s character. I answer that the motive of duty can itself be a stable virtue—call it conscientiousness—whose internal good is precisely the maintenance of equal respect. Moreover, where particular virtues conflict, conscientiousness adjudicates, thereby enabling harmonious integrity.

Care ethicists worry that duty-first agents overlook relationships. Yet nothing in the de-dicto motive forbids attending to relational contexts; it merely ensures that care is delivered as something owed, not merely as optional benevolence.

15. A Final Example: The Climate Voter

Lee cares little about polar bears or abstract future harms, but she has internalized the de-dicto maxim “vote for policies that are morally right.” After careful study she judges, reluctantly, that aggressive climate action is required. On voting day, her friends offer a beach trip; she forgoes it and casts her vote. Her motive is thinly de-dicto; nonetheless, her act contributes to intergenerational justice. Praising Lee is appropriate, for she embodies citizens’ duty to justify collective coercion. If everyone acted thus, large-scale moral goods would be better secured than if we relied solely on spontaneous empathy for future strangers.

16. Conclusion

A de-dicto desire to do what is morally right can fully ground moral worth, provided it meets two adequacy conditions: reliable normative tracking and respect-expressive form. When those are in place, the dutiful agent is not a fetishist but a self-legislating equalizer; her motivation secures impartiality, reliability, and public accountability. The fetish and alienation critiques misfire because they misconstrue the phenomenology of duty: they imagine a vacuous abstraction where in fact there is a substantive commitment to common moral governance. Accordingly, acting solely from duty can be—not just sufficient for minimal moral decency—but positively praiseworthy.

1. Introduction: The Puzzle

The ordinary thought that morality is about concrete concern for people, animals, and the planet puts pressure on a Kantian-sounding ideal: acting “from duty” in the austere sense of treating the fact that an act is morally right, as such, as one’s sole motivating consideration.  Railton, Stocker, and Herman worry that such agents are “moral fetishists,” estranged from what truly matters.  Yet Kant’s own analysis of moral worth relies precisely on the idea that an indifferent, even depressed, shopkeeper can still deserve esteem if he charges fair prices only because it is right.  Who is correct?

I defend the following thesis:

     An agent whose sole first-order motive is the abstract desire to do what is morally right can act with full moral worth, provided (i) that desire expresses a stable and reliable sensitivity to the underlying reasons that make actions right, and (ii) the agent’s practical deliberation is properly integrated with those reasons.  Moral worth, on this view, consists not in the presence of concrete sentiments but in a certain quality of rational will: a reason-responsive disposition to treat moral reasons as decisive.

The argument proceeds in six steps.  (1) I disambiguate “acting from duty,” introducing distinctions between de dicto and de re moral motivation, first- and higher-order desires, and moral rightness vs. the grounds of rightness.  (2) I advance a positive account of why a de dicto motive can ground praiseworthiness—call it the “reason-responsive will” account.  (3) I show how this account explains the special value Kant saw in acting from duty while avoiding fetishism.  (4) I answer four leading objections: the fetishism objection, the alienation objection, the emotional impoverishment objection, and the practical unreliability objection.  (5) I illustrate with three test cases that sharpen the dialectic.  (6) I conclude by situating the proposal in contemporary debates about quality-of-will theories.

Total length: roughly 2,000 words.

2. Mapping the Conceptual Terrain

a. De dicto vs. de re moral motivation  
In de re moral motivation I desire, say, to keep my promise because it is a promise.  In de dicto moral motivation I desire, simply, to do whatever is morally right, whatever that turns out to be.  The dispute centers on whether the latter, abstract desire alone can underwrite moral worth.

b. First-order vs. higher-order desires  
One can have a first-order desire to do the right thing while also endorsing that desire at a higher level (“I want to want to do what is right”).  Praiseworthiness depends, I argue, on the integrated higher-order picture of oneself as a responsible agent, not merely on the presence of a bare first-order push.

c. Right-making features vs. the fact of rightness  
An act is right because of concrete features—minimizing suffering, honoring rights, etc.  The critic insists that being moved only by the fact that the act is right misses these underlying values.  My reply will hinge on showing that genuine responsiveness to “rightness” can implicitly track those very features, even if they are not the content of the conscious motive.

3. A Positive Proposal: The Reason-Responsive-Will Account

What, exactly, confers moral worth?  Following Kant, Strawson, and recent “quality of will” theorists (Arpaly, Markovits, Skorupski), I locate worth not in which desire one feels, but in how one’s will is attuned to moral reasons.  An agent acts with moral worth if:

1. She recognizes that moral considerations decisively favor the action.  
2. This recognition reliably guides her conduct.  
3. She acts from a disposition that is stably connected to those considerations, rather than, say, luck or fear.

Call this a reason-responsive disposition.  The content of the first-order desire—“do right”—is morally generic, but its functional role is to make the agent reliably sensitive to concrete right-makers.  Two explanatory points follow.

Reliability.  A general love of rightness, when sincerely held, is an excellent predictor of right action across contexts, including unfamiliar ones where concrete sympathy may mislead.  It therefore satisfies the reliability condition on moral worth.

Epistemic humility.  Agents often face moral uncertainty; they may not know exactly which feature of a situation grounds rightness.  A de dicto desire allows them to act correctly without presuming infallible grasp of all right-making properties.  Far from fetishistic, it is a rational safeguard against error.

4. Avoiding Fetishism: Respect Forms of Valuing

Why is the “desire to do what is right” not a fetish?  Because valuing something under an abstract description can itself be an authentic mode of valuing the particulars subsumed by that description.  Compare: loving “my children, whoever they turn out to be” is not a fetish; it is a form of unconditional commitment.  Similarly, I manifest respect for persons by treating their claims as binding, even on days when I am too tired to feel tender concern.  The crucial point is integration: the de dicto motive must be formed and sustained by appreciation of moral reasons over time, not by brute conformism.

5. Four Objections Answered

Objection 1: The Fetishism Charge (Railton).  If you desire only “right action,” you treat rightness like a collector treats rare stamps—prized for its own sake, detached from what makes stamps beautiful.  

Reply.  The stamp analogy fails because moral rightness is an essentially reason-laden property: to want rightness just is to want what there are overriding reasons to do.  Wanting stamps, by contrast, need not track any value internal to the stamps’ being stamps.  Thus the fetish worry conflates an evaluatively empty predicate (“being a stamp”) with a normatively loaded one (“being morally required”).

Objection 2: Alienation (Stocker).  Your friend visits you in hospital solely out of duty; you feel chilled.  That shows duty motives lack value.

Reply.  Two points.  (a) The emotional disappointment concerns interpersonal warmth, not moral worth.  A nurse who dutifully tends me deserves esteem even if we lack intimacy.  (b) The case conflates sufficiency with preferability.  Granting that mixed motives (duty + affection) are ideal, it does not follow that pure duty is insufficient for worth.

Objection 3: Emotional impoverishment.  Agents driven by duty alone lack compassion, so their actions express a deficient moral character.

Reply.  A disposition to act for moral reasons is itself a significant moral virtue—call it conscientiousness.  One can admire a firefighter’s principled courage even if he feels no compassion while charging into flames.  Moreover, the reason-responsive framework encourages, though it does not require, cultivation of concrete sympathies as instrumental to recognizing moral reasons quickly.  Thus duty-based agents are not condemned to emotional aridity.

Objection 4: Reliability.  Abstract commitment may fail when the agent misidentifies the right act; concrete concern for welfare offers a firmer guide.

Reply.  The reliability calculus cuts both ways.  Sympathy can misfire (implicit bias, near-sighted altruism).  A principled desire tracks reasons across cases, provided the agent is rational and reflective.  Empirical data on moral reasoning (e.g., the Kohlberg/Gilligan debates) suggest that principled reasoning often corrects parochial feeling.  Hence duty motivation can be at least as reliable as sentiment.

6. Three Test Cases

Case 1: The Nuclear Technician.  Jordana works in a control room.  She double-checks safety protocols nightly.  Her sole conscious motive is that it is morally required; she feels no warmth toward distant strangers who would die in a meltdown.  Yet her vigilance stems from stable recognition of their rights to life and security.  Intuitively, Jordana is highly praiseworthy—indeed more so than a technician moved by thrill-seeking heroism.

Case 2: The Misanthrope Revisited (Kant).  A reclusive philanthropist sends anonymous donations only because “it is the right thing to do.”  He dislikes people.  Is he worthy of esteem?  According to the reason-responsive account, yes: he reliably acts on moral reasons despite adverse inclinations.  His lack of affection is lamentable, but the quality of his will—placing duty above dislike—merits praise.

Case 3: The Disaster Triage Doctor.  Under chaotic conditions Dr. Liu cannot grasp which patient will benefit most.  She therefore follows a well-validated utilitarian protocol purely out of duty to do what is right.  Her abstract motive allows swift, impartial action where concrete compassion would be overwhelmed.  Again, we judge her praiseworthy.

These examples show that pure duty motivation, when properly integrated, can embody moral dedication, foresight, and impartiality—traits at the heart of what we admire.

7. Why Praiseworthiness?  Two Deeper Explanations

First, epistemic difficulty.  Moral reality is complex.  A meta-desire to conform to moral reasons elegantly coordinates deliberation under uncertainty.  The dutiful agent models the stance of an inquirer: “Whatever turns out to be required, that I shall do.”  This intellectual humility is itself morally admirable.

Second, impartial respect.  Treating actions under the formal guise of rightness reflects the idea that each person’s reasons count equally, independent of my affective ties.  The de dicto motive therefore symbolizes recognition of others as moral equals, a core Kantian insight.

8. Addressing a Residual Worry: Is Content Irrelevant?

One might object that my view collapses into a de re view: because the desire to do what is right is responsive to right-making considerations, the agent is effectively motivated by those considerations after all.  Not quite.  The content of the motivating desire remains abstract; what matters is the functional link between that desire and the agent’s deliberative capacities.  We need not say she “desired to relieve suffering.”  It is enough that her abstract desire reliably would have changed had she learned that relieving suffering was not, after all, required in present circumstances.  Thus de dicto and de re motives remain distinct, yet the de dicto motive is not blind.

9. Relation to Existing Literature

Arpaly (2003) argues that acting from the right reasons, even unknowingly so, suffices for praiseworthiness.  Markovits (2010) responds that moral worth requires acting for moral reasons as such.  My account blends their insights: the agent must be guided by moral reasons (Arpaly) but may do so under the abstract description “what is morally required” (Markovits), provided the guiding disposition is reason-responsive.

10. Conclusion

Acting merely from the desire to do what is morally right can fully suffice for moral worth.  The key lies not in the descriptive richness of one’s motive but in its rational quality: its stability, responsiveness, and integration with moral reasons.  Fetishism and alienation arise only when the desire is detached from those reasons—when it becomes a matter of social signaling, scrupulosity, or blind rule-worship.  Properly understood, however, duty motivation is a rational, impartial, and often epistemically superior vehicle for moral agency.  The praiseworthiness of such action flows from the agent’s commitment to treat moral reasons as decisively authoritative—a commitment that is itself one of the highest expressions of respect for persons and morality alike.

1. Introduction and Thesis  

Do epistemic agents have to know what they are doing epistemically in order to be doing it? More precisely: must a subject be consciously aware of the reasons on which a belief or other cognitive state is based for that state to enjoy an epistemic status—say, to be justified? I shall argue that the answer is “no.” Conscious awareness of one’s reasons is sufficient for bona fide epistemic basing, but it is not necessary. What *is* necessary is that (i) the belief be causally sustained by the relevant reasons in a way that makes those reasons explanatory at the personal level, and (ii) the subject have a disposition to achieve conscious access to the reasons on reflective demand. If these conditions are met, a mental state can be epistemically based on reasons even when, as a matter of phenomenology, the subject is unaware of any such reasons at the time.

The argument proceeds in six stages. Section 2 disentangles the key notions: “reasons,” “basing,” and “awareness.” Section 3 lays out the principal motivations for the “awareness requirement.” Section 4 develops counter-considerations drawn from empirical psychology and ordinary epistemic practice. Section 5 offers a two-tier “dispositional accessibility” account that preserves what is compelling in the awareness requirement while allowing epistemic credit to automatic processes. Section 6 replies to three prominent objections: the Responsibility Objection, the Deviant-Causality Objection, and the Blindsight Objection. Section 7 concludes by summarizing the broader implications for epistemology and cognitive science.

2. Preliminary Distinctions  

2.1 Normative vs. Motivating Reasons  
Normative epistemic reasons are facts that count in favor of believing p (e.g., “the gauge reads ‘E’” is a reason to believe one is low on fuel). Motivating reasons are the reasons for which the subject actually believes p; they enter the causal-explanatory story of how the belief is formed or sustained. The basing relation concerns motivating reasons.

2.2 Personal-Level vs. Subpersonal Causation  
A stimulus can cause a neuron to fire (subpersonal), but that neuronal spike is not the agent’s reason. Personal-level causation is the level at which we attribute beliefs, desires, intentions, and reasons to whole agents. Automatic inferences delivered by encapsulated modules—say, face recognition—must be connectable to the agent’s web of commitments to count as personal-level.

2.3 Occurrent vs. Dispositional Awareness  
Occurrent awareness is conscious access *right now*. Dispositional awareness is the ability to bring the relevant content to consciousness through reflection or inquiry. The traditional awareness requirement is typically formulated in occurrent terms. A weaker, dispositional version will turn out to be all we need.

3. The Case for the Awareness Requirement  

Three main lines of argument motivate the claim that justification requires occurrent awareness of one’s reasons:

A. The Transparency Argument  
Belief is *transparent to the question whether p is true* (Evans, Moran). When one asks, “Do I believe that p?” one answers by considering whether p. This transparency is alleged to break down if the reasons for p are unconscious; hence, the belief would be epistemically opaque, undermining its status as reason-based.

B. The Guidance Argument  
To be creditworthy, an agent must guide her belief by reasons she recognizes. Otherwise, the belief is at best a happy accident. Active guidance seems to require explicit, occurrent access to the guiding considerations.

C. The Responsibility Argument  
Epistemic norms have an element of responsibility: we appraise agents, praise and blame them, and demand reasons. If subjects cannot articulate any grounds for their beliefs, how can they be held responsible for believing well or badly?

These arguments have force, but none is decisive. Each overreaches by moving from a genuine insight—awareness enhances epistemic standing—to the stronger conclusion that awareness is necessary. 

4. Counter-Considerations: Why Awareness Cannot Be Necessary  

4.1 Ubiquitous Automaticity  
Perception, memory retrieval, language comprehension, and even much mathematical intuition are subpersonal and automatic, yet obviously contribute to epistemic justification. A radiologist “just sees” the hairline fracture; a chess grandmaster “just knows” that the knight move is winning. If we deny that these beliefs are justified because the reasons remain unconscious, we commit ourselves to skepticism about most ordinary knowledge.

4.2 Developmental and Cross-Species Evidence  
Infants track gaze direction to locate hidden objects; dogs follow human pointing. If conscious reflection were required for epistemic justification, creatures lacking sophisticated metacognition could never possess justified beliefs. Yet it is counterintuitive to say an adult dog that tracks a thrown ball has no justified expectation about its landing place.

4.3 The Cognitive Burden Problem  
Human cognitive resources are limited. Requiring occurrent awareness of all reasons would paralyze inquiry; one could never believe anything without first conducting a metacognitive audit. A plausible epistemology must respect bounded rationality.

4.4 The Self-Defeat Problem  
Meeting the awareness requirement itself depends on further, often unconscious processes (e.g., retrieving memories). If only conscious processes can ground justification, then the very reasons retrieved to satisfy the requirement would be unjustified, triggering regress.

Taken together, these considerations shift the burden of proof: unless awareness advocates can explain away the intuitive force of these cases, awareness cannot be necessary.

5. A Dispositional Accessibility Account  

5.1 The Core Proposal  
A belief B is epistemically based on a body of reasons R iff:

(DA-1) B is causally sustained by R in a way that preserves the counterfactual dependence characteristic of basing: had R been different, B would have differed accordingly.  
(DA-2) The subject is disposed, under conditions of critical reflection and absent defeating pressures, to access R and to recognize their epistemic relevance.

Occurrent consciousness is not required, but *cognitive ownership* is: the reasons must belong to the subject’s rational architecture such that she can—given sufficient prompting—bring them to light.

5.2 Why DA Satisfies the Original Motivations  
Transparency: If the subject reflects, the reasons do become transparent; the guidance function is preserved dispositionally.  
Guidance: Real-time guidance can be mediated by subpersonal mechanisms that are nonetheless integrated with the agent’s goals and background knowledge; guidance need not be consciously mediated.  
Responsibility: When asked, a competent subject can articulate at least schematic reasons (“The gauge said E”). Failure to do so indicates either that DA-2 is unmet or that the subject is in abnormal conditions (fatigue, intimidation), which we routinely excuse.

5.3 Relation to Existing Theories  
DA shares affinities with Conee & Feldman’s mentalist evidentialism but relaxes their “awareness” clause; with Goldman’s reliabilism but imposes an accessibility constraint; and with virtue epistemology in assigning responsibility to the agent’s stable competences. It aims to integrate the strongest intuitions from each tradition.

6. Reply to Objections  

6.1 The Responsibility Objection  
“Without awareness, there is no responsibility.” — Reply: Responsibility admits degrees.
