We hold people responsible for careless driving even when they are unaware of some hazard they should have noticed; what matters is their *ability* to notice. Similarly, an epistemic agent who can, upon reflection, cite her perceptual evidence is responsible, even if she hasn’t actually done the reflective work at t.

6.2 The Deviant-Causality Objection  
“Causal relations can be deviant; DA-1 by itself cannot secure non-deviant basing.” — Reply: DA-2 blocks deviance. Suppose a hypnotist implants a belief via reasons that never become accessible; DA-2 fails, so no basing. Suppose, by contrast, the subject’s perceptual system subpersonally computes depth cues she can later access (“It looked nearer than the other object”). DA-2 holds, hence genuine basing.

6.3 The Blindsight Challenge  
Blindsighted patients guess correctly about stimuli they do not see. Are these guesses justified on DA? No. Although subpersonal visual information causally sustains the guess (DA-1), patients lack the disposition to access it as epistemic evidence; indeed, they deny having any basis. DA-2 fails, vindicating the intuition that blindsight yields reliability without justification.

7. Conclusion  

Lack of *occurrent* awareness does not preclude epistemic basing. What matters is that the reasons be (i) appropriately explanatory at the personal level and (ii) dispositionally accessible for reflection. This middle ground secures the virtues that motivate the awareness requirement—transparency, guidance, responsibility—while accommodating the empirical reality that much of our cognitive labor is automatic. Epistemic justification, on this view, is a partnership between the luminous and the subterranean: conscious reflection ratifies and regulates an underlying architecture of mostly unconscious but genuinely reason-giving processes.

Does lack of conscious awareness of one’s reasons preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons? I shall argue that it does not. Occurrent, explicit awareness of one’s grounds is neither necessary nor sufficient for the basing relation that underwrites epistemic justification. Instead, what matters is that (i) the subject’s cognitive system is properly sensitive to the truth-conducive features that constitute the reasons, and (ii) the subject retains a standing capacity to vindicate the state by citably appealing to those features under conditions of critical reflection. Conscious access is thus optional at the moment of belief‐formation, even though accessibility in principle—and the rational competence it manifests—remains indispensable. Once these distinctions are in place, the apparent tension between automatic, modular processes and genuine epistemic basing dissolves: such processes can confer justification so long as they are reason-responsive in the right way and embedded in an agent who could, if prompted, bring the operative grounds to reflective awareness.

The remainder of the essay unfolds as follows. Section 1 clarifies the target phenomenon—the basing relation—and isolates three distinct readings of the awareness requirement. Section 2 reconstructs the best arguments for the strong awareness thesis, according to which occurrent consciousness of one’s reasons is required for justification. Section 3 marshals empirical and conceptual considerations that jointly undermine this thesis. Section 4 develops a moderate, competence-based account that accommodates non-conscious, subpersonal reasoning while retaining the link between reasons and epistemic responsibility. Section 5 addresses two residual worries: first, that the view lapses into externalism by relocating epistemic credit to subpersonal mechanisms; second, that it cannot explain cases of epistemic defeat that seemingly depend on conscious reflection. Section 6 concludes by summarizing the dialectical upshot and sketching avenues for further research.

1. Clarifying basing and three awareness theses

“R’s belief that p is based on reason q” can be used in at least three registers:

a) Etiological: q causally explains R’s holding p.  
b) Rationalizing: q makes R’s believing p intelligible as an exercise of her rational agency.  
c) Epistemic: q confers justification on R’s believing p.

While these dimensions often coincide, they can come apart. A hypnotist might causally implant a belief in virtue of suggestion (a), rendering it neither rationally intelligible (b) nor justified (c). The present debate concerns the epistemic dimension: does q confer justification only when R is consciously aware of q when forming or sustaining the belief that p?

Awareness can itself be interpreted in three increasingly demanding ways:

1. Occurrent-phenomenal: R is vividly representing q as a premise at the very moment she comes to believe p.  
2. Standing-access: R is not currently thinking about q but could, without fresh empirical inquiry, cite q if asked why she believes p.  
3. Implicit-structural: q figures in the information-processing causal chain that produces R’s belief, though R could not articulate q even upon reflection.

The strong awareness thesis endorses (1); accessibilist internalism accepts (2); externalist reliabilism is friendly to (3). My task is to show that (1) is untenable and that something like (2) suffices for epistemic basing. I remain neutral between internalist and externalist embellishments, aiming only to secure the claim that conscious occurrent awareness is not necessary.

2. Arguments for the strong awareness thesis

A. The agency argument: Epistemic appraisal seems to presuppose rational agency. One is responsible for a belief only if one formed it as the result of one’s own reasoning rather than as a passive receptacle of causes. Because agency is paradigmatically conscious, having reasons play the right role allegedly requires their conscious citation.

B. The transparency argument: Introspection exhibits a peculiar transparency: when one asks “Why do I believe that p?” one immediately considers the truth of p, not the causal path by which the belief was produced. This suggests that justification is tied to reasons that are present to the subject’s mind.

C. The deontic argument: Ought implies can. If justification confers epistemic permissibility, the subject must have control over whether to believe. Control, in turn, requires conscious appreciation of reasons. Otherwise the normativity of epistemic “ought”s would collapse into mere biological good fortune.

Collectively, these arguments invite the verdict that absence of conscious awareness undermines basing, and hence justification.

3. Problems for the strong awareness thesis

3.1 Ubiquity of non-conscious cognitive success
Consider expert radiologists who, at a glance, correctly identify subtle tumors on a scan yet are unable to verbalize the decisive features. Or the famed Japanese “chicken-sexers,” who reliably sort male from female chicks within seconds without access to an explicit rule. These agents are epistemically justified: we trust their judgments, rely on them for surgery scheduling, or breed programs. Their reliability is not flukish; it is systematic and attributable to cultivated perceptual attunement to statistically diagnostic cues. Requiring occurrent awareness would bizarrely strip these experts of justification, despite their epistemic superiority to novices who can cite textbook indicators but misclassify.

3.2 Perception as reason without awareness
If any cognitive domain is plausibly justified without occurrent awareness of reasons, it is ordinary perception. Standing in daylight I believe “There is a coffee mug on my desk” because I see it. Yet, in forming that belief, I do not consciously rehearse “Because the lighting is good, my eyes function normally, and mugs typically look like that shape.” The visual system delivers content whose justificatory pedigree is implicit in its proper functioning, not in my contemporaneous consciousness of optical principles.

3.3 The “consciousness is not sufficient” consideration
Cases of confabulation and motivated reasoning reveal that conscious awareness—even of actual evidence—fails to guarantee basing. A juror may overtly cite legitimate testimony while in fact convicting out of implicit bias. The availability of reasons to consciousness is compatible with their playing no causal role. Therefore, insistence on conscious awareness confuses an epistemic enabling condition with a poor proxy.

3.4 Empirical evidence about temporal order
Neuroscientific studies (e.g., Libet-style readiness potentials and Haidt’s work on moral judgment) show that decisions often precede the subject’s conscious awareness of reasons by hundreds of milliseconds. If mental causation requires such awareness, much of human reasoning would be rendered irrational ex hypothesi, an unattractive result bordering on skepticism.

Together, considerations (3.1)–(3.4) tilt the scales: the strong awareness thesis sacrifices too many bona fide cases of justified belief and does not even secure basing when awareness is present. Something more nuanced is required.

4. A competence-based account of basing

The empirical cases just canvassed suggest that justification depends on competence: the reliable, reasons-sensitive functioning of cognitive capacities. Let me articulate this idea more carefully.

Definition (Epistemic Competence): A cognitive disposition C is an epistemic competence regarding proposition-type Φ if and only if (i) C reliably produces true Φ-beliefs across a sufficiently wide range of normal conditions, and (ii) C’s reliability is modally robust, i.e., would continue under relevant nearby circumstances. Paradigm competences include normal vision, educated statistical inference, and expert pattern recognition.

Competence yields a distinctive sort of counterfactual dependence: had the truth-conducive features been absent, the competence would not have produced the Φ-belief. This is precisely what we want from reasons-responsiveness: the features that actually obtain (the reasons) make an explanatory difference to the belief’s presence.

How does consciousness enter the picture? On my view, occurrent awareness is not constitutive of competence but is one way—often a useful way—of exercising it. What matters for basing is that the belief inherits its epistemic status from a mechanism whose reliability is keyed to the reasons, coupled with the agent’s owning that mechanism as part of her rational repertoire. “Owning” is cashed out by standing-access awareness: upon reflective scrutiny, the agent can, at least in outline, articulate what would count as defeating conditions (e.g., bad lighting, blurry image) and would be disposed to revise the belief accordingly. This satisfies epistemic responsibility without inflating every belief episode into a phenomenologically crowded inference.

4.1 Comparison with rival views
• Pure reliabilism (process externalism) discards any awareness requirement. My position diverges by insisting that justification must be sensitive to the first-person perspective in a counterfactual sense: were the agent to seek reasons, she could supply them by deploying the very competence that produced the belief.

• Accessibilist internalism equates justificatory status with what is actually accessible. I think this view is too conservative: recall the chicken-sexer who cannot fully articulate her evidence but can at least cite that “the pattern of down and wing vibration” looks a certain way. That rudimentary articulation, plus her history of corrigibility, suffices—even if she cannot specify the spectral frequency distribution that visually guides her.

5. Two residual worries

Worry 1: Does the competence view dissolve into externalism, rendering justification a matter of lucky subpersonal processes rather than the agent’s rational control?

Response: The subpersonal competence must be integrated with higher-level dispositions to respond to counter-evidence. Suppose the radiologist learns that the scan had a software glitch producing false shadows; she retracts the tumor belief. This shows that her belief is not a mere reflex of a module but part of an interconnected rational system. Contrast with a brain-lesion patient who blurts out tumor diagnoses yet cannot heed negative feedback; his process lacks the modally robust sensitivity to reasons and thus fails to ground justification.

Worry 2: Epistemic defeat seems to require conscious awareness. If the agent is unaware of the defeater, how can responsibilities concerning defeat be satisfied?

Response: Two points:

a) There are both possessed and unpossessed defeaters. Agents are responsible only for responding to defeaters within their cognitive ken.  
b) My view happily allows that once the defeater becomes possessed—i.e., once the agent becomes aware of it—she must revise her belief. The competence account handles this because competences encode conditional connections not just to reasons for p but to defeaters of p; acquiring awareness of such conditions activates a revision disposition. Absence of awareness at t₁ is no bar to possessing a justified belief at t₁ so long as the agent stands ready to revise at t₂ upon learning of the defeater.

6. Conclusion and prospects

We began with a prima facie plausible claim: that epistemic basing requires conscious awareness of one’s reasons. I have argued that this claim, interpreted strongly, is untenable. Perception, skilled cognition, and the empirical science of decision making attest to widespread justified belief without occurrent awareness. Yet we need not slide into blind externalism. By invoking the notion of epistemic competence—reliable, reasons-responsive capacities owned by the agent—we secure both epistemic value and rational responsibility. Conscious access remains important as a reflective safeguard and for articulate deliberation, but it is not the sine qua non of justification.

Future work might enrich this competence framework by integrating it with virtue epistemology, exploring its implications for machine learning systems that lack phenomenology yet exhibit reason-responsiveness, and examining how it handles higher-order knowledge (knowing that one knows). If the arguments above are sound, they vindicate the epistemic legitimacy of our vast, automatic mental life—granting the modular mind its rightful place in the economy of reasons.

1. Orienting the debate  

At least since Plato’s image of the “wax tablet” in the Theaetetus, epistemologists have worried about the connection between the mental causes of a belief and the *reasons* for which the believer holds it. One influential strand of that worry insists that for a belief to be *epistemically based*—and thus to be justified rather than a mere happen­stance—it must be formed (or sustained) in light of reasons the subject is consciously aware of. This *access requirement* is attractive: it seems to capture the intuition that justification is something for which a subject can be called to account. Yet it sits uneasily with contemporary cognitive science, which teaches that a large share of our belief formation is accomplished by fast, automatic, modular systems that operate below the level of consciousness. The question, then, is whether lack of conscious awareness of one’s reasons really rules out epistemic basing.  

I shall argue that the answer is “no.” More precisely:  

Thesis. Conscious awareness is not a necessary condition for a mental state’s being epistemically based on reasons. What matters is that the belief be causally sensitive, in the right explanatory way, to epistemic grounds that are *functionally available* to the believer’s cognitive system, even if they never rise to occurrent consciousness.  

The argument unfolds in six steps. I begin by clarifying three distinctions that can easily be run together (Section 2). I then set out the access requirement and the motivations behind it (Section 3). Sections 4–5 offer a positive account of sub-personal basing and a battery of examples that make it plausible. Section 6 replies to the two most serious objections—one about epistemic responsibility, the other about epistemic credit. I close by sketching a hybrid picture that preserves what is compelling in the access requirement while letting cognitive science have its due (Section 7).  

2. Three preliminary distinctions  

Distinction 1: Normative versus motivating reasons. A *normative* reason is a fact or consideration that counts in favor of believing. A *motivating* reason is the factor in light of which the subject actually believes. The basing relation concerns motivating reasons, though justificatory status then depends on whether those motivating reasons are also (or include) good normative ones.  

Distinction 2: Doxastic versus propositional justification. One may be *propositionally* justified in believing p without actually believing it on those grounds. *Doxastic* justification requires that the belief be appropriately based. The present debate is entirely about doxastic justification: even if I have good evidence stored in memory, if my belief in p is the upshot of wishful thinking, it is not doxastically justified.  

Distinction 3: Personal-level versus sub-personal representation. Philosophical reflection tends to privilege personal-level states—those we can report, reason with, and cite in explanations that make sense to us as agents. But the cognitive architecture that produces those states includes sub-personal computations to which we lack introspective access. Nothing in the concept of a *reason* requires that it be personal-level; what matters is that it plays the right role in rationalizing the attitude.  

These distinctions clear the ground. The issue is whether motivating reasons must be *consciously* personal-level for a belief to enjoy doxastic justification.  

3. The access requirement and its motivations  

Proponents of the access requirement (e.g., Fumerton, Alston, Steup) typically offer two lines of thought.  

3.1. The Accountability Argument. Epistemic appraisal is a species of normative appraisal. Justification is, at least pro tanto, that in virtue of which it is appropriate to praise or blame a believer for her attitudes. Since we do not praise or blame people for things hidden from their consciousness, justificatory grounds must be consciously accessible.  

3.2. The Non-Accidentalness Argument. Mere causal reliability is not enough for basing; the subject must treat the grounds *as* reasons. If I believe that the road is wet because I have been hypnotically programmed to form that belief whenever I see a red truck, the fact that the truck’s color causally preceded my belief does not make it epistemically based. Conscious endorsement, or at least awareness, is what separates genuinely reason-responsive causation from deviant causal chains.  

Both arguments capture insights worth retaining. But neither compels the conclusion that basing demands occurrent consciousness. To see why, we first need a more discriminating account of what sub-personal basing could look like.  

4. Basing without consciousness: a positive proposal  

Call a cognitive transition *epistemically appropriate* just in case (i) it is sensitive to factors that are truth-reliable in the relevant environment, (ii) it occurs through a process that is part of the subject’s standing cognitive repertoire, and (iii) if challenged, the subject could in principle recover or reconstruct those factors as considerations that *would* justify the belief.  

Point (iii)—the *recoverability* condition—allows us to retain an intuitive link to accountability without insisting on present-tense awareness. (We come back to why “in principle” is not a vacuous escape clause.) Given this picture, a belief can be based on reasons that are represented only sub-personally: they function in the cognitive system’s information-processing, are available for later explicit articulation, and would be recruited by the subject when reflecting.  

Such *functional availability* is enough to satisfy the demand that the subject’s belief be guided by reasons rather than merely caused. The relevant guidance is implemented by the cognitive architecture, not necessarily by conscious supervision.  

5. Why the proposal is plausible: five cases  

Case 1: Perceptual belief. Suppose I look out the window and believe there is a dog in the yard. My visual system extracts edges, motion parallax, color constancy, etc., delivering a high-level representation DOG-PRESENT. I could, if asked, cite what I take to be evidence (“I see a wagging tail, floppy ears …”). But before such articulation, the sub-personal visual computations already encode reasons sufficient to justify the belief. If conscious awareness were necessary *ab initio*, no ordinary perceptual belief would count as doxastically justified, which is an untenable sceptical result.  

Case 2: Implicit statistical reasoning. Tversky and Kahneman’s subjects can correctly estimate frequencies when presented with arrays of dots even though they cannot consciously compute percentages. Their success is driven by automatic sampling mechanisms that track frequency information. When a subject judges, “about seventy percent are blue,” her belief is sensitive to the proportion of blue dots—a normative reason—without being the upshot of any conscious calculation. Yet it is not luck: if the dot array had been different, she would have judged differently.  

Case 3: The expert chess intuitor. A grandmaster glances at a position and says, “White should play Qg4.” Decades of practice have trained her pattern-recognition module to tag certain configurations as dangerous. She is not consciously aware of the twenty-five-ply refutation; nevertheless, her belief is explained by her internalization of patterns that historically track truth about good moves. We count her belief as epistemically excellent, not a mere hunch.  

Case 4: Linguistic competence. I believe that (1) “Who did you see?” is grammatical but that (2) “Who did you see him?” is not. My belief is grounded in tacit knowledge of English syntax. I cannot formulate the Subjacency Condition, yet the sub-personal grammar engine applies it. This is a canonical example of justified belief grounded in reasons (syntactic constraints) of which the subject lacks conscious awareness.  

Case 5: Blindsight with introspective access restored. In classic blindsight, patients guess the presence of stimuli they claim not to see. Suppose a subject is given training that allows her, on reflection, to cite reliable indicators (a “feeling of presence,” slight muscle tension). After training, her guesses become beliefs she would defend verbally. At the moment of formation, she still lacks visual phenomenology, but the belief is based on sub-personal visual processing. Once again, justification seems to accrue.  

The common thread: in each case, the belief is the output of a cognitive process that tracks truth via sub-personal sensitivity to epistemic grounds. Demanding occurrent awareness would force us to declare all such beliefs unjustified, an implausible cost.  

6. Objections and replies  

6.1. The Responsibility Objection  

“You dodge responsibility,” the critic says. “If the subject cannot bring the reasons to consciousness, she cannot be held epistemically accountable. Justification without accountability is an empty honorific.”  

Reply. Responsibility comes in degrees and modalities. Moral responsibility paradigms already distinguish between *attributability* (the state reflects on the agent’s character) and *accountability* (the agent is fit to answer). Epistemic responsibility can be similarly disambiguated. A subject is *attributably* responsible for beliefs produced by her own standing cognitive equipment, provided she has no defeaters and no negligence in maintenance of that equipment. Accountability, in the sense of being able to articulate reasons on demand, is a higher bar that matters for *evaluative discourse* but not for the metaphysics of justification. The *recoverability* condition suffices: if, upon challenge, the subject can investigate and articulate reasons (e.g., “Well, I looked, and there was clearly a dog”), we have all the accountability we need.  

6.2. The Credit Objection  

Another worry (Greco, Pritchard) is that epistemic goods confer credit only if the believer’s success is because of her exercise of cognitive agency, not because of lucky factors outside her agential control. If sub-personal processes do the heavy lifting, does credit vanish?  

Reply. Agency is not exhausted by conscious supervision. Driving a car safely involves muscle-control micro-adjustments beyond consciousness; yet the safe arrival is creditable to the driver. Similarly, epistemic agency includes maintaining reliable perceptual systems, training pattern-recognition, and being disposed to off-load sub-tasks to specialized modules. Those sub-personal operations are constituents of the agent, not alien intruders. Hence credit is preserved. Removing credit would also undermine perceptual knowledge wholesale, an unacceptable consequence.  

7. A conciliatory synthesis  

Still, the access requirement captures something intuitive: a subject who could *in no way* bring her putative reasons to consciousness looks, from the armchair, akin to a mere conduit. To honor that intuition, we can articulate a *two-tier* model.  

Tier 1: Sub-personal basing confers *prima facie* doxastic justification, provided the belief derives from a process that (a) tracks truth in the local environment, (b) is part of the subject’s standing cognitive architecture, and (c) yields content that would serve as an explicit reason were the subject to reflect.  

Tier 2: Reflective endorsement (which may, but need not, occur) upgrades justification by immunizing it against certain defeaters and by underwriting higher-order epistemic goods such as *understanding*.  

This model predicts that a novice’s perceptual belief and an expert’s reflective judgement can both be justified, but the latter enjoys an additional epistemic virtue. Conscious awareness, then, is an *enhancer* rather than a *precondition* of basing. The synthesis also explains why hypnotic causation and randomly reliable processes are excluded: they fail condition (c); there is nothing the subject could, even in principle, cite that would count as a reason.  

8. Consequences and concluding remarks  

The conclusion that consciousness is not required for epistemic basing has several attractive upshots.  

1. It aligns epistemology with cognitive science, which presents us with an architecture rife with information-processing we do not experience phenomenally.  

2. It avoids global scepticism about ordinary perceptual and inferential beliefs.  

3. It accommodates a layered conception of epistemic normativity: minimal justification through reliable sub-personal basing; stronger goods (understanding, capacity for articulation) through reflective access.  

4. It offers a principled distinction between legitimate automatic processes (perception, language processing, expert intuition) and deviant ones (hypnosis, wishful thinking) by invoking the *recoverability* condition.  

If the argument is sound, the burden shifts. Those who insist on conscious awareness must explain why, in the face of the five cases and the two-tier model, we should accept a requirement that entails widespread scepticism and conflicts with our best cognitive science. Until such an account is offered, we are licensed to believe that the lights can be on epistemically even when consciousness is partially, or momentarily, in the dark.

Lack of Conscious Awareness and Epistemic Basing  

1. Introduction and Thesis  

When I glance at the sky and judge that a storm is coming, I do not explicitly rehearse the dark hue of the clouds, the humidity on my skin, and the sudden stillness of the air. Yet the perceptual features that caused my belief also seem to be the reasons on which that belief is epistemically based. Does the fact that I was not consciously aware of those reasons at the moment of judgment deprive the belief of its justificatory pedigree?  

I shall argue that occurrent, first-personal awareness of one’s reasons is not required for a mental state to be epistemically based on those reasons. What is required is that (i) the reasons stand in the right kind of counterfactual, non-deviant explanatory relation to the belief (they are what the belief is “for” from within the subject’s cognitive economy) and (ii) the subject has a standing capacity to bring those reasons under conscious scrutiny when the need for reflective assessment arises. Call this the Potential Uptake Account. It preserves the intuition that epistemic reasons must be in some sense “available to the subject” while still making room for the justificatory force of modular, automatic, or even sub-personal processes.  

The argument proceeds as follows. Section 2 clarifies the distinction between causal and epistemic basing. Section 3 lays out the Conscious Awareness Requirement (CAR) and the motivations for it. Section 4 presents four problem cases for CAR. Section 5 develops the Potential Uptake Account and shows how it handles those cases. Section 6 replies to two major objections. Section 7 concludes by situating the view within the broader internalism/externalism debate.  

2. Causal vs. Epistemic Basing  

A belief can be *caused* by some state of affairs without being *based* on it in the epistemic sense. Suppose a hypnotist says the word “blue,” thereby causing me to believe the stock market will rise. The acoustic stimulus is a cause, but not a reason. To capture the difference we need three ingredients.  

a. Direction of fit. Reasons aim to *justify*; causes need not.  
b. Non-deviance. The connection must be of the right kind—roughly, the normal operation of mechanisms aimed at truth.  
c. Cognitive integration. The putative reasons must belong to the subject’s reasoning system rather than bypass it (as in the hypnotist case).  

These constraints leave open whether conscious awareness is required. CAR claims it is.  

3. The Conscious Awareness Requirement (CAR)  

CAR: S’s mental state M is epistemically based on reason R only if S is consciously aware of R (or of some representation of R) at the time M is formed or sustained.  

Why might one endorse CAR? Three motivations are common.  

Motivation 1—Transparency. Basing seems answerable to the *space of reasons*. If I cannot cite my reason, how could it truly be *my* reason?  

Motivation 2—Responsible Agency. Justification is linked to epistemic responsibility; responsibility, in turn, presupposes access to the grounds of one’s beliefs.  

Motivation 3—Phenomenal Evidence. Some theories hold that the phenomenal character of perceptual experience is itself epistemic. If evidence is a matter of what it is *like* for me, then lack of awareness of that phenomenal character threatens basing.  

These motivations make CAR attractive, yet each has limits, as the following cases reveal.  

4. Four Problem Cases for CAR  

Case A: Routine Perception. While walking, I unreflectively believe there is a bench ahead. I do not occurrently attend to the way light patterns impact my retina, yet the perceptual information surely justifies my belief. If CAR is right, my everyday perceptual beliefs are unjustified.  

Case B: Expert Automaticity. A birdwatcher glimpses a silhouette and immediately judges “Black-throated Blue Warbler.” Years of training have tuned her visual module to extract diagnostic features unconsciously. With no occurrent articulation of those features, CAR implies her belief lacks a reasoned basis despite her expertise.  

Case C: Memory Retrieval. I recall that the capital of Vermont is Montpelier, though I have forgotten the textbook passage from which I learned it. The testimonial evidence is not consciously available, yet it seems to remain my reason.  

Case D: Child Cognition. Five-year-old Ana believes that pushing her cup will make it fall, based on rudimentary causal inferences she cannot articulate. CAR threatens to deny justification to young children across the board.  

The ubiquity of such cases suggests that CAR is too restrictive. That is not yet decisive—maybe most human beliefs are unjustified!—but it does put pressure on CAR to do explanatory work that matches our intuitions.  

5. The Potential Uptake Account  

I propose that epistemic basing consists in a *potential for conscious uptak*e rather than occurrent awareness. Formally:  

PUA: M is epistemically based on R for S iff  
(1) R non-deviantly causes M via mechanisms whose *functional role* is to respond to reasons, and  
(2) Were S to enter a context of reflective scrutiny—prompted by challenge, doubt, or inquiry—those very mechanisms would make R (or a suitable surrogate) accessible to S’s consciousness as the basis for M.  

Condition (1) secures the truth-aiming etiology; condition (2) secures the agency and responsibility intuitions. Let us see how PUA handles the earlier cases.  

Routine Perception. The perceptual module is reason-responsive: it encodes features bearing on truth (luminance, depth cues, etc.). Were I to wonder whether there is really a bench, a quick glance or mental replay would surface those features, satisfying (2).  

Expert Automaticity. The birder’s visual system registers the warbler’s wing bars and tail contrast. If asked, she can slow down, point to the diagnostic features, and justify her belief. That dispositional accessibility suffices.  

Memory Retrieval. Although I cannot recall the original testimonial chain, I can recall that I learned it from a reliable source. When pressed, I can say, “I was taught that in school and have never encountered any contrary evidence.” The underlying memory network would deliver enough content for uptake.  

Child Cognition. Ana may not cite *laws of physics*, but her cognitive system represents regularities of support and motion. If challenged, she can produce behaviorally available surrogates: “When you push things, they fall.” That meets (2) at a developmentally appropriate granularity.  

Hence PUA vindicates the intuitive judgments while rejecting CAR.  

6. Replies to Two Objections  

Objection 1: Availability is Cheap. Won’t any causal base count as ‘potentially accessible’ given enough prompting? Suppose the hypnotist earlier implanted the stock-market belief. If I later undergo regression therapy, I might recall the hypnotic session. Does PUA mistakenly confer justification?  

Reply. Condition (1) restricts the causal pathway to *reason-responsive mechanisms*. The hypnotic trigger bypasses the epistemic system; it is akin to electro-stimulation of motor cortex causing my arm to rise—not an action for which I am responsible. Because the belief-forming pathway is not designed to track truth, the hypnotic cause fails (1), regardless of later recollection.  

Objection 2: Circularity. PUA appeals to ‘mechanisms whose functional role is to respond to reasons.’ But whether a process is reason-responsive seems itself an epistemic matter. Isn’t the account circular?  

Reply. Functional role can be specified in non-epistemic computational terms: the process takes informational inputs that covary with world states and yields outputs that better than chance co-vary with those states across normal environments. This naturalistic proxy for truth-aiming avoids circularity while capturing the core of epistemic functionality.  

7. Relation to Internalism and Externalism  

CAR is a form of *access internalism*: justification supervenes on what is introspectively available now. PUA is a hybrid. Condition (1) is externalist, requiring the right causal etiology, while (2) is internalist, demanding potential access. The view thereby explains why classic externalisms (reliabilism) feel too detached from agency, and pure internalisms too restrictive.  

Some will complain that hybrid theories are unstable compromises. Yet PUA is principled: epistemic justification is for thinkers who can *learn* and *correct* themselves. Dispositional accessibility is what makes reasons usable for future inquiry, meeting the deontic dimension without over-intellectualizing everyday cognition.  

8. Conclusion  

Conscious occurrent awareness is not a prerequisite for epistemic basing. What matters is that the subject’s cognitive architecture treats certain states as reason-giving and can, when circumstances demand, elevate them into the space of reasons. The Potential Uptake Account captures this insight, rescuing ordinary perception, expert automaticity, memory, and child cognition from skeptical threat while preserving the central intuition that reasons must in some sense be *one’s own*.
