Is Conscious Awareness Necessary for Epistemic Basing?                                                    

1. Orientation and Thesis  

A familiar, venerable thought in epistemology holds that if a belief counts as epistemically justified for a subject, that subject must in some sense “base” the belief on the reasons that render it justified.  A still more demanding proposal says that basing requires the *conscious* appreciation of those reasons: unless I can tell (at least to myself) why I believe p, the belief is not genuinely *my* epistemic achievement.  On this view, the deliverances of automatic, modular, or otherwise unconscious cognitive routines—paradigmatically perception and linguistic processing—could never be epistemically credit-conferring in their own right; at best they supply raw causal antecedents to which one later “adds” justification by bringing the supporting considerations to consciousness.

I shall argue that the requirement is too strong.  Conscious awareness of one’s reasons is *sufficient* for epistemic basing, but not *necessary*.  What *is* necessary is that the relevant subpersonally represented information (i) be the kind of content that *would* justify the attitude if it were raised to consciousness, and (ii) figure in a suitably “reasons-responsive” causal pathway that is properly attributable to the subject’s cognitive agency.  Call this the *Accessibility-Plus-Control* account.  The upshot is that modular, automatic processes can generate attitudes that are justified in virtue of the epistemic credentials of the (unconsciously) tokened representations on which they are based.  

My case proceeds in four stages.  Section 2 disentangles three senses of “awareness” and “basing.”  Section 3 canvasses the main arguments for the awareness requirement and diagnoses where they overreach.  Section 4 develops the positive Accessibility-Plus-Control account, drawing on empirical and philosophical considerations.  Section 5 replies to five objections—concerning epistemic responsibility, the problem of deviant causation, blind-sighted reliability, bootstrapping worries, and cases of pathological implicit bias.  Section 6 concludes by locating the proposal in the broader internalism–externalism landscape.

If successful, the discussion shows that the phenomenology of reasoning, while epistemically important, does not set the boundary of epistemic basing.  The mind’s backstage labor can itself be a rational engine.

2. Distinctions: Awareness, Basing, and Agency  

2.1 Three Grades of Awareness  

(a) Phenomenal Awareness: occurrent, introspectively accessible episodes—“seeing” the justificatory connection.  
(b) Reflective Accessibility: the subject is not presently attending to the reason, but could bring it to conscious reflection with ordinary effort (e.g., when asked “Why do you believe that?”).  
(c) Subpersonal Representation: the information is encoded in the cognitive system in a way that guides inference or belief-formation, though it may never be accessible to consciousness (e.g., statistical priors in perceptual inference).

2.2 Two Kinds of Basing  

(i) Explanatory Basing: purely causal; R produces B.  
(ii) Epistemic Basing: the causal relation counts as *reasons-responsive*—the belief is *because* of the epistemic support that R provides.  This is the normative notion at issue.

2.3 Agency and Control  

An attitude is credit-conferring for S only if it issues from a subsystem that is integrated with S’s overall cognitive agency—roughly, it must be a system S uses for forming beliefs about the world, and it must be appropriately sensitive to error signals and override mechanisms.  Mere causal production (e.g., trauma-induced aversion) is not enough.

With these distinctions in place we can now assess the awareness requirement.

3. The Case *For* the Awareness Requirement  

Advocates offer three main lines of argument.

3.1 The Guidance Argument  

Belief-formation is an exercise of epistemic *guidance*.  I guide my doxastic conduct only if I can tell, at least in principle, what considerations I am acting on.  Otherwise the attitude is, from my reflective perspective, a black-box deliverance, more akin to a passive sensation than an achievement of rational agency.

3.2 The Responsibility Argument  

Epistemic justification implies *responsibility*.  One can be responsible for a belief only if one could *answer* for it.  Answerability demands the ability to cite one’s reasons, hence conscious awareness.

3.3 The Deviance Worry  

If a merely causal link suffices for basing, we face deviant causal chains: suppose an evil neuroscientist subliminally flashes “p → q; p” so that I non-consciously believe q.  Intuitively I have no justification, yet R (the premises) caused my belief.  Something like awareness seems needed to block deviance.

Taken together, the arguments aim to show that phenomenal or at least reflective awareness is a necessary condition.

4. Why Awareness Is Not Necessary  

4.1 The Continuity of Rational Architecture  

Cognitive science depicts a continuum from fully conscious theorizing to fast, probabilistic inference in perception.  The same Bayesian machinery underwrites both, differing mainly in speed and encapsulation.  If rationality is a matter of *structural conformity* to good inference, it would be mysterious to draw a justificatory line at the phenomenological boundary.  

Consider the ventral visual stream’s estimation of 3-D shape from shading.  The system encodes the prior assumption that light comes from above; when the prior is disconfirmed, the system revises its estimate.  Ignoring conscious supervision, the process is *responsive to reasons* (here, photometric cues).  If the subject consciously performed the same Bayesian update on explicit premises, she would be praised for rational inference.  To deny justificatory status to the automatic case is to make consciousness do epistemic work for which we lack an explanatory story.

4.2 The Regress Consideration  

If conscious awareness is required for each step of inference, a regress looms: for my awareness of R to justify B, must I be aware that I am aware of R, and so on?  A more plausible stopping-point is that some reason-relations can confer justification without being occurrently in view.  That suggests that what matters is the *availability* of reasons in the cognitive system, not their phenomenological presence.

4.3 Responsibility Without Occurrent Awareness  

Moral agency involves responsible automaticity—my ingrained habit of keeping promises is praiseworthy even if I act without deliberation each time.  Analogously, epistemic responsibility can attach to well-trained inferential dispositions.  What I must be able to do, when challenged, is *audit* the process, not replicate it step by step in consciousness.

4.4 Empirical Examples  

Case A: Rapid linguistic comprehension.  I hear “The astronomer married the star” and believe it reports a wedding, not astrophysical fusion.  The parse is driven by syntactic-semantic heuristics outside awareness but cancels if later context (“…achieved by gravity waves”) demands it.  The belief tracks evidence and retracts under defeaters; it behaves like an epistemically based attitude.

Case B: Radiologist expertise.  Veteran radiologists spot tumors “at a glance,” often unable initially to articulate the tell-tale patterns.  Subsequent verbalization is labored, yet their snap judgments correlate with ground truth.  Their perceptual attunement is a learned sensitivity to reasons (radiographic cues) even absent conscious articulation.

Case C: Infant statistical reasoning.  Six-month-olds expect a box with mostly red balls to yield a red sample and display surprise otherwise.  They cannot articulate proportions, but their expectations respect probabilistic evidence.  Denying them epistemic standing seems parochial.

Together these cases put pressure on the phenomenological boundary.

5. The Accessibility-Plus-Control Account  

5.1 The Core Proposal  

S’s belief that p is epistemically based on R even if S lacks conscious awareness of R, provided:  

(A) Subpersonal Justificatory Encoding: R is tokened *in content*—not merely as a neural cause but as a representational state that bears the appropriate justificatory relation to p.  

(B) Reasons-Responsive Causal Path: S’s belief-forming mechanism would not have produced p in the absence of R and would have produced ¬p given contra-evidence R*; i.e., it tracks truth via the justificatory link.  

(C) Auditability: Upon reflective challenge, S retains *executive* control—she can endorse, suspend, or correct the output, drawing (if needed) on further conscious reasoning.  The mechanism is integrated with higher-level monitoring.

When all three conditions obtain, the belief is the subject’s epistemic achievement even if, at the time of formation, the reasons never cross the threshold of awareness.

5.2 Why the Account Blocks Deviance  

In the evil neuroscientist scenario, (B) fails: had the neuroscientist flashed random nonsense, I would still have believed q, so the pathway is not reasons-responsive.  The proposal thus explains why deviant causation does not confer justification without appealing to consciousness per se.

5.3 Relation to Internalism and Externalism  

Accessibility-Plus-Control occupies middle ground.  Condition (A) satisfies the internalist’s insistence on representationally encoded reasons “within the subject’s perspective,” while (B) and (C) embed externalist sensitivity to truth and agency.  Conscious awareness becomes one *mode* of satisfying (A)–(C), not the sole mode.

6. Replies to Five Objections  

Objection 1: Epistemic Responsibility Revisited.  “But how can I be *responsible* for subpersonal processes I cannot inspect?”

Reply: Responsibility attaches to dispositions I rationally maintain.  I entrust perceptual modules because I have higher-level evidence of their reliability and corrective control (closing one eye, moving closer, asking others).  Responsibility is thus *indirectly* anchored in reflective endorsement of the system, not in occurrent supervision of each inference.

Objection 2: The Transparency of Reasons.  “Part of what it is to count as a *reason* for me is that it strikes me as such.  Otherwise the state is just a cause.”

Reply: The guiding intuition can be preserved by noting that qualification (A) requires representational encoding *as a telling consideration*.  For Bayesian perceptual inference, the system represents likelihoods and priors precisely in the form that would justify the updated posterior.  What makes it a *reason* is the functional role, not the phenomenology.

Objection 3: Blindsight Counter-example.  In blindsight, subjects form reliable guesses without conscious experience.  Yet they lack justification.  Doesn’t that show awareness is required?

Reply: Blindsight mechanisms violate condition (C): patients do not integrate the outputs into conscious cognitive control; they persistently deny having the relevant information.  Hence their “guesses” are not attributable to their epistemic agency.  The deficit is not absence of phenomenology *per se* but of the executive connectivity that underwrites auditability.

Objection 4: Bootstrapping Worry.  If unconscious processes confer justification, couldn’t I “justify” any wild belief so long as my brain happens to encode matching data?  We lose the ability to discriminate good from bad inference.

Reply: Condition (B) forestalls bootstrapping.  The mechanism must be stably reasons-responsive across counterfactual scenarios.  Mere accidental correlation or one-off causal linkage will not satisfy the requirement.

Objection 5: Implicit Bias as Counter-example.  Implicit racial biases operate automatically and subpersonally.  Should we therefore treat racist snap-judgments as justified?

Reply: No, because they fail (A) and (B).  The triggering states are not *epistemic* reasons—statistical generalizations polluted by social prejudice—and the mechanism is not truth-tracking.  Automaticity alone neither confers nor defeats justification; what matters is the quality of the encoded reasons and their integration with control.  Indeed, the framework explains why subjects can rightly be held epistemically *blameworthy* for biased beliefs: the mechanism is responsive to evidence (e.g., counter-stereotypical examples) and under their long-term rational control; neglecting to retrain it violates epistemic duty.

7. Conscious Reflection’s Residual Value  

While awareness is not necessary, it remains epistemically valuable.  It:

(i) Expands the pool of reasons that can be integrated across domains,  
(ii) Enables second-order evaluation (spotting systematic errors), and  
(iii) Grounds interpersonal justification—offering reasons to others.  

Hence phenomenology plays a crucial, though not foundational, role: it is a tool for enhancing justification, not the gatekeeper of basing.

8. Conclusion: Two Levels of Epistemic Life  

Human cognition operates on a layered architecture.  Subpersonal modules supply fast, probabilistic inference; conscious deliberation offers slow, cross-domain reasoning.  Epistemic virtue lies in the harmonious orchestration of both.  The Accessibility-Plus-Control account secures that harmony.  When my visual system non-consciously aggregates cues to deliver the belief “There’s a desk before me,” and I stand ready to check, correct, or explain that verdict, the belief is no less epistemically based for having originated in cognitive darkness.

Therefore, lack of conscious awareness does *not* preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on the reasons that subserve it.  What matters is the reasons’ presence in the agent’s cognitive economy in a form that guides belief in a reasons-responsive, agency-integrated way.  Conscious light can illuminate our reasons; it need not create them.

1. Orienting the Issue  

When I open my eyes and form the belief that there is a red coffee mug on the desk, I rarely advert, in consciousness, to anything I would call “my reasons.” The perceptual system delivers the representation automatically; I am struck by the mug’s presence, not by the evidential support for believing in it. Yet nearly every epistemological theory treats such perceptual beliefs as paradigmatically justified. How, then, should we evaluate the claim—advanced by some advocates of access‐internalism and of “responsibilist” epistemology—that a mental state is epistemically based on reasons only if the subject is consciously aware of those reasons? I will argue that lack of occurrent awareness does not preclude genuine epistemic basing, although dispositions for reflective awareness play an important downstream role. To make that case, I distinguish five things often run together: (i) the metaphysical basing relation, (ii) epistemic justification, (iii) epistemic responsibility, (iv) reflective endorsement, and (v) rational self‐assessment. Once these pieces are separated, we see that subpersonal, modular, and automatic processes can ground epistemic basing even in the absence of conscious access, while responsibility and self‐assessment depend on further conditions.

2. Why Some Think Awareness is Needed  

Two families of argument drive the awareness requirement.

A. The Responsibility Argument  
1. A belief is justified only if the subject is epistemically responsible for holding it.  
2. Responsibility entails the ability to cite or evaluate one’s reasons.  
3. Ability to cite or evaluate reasons requires conscious awareness of them.  
Therefore, justified belief requires awareness of one’s reasons.

B. The Guidance‐Control Argument  
Epistemic agency is analogous to practical agency: what merits credit is that which is under the agent’s guidance‐control. Guidance requires reasons that are available in consciousness, otherwise the process is merely causal, like a reflex.

If either argument succeeds, subpersonal processes confer, at best, animal‐level reliability, not genuine epistemic standing. I contend that both arguments overextend the concept of responsibility and misconstrue the locus of epistemic credit.

3. Distinguishing Four Kinds of ‘Reason’  

The debate is muddied by equivocation on “reason.” We need four contrasts.

i. Normative vs. Motivating Reasons  
A normative reason is a fact that counts in favor of a proposition’s truth. A motivating reason is the consideration that actually moves a subject to believe. Normative reasons need not be mentally represented; motivating reasons must be.

ii. Personal‐Level vs. Subpersonal‐Level Reasons  
Personal‐level reasons are those to which the agent could, in principle, have access through introspection or reflection. Subpersonal reasons are information‐bearing states within specialized modules—edge detectors in vision, syntactic parsers in language—that play a justificatory role without being accessible.

iii. Occurrent vs. Dispositional Awareness  
I might not now be consciously aware that “there is a red surface in front of me,” but with minimal prompting I can avow that as my reason. Awareness can therefore be standing rather than currently entertained.

iv. Justificatory vs. Explanatory Basing  
The explanatory base of a belief is the causal chain that produced it; the justificatory base is that subset of the chain that also provides epistemic support. Only the latter is relevant to epistemic status.

Armed with these distinctions, we can ask a cleaner question: Does a belief that is produced by subpersonal processes whose representational content is not consciously accessible nevertheless stand in the justificatory basing relation to the content of those states? I answer: yes, provided the process is of the right epistemic type.

4. The Case from Perception and Memory  

Perceptual belief is the paradigmatic counterexample to the awareness criterion. Consider three cases:

(i) Standard Vision: Anne looks at a tomato and believes it is red. She has no occurrent awareness of the low‐level luminance gradients that function as her evidence.  
(ii) Blindsight: Bob has damage in area V1; he denies seeing anything but guesses correctly where a light flashes. Bob lacks conscious experience, yet his guesses are reliably based on visual information.  
(iii) Change Blindness: Claire stares at a scene in which a large object is replaced in a flicker paradigm. She remains unaware of the change, though her eyes and early visual system registered it.

Anne’s belief is justified, Bob’s guesses are at least prima facie justified (though fragile), and Claire’s failure to notice the change is not blamed on irresponsibility; it is a limitation of normal cognition. These cases suggest that epistemic basing can occur in virtue of sub‐personal information processing, independent of awareness.

5. A Competence‐Based Account of Basing  

My positive proposal is a competence model, integrating insights from virtue epistemology and etiological accounts of normativity.

Thesis: A mental state M is epistemically based on reason‐bearing state R for subject S iff (i) R causally produces M via S’s epistemic competence C, (ii) C is a disposition that functions to produce truth in the relevant environment, and (iii) R is the content that C is designed to track.

Competence C can be implemented subpersonally; what matters is that it is the agent’s competence, constitutive of her cognitive architecture. Epistemic basing, on this view, is analogous to a skilled archer’s shot being guided by proprioceptive feedback she cannot articulate. Credit accrues because the shot issues from her competence, not because she can cite the micro‐corrections that served as her reasons.

6. Why Responsibility Does Not Require Occurrent Awareness  

Responsibility in ordinary moral contexts does not require contemporaneous, explicit reasoning. We laud the driver who reflexively brakes to avoid a child; we do not demand that she consciously computed stopping distances. Likewise, epistemic responsibility is anchored in the possession and proper deployment of competences. When things go well, the agent deserves credit even without occurrent reflection; when they go badly, criticism is warranted only if the agent failed to maintain competences she could reasonably sustain (e.g., ignored contrary evidence she might easily have noticed).

This view preserves a role for awareness: reflective endorsement is the mechanism by which agents monitor and repair their epistemic competences. But it is not a prerequisite for every justified belief. The awareness requirement mistakes the means of second‐order monitoring for the first‐order basis of justification.

7. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1 (The Alien Implant): Suppose my belief that p is produced by an alien chip that reliably stimulates the relevant neural pattern. I lack awareness of its operation. Yet by the competence account, p seems justified. Intuitively, it is not.  
Reply: The chip is not integrated into the agent’s epistemic competences; it bypasses them. Clause (i) of the competence model requires production via the subject’s own competences, not any reliable cause.

Objection 2 (Meta‐Inaccessibility): If the reasons are meta‐inaccessible, the subject cannot tell whether she is hallucinating or seeing. Doesn’t that undermine justification?  
Reply: The inability to *distinguish* between good and bad cases does not entail that the good case lacks justification. New Evil Demon scenarios teach us that internal similarity suffices for justification. All that is required is that, in the actual world, the competence functions properly.

Objection 3 (No Guidance): Without awareness, there is no guidance; the process is merely a causal pipeline.  
Reply: Control can be subpersonal. A skilled pianist executes arpeggios faster than conscious monitoring allows, yet we credit her. Guidance is exhibited by the system’s capacity to correct errors and to integrate with higher‐level goals; both occur below the threshold of attention.

8. Why Not Downgrade Basing to the Dispositional Level?  

A popular fallback is to say that what is necessary is not occurrent but dispositional awareness: the agent could, upon reflection, cite her reasons. I accept a *limited* version: for many human beliefs, such ability is present and contributes to epistemic virtue. But two points caution against enshrining it as necessary.

First, animals and preverbal children form perceptual beliefs that we deem epistemically good, though they lack the capacity to cite reasons even dispositionally. Second, sophisticated cognitive science shows that the lion’s share of our belief formation depends on processes whose data are *never* available to consciousness—feature maps, Bayesian weighting, and unconscious inference. Making “availability to reflection” a condition on epistemic basing would falsely classify most human cognition as unjustified.

9. A Division of Epistemic Labor  

The competence account thus supports a division of epistemic labor.

Level 1: Subpersonal competences generate beliefs from information (reasons) they internally represent.  
Level 2: Personal‐level awareness allows monitoring, criticism, and higher‐order justification (e.g., inferential beliefs, theoretical reasoning).  
Level 3: Collective‐level processes (peer review, testimony) further scaffold justification.

Only at Level 2 does conscious awareness become central; Level 1 already carries an irreducible portion of epistemic basing.

10. Implications for Modular and Automatic Processes  

Consider fast‐and‐frugal heuristics studied by Gigerenzer, or the face‐recognition module that yields the belief “That’s Jane.” If these heuristics are statistically tuned to the environment, their outputs are justified absent defeaters, even though the subject lacks access to the cue‐weighting matrices. Epistemic evaluation attaches to the *design* of the module, much as the reliability of a measuring instrument attaches to its calibration. Human cognitive architecture is itself one of our “instruments.”

Automaticity therefore poses no general threat to epistemic basing; the threat arises only when automation is *maladaptive* (as with implicit racial bias). Here, personal‐level reflection is crucial, not to supply first‐order justification, but to identify and correct malfunctioning competences. The awareness requirement is reinterpreted as a *regulative* norm: be in a position to notice when your own cognitive instruments misfire.

11. An Illustrative Example: Chicken Sexers  

Old‐school chicken sexers can identify the sex of a day‐old chick at 90% accuracy but cannot articulate how. Their judgments are justified: they possess a skill attuned to subtle visual cues serving as reasons, though inaccessible. The training process inculcates the competence; the resulting judgments exemplify epistemic basing without conscious awareness. What they lack is the capacity to *teach* the method verbally, not the epistemic status of their beliefs. The case vividly underscores the gap between knowing‐that and knowing‐why.

12. Residual Worries: Epistemic Luck and Error Cases  

Does subpersonal basing invite epistemic luck? Suppose a normally reliable module is temporarily disoriented by fog yet still by chance yields a true belief. The competence account copes by building in a performance condition: justification obtains only when the competence functions properly in *normal* conditions. If environmental degradation defeats the competence, justification lapses—even if, fortuitously, the belief is true. Awareness is irrelevant to this luck‐blocking condition.

13. Bringing It Together  

We can now answer the guiding question.

1. A mental state can be epistemically based on reasons that are encoded only subpersonally.  
2. Conscious awareness is neither metaphysically nor normatively necessary for first‐order justification.  
3. Awareness has a crucial but derivative role: it underwrites higher‐order epistemic responsibilities—calibration, error correction, intellectual virtue.  
4. Therefore, automatic, modular processes are legitimate carriers of epistemic basing, provided they are integrated into the subject’s competences and function properly in the environment.

14. Concluding Synthesis  

Philosophical pressure for the awareness requirement springs from conflating justification with the capacity to *defend* or *explain* one’s beliefs. Yet the latter is a second‐order virtue. Justification proper happens wherever the world’s informational structure is suitably registered by the subject’s cognitive architecture—whether or not that registration surfaces in consciousness. By acknowledging this layered picture, we do justice to two seemingly opposed intuitions: (a) that perceptual and other automatic beliefs are often justified, and (b) that reflective awareness is integral to responsible inquiry. The result is an epistemology that is both psycholog­ically realistic and normatively demanding—without insisting that the light of reason must illuminate every corner of the mind for knowledge to dawn.

1. Introduction and Thesis

When I avert my eyes from the road and automatically swerve to avoid a stray dog, none of the reasons that led me to turn the wheel—knowledge of canine fragility, a general aversion to harming living things, a standing desire to keep my car undamaged—were occurrently in consciousness. Still, it would be odd to say my maneuver was epistemically baseless, on a par with a mere twitch. What seems right is that I had the right reasons, even though they never became the focus of attention.  

This intuitive verdict conflicts with a prominent “awareness requirement.” According to that requirement, a person’s mental state (belief, intention, perceptual judgment, etc.) is justified or rational only if she is consciously aware of the reasons on which it is based—perhaps by entertaining them as premises, perhaps by having them “before the mind” in a felt way. The demand is advanced by some access‐internalists (e.g., BonJour 1998, Fumerton 2001) and by recent agency‐driven accounts of basing (e.g., Lord 2021, Littlejohn 2020). These philosophers worry that unless reasons are consciously accessible, the state is just the upshot of a subpersonal mechanism, devoid of epistemic credit.  

My thesis is that lack of conscious awareness does not, in general, preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on the reasons that in fact support it. Conscious access may be important for certain grades of epistemic standing—reflective justification, second‐order knowledge that one knows—but not for the primitive basing relation that grounds first‐order justification. I defend a “functional accessibility” model: R bases belief B in subject S just in case (i) R is a contentful state in S’s cognitive architecture, (ii) R non‐deviantly causes or sustains B in virtue of its content, and (iii) R is poised—should circumstances of reflection arise—to be retrieved and deployed in conscious reasoning. Conscious awareness is sufficient but not necessary—a dispositional capacity to bring reasons to consciousness suffices.  

The discussion proceeds in four stages. Section 2 clarifies the target claim and distinguishes basing, having a reason, and being justified. Section 3 presents three lines of argument for the awareness requirement and diagnoses their weaknesses. Section 4 develops the functional accessibility account and shows how it handles cases of modular or automatic cognition. Section 5 replies to residual objections and draws implications for epistemic agency.

2. Clarifying the Terrain

2.1 Basing vs. Possessing Reasons  
A person can have a reason R in her belief‐set without B being based on R. I believe the barometer has dropped and I believe a storm is coming; but if the causal route from the first belief to the second runs through wishful thinking rather than meteorological inference, the belief is not based on the barometer reading even though that reading is among my stored propositions.

2.2 Justification vs. Basing  
Many reliabilists hold that a belief may be justified (in virtue of arising from a reliable process) even if it is not based on the subject’s own reasons. The awareness theorist’s focus is narrower: she targets the basing relation itself, not every route to justification. The question, then, is whether awareness is necessary to differentiate “good” from “deviant” causation when R actually does sustain B.

2.3 Grades of Awareness  
Awareness has at least three grades:  
A) Phenomenal consciousness: R’s content figures in current phenomenal experience.  
B) Access consciousness: R is available for report and deliberate control, though not presently attended to.  
C) Dispositional availability: R could be brought under access consciousness through ordinary reflective effort.

The awareness requirement, as defended by its proponents, typically points to (A) or (B). My functional accessibility model aligns basing with (C).

3. Arguments for the Awareness Requirement

3.1 The Credit Argument  
Epistemic credit, some say, belongs to the agent only if she guided herself by reasons she appreciated. Suppose a clairvoyant unknowingly forms true beliefs via an unreliable faculty. Lacking awareness of any reasons, her true beliefs are not creditable. From this, the awareness theorist generalizes: genuine basing always requires conscious appreciation.

Diagnosis. The inference is hasty. The clairvoyant lacks not merely awareness of reasons but the reasons themselves—her faculty delivers beliefs without evidence. By contrast, automatic perceptual judgments are delivered by mechanisms that encode and deploy rich informational states (edge detection, motion parallax, etc.) that truly support the judgments. The presence of reasons, not their occurrent appreciation, secures credit. Skillful action offers an analogy: the pianist merits praise for her effortless arpeggios even if she could not articulate every micro‐movement; what matters is that the execution flows from her trained capacities, which are attributively hers.

3.2 The Control Argument  
Being rational requires guidance by norm‐responsive control. If reasons are subpersonal, they cannot be integrated into the agent’s rational control system; hence no basing.

Diagnosis. Cognitive science draws the agent/subpersonal line differently. Much “System 1” processing, though fast and automatic, is sensitive to informational inputs in norm‐governed ways. Witness Bayesian perceptual cue integration: the brain weights cues by their reliability. Such probabilistic tuning is part of the agent’s control system, just at a non‐conscious level. Control, therefore, does not entail consciousness; it entails the right kind of informational sensitivity.

3.3 The Introspective Test  
Ask the subject “Why do you believe p?” If she cannot cite R, that shows p is not based on R. Introspective accessibility seems built into the concept of basing.

Diagnosis. Two fallacies lurk. First, basing is synchronic; interrogation is diachronic. A belief might be well‐based at t₀ though the subject forgets the supporting considerations at t₁. Second, people often have poor self‐knowledge of their evidential motives (Nisbett & Wilson 1977). If their inability to articulate reasons nullified basing, most of our everyday reasoning would be irrational. The introspection test is defeasible evidence at best.

4. The Functional Accessibility Account

4.1 Core Idea  
A mental state R bases belief B for S when:

(i) Content‐Causation: R’s content non‐deviantly causes B. If R were absent or had different content, B would differ accordingly.  
(ii) Integration: R is stored within S’s personal‐level cognitive architecture (not merely in environmental scaffolding).  
(iii) Accessibility Condition: S is in principle able, through normal reflective routes, to become aware of R and to use it in explicit reasoning.

4.2 Why Condition (iii)?  
We need (iii) to safeguard against deviant causal coincidences (e.g., a brain lesion that both implants B and separately produces R). If the causal route does not pass through pathways that make R retrievable, R is not the agent’s reason. But (iii) is weaker than the awareness requirement: R must be available, not occurrent.

4.3 Automatic Inference Cases

Case 1: Face recognition. You glance at a stranger and believe “He’s angry.” The visual system computes features (furrowed brow, tightened lips) and, drawing on learned associations, outputs the categorical judgment. You cannot list the micro‐features, but given training in emotion recognition you could come to articulate some of them. Conditions (i)–(iii) are met: the features causally ground the judgment, reside in your visual memory, and are accessible to reflection. The belief is based on reasons you are not yet aware of.

Case 2: Expert chess move. A grandmaster “just sees” that Qe4 is best. Eye‐tracking shows her gaze lingers on threatened squares; her pattern‐recognition modules crunch tactical motifs. She later justifies the move verbally upon demand. Again, the reasons were available but not consciously front‐and‐center during decision.

4.4 Blind‐Sight and the Limit Case  
Why not say the blindsight subject’s guess is based on reasons? Because Condition (iii) fails. Although subpersonal states convey information about stimuli, the subject cannot—without prompting that bypasses the damaged V1 route—bring those states under conscious scrutiny. Hence the informational states are not functionally accessible in the relevant sense; they are encapsulated from personal‐level cognition. The model thus preserves the intuition that blindsight lacks epistemic basing.

5. Objections and Replies

Objection 1: The model trivializes basing; any reliable causal chain will satisfy (i)–(iii).  
Reply: Reliability without content‐sensitive causation or accessibility does not meet (iii). Consider an AI chip surreptitiously implanted in my skull that outputs stock tips. The data flow is not stored within my cognitive architecture; I cannot retrieve or manipulate it. So condition (ii) fails. The account is stricter than bare reliabilism.

Objection 2: Reflective equilibrium demands more. Unless the subject actually endorses R, she cannot rationally integrate new evidence that bears on R.  
Reply: Actual endorsement is necessary for some higher‐order norms (“be able to defend your beliefs”), but first‐order justification precedes such reflection. Infants, animals, and distracted adults still form perceptual beliefs that are prima facie justified, even if they lack the metacognitive prowess to endorse reasons.

Objection 3: The awareness requirement explains over‐rationalization; people confabulate reasons because they sense a normative pressure to be aware.  
Reply: Confabulation shows that people mistake the conditions of rationality; it does not show the mistake is correct. Indeed, they confabulate precisely because the real subpersonal reasons are unreportable, yet efficacious. Functional accessibility places the reasons within the agent; confabulation arises when accessibility is impeded or memory is degraded, not because basing always demands current awareness.

6. Epistemic Agency Revisited

On the proposed view, epistemic agency operates on two levels.

Tier 1: Sub‐reflective agency. Here, perception, memory, and inference run automatically but in ways that track evidence. Justification accrues as long as the cognitive system is properly calibrated.  

Tier 2: Reflective agency. When time and attention permit, we audit our Tier-1 outputs, integrating them, revising them, or discarding them. Conscious awareness of reasons enhances agency, enabling deliberate reasoning, but Tier-1 agency already earns a kind of credit: the credit due a well‐trained, responsible cognitive system.

This two‐tier picture aligns with empirical findings (dual‐process theory), with virtue epistemology (where well‐functioning capacities ground credit), and with ordinary practice (praise the doctor for a swift, intuitive diagnosis, yet still expect a reasoned explanation on request).

7. Conclusion

The awareness requirement overplays the role of consciousness in grounding epistemic basing. While conscious access is pivotal for reflective knowledge, the primitive basing relation is secured whenever reasons are functionally accessible—integrated into the agent’s cognitive system and causally responsible for her belief. Modular, automatic processes therefore can, and often do, provide genuine epistemic grounding. The upshot is a more ecologically realistic epistemology, one that recognizes human reasoning for what it largely is: fast, frugal, and mostly invisible to introspection, yet nonetheless rational in virtue of the reasons silently doing their work beneath the limelight of consciousness.

1. Framing the Problem  

The contemporary debate about epistemic basing is pulled between two desiderata. On the one hand, we want an account on which the justification of my beliefs is creditable to me; epistemic status should not be a mere accident of brain chemistry but something for which I can, in principle, be held responsible. That impulse tempts us toward a “conscious-awareness requirement”: my belief that p is justified by reason R only if I consciously entertain (or at least can consciously recall) R as my reason. On the other hand, cognitive science stresses that most ordinary belief-formation is automatic, modular, and largely inaccessible to introspection. If conscious awareness were strictly required, it would follow that the lion’s share of human (and animal) cognition is epistemically blind—an unpalatable conclusion.  

Thesis.  Lack of occurrent conscious awareness of reasons does not in itself bar a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons. What epistemic basing requires is that the subject’s cognitive system deploy the reasons in a way that is (i) counterfactually sensitive to their truth-makers and (ii) suitably available for personal-level endorsement under normal conditions of reflection. Conscious access can play a facilitating role, but it is neither necessary nor sufficient for genuine basing.

I defend that claim in five steps. (1) I clarify the target: “conscious awareness,” “reasons,” and “basing.” (2) I present the strongest case for the awareness requirement, drawn from responsibility, transparency, and deference considerations. (3) I show that each argument overgeneralises once we examine uncontroversial cases of justified automatic inference. (4) I develop a dispositional-accessibility model that preserves the agentive element without demanding occurrent consciousness. (5) I answer three residual objections and draw broader implications for epistemology and the philosophy of cognitive science.

2. Three Crucial Distinctions  

2.1 Occurrent vs. dispositional awareness. One can have a reason “before the mind” (currently entertaining it), one can have the capacity to recall it given minimal reflection (dispositional awareness), or one can lack even that capacity. The awareness requirement as commonly pressed is specifically about occurrent awareness.

2.2 Personal-level vs. subpersonal processes. An inference is personal-level when the subject, not merely a subsystem, is the functional “consumer” of the content. The oculomotor system that triggers a saccade is subpersonal; the recognition that a student in the back has raised her hand is personal. Many automatic inferences—e.g., grammatical parsing—are personal-level even though they are not consciously controlled.

2.3 Guiding vs. merely causing. For R to function as my reason for believing p, the presence of R must guide the formation or maintenance of the belief, not merely cause it in some deviant way. The basing relation is therefore a norm-governed causal relation.

3. The Best Case for a Conscious-Awareness Requirement  

3.1 Responsibility. We praise or blame agents only for what they do knowingly. If epistemic evaluation is a species of normative appraisal, justified belief must be one for which the subject knowingly relies on the appropriate reasons.

3.2 Transparency. One distinctive feature of epistemic reasons is that we can answer the transparency question: “Why do you believe that p?” If I cannot cite any reason, arguably my belief floats free of epistemic moorings.

3.3 Deference. Epistemic rationality involves deference to one’s reasons: I form a belief because the reasons support it, not vice-versa. But if the reasons never even appear in consciousness, deference seems impossible; the dependence relation is hidden behind cognitive black boxes.

4. Why the Case Overgeneralises  

4.1 Ubiquity of Unconscious Yet Justified Inference.  

Visual shape constancy: I judge the door is rectangular despite its retinal image being trapezoidal. The shape-from-shading modules integrate depth cues and project a 3-D model; I am utterly unaware of the geometrical reasons exploited, yet few would say my belief is unjustified.  

Statistical reasoning: Experts who can instantly tell the sex of a chick or the authorship of a painting often cannot articulate the features on which they rely. Psychologists call this “expert intuition,” and it reliably outperforms conscious novices. If the awareness requirement were strict, we would have to deny that such expertise produces knowledge.  

4.2 Confabulation and the Argument from Sufficiency. Conscious avowal is frequently too cheap. Split-brain and priming experiments show that subjects will produce post-hoc “reasons” that are unrelated to the actual causal basis of their choices. If mere consciousness sufficed for basing, these confabulated reasons would count. So consciousness is not sufficient; that casts doubt on its necessity.

4.3 Skill Analogy. In ethics we happily credit an agent for skilled automatic action—e.g. the pianist’s arpeggio—even though she is not consciously aware of the micro-movements guiding her fingers. The epistemic analogue is the expert whose reasoning is automatic yet trained. Responsibility can extend to the cultivated dispositions even when moment-to-moment awareness is absent.

5. A Dispositional-Accessibility Account  

Core idea: For a belief B to be based on reason R, the agent must possess a competence C such that:

(Comp1) C token-processes input R into output B in normal conditions.

(Comp2) If the agent were to reflect under conditions conducive to epistemic self-assessment—no time pressure, no drugs interfering with working memory—she would be able to cite R (perhaps after some search) as what justifies B.

(Comp3) The process instantiating C is counterfactually sensitive to the truth-makers of R: were R false or unreliable, C would, with high probability, refrain from outputting B.

This view borrows from internalist “evidence access” and externalist “proper function.” Consciousness drops out as a necessary condition; what matters is integration within the subject’s epistemic agency. Let me show how the account handles the earlier desiderata.

5.1 Responsibility. The subject is evaluatively responsible because C is her competence—formed through learning and open to critical scrutiny. She can, if prompted, examine and amend C. That satisfies the moral analogue: I am responsible for my driving even when I change gears automatically.

5.2 Transparency. Although she may initially shrug when asked for reasons, under Comp2 the reflectively idealised subject can retrieve them. Transparency is thus preserved in principle, though not necessarily in every conversational context.

5.3 Deference. The guidance condition (Comp1) ensures that R, not some deviant cause, controls the belief-forming process. Conscious appreciation is one but not the only way that guidance can be realised.

6. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: Epistemic evaluation is moment-sensitive. At t1 the subject believes p without conscious reasons; at t2, after reflection, she gains access to R. Our account seems to back-date justification to t1, which some find implausible.  

Reply. Basing is synchronic; justification is not. At t1 the competence C is already in play; what reflection adds is **recognitional justification**—knowledge that one’s belief is justified. Basic justification can obtain because the competence is already sensitive to R.

Objection 2: What about cases of unconscious bias? A hiring manager may automatically judge a candidate unsuitable because of subliminal cues correlated with race. The competence is dispositional, accessible upon reflection, counterfactually sensitive—yet wrongfully biased. Does our model wrongly count these as justified?  

Reply. Comp3 blocks the result. The heuristic linking race-cue to job suitability is not sensitive to truth-makers; it tracks irrelevant features. Because the process is not truth-conducive, the resulting belief fails condition Comp3.

Objection 3: Animals and infants have no capacity to access reasons even dispositionally. Do they therefore lack justified belief?  

Reply. We can incorporate a “graded” notion of basing. Minimal epistemic status—call it proto-justification—requires only that the belief arise from a properly functioning truth-tracking mechanism. Full-fledged justification, evaluable in normative terms, adds the dispositional-accessibility condition. Humans typically occupy the higher tier; animals the lower. The account explains why we hesitate to attribute “ought”-level responsibility to a dog yet are comfortable saying it “knows” where the bone is buried.

7. Comparison with Rival Accounts  

7.1 Phenomenal Conception (McHugh, Lord). These views hold that justification supervenes on phenomenal character: your seeming that p provides you with conscious evidence. Our dispositional view agrees that seemings can justify but denies they are the only route. A tacit inference from “the door looks trapezoidal” to “the door is rectangular” is justified even when the rectangular seeming is absent (e.g., in peripheral vision).

7.2 Strict Internalism (Fumerton). The Cartesian idea that justificatory relations are available “by the light of reason” struggles with scientific cases (e.g., statistical modeling) where the explanatory patterns are cognitively opaque. Dispositional access rescues internalist intuitions without demanding infallible self-presenting states.

7.3 Pure Reliabilism. By removing any accessibility demand, pure reliabilism over-generates justification to cognitively impenetrable processes (black-box clairvoyance). Requiring Comp2 bars those cases: if I cannot in principle discover why my hunches about market fluctuations are reliable, I lack full justification even if they work by accident.

8. Broader Implications  

8.1 Epistemic Agency as Scaffolded. Conscious reasoning is the tip of an iceberg. Our automatic competences scaffold rational agency much like muscle memory scaffolds athletic performance. Recognising this allows epistemology to partner fruitfully with cognitive science instead of policing it.

8.2 Education and Deliberate Practice. The model vindicates the pedagogical emphasis on training automaticity (e.g., in mathematics). Once a student has drilled proofs, she can leap to conclusions rapidly yet remain justified because the practice embeds an accessible rationale.

8.3 Artificial Intelligence. Consider a self-explainable neural net that, when asked, can output a human-interpretable decision rule. Such a system satisfies Comp2. A black-box net that cannot expound its implicit rules does not. Thus the dispositional-accessibility test offers a principled benchmark for explainable AI.

9. Conclusion  

Conscious awareness is epistemically significant but not mandatory for basing. What justifies a belief is not the glow of phenomenology but the integration of the operative reasons into the subject’s cognitive architecture in a way that remains, in principle, transparent to her reflective capacities and that tracks the relevant truth-makers. Automatic modules can, and often do, satisfy these conditions; indeed, human knowledge would be impoverished without them. The hard work for epistemologists is therefore not to draw a bright line at consciousness, but to chart the contours of guidance, competence, and dispositional access—the deeper structures that tether mind to world even when the tether is hidden from view.

I. Introduction and Thesis

Can a belief or other doxastic attitude be epistemically based on reasons the subject does not consciously appreciate? I argue that the answer is Yes: occurrent, phenomenal awareness of one’s reasons is not necessary for epistemic basing. What is necessary is that the attitude be produced and sustained by a competence that functions to track epistemic reasons and that places those reasons within a space of reflective accessibility—i.e., the subject could, with ordinary reflective effort, cite considerations that are sufficiently close to the actual grounds of the belief. Conscious awareness is sufficient, but not necessary, for such basing. Modular, automatic, and sub-personal processes therefore can (and routinely do) yield justified beliefs. I defend this view by (i) clarifying the notion of basing; (ii) reconstructing the standard “awareness requirement” and diagnosing its appeal; (iii) presenting counter-examples that show awareness is not necessary; (iv) developing a competence-based alternative; and (v) answering residual objections about responsibility, defeat, and deviant causal chains.

II. What Is Epistemic Basing?

To say that S’s belief that p is justified because of evidence E is to say more than that E stands in an abstract evidential relation to p. It is to say that S’s belief is based on E—in virtue of some explanatory, typically causal, connection. This basing relation is located at the “personal level”: it is a relation in virtue of which an epistemic standing accrues to a mental state of the agent, under some description that figures in her cognitive economy. The disputed question is whether that relation always includes conscious appreciation of E, or whether non-conscious sensitivity to E can suffice.

III. The Awareness Requirement: Why It Seems Plausible

Defenders of the requirement offer three main lines of thought.

1. Agency and responsibility. Epistemic justification, they say, is answerability to reasons. One cannot be answerable to considerations of which one is entirely unaware. Our intuitive practice of praise and blame—“You should have known better!”—presupposes that the agent had her reasons in view.

2. Regress considerations. If the basing relation can obtain without awareness, justification becomes opaque: Why count some non-conscious causal routes as reason-responsive and others as deviant? Requiring awareness supplies an internal check that ends the regress of “And how do you know that?”

3. Transparency: When we shift to the epistemic perspective, we ask ourselves, “Why do I believe p?” and expect an answer in terms we can endorse. That first-person transparency, they argue, is constitutive of epistemic appraisal.

Taken together, these considerations make the awareness requirement attractive: it promises a principled mark of epistemic agency and avoids collapsing justification into mere reliability.

IV. Three Families of Counter-example

The requirement falters, however, when we consider commonplace cognitive cases.

1. Perceptual belief. I look out the window and believe there is a red car parked outside. My reason is presumably my visual experience. But I am typically not aware of that reason under the description “I see a red car.” My belief is, rather, spontaneously triggered; I may only become reflectively aware of my experiential grounds if prompted. Yet nearly everyone agrees such perceptual beliefs are paradigms of justification.

2. Automatic expertise. A chess grandmaster glances at a position and declares, “Qg4 wins.” Asked why, she might initially say, “It just looks right,” though, if pushed, she can unpack variations. The epistemic work is done by pattern-recognition modules honed through practice. Because the implicit statistical information is what makes the move correct, the belief is grounded in good reasons—even before she retrieves them consciously.

3. Linguistic comprehension. When a native speaker hears, “The senator objected to the bill,” she instantly believes that the senator, not the bill, did the objecting, based on syntactic cues about thematic roles. Syntax operates sub-personally, yet surely her interpretation is epistemically warranted.

These cases are not exotic; they are the fabric of ordinary cognition. So if conscious awareness were necessary, the domain of justified belief would shrink to deliberative reasoning—a revisionary and costly result.

V. Diagnosing the Appeal of the Requirement

Why, then, did the awareness requirement look compelling? Notice two conflations. First, between occurrent awareness and reflective availability. The fact that I can, upon reflection, cite E does not entail that I was consciously attending to E at t1, when I formed the belief. Second, between subjective justification (what S can humbly vindicate) and objective justification (what considerations genuinely supported her belief). The awareness theorist tries to secure both with a single condition, but this over-strains the notion of basing.

VI. A Competence-Based Account of Basing

1. Core idea. A belief is epistemically based on reasons R just in case it is produced and sustained by a cognitive competence whose proper function is to track truths via sensitivity to R-type information. Conscious awareness is one mode in which such sensitivity can manifest, but not the only one. On this view, basing is neither a mere causal link (too promiscuous) nor a purely phenomenological link (too demanding), but a teleological, function-grounded relation analogous to biological explanation: the heart’s beating circulates the blood whether or not it feels itself doing so.

2. Reflective accessibility. Still, epistemic agency matters. Competences that ground justification must integrate with higher-level cognition such that the subject can, given ordinary effort, bring the operative reasons into view. The grandmaster who can eventually spell out the combination meets this condition; the clairvoyant who cannot, does not. Accessibility, not occurrent awareness, is what responsibility requires.

3. Normative functioning. The competence must be functioning properly in the environment for which it was selected or trained. When vision is distorted by psychedelic drugs, perceptual beliefs lose justification even though produced by the same module. This “proper functioning” clause screens off deviant causal chains without invoking awareness.

VII. Meeting the Objections

A. Responsibility and answerability. Critics worry that if I am not aware of my reasons, I cannot own my beliefs. The competence model preserves responsibility because it ties justification to capacities that are under the agent’s rational control in the long run. I am commendable for using my vision and blame-worthy if I ignore clear defeaters (e.g., evidence I’m hallucinating). Responsibility accrues at the level of maintaining healthy competences and monitoring their outputs—tasks that presuppose, but do not reducibly consist in, moment-by-moment awareness.

B. The regress. The awareness theorist hopes to halt a regress by having each belief explicitly underwritten by another representational state. But that demand is self-defeating; it would require an infinite stack of higher-order beliefs. Competence-based basing is regress-resistant because competences are not themselves beliefs; they are standing abilities whose normative status rests on a posteriori facts about reliable design. The chain therefore terminates in the proper functioning of the cognitive system.

C. Transparency. Admittedly, first-person access is central to the epistemic perspective. Yet transparency is a regulative ideal, not a constitutive feature. My perspective enlarges when I discover the optics of color perception; I thereby gain finer-grained awareness of my reasons. But my earlier, naive color beliefs were nonetheless justified insofar as the same healthy visual system produced them. Justification is graded: consciousness sharpens it but is not its pre-condition.

VIII. Handling Potential Counter-examples

1. Blindsight. In blindsight, patients lack visual consciousness yet can guess object locations above chance. Are these guesses justified? No: although the sub-personal information is reliable, it is not integrated with the subject’s broader cognition; she herself takes the guesses to be random. That is why blindsight is epistemically defective. The competence account captures this: the relevant module is severed from higher-level systems, so reflective accessibility is absent.

2. Cognitive penetrability and wishful thinking. Suppose I desire that the stock market rise, and that desire non-consciously biases my interpretation of ambiguous financial news toward optimism. Is the resulting belief justified? The competence model says no: the biasing mechanism is not truth-aimed; it is a performance error in the reasoning system. Lack of consciousness does not condemn, but the improper function does.

3. The clairvoyant (BonJour). A clairvoyant believes that the President is in New York, on the basis of a reliable but mysterious faculty of which she is not aware. Lacking any reason to trust the process, she is not justified. Again, the competence account explains why: the faculty is not integrated with her network of epistemic competences; she lacks the capacity to recognize or respond to defeaters. Awareness could have served integration, but what is essential is integration itself.

IX. Why Modularity Is Epistemically Potent

Cognitive science portrays the mind as a patchwork of specialized, often encapsulated modules. If the awareness requirement were true, most outputs of these modules would fall outside the scope of epistemic appraisal. Yet our practices—scientific, everyday, and philosophical—grade visual, auditory, and syntactic deliverances as evidence. The competence model vindicates this practice without collapsing epistemology into psychologism. It credits modular deliverances when (i) they are the outputs of proper functioning mechanisms designed or learned to track truth, and (ii) the subject retains the ability to vet, contest, or corroborate those outputs.

X. Deliberative Versus Automatic Basing

We can now distinguish two species of basing.

1. Deliberative basing: The evidential considerations are present to consciousness as premises in an explicit inference. This is common in theoretical reasoning and in philosophical reflection.

2. Automatic basing: The evidential considerations are processed sub-personally; the resulting belief springs up without conscious inference. This is common in perception, language, face recognition, moral cognition, and expert intuition.

Both are epistemically potent, though the former affords finer self-scrutiny. We can even chart a continuum: what begins life as deliberative often becomes automatized through practice (driving a car, doing arithmetic). Automatization does not bleed away justification; indeed, it often increases reliability.

XI. Interaction with Defeat

One might worry that, absent awareness, the subject cannot appreciate defeaters. Yet competence-based basing has the resources to explain defeat. If a belief B is based on module M’s output, then a defeater D is any input that, given M’s proper function and its integration with higher cognition, should lead S to suspend or revise B. For perceptual beliefs, learning that one’s drink was spiked with LSD is a defeater; for moral intuitions, learning about framing effects may be partial defeater. The key again is integration: being part of a self-correcting network makes modules accountable to each other.

XII. Implications for Epistemic Theories

Our conclusion pushes against two poles of the internalism/externalism debate.

• Pure access internalism (justification supervenes on what is reflectively accessible) is too strict; it cannot credit justified perceptual beliefs in infants or animals.

• Pure process reliabilism is too lax; it credits clairvoyant beliefs and blindsight guesses that are not within the subject’s rational reach.

The competence model is a moderate externalism tempered by internalist accessibility: justification depends on reliable functioning, but only in competences poised for integration with reflective cognition. This hybrid captures the best intuitions on both sides.

XIII. Residual Worries

(1) Isn’t “could become aware with effort” a fudge factor? No. There are empirical markers for integration: inter-modular causal pathways, availability to working memory, ability to trigger surprise when mismatched with higher-level expectations. These can be studied scientifically.

(2) Does the view over-intellectualize animal knowledge? Not if we relativize reflective accessibility to species-typical capacities. For a dog, integration might require only that olfactory perception link to motor planning and error correction. Conscious reasons enter only where the architecture supports them.

XIV. What We Gain

1. A unified account. We need not posit two fundamentally different notions of justification—one for deliberation, one for perception.

2. Compatibility with cognitive science. The mind’s modularity and automaticity are not embarrassments but the engines of epistemic success.

3. Flexibility. The view predicts gradations of justification: as automatic outputs gain or lose integration (e.g., through neurological damage), the epistemic status shifts accordingly.

4. Responsiveness to agency. Responsibility is preserved insofar as agents maintain, monitor, and, when possible, improve their competences.

XV. Conclusion

Occurrent awareness of reasons is epistemically potent but not indispensable. What grounds the basing relation is the operation of truth-tracking competences that make reasons—whether perceptual, inferential, or statistical—matter causally to belief formation, and that embed those reasons within a system open to reflection, criticism, and correction. The consciousness requirement conflates the phenomenology of inquiry with its underlying functional architecture. Once we disentangle them, we see that modular, automatic cognition is not merely compatible with epistemic basing; it is one of its primary vehicles.

Does lack of conscious awareness of one’s reasons preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons? I shall argue that it does not. Occurrent consciousness of reasons is neither necessary for, nor constitutive of, the basing relation that underwrites epistemic justification. What matters instead is that the subject — under the right reflective and motivational profile — stands in a counterfactual-supporting, agency-implicating relation to the considerations that actually guide the formation or retention of her belief. Conscious access can facilitate that relation, and sometimes is required for higher-order epistemic goods (like understanding or knowledge that one knows), but it is not required for the basic normative status of being justified. In defending this thesis I proceed as follows.

1. The dialectical landscape: why consciousness is thought essential.  
2. Clarifying the basing relation: from causal pathways to rational guidance.  
3. A graded conception of awareness: occurrent, standing, and potential.  
4. Three arguments against the consciousness requirement.  
5. Replying to four influential objections.  
6. Positive account: agency-centred counterfactualism.  
7. Implications for modular cognition and automatic inference.  
8. Residual worries and prospects for future work.

Throughout I use “reasons” narrowly for epistemic reasons — considerations that bear on the truth of a proposition and can justify belief.

1. Why think consciousness is required?

The consciousness requirement is attractive for at least three connected motivations.

a. Accessibility Intuition: Justification seems to be something we can *give* when challenged (“Why believe p?”). If I cannot even bring to mind the reasons on which my belief is based, it is hard to see how the belief could be my rational doing rather than a mere causal happening.

b. New Evil Demon Parity: Internalists stress that two phenomenally indistinguishable subjects should share justificatory status. Thus, what justifies must be within the phenomenal perspective.

c. Guidance of Reason: To exercise my capacity as a rational agent I must *follow* reasons. Following appears to be a consciously guided activity.

These lines of thought suggest that if reasons operate entirely subpersonally, the agent is sidelined; whatever normative status accrues is, at best, a happy accident of cognitive engineering, not genuine rationality.

2. The basing relation

To assess the consciousness claim we need a clear conception of the basing relation, the “because” that links a belief to its justificatory grounds. Two traditions dominate:

Causal accounts: A belief is based on R just in case R non-deviantly causes (or sustains) the belief.

Reason-manifesting accounts: The belief is based on R iff the belief’s formation manifests the subject’s sensitivity to R as a reason; had R been absent or defeated, the belief would have changed in reason-appropriate ways.

Purely causal models are too permissive (the chicken-sexer’s lucky hunch can be caused by subtle features of the chicks without those features being reasons) whereas purely manifesting models can be too stringent (they threaten to collapse basing into conscious following). I propose a hybrid: basing requires (i) causal dependence of the belief on R under (ii) an *agency-implying rational sensitivity* condition. The agent’s cognitive architecture must be such that, *ceteris paribus*, variations in R would lead her to correspondingly rational doxastic variation. This modal condition counters deviant causation. Notice that it makes no mention of occurrent consciousness; it is a condition on capacities and counterfactuals.

3. Three grades of awareness

We need a richer taxonomy than “conscious/unconscious”.

• Occurrent awareness: the reason is presently before the mind, tokened in working memory or inner speech.

• Standing (or dispositional) awareness: the subject is not presently entertaining R, but could, with minimal reflection, recall or recognize it as her basis.

• Potential awareness: the subject could not articulate R even after reflection, yet the cognitive system she appropriately identifies with could, through learning or therapy, make R occurrent. Think of implicit biases one can eventually surface.

Consciousness sceptics about basing need show only that standing or potential awareness suffices for justification.

4. Arguments against the consciousness requirement

(i) The Continuity of Epistemic Practice

Our everyday attributions of justified belief do not track occurrent awareness. Suppose Alice glances at her office clock (which she has every reason to trust) at 3 pm, then becomes absorbed in writing. At 3:15 she believes it is approximately 3 pm. She has forgotten the perceptual experience; her belief is now subserved by memory. It seems paradigmatically justified, yet she is not consciously aware of any reason. To insist that her belief’s justificatory status evaporates the moment the perceptual content fades from consciousness is ad hoc and conflicts with epistemic practice.

(ii) The Problem of Inferential Intermediate Steps

Many deductive and statistical inferences rely on background rules we cannot consciously rehearse. Consider Bayesian updating: cognitive scientists posit quasi-Bayesian mechanisms in perceptual learning. When I see a blurred object and judge it is more likely a dog than a cat, that judgment is sensitive to the likelihoods of the percept under competing hypotheses. I lack conscious access to the conditional probability tables, yet the belief qualifies as epistemically good. Requiring awareness would render much of human (and scientific) inference unjustified unless mediated by overt reasoning, which is psychologically implausible.

(iii) The Child Epistemologist

Children acquire justified beliefs long before they can give reasons. A four-year-old who sees rain and believes the street is wet is justified. To deny this is to tie justification to sophisticated metacognition, contradicting developmental evidence about confident but epistemically appropriate belief in infancy. But if children can be justified without conscious reasons, so, by parity, can adults whose automatic modules do the same job.

5. Replies to four objections

Objection 1: Conscious recall vs. conscious availability

Defenders of the requirement might concede that occurrent awareness is not needed, but standing awareness is. Alice can *recover* the perceptual reason on demand; the Bayesian cannot. Is this a principled line?

Reply: Many perceptual cases do not allow standing awareness of reasons beyond “it looks that way.” Yet internalists accept such reasons. The Bayesian visual system delivers the “looks” content; the subject can cite it (“It looks like a dog”), satisfying standing awareness. Similarly, an implicit statistical reason can be available under generic descriptions the subject owns (“The evidence of what I saw”). Thus the line collapses.

Objection 2: Epistemic Responsibility

Justification is tied to responsibility; we can criticise beliefs for which the agent cannot provide reasons. So subpersonal basing excuses responsibility.

Reply: Responsibility is gradable. Holding agents answerable does not entail they must articulate their operative reasons in real-time; rather, they must be able to revise beliefs when presented with new reasons. Agency-centric counterfactualism secures this: if the dog-like patch turned out to be a trick of light, the subject would (ceteris paribus) drop the dog belief. That capacity grounds responsibility.

Objection 3: Swamping by Reliability

If subpersonal processes suffice, epistemic justification collapses into reliabilism. Consciousness marks the distinctively normative level.

Reply: The agency condition restores normativity. A belief formed by a reliable but totally encapsulated mechanism (a brain implant none of whose informational states integrate with the subject’s doxastic network) would fail the agency condition and thus fail to be justified. Reliability is necessary but not sufficient; integration in the agent’s reasoning system matters.

Objection 4: The Problem of Forgotten Evidence

The memory case shows that justification can persist without consciousness, but only derivatively: originally the belief was conscious, then memory inherits warrant. Automatic modular processes lack such pedigree.

Reply: The heritage model does not explain first-time justified beliefs delivered by vision, proprioception, or linguistic uptake, none of which involve prior conscious access to the subpersonal computations. Yet they are prima facie justified. Therefore pedigree cannot do the work.

6. Positive proposal: agency-centred counterfactualism

A subject S’s belief that p is epistemically based on reasons R iff:

(a) R are in fact explanatorily causally implicated in S’s forming or sustaining p, via mechanisms that belong to S’s cognitive agency — those upon which S relies in epistemic conduct.  
(b) The mechanism is *rationally sensitive to R*: under counterfactual scenarios where R were absent, or salient defeaters present, the mechanism would, in normal operating conditions, refrain from or revise p.  
(c) The information encoded by R is, under reflection and with sufficient cognitive resources, integrable into S’s conscious deliberation, permitting uptake into the space of reasons (though no guarantee it will actually be so integrated).

Clause (c) secures the connection with responsibility and reflection without demanding occurrent awareness. Clause (b) blocks deviant causal chains. Clause (a) ensures the belief’s formation is genuinely *hers* rather than imposed.

7. Modular cognition and automatic inference

On this view, modular processes can indeed yield epistemically based beliefs insofar as they meet the agency counterfactual. Perceptual modules, face-recognition systems, or linguistic decoders are not alien invaders; they are constitutive of our cognitive agency. They operate automatically, but their outputs are poised for rational control: we can suppress them when given override information (e.g., Muller-Lyer illusion lines are equal length; prosopagnosics learn to distrust “face looks familiar” intuitions). This capacity for override satisfies (b) and (c). Where override is impossible (a fMRI-based mind-control device implanting beliefs irrespective of defeaters) justification fails.

The upshot is layered normativity:  

• Subpersonal reliability is epistemically relevant when *integrated*.  
• Conscious reflection adds higher-order justification, yielding *warrant security* (knowledge that one’s belief is justified).  
• Modular automatic beliefs are often *prima facie* justified, defeasible by higher-level scrutiny.

This maps neatly onto epistemic practice: we trust perception provisionally, override when warned of illusions, and demand explicit arguments in contentious domains.

8. Residual worries and next steps

Two challenges merit future exploration.

First, does the agency-centred approach imply that non-human animals or infants, whose override capacities are limited, seldom have justified beliefs? I am inclined to a two-tier model: justification-as-apt (possession of truth-conducive processes) is available widely; justification-as-responsible (agent-level counterfactual sensitivity) comes in degrees. The basal tier suffices for many epistemic evaluations, the upper for assessments of cognitive responsibility.

Second, the account leans on modal claims about how the subject would respond to defeaters. Empirically, humans resist correction in belief perseverance scenarios. Does that undermine justification? I think not: the relevant modality is “under normal rational functioning.” Psychological impediments like motivational bias can prevent ideal operation. Justification should not be hostage to akrasia; otherwise no belief would be justified for imperfect agents. Still, calibrating the normalcy condition is delicate and intersects with debates over idealized epistemic norms.

Conclusion

Occurrent conscious awareness is not required for a mental state to be epistemically based on reasons. Justification hinges on whether the belief stands in a reason-sensitive relation to considerations integrated within the subject’s cognitive agency. Modular, automatic processes qualify provided they are reliable, defeater-sensitive, and poised for reflective endorsement. Conscious reflection deepens epistemic status but is not its ground floor. Thus the challenge to modular epistemology dissolves: lack of current awareness does not bar genuine epistemic basing; it merely locates that basing at a sub-personal yet agency-integrated level.

Does lack of conscious awareness of one’s reasons preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons? I shall argue that it does not. More precisely, I defend the following thesis:

Thesis. A subject S’s mental state M can be epistemically based on a body of reasons R even when S lacks occurrent or even dispositional conscious awareness of R, provided that (i) R figures in the sub-personal cognitive etiology of M in the right way and (ii) S is the proprietor of a cognitive competence that would, in normal circumstances, allow her to heed R when she turns her reflective attention to the matter. Conscious access to R is sufficient for epistemic basing, but it is not necessary.

1. Clarifying the terrain: basing, reasons, consciousness.  
2. Two arguments for the necessity of awareness and why they overreach.  
3. The positive case from perceptual justification, skill-based inference, and empirical psychology.  
4. A dual-level account of basing without awareness.  
5. Replies to four key objections.  
6. Broader implications for epistemic responsibility and the scope of the mental.

------------------------------------------------
1. Clarifying the terrain
------------------------------------------------
1.1 Epistemic basing.  A belief (or other cognitive attitude) is based on R when R is not merely available or possessed by the subject but actually plays the right kind of explanatory role in producing or sustaining the attitude.   Two broad families of accounts exist: causal-explanatory theories (Alston 1988; Khatchadourian 1963) and teleological/functional theories (Turri 2011; Kelp 2015).  I remain ecumenical: both can accommodate my thesis as long as they accept sub-personal causation as epistemically relevant.

1.2 “Reasons.”  I follow the widely shared view that epistemic reasons are facts or states of affairs that stand in the right kind of evidential relation to a proposition.  They need not be propositions entertained by the agent; they can be non-conceptual contents delivered by perception.  What matters is their evidential bearing, not their conceptual format.

1.3 Awareness and consciousness.
