Hence there is also what Philip Kitcher (2021) calls a *pragmatic aim* of belief: to contribute to human flourishing.  Call that value *Practical-Value* (PV).  TV and PV are not reducible, but they can be ordered by a *default priority rule* embedded in our practice of responsible believing:

(Priority) When PV considerations are ordinary (i.e., involving no catastrophic stakes), TV takes lexical priority.

The priority rule is justified in two complementary ways:

1. Epistemic Autonomy: Recognising a belief as such requires seeing it as answerable to evidence (Lynch, 2009).  A person whose beliefs float free of evidence does not count as a believer but as a fantasist or fiction-maker.

2. Social Division of Epistemic Labour: Communities need reliable transmitters of truth; if practical value routinely overrode evidence, testimonial trust would collapse (a point already implicit in Clifford).

However, lexical priority cannot be absolute.  Suppose an oncologist has weak evidence (60% confidence) that an experimental drug will help her patient but also knows that the patient’s only hope is to believe strongly that recovery is possible—the placebo effect may increase survival odds dramatically.  The oncologist’s *practical* reason to believe (and convey her belief) that the drug will work might, in this exceptional case, override the epistemic deficit.  That seems rational, not merely excusable.  So we need a mechanism by which PV can outweigh TV when the stakes are high enough.

III.  Modelling Override: The Threshold Strategy

Let us model belief choice via an *Epistemic-Pragmatic Utility (EPU)* function:

EPU(b) = w · TV(b) + PV(b),

where TV(b) is the expected truth accuracy of belief b, PV(b) its expected practical value, and w > 0 a weight capturing the agent’s intrinsic valuation of truth.

To honour lexical priority we set w normally at a very large value compared with the scale on which PV is measured; but w is not infinite.  The bigger the practical stakes, the more PV can rise to offset even a moderate loss in TV.  In ordinary contexts (buying milk, reading the news) PV differentials are trivial: the cost of a false belief about last week’s football score is negligible.  TV thus dominates.  In extraordinary contexts (life-or-death morale, incorrigible prejudice, the afterlife wager) PV skyrockets; TV may be outweighed.

This threshold picture avoids crude cardinal commensuration.  We do not require a single natural unit for truth and value; we need only a comparative relation expressing “worth sacrificing this increment of accuracy for that increment of welfare.”  Agents possess such comparative preferences, evidenced by their readiness to rely on quick heuristics in emergencies (sacrificing accuracy for speed) or to pay high costs for painstaking investigation when the margin for error is tiny (aircraft design).

One might object that the model collapses into Common-Currency Pragmatism.  The reply is that TV remains *non-instrumental* in the utility function—it is valued for its own sake, not merely for causal contributions to PV.  That is why w enters multiplicatively rather than deriving from PV.  A second objection is that the function is ad hoc unless we say how w is fixed.  Two answers: (i) *Constitutive*: Being an epistemic agent sets a normative floor such that w must exceed a minimum value if one’s cognitive life is to count as belief-governed.  (ii) *Contextual*: Social roles (scientist, friend, parent) encode variable w’s; a scientist’s professional w is higher, which is why wishful belief is more culpable in the lab than at a child’s bedside.

IV.  Objections and Replies

1. Deontic Disunity:  The Threshold Strategy still delivers conflicting prescriptions: “epistemically, believe not-p; all-things-considered, believe p.”  Is that stable?  Yes.  Consider moral cases: legally you may speak hateful speech, but morally you ought not.  Agents navigate layered normativities constantly without confusion.  What matters is transparent ordering: we know which norm trumps when they conflict.

2.  Clifford’s Accusation:  Clifford argued that any departure from evidence is culpable because it encourages bad epistemic habits.  The model answers that Clifford correctly notes a *systemic* PV of truth-responsiveness.  That systemic PV is built into w; hence only huge additional PV can outweigh it.  The oncologist case clears the bar; everyday superstitions do not.

3.  Suspension Cases:  What about cases where evidence is ambiguous and practical stakes urge belief?  The model does not license wishful belief because suspension has the highest TV when confidence is low, and PV may often be served equally by adopting certain actions without adopting the belief (acting *as if*).  That option subtracts from PV(believe) the cost of potential embarrassment or self-deception, raising the threshold still further.

4.  Doxastic Involuntarism:  “We cannot believe at will; talk of ‘ought’ is pointless.”  Even granting involuntarism, we can ask what attitudes we *ought* to cultivate, what evidence to seek, what testimony to expose ourselves to, etc.  Furthermore, partial control (e.g., attention, imaginative framing) suffices for normativity—as with emotions, which are also partly involuntary but subject to rational evaluation.

V.  Examples Doing Work

A.  The Bridge Engineer.  An engineer inspects an old bridge.  Evidence of corrosion suggests a 5% chance of collapse.  A busload of children must cross.  If the engineer believes the bridge is safe, she may let them cross; if she believes it unsafe, she blocks the route, delaying vital medical supplies.  The practical cost of a false *safe* belief is catastrophic; the cost of a false *unsafe* belief is a minor delay.  TV pulls towards suspension (insufficient evidence either way), PV strongly favours the cautious belief (unsafe).  Since PV is high and lines up with TV’s uncertainty, the model endorses believing “the bridge is unsafe.”  No paradox arises.

B.  Religious Consolation.  A grieving parent finds profound solace in believing she will see her child again.  Epistemic evidence is ambiguous; PV is immense.  Is belief rational?  The model asks how high w is for the parent in the given context.  Suppose w is high (she values truth deeply) and the social cost of delusion is medium.  PV may not suffice to cross the threshold; suspension or hope, rather than outright belief, remains rational.  The upshot vindicates many people’s ambivalence about religious faith: they may *hope* rather than *believe*.

C.  Stereotype Correction.  You suspect, on slim evidence, that a promising student might underperform.  Historical injustice gives a powerful practical reason *not* to believe the stereotype.  Because false negative expectations can sabotage performance (stereotype threat), the PV of suspending belief is high.  Importantly, TV does not clearly lean the other way—your evidence is weak.  The model therefore supports suspension, aligning with recent work on “moral encroachment” without granting that morality directly changes evidential thresholds.  It is the *all-things-considered* inquiry that favours suspension.

VI.  Advantages over Rivals

1.  Over SEP: Explains rational permissibility of some pragmatic beliefs without denying reality of epistemic normativity.

2.  Over Distinct-Ought: Provides a single deliberative verdict when needed for action; preserves agents’ integrity.

3.  Over Common-Currency: Retains the sui generis value of accuracy, thus accommodating the intuition that *even harmless falsehoods* are epistemically defective.

4.  Over Crude Hybrid Weighing: Avoids proliferation of arbitrary utility tradeoffs by embedding a default lexical priority and context-sensitive threshold.

VII.  Metanormative Payoff

The Conditional Priority Model suggests a broader lesson: apparent incommensurability often stems from category mistakes about *where* commensuration must occur.  Truth-conduciveness and welfare are heterogeneous properties of propositions, but deliberation happens at the level of agency, where reasons of different kinds become comparable because the agent must adopt a single course—believe, disbelieve, or suspend.  Practical rationality is the crucible in which distinct normative metals can be alloyed, not by reducing them to a common essence but by fixing a practical order of authority.

This resonates with John Broome’s “normative requirement” view, on which rationality consists in conforming one’s attitudes to higher-order relations among them.  It also echoes Aristotle’s phronesis: the virtuous agent discerns the *right* mean, sensitive to the salience of goods in each situation.  What modern decision theory adds is simply a formal language for thresholds.

VIII.  Concluding Synthesis

We began with a worry: epistemic and practical reasons seem incommensurable, so how could they jointly determine what one ought to believe?  The Conditional Priority Model answers:

1.  They need not be weighed as homogeneous tokens; they are evaluated via the agent’s higher-order standard that accords default lexical priority to truth.

2.  Practical reasons override only when the pragmatic stakes exceed a robust but finite threshold, fixed by the constitutive and social importance we place on accuracy.

3.  Decision-theoretic representation clarifies, but does not reduce, the distinctive authority of epistemic reasons.

Far from being an impossible marriage, epistemic and practical reasons form a hierarchical partnership: truth normally leads, but value can take the wheel on rare, momentous occasions.  Such a division of normative labour fits both our reflective intuitions and our lived practices.  And it resolves the spectre of incommensurability by showing that the locus of comparison is not the reasons themselves but the agent who must shoulder them.

Truth, Benefit, and the Normativity of Belief: A Threshold-Lexical Model for Integrating Epistemic and Practical Reasons

1. Introduction and Statement of Thesis  

The question presupposes three claims many philosophers accept yet find hard to reconcile.  

(i) Epistemic reasons—features such as evidential support, explanatory power, and reliability—bear on what one ought to believe because they track the aim of belief: truth.  
(ii) Practical reasons—features such as moral stakes, prudential usefulness, or social harm—also appear to bear on what one ought to believe; William James’s “will to believe,” Pascalian wager cases, or high-stakes pragmatic encroachment all suggest that sometimes usefulness matters.  
(iii) Epistemic and practical reasons differ in kind, so there seems to be no common currency for balancing them.  

I shall defend the following thesis:  

A person’s all-things-considered (ATO) doxastic ‘ought’ is governed by a two-tier normative structure. Epistemic reasons have lexical priority, in that practical considerations are normatively inert until a sufficiently high epistemic threshold has been met—roughly, until the evidential state makes the relevant proposition doxastically permissible. Once that threshold is reached, practical reasons may tilt the balance among the epistemically permissible options. Where the threshold is unmet, practical reasons can influence only indirect policies (e.g., inquiry management) but cannot directly justify belief.  

This threshold-lexical model yields interaction without commensuration: practical reasons never compete head-to-head with evidential support; they speak only after the evidential bar of permissibility is cleared. The picture combines insights from James, Clifford, Raz’s exclusionary-reasons framework, and recent work on epistemic permissivism and pragmatic encroachment, yet it departs from each by introducing a specific threshold mechanism that explains and limits practical influence.

The argument proceeds in six stages: (2) clarifying the varieties of ‘ought’; (3) diagnosing the incommensurability worry; (4) developing the threshold-lexical model; (5) replying to four major objections; (6) showing how the model illuminates familiar cases; and (7) briefly indicating implications for epistemic norms and social epistemology.

2. Two Senses of ‘Ought’ Governing Belief  

Philosophers routinely conflate three distinct uses of ‘ought’:

Epistemic ought (E-ought): the standard of truth-conduciveness. One E-ought to believe p just in case p is sufficiently supported by her evidence.  
Practical or pragmatic ought (P-ought): the standard of value or utility. One P-ought to believe p if believing p maximizes expected practical value (prudential, moral, or otherwise).  
All-things-considered doxastic ought (ATO-ought): the unique normative verdict that integrates all pro-belief reasons, whatever their source.

Statements of the form “you ought to believe climate change is anthropogenic” are often ambiguous between E-ought (what your evidence says) and P-ought (because acting on that belief averts catastrophe). The explanatory challenge concerns ATO-ought: how do E-reasons and P-reasons combine to yield one net directive?

3. Why Incommensurability Looks Inevitable  

Three arguments for incommensurability seem especially forceful.

3.1 Different Aims Argument. Belief aims at truth; practical rationality aims (inter alia) at welfare. Because the constitutive aim of belief is truth, the standards governing it must be exclusively epistemic; to weigh usefulness against truth is to replace the activity with something else (acceptance, make-believe).  

3.2 Value-Type Argument. Epistemic reasons are alethic goods, practical reasons are prudential/moral goods, and there is no single scale relating the two. You cannot sensibly add ‘3 units of probability’ to ‘5 units of expected utility’.  

3.3 Doxastic Deliberation Argument. When one asks oneself whether p, one can respond only to considerations bearing on p’s truth. A pragmatic consideration like “believing p will keep me healthy” is motivationally inert within the distinctive phenomenology of belief-formation.

The upshot appears to be stalemate: either practical reasons are screened off (purism) or they swamp epistemic ones (radical pragmatism); no stable mixed view seems coherent.

4. The Threshold-Lexical Model  

4.1 Two Normatively Distinct Phases  

The key move is to notice that ‘what to believe’ is decided in two temporally and normatively distinct phases:

Phase 1 – Permissibility determination. What beliefs are epistemically permissible given my evidence? Here only E-reasons have normative force.

Phase 2 – Optionality resolution. Among the permissible options (believe p, suspend, believe ¬p), which should I adopt? Here, if multiple options remain permissible, practical reasons can legitimately tip the scale.

Thus practical considerations never trade off against evidential support; they operate only when the evidential hurdle is cleared. We thereby secure a form of interaction (practical reasons can indeed matter) without commensuration (they never go toe-to-toe with evidence).

4.2 The Threshold  

How strong must evidence be to make a doxastic attitude epistemically permissible? The model allows context-sensitive thresholds, but a natural default is the “preponderance” level: credence > .5 for belief, < .5 for disbelief, and = .5 for suspension. More sophisticated versions could appeal to safety or knowledge thresholds. Crucially, the threshold must be fixed independently of practical stakes, or lexical priority collapses.

4.3 Why Lexical, Not Merely Weighted  

Could we instead assign cardinal values to truth and welfare and maximize the sum? That returns us to incommensurability worries. By giving epistemic reasons lexical priority, we honor the constitutive aim of belief: one cannot, within the practice of belief, settle for a claim one takes to be under-evidenced merely because it is convenient. Practical reasons then play only a tie-breaking or option-selecting role.

4.4 Razian Exclusionary Structure  

The model can be recast in the idiom of exclusionary reasons. Epistemic reasons generate first-order reasons for belief and, at the same time, a second-order exclusionary reason disabling the consideration of practical factors unless the first-order balance yields permissibility. Once the exclusionary reason is lifted (threshold met), practical reasons regain normative force.

5. Replies to Four Objections  

Objection 1: High-stakes pragmatic encroachment shows that practical stakes raise the evidential bar itself (e.g., you need more evidence to know the bank will be open if the payoff of error is high).  

Reply: Pragmatic encroachment concerns knowledge, not permissibility of outright belief. Even if knowledge is stake-sensitive, belief permissibility can remain stake-insensitive. Alternatively, one might fold encroachment into the model by allowing the threshold to vary with stakes—but then lexical priority is lost. I argue that keeping belief permissibility stake-insensitive better preserves the distinctive nature of doxastic attitudes.

Objection 2: The model still permits morally disastrous beliefs, provided minimal evidence supports them. Suppose a racist has weak but non-negligible evidence for a repugnant claim; if believing would cause harm, shouldn’t practical reasons forbid belief?  

Reply: Two answers. First, ‘weak but non-negligible’ evidence will seldom cross even a modest threshold once contrary public evidence is counted. Second, the model leaves room for a higher-order moral requirement governing inquiry: the racist ought to seek further evidence, precisely because acting on a barely permissible belief would risk harm. Failure of epistemic due diligence, not the lexical order, is the culprit.

Objection 3: The phenomenology of doxastic deliberation excludes practical considerations entirely; they cannot function even as tie-breakers because belief just is the attitude you take when evidence persuades you.  

Reply: Cases of evidential equipoise show otherwise. Imagine two rival scientific theories equally supported by current data. A researcher may adopt one rather than suspend, perhaps because funding agencies require a commitment to secure a grant. Phenomenologically, she is aware that either option is epistemically fine, yet practical utility selects one. So tie-breaking does occur in genuine doxastic settings.

Objection 4: The view collapses into evidentialism because practical reasons rarely operate—the space of true ties is too narrow.  

Reply: (a) Science, law, and everyday life abound with underdetermination. (b) Suspension itself is an epistemically permissible option; practical reasons can urge confident belief rather than suspension (e.g., the doctor who must decide on a diagnosis under uncertain evidence). So practical influence is neither trivial nor rare.

6. Case Studies  

6.1 Pascal’s Wager  

Pascal urges belief in God on prudential grounds alone. On the threshold-lexical model, since Pascal concedes that the evidence for God is indecisive, belief is not yet permissible; practical reasons cannot justify theistic belief. What they can justify is a policy of cultivating evidence-gathering practices (e.g., church attendance) likely to raise epistemic confidence. The classic discomfort with Pascal thus receives principled explanation: he violates lexical priority.

6.2 William James’s Sick Mountain Climber  

James imagines a climber whose chance of succeeding is enhanced by believing he will succeed. If available evidence makes success slightly more probable than failure, belief crosses the threshold; epistemically, both belief and suspension may be permissible. Practical reasons (survival) now kick in and make belief ATO-required. The climber’s “faith” is vindicated, but only because the evidential bar is cleared.

6.3 The Psychologically Fragile Patient  

Suppose a doctor hesitates to disclose a grim but uncertain prognosis because the patient’s health depends on optimism. If the doctor’s evidence only weakly supports the negative prognosis, suspension lies within the permissible range. Practical reasons (patient welfare) can then justify withholding belief in the dire outcome. Again, no direct trade-off is needed.

6.4 Gettier, Lottery, and Thresholds  

Gettier cases show that justified true belief may fall short of knowledge. Our model handles this by recognizing that the epistemic threshold for permissibility is lower than that for knowledge. Practical reasons can interact with beliefs that are justified but not known; they cannot salvage outright unjustified beliefs.

7. Broader Implications  

7.1 Permissivism Without Relativism  

Epistemic permissivism—the view that more than one belief can be rationally permissible on the same evidence—gains a rationale: permissivism creates space for practical tie-breakers. Yet because the initial threshold is evidence-fixed, we avoid slipping into epistemic relativism.

7.2 Doxastic Wronging and Social Epistemology  

Recent debates on “doxastic wrongdoing” hold that believing harmful stereotypes can wrong their targets. The threshold-lexical model locates such wrongs at two sites: (i) believing below the threshold (epistemic wrong), and (ii) failing to inquire further when practical stakes demand caution (practical wrong at the level of inquiry, not belief). The view thereby clarifies where social and moral critiques of belief properly apply.

7.3 Partial Control of Belief  

Because direct voluntary control over belief is limited, practical reasons mainly operate indirectly: regulating evidence exposure, seeking further data, or managing doxastic habits. The model honors this psychological fact and explains why outright wishful thinking fails: direct belief contrary to evidence would breach the epistemic threshold.

8. Conclusion  

The apparent incommensurability of epistemic and practical reasons for belief dissolves once we recognize a two-tier normative structure with a non-negotiable evidential threshold. Epistemic reasons set the domain of permissible belief; practical reasons select within that domain when multiplicity remains. This threshold-lexical architecture respects the constitutive aim of belief, secures room for pragmatic considerations where they are intuitively appropriate, and avoids the pitfalls of both purist evidentialism and unbridled pragmatism. Though further work is needed to specify thresholds across contexts, the model provides a principled framework for understanding how truth and value jointly govern doxastic life.

Epistemic and practical reasons look, at first blush, like inhabitants of different normative universes.  Epistemic reasons bear on the truth of a proposition; practical reasons bear on how holding that proposition would affect what matters to us—our safety, our relationships, our moral standing, our flourishing.  When a single doxastic choice is apparently pulled in both directions, we seem forced to ask an impossible question: how many units of truth-conduciveness equal one unit of utility or one violation of another’s rights?  The specter of incommensurability has led many philosophers either to deny that practical considerations ever really count as reasons for belief (epistemic purism) or to concede that they count but only in a separate ledger that never gets summed with the epistemic one (two-ought views).  I will argue for a third option: a unified, all-things-considered (ATC) “common-currency” model on which epistemic and practical considerations are indeed comparable, though the comparison is context-sensitive, structured, and often lexically ordered.  Truth is not the only value that beliefs realize; it is, however, normally the dominant one.  In extreme circumstances—where practical stakes are high enough—practical reasons can outweigh epistemic reasons, and they can do so without reducing the practice of belief formation to wishful thinking.  Far from being incoherent, this view explains everyday normative judgments, integrates with decision-theoretic work in epistemic utility theory, and handles the standard objections more gracefully than its rivals.

1.  Setting Up the Puzzle

Take Morally Troubled Doctor.  A physician learns, from highly reliable evidence, that a contagious disease is not airborne but exclusively blood-borne.  She also knows that if she publicizes this conclusion immediately, thousands of frightened citizens will prematurely flee the quarantine zone, spreading the disease farther and likely killing tens of thousands.  Her moral conscience counsels silence or even, temporarily, belief in the airborne hypothesis.  What ought she believe about the mode of transmission?

Intuitively, two different kinds of considerations are at play:

Epistemic: The evidence strongly supports blood-borne transmission; believing otherwise would be false or at least less likely to be true.

Practical: Believing (and saying) that the disease is airborne would avert catastrophe.

How, if at all, can these be weighed together?  That is the central question.

2.  Rejecting Two Familiar Escapes

2.1  Epistemic Purism  
Purists (e.g., Owens 2000; Shah 2006) insist that only truth-related factors are genuine reasons for belief.  The doctor epistemically ought to believe what her evidence indicates.  Period.  Purism protects a certain conception of the “epistemic enterprise,” but at the cost of re-describing commonplace moral talk—“You shouldn’t believe that conspiracy theory; it’s dangerous”—as really about asserting or acting, never about believing.  Worse, purism forces a deep discontinuity between doxastic and practical normativity.  Reasons can interact seamlessly in action (prudential, moral, aesthetic), but in belief we postulate a mysterious firewall.  Explaining why belief is unique requires more than stipulation.

2.2  Two-Ought (Dual Ledger) Views  
Alternately, one can maintain that there are two autonomous ‘ought’s: an epistemic ought entirely fixed by evidence and a practical ought fixed by stakes (Feldman 2000; Gibbons 2013).  The doctor epistemically ought to believe the truth and practically ought not to, with no fact of the matter about what she simply ought (all things considered) to believe.  Yet decisions must ultimately be made.  A single doxastic act will occur; she either believes or withholds.  A theory that refuses to say which single attitude is fitting leaves the normative space fractured right where we need guidance most.

3.  Toward a Common Currency

The alternative is to treat epistemic and practical reasons as items of the same genus: considerations that count in favor of adopting a cognitive attitude.  They differ in their *grounds*—truth versus welfare—but share a *normative role*: providing weight toward believing.  What makes commensurability possible is that reasons are individuated by their directional force, not by their content domain.  Compare action: that a promise was made (moral) and that fine wine awaits (prudential) can both bear on whether to dine with a friend.  Few conclude that such reasons are incommensurable in principle.  Why should belief be stranger?

3.1  The Metaphysics of Weight  
On a reasons-first picture (Parfit 2011; Scanlon 1998), “weight” is a primitive normative property: *A’s being the case counts for x units in favor of φ-ing.*  We do not demand a further measure.  In decision contexts we often introduce numbers for clarity, but the comparability is there before any cardinalization.  Likewise, the doctor’s evidence might be said loosely to carry “very great”—perhaps not infinite—epistemic weight; the catastrophic public-health consequences carry “enormous” practical weight.  The important point is that the comparative relations (“outweighs,” “is trumped by”) are intelligible even if not exactly measurable.

3.2  Decision-Theoretic Support  
Epistemic utility theory bolsters this metaphysical sketch.  Joyce (1998) and Leitgeb & Pettigrew (2010) show that standard accuracy measures like Brier score or log-score vindicate probabilism: believing in proportion to evidence maximizes expected epistemic utility.  Nothing prevents extending the utility function to include non-accuracy components such as moral consequences.  Indeed, Greaves & Wallace’s “expectationalism” about *axiological* as well as *epistemic* value makes rendering them comparable straightforward: the agent’s total utility = α·(expected accuracy) + β·(expected moral/prudential benefit).  α and β are weighting parameters, normally heavily skewed toward accuracy but perhaps not lexically so.  The theory need not pretend agents literally perform these calculations; it suffices that choice dispositions can be represented *as if* they respect such a ranking.

4.  Lexical Dominance Rather Than Infinite Value

A common objection is that truth has unlimited worth; to trade it for utility is to license wishful thinking.  Yet our practice belies this absolutism.  We routinely treat secrecy and promise-keeping as moral reasons to withhold certain true beliefs, and we often judge agnosticism permissible when investigation would be ruinous or vulgar.  Still, there is something right in the absolutist intuition: truth is the central telos of belief.  The best way to capture both thoughts is to posit *lexical dominance*, not infinite value.  Lexical ordering says: move to practical considerations only when epistemic ones reach a plateau of near-indifference (e.g., under evidential tie or minimal evidential tilt).  Most everyday cases never reach that stage; hence, evidence reigns.  But in high-stakes outlier scenarios—religious martyrs facing torture, the colonel transmitting a false code to mislead enemy spies—practical stakes can legitimately override.

5.  Replying to Four Standard Objections

Objection 1:  Doxastic Involuntarism  
“Beliefs aren’t under voluntary control; practical reasons cannot rationally necessitate what you cannot choose.”  But what matters for normative assessment is not direct voluntary control but *responsiveness to reasons*.  We lack direct control over sneezes, yet we can be asked to stifle them in a library.  Control is indirect, via prior planning or attention management.  Likewise, we influence our future beliefs through information exposure, selective attention, and evidential search.  Practical reasons guide these diachronic strategies, and that suffices for them to be genuine reasons.

Objection 2:  Transparency  
Shoemaker (1994) observes that sincere deliberation about whether to believe p collapses into deliberation about p’s truth.  How, then, could one deliberate about whether it would be *useful* to believe p?  The answer is two-level.  At the *moment* of belief formation, one’s attention is indeed captured by considerations bearing on truth.  But the *prior* deliberation that sets up which evidence one will look at or how strictly one will demand evidential thresholds can and often does incorporate pragmatic factors.  Pragmatic encroachment effects (Stanley 2005; Fantl & McGrath 2009) exemplify this structure.

Objection 3:  Evidence-Responsiveness as Constitutive of Belief  
Purists often claim that believing just is the attitude that aims at truth; to pollute its regulation with pragmatic factors is to change the subject to acceptance or make-believe.  Yet aiming at truth is consistent with allowing auxiliary aims when truth and value conflict.  The archer’s form is constituted by targeting the center, but in a crowded field she may intentionally miss to avoid harm.  She is still shooting arrows, still guided by the constitutive standard, but not enslaved to it in every circumstance.

Objection 4:  Slippery Slope to Wishful Thinking  
If some practical reasons count, why not always believe whatever makes us happiest?  Because most practical contexts do not supply reasons strong enough to outweigh even mediocre evidence.  Furthermore, wishful beliefs quickly undermine their own practical value once confronted with recalcitrant reality.  The common-currency model predicts this: when the expected disutility of error is high (as it usually is), epistemic reasons regain dominance.

6.  The Doctor Again

Let us apply the framework.  The doctor’s high-quality evidence supplies enormous epistemic weight.  The expected moral catastrophe, however, is even more enormous—tens of thousands of innocent deaths.  Suppose the doctor can, by delaying her belief or by maintaining public agnosticism for 48 hours, allow containment to take effect.  The practical reason’s weight plausibly eclipses the epistemic reason’s, at least for that window.  After the delay, once evacuation no longer threatens, the practical reason evaporates and epistemic dominance resumes.  The theory thus yields the nuanced verdict we want: temporarily withhold or disguise belief for grave moral reasons, then believe according to evidence.  Neither purism nor dual-ledger views can deliver this dynamically integrated guidance.

7.  Non-Ideal Comparisons and Indeterminacy

The model does not pretend to solve every case.  Some comparisons produce intransitivity or vagueness.  But this is a feature, not a bug.  Normative life is sometimes indecisive.  The incommensurability worry derives from mistakenly inferring from occasional imprecision to principled incomparability.  The common-currency view allows that some cases will be indeterminate, just as in ethics we confront hard moral dilemmas without concluding that moral and prudential reasons operate in alien currencies.

8.  Broader Payoffs

8.1  Explaining Pragmatic Encroachment  
If practical stakes can affect whether one *knows*, it is natural that they can affect whether one ought to believe.  The common-currency view unifies doxastic normativity with recent accounts of knowledge as interest-relative.

8.2  Connecting to Social Epistemology  
Group epistemic norms (e.g., scientific consensus rules) explicitly balance accuracy against the social costs of error.  A theory that forbids such trade-offs would misdescribe scientific practice.  The common-currency approach aligns individual and collective levels.

8.3  Moral Encroachment in Belief  
Debates about morally charged statistical generalizations (“Stereotype Beliefs”) hinge on whether moral reasons can defeat evidence.  My view vindicates the moderate position: yes, moral stakes can be weighty enough, but only under stringent conditions (high potential for harm, low evidential differential).

9.  Comparison with Sui Generis Truth-Value Hybrid Theories

Particularists like Weatherson (2005) propose that there are multiple epistemic goods—truth, understanding, wisdom—that cannot be reduced to a single scale.  I agree but hold that multidimensional value still allows comparison via dominance, lexicographic ordering, or thresholding.  The mathematical formalism of *vector utilities* suffices: belief A is better than belief B if it is at least as good in every dimension and strictly better in one, or when trade-off coefficients are contextually justified.

10.  A New Distinction: Direct vs. Indirect Practical Reasons

To clarify the dialectic, introduce a distinction often missed:

Direct practical reasons: reasons whose content directly recommends the belief itself because having the belief produces value (e.g., placebo effect).

Indirect practical reasons: reasons to manipulate upstream processes (search, attention, exposure) so that later beliefs will be epistemically better.  

The common-currency model accommodates both, but their normative profiles differ: direct reasons must be weighty indeed to override truth; indirect reasons need only modest weight because they promote truth in the long run.  Recognizing this distinction dissolves many apparent counterexamples.

11.  Summing Up

We face a menu:

A.  Purism: denies practical reasons; implausibly stovepipes normativity.  
B.  Dual-Ought: admits both but refuses integration; abdicates guidance.  
C.  Common Currency: treats all reasons as comparable though not always precisely commensurable; truth normally lexically prior, but practical stakes can override in extremis.

Option C best respects ordinary practice, harmonizes with decision theory, and defuses the incommensurability worry.  Epistemic and practical reasons interact because they inhabit a shared normative space structured by weight.  The weights need not be measurable on a single cardinal scale; it suffices that their comparative orderings be well-founded enough to guide action and self-regulation.

12.  Coda: Implications for Future Research

The common-currency view invites two lines of inquiry.

First, empirical: How do real people integrate epistemic and practical considerations?  Cognitive science can test whether motivational and evidential factors combine additively, lexically, or via threshold effects.  Finding the psychological mechanisms would inform normative fine-tuning.

Second, theoretical: What determines the default α/β weighting between accuracy and other values?  One promising hypothesis is that these parameters are socially constructed: communities calibrate them through cultural evolution, sanctioning epistemically reckless but practically beneficial credences and vice versa.  Investigating this could bridge virtue epistemology and social choice theory.

If these projects bear fruit, the allegedly impossible task of balancing truth and value in belief will turn out not to be incoherent but instead a sophisticated, context-sensitive art—one we already practice, and one philosophy can help us practice better.

Epistemic-practical incommensurability is one of those apparently intractable problems that arise whenever two very different normative domains are invited to speak to the same question.  On the one hand, believing is a paradigmatically truth-directed attitude: to believe that p is (normally) to take p to be true, and epistemic reasons are, by their nature, considerations that bear on the truth of p.  On the other hand, to be a believer is also to be an agent whose beliefs guide action and affect others, sometimes for good, sometimes for ill.  Those downstream consequences generate practical or moral reasons that appear, at least in principle, to pull in directions independent of (and occasionally opposed to) truth.  How, if at all, can such heterogeneous considerations be aggregated into a single “all-things-considered” verdict about what one ought to believe?

I shall defend a two-tier, “permissive-hierarchical” picture:

1. Epistemic reasons enjoy lexical priority: they unilaterally determine whether it is epistemically obligatory, forbidden, or merely permissible to believe p.  
2. When the epistemic verdict falls into the “permissible” range—when the evidence neither requires nor excludes belief—practical reasons may legitimately break the tie.  
3. Because practical reasons get a voice only where epistemic permissiveness obtains, the worry about weighing incommensurable currencies is defused; the two kinds of reasons never have to be balanced on the same scale.  They enter sequentially, not simultaneously.

I shall argue that this model fits our best thinking about the nature of belief, makes room for familiar Jamesian and pragmatic intuitions, and handles some thorny counter-examples better than its main rivals (pure epistemicism, pragmatic encroachment, and full-blown aggregationism). II.	Four Families of Responses and Their Shortcomings  
III.	The Case for Lexical Epistemic Priority  
IV.	The Necessity (and Limits) of Epistemic Permissivism  
V.	How Practical Reasons Operate Within the Permissive Zone  
VI.	Objections and Replies

I. Clarifying the Target Question

“What ought I to believe?” is ambiguous.  We should distinguish:

A.	The epistemic ought (OE): the ought of truth-seeking or accuracy.  
B.	The practical ought (OP): the ought of action, value, or morality.  
C.	The overall ought (OA): the verdict that tells an agent, simpliciter, whether to adopt attitude A toward p.

Most of the intuitive puzzles arise because we tacitly presuppose that there is a unitary OA that somehow synthesises OE and OP.  Incommensurability anxiety is therefore anxiety about the synthetic step: how, given their different natures, could OE and OP feed into a single OA?

Notice, however, that almost everyone agrees on the following:

1.	If believing p is epistemically mandatory (evidence makes ¬p irrational), no practical consideration can make it overall rational to suspend or to disbelieve.  (If I have conclusive evidence that the bridge is unsafe, no amount of economic benefit from its continued use can make it reasonable for me to believe otherwise.)  
2.	If believing p is epistemically forbidden (evidence decisively supports ¬p), practical considerations cannot make it overall reasonable to believe p.

So the real battleground is the “indeterminate middle”—cases in which the evidence neither decisively supports p nor decisively supports ¬p.  It is here that William James’s ethics of belief, Pascalian wagering, and high-stakes pragmatic encroachment are typically invoked.  The two-tier account I shall develop acknowledges that this middle region exists and is philosophically important; indeed, practical reasons get their hearing precisely there.  But outside that region, epistemic reasons reign supreme.

II. Four Families of Responses and Their Shortcomings

1. Pure Epistemicism: Only epistemic reasons ever bear on belief; talk of “practical reasons for belief” is a category mistake.  
   Objection: This view cannot explain our intuitive approval of certain belief choices under grave risk or profound moral pressure.  The terminal cancer patient who chooses to believe she will recover, thereby rallying medically crucial optimism, seems rational in a perfectly ordinary sense.  Denying that her practical reasons count at all looks unduly purist.

2. Full Aggregationism: Both sorts of reasons share a single normative common currency (e.g. expected utility), so they can be weighed directly.  
   Objection: The very idea that “truth-points” and “utility-points” can be put on the same scale is implausible.  Moreover, aggregationism predicts that possessing overwhelming evidence can be overridden by sufficiently large practical stakes, a prediction most find unacceptable.

3. Pragmatic Encroachment: Practical stakes modulate the strength or amount of evidence required for knowledge or justified belief; thus practical considerations affect belief indirectly by redefining epistemic thresholds.  
   Objection: While elegant, encroachment threatens a category conflation: if “how much evidence is required” varies with the utility of being right, we have ceased to be discussing purely truth-directed standards.  Many epistemologists regard this as giving up what is distinctive about epistemic normativity.

4. Dual Ought Pluralism: There is no OA; there are only OE and OP, and conflicts are brute.  
   Objection: Ordinary deliberators need guidance; telling them only that “epistemically you should believe p but prudentially you shouldn’t” without further advice leaves them in limbo.

Each view captures something plausible—the purity of truth, the pragmatic importance of consequences, the variable salience of stakes, and the reality of plural norms.  My proposal borrows from all four while avoiding their excesses.

III. The Case for Lexical Epistemic Priority

Beliefs are, in an important sense, transparent to the truth.  When one wonders “Should I believe p?”, the rational way to answer is by asking “Is p true (or probably true)?”  Deciding by inspection of non-truth considerations is a form of pragmatic self-manipulation, and that sits poorly with the constitutive aim of belief.

Because of this transparency phenomenon, epistemic norms have a strong claim to lexical priority: they directly govern the attitude in question.  Practical norms, though genuinely important, enter only indirectly—by governing which doxastic states it is beneficial or harmful to occupy, not by governing the epistemic propriety of taking p as true.

Lexical priority vindicates two desiderata:

a)	It respects the internal connection between belief and truth, thus preserving the distinctive role of epistemic reasons.  
b)	It still allows practical reasons to matter, provided they do not dictate belief against decisive evidence.

If lexical priority is granted, the remaining puzzle is: Where exactly does the line between decisiveness and permissiveness fall?  Enter the topic of epistemic permissivism.

IV. The Necessity (and Limits) of Epistemic Permissivism

Epistemic Uniqueness theorists hold that for any body of evidence E and proposition p, there is exactly one doxastic attitude toward p that is epistemically rational.  If Uniqueness were true, the permissive zone would vanish, leaving no room for practical reasons to do any tie-breaking.  But Uniqueness is, I think, untenable for two reasons.

1.	Incompleteness of Evidence: Normal empirical evidence underdetermines theory choice (consider under-constrained scientific models or ordinary perceptual disputes in poor lighting).  Different but equally conscientious reasoners may permissibly adopt different credences.  
2.	Symmetry Cases: Suppose my evidence is a purely statistical 0.5 chance for p.  An attitude of suspension, a tentative credence of 0.5, or even a cautious acceptance (if costs of falsity are minor) all seem epistemically okay.  To insist that only one of these is uniquely rational is to legislate standards more precise than our practice supports.

Adopting a graded picture of epistemic rationality—where attitudes can be required, forbidden, or merely allowed—gives space for the “permissive zone” that tier-two practical deliberation will occupy.

V. How Practical Reasons Operate Within the Permissive Zone

Once the evidence delivers its verdict—mandatory, forbidden, or permissible—we ask: what next?  If permissible, the agent is free to let practical considerations settle the matter.  Two questions arise:

A) Must the agent exercise that freedom?  
B) How should practical reasons be evaluated?

On (A): No.  Permissibility is precisely the absence of epistemic imperative.  An agent may defer choice (suspend belief) or consult practical reasons as she sees fit.  There is no further “ought” generated by epistemic norms.  But practical rationality may, of course, urge a stance; for example, medical policy may require a surgeon to assume worst-case scenarios when test results are inconclusive.

On (B): Here ordinary decision theory applies.  Practical reasons are already denominated in utilities, moral values, or welfare outcomes.  Within the permissive range, agents may weigh costs and benefits of being right or wrong about p.  Importantly, because epistemic standings have already been settled as permissible, no incommensurability arises: practical reasons are compared only with each other, not against epistemic reasons.

Example 1 (Medical Diagnosis):  
Evidence suggests a 40% probability of infection X but is indeterminate.  Believing “X is present” will prompt immediate antibiotics; disbelieving or suspending delays treatment.  Given high morbidity, practical reasons favour believing.  Since the evidence neither mandates nor prohibits belief, the physician rightly forms the belief and acts accordingly.

Example 2 (Comforting Falsehood):  
A parent’s evidence indicates with 95% probability that the family dog has died.  The child is emotionally fragile, and believing “the dog is still alive” would avert a traumatic breakdown.  Here the epistemic reasons are decisive: it is epistemically mandatory to believe the dog is dead.  Lexical priority blocks the practical inducement to adopt the comforting falsehood.  The parent may withhold the information or lie in speech, but she ought not form the contrary belief.

Notice how the two-tier model straightforwardly adjudicates both cases without needing to place “truth-points” on one side of a common scale.

VI. Objections and Replies

Objection 1: What about extremely high-stakes cases—say, Pascal’s Wager—where practical benefits are infinite?  Doesn’t lexical priority then look irrationally conservative?

Reply: The wager assumes epistemic permissiveness (uncertainty about God’s existence).  If evidence cannot settle the question, practical reasons (infinite utility) may indeed rationally move one to believe.  Lexical priority is upheld; the permissiveness of the evidence is a precondition.  If the evidence were conclusively atheistic, the wager would not license belief.  Hence no counter-example.

Objection 2: Doesn’t pragmatic encroachment show that stakes affect not merely a second tier but the very thresholds of knowledge?  For instance, in low-stakes contexts I can say “I know the bank is open Saturday,” but not in high-stakes contexts.

Reply: The encroachment data can be reconstrued as linguistic rather than normative.  High stakes often raise conversational standards for asserting “knows”; they need not alter what epistemic reasons require.  What matters for our purposes is that, at the level of belief, encroachment phenomena can be captured by shifting from categorical belief to graded confidence.  A high-stakes agent may rationally retain the same credence but refrain from the categorical belief state because categorical belief is more dangerous.  That is a practical, second-tier consideration.

Objection 3: Permissivism is controversial; what if Uniqueness is true?

Reply: If Uniqueness were true, then either epistemic reasons always mandate a precise credence (leaving no space for practical input) or mandate suspension whenever evidence is equivocal.  In the latter variant, practical reasons might re-enter indirectly via decision rules that map suspension to action.  Either way, incommensurability worries disappear because there is nothing left to be weighed.  So the two-tier model reduces to pure epistemicism under Uniqueness and is therefore strictly more general.

Objection 4: Doesn’t lexical priority ignore cases where believing truly would be morally monstrous?  Consider someone with conclusive evidence that a hidden refugee is in the attic, confronted by a murderous tyrant.

Reply: Here we must separate believing from telling.  The epistemic mandate is to believe the truth.  Morality governs what one may say or reveal.  Lying to the tyrant is permissible, even obligatory, but forming the opposite belief is not required and may be psychologically impossible.  If, ex hypothesi, the evidence is conclusive, epistemic norms fix belief.  Practical norms govern communicative action.

Objection 5: Is the hierarchical model ad hoc?  Why should epistemic reasons get lexical priority rather than, say, moral reasons?

Reply: The proposal is not arbitrary; it is grounded in the constitutive nature of belief.  Belief is, to borrow Bernard Williams’s phrase, “transparent to the truth.”  While actions have mixed aims and admit of compromises, belief aims at truth non-derivatively.  If we called something “belief” that could be directly chosen for non-truth reasons against the evidence, we would have changed the subject to something closer to wish-fulfilment or self-induced delusion.  Lexical priority thus honours a conceptual truth about what believing is.

Conclusion

The philosopher’s impulse to aggregate all normative reasons into a single balance-sheet is understandable but, in this domain, misguided.  Belief is governed, first and foremost, by its epistemic telos.  Practical considerations do matter, yet they do so only when epistemic norms permit multiple permissible attitudes.  In such cases practical stakes legitimately break epistemic ties, and there is no need for a mysterious commensuration of truth and utility.  Rather than imagining an impossible common currency, we should recognise a temporal and normative division of labour: epistemic reasons speak first, and when they fall silent, practical reasons speak second.  The incommensurability problem dissolves once we notice that the two speeches never overlap.

By capturing what is right in Clifford’s evidentialism (truth priority), James’s pragmatism (the rational permissibility of letting practical stakes decide), and contemporary permissivism (the existence of epistemic slack), the two-tier hierarchical model offers a principled and ecumenical resolution.  It shows how epistemic and practical reasons can indeed “interact,” not by being weighed together, but by entering the deliberative arena in sequence.  The structure is not a compromise but a stable marriage: each type of reason occupies the domain suited to its nature, and together they generate the nuanced verdicts about belief that our actual epistemic lives require.

Epistemic–practical conflict is a hardy perennial in philosophy.  On the one hand it seems obvious that what one ought to believe is fixed by the evidence: if my best total evidence strongly supports that the earth orbits the sun, then, epistemically speaking, I ought to believe it, regardless of any consequences of doing so.  On the other hand, we routinely evaluate beliefs by appeal to non-epistemic considerations: we criticise the zealot who embraces a politically incendiary conspiracy theory because it “gives his life meaning,” or we praise the terminally ill patient who convinces herself that remission is just around the corner because the hope sustains her children.  These latter appraisals appeal to practical reasons—reasons of welfare, morality, prudence, solidarity, or dignity.  The puzzle is that the two kinds of reasons appear to be radically different currencies.  Epistemic reasons track truth; practical reasons track value.  How, then, could a single, all-things-considered doxastic “ought” possibly result from combining them?

My thesis is an answer in two parts.

1.  Epistemic and practical reasons do not compete in a single balance-of-reasons marketplace.  They govern different normative questions, each of which issues in its own pro tanto verdict.  Epistemic reasons answer the question “What is credible?”, while practical reasons answer the question “What, if any, doxastic attitude should I adopt, given my total interests and values, toward propositions whose credibility falls within a zone of evidential indeterminacy?”  The two sets of reasons therefore interact sequentially rather than commensurately: evidence has lexical priority, but where it leaves matters indeterminate, practical reasons legitimately decide.

2.  The resultant picture accommodates our intuitions better than both pure evidentialism (which cannot explain why hope is sometimes rational) and unqualified pragmatism (which collapses truth-conduciveness into just another instrumental good).  It also shows why the apparent incommensurability of the two reason-types is not an obstacle: the justificatory division of labour leaves nothing for them to commensurate about.

I. Mapping the dialectical terrain

There are three classical strategies for resolving the puzzle.

a) Strict evidentialism: only epistemic reasons bear on belief.  Practical evaluations apply solely to the downstream effects of having the belief, not to the belief’s rationality.  William Clifford’s famous maxim “it is wrong always, everywhere, and for anyone, to believe anything upon insufficient evidence” is paradigmatic.

b) Unitary pragmatism: practical reasons are fundamental, and epistemic reasons matter only derivatively, because truth is typically instrumentally useful.  Jamesian “will-to-believe” arguments lie here.

c) Pluralistic weighing: both reason-types matter and must somehow be balanced in a single ledger.  The difficulty is articulating a common scale without trivialising their differences.

The proposal I defend blends the first and third strategies while evading their pitfalls: evidence enjoys lexical priority, preserving the distinctively alethic character of epistemic normativity, but practical reasons remain normatively relevant once evidence runs out of resolving power.

II. Distinguishing three normative questions

We typically run together three separate ‘oughts’:

(1) Epistemic ought: Oe(S, p) — subject S epistemically ought to believe p.
(2) Practical-doxastic ought: Op(S, p) — S practically ought to believe p (or refrain from believing p).
(3) All-things-considered doxastic ought: Oa(S, p) — S ought, simpliciter, to believe p.

The first is sensitive exclusively to truth-conduciveness; the second to the subject’s goals, values, and commitments; the third integrates the two.  My contention is that Oa is not obtained by arithmetic aggregation but by a lexical, two-tier decision procedure:

Step 1 (Epistemic filter):
   If S’s total evidence makes p credible beyond a threshold T (strong evidential support), then Oa(S, p) = believe p.
   If the evidence makes ~p credible beyond T, then Oa(S, p) = disbelieve p.
   If evidence leaves p in the undecided middle zone (call it the Gap), proceed to Step 2.

Step 2 (Practical selector):
   Consult S’s practical reasons.  They determine whether it is better (morally, prudentially, aesthetically, etc.) to believe, to disbelieve, or to suspend.

Because practical reasons are consulted only after the epistemic filter, they never override strong evidence.  Conversely, within the Gap, epistemic reasons are silent because they deliver no determinate verdict; practical reasons therefore govern.

III. Why lexical priority is not ad hoc

Why think the normative architecture should be tiered rather than scalar?  Three arguments:

1. Constitutive aim argument.  On the widely accepted “teleological normativity of belief” thesis, belief constitutively aims at truth; a state that does not answer to truth is not a proper belief at all but wishful fancy.  This gives evidence an intrinsic, not merely instrumental, authority over belief formation.  Practical goals, by contrast, relate to belief only extrinsically, via the expected effects of having that belief.  Lexical priority honours the constitutive aim.

2. Transparency phenomenon.  When we are asked “Why do you believe p?”, it is natural to answer with our evidence (“because I saw it with my own eyes”) rather than our interests (“because it comforts me”).  The fact that questions about belief characteristically solicit evidential justifications suggests that evidence is the primary normative standard.

3. Normative convergence under idealisation.  Suppose two agents share identical evidence but differ radically in practical stakes.  On a weighing model, what each ought to believe may differ.  Yet our intuitive judgments about, say, historical or mathematical claims do not vary with the believer’s idiosyncratic utilities.  Lexical priority secures convergence: truth-directed reasons bind equally across contexts, while practical considerations decide only where evidence leaves rational slack.

IV. How the sequential model resolves the incommensurability worry

Incommensurability arises only if we insist that epistemic and practical reasons must be weighed directly.  Under the proposed sequencing, they never meet head-to-head.  Epistemic reasons either settle the matter, or else declare abstention, in which case practical reasons take over.  There is therefore no need for a common measure.

Think of judicial procedure.  A criminal court first asks whether the prosecution has established guilt beyond reasonable doubt.  If yes, the verdict is “guilty” irrespective of the practical value of acquittal.  If no, the defendant is acquitted; the jury does not then weigh the social utility of incarceration versus release.  Similarly, the epistemic tribunal issues a verdict only if the evidential burden is met; otherwise it demurs, leaving room for practical legislatures to pass normative statutes.

V. Illustrative examples

Example 1: The calibrated oncologist (Gap + practical override).
Dr Lee must decide whether to tell her patient that an experimental therapy is likely to succeed.  The current trial data provide a 40 % success probability—below the epistemic confidence threshold for outright belief.  Dr Lee knows that the patient’s adherence to a gruelling regimen depends critically on hope.  Here the epistemic tribunal withholds judgment (evidence insufficient).  Practical reasons—promoting the patient’s welfare—may permissibly tilt Dr Lee toward believing (and communicating) that the therapy will work.  She does not flout truth-aim because the evidential filter has rendered the proposition epistemically permissible though not mandated.

Example 2: The climate sceptic (strong evidence blocks practical reasons).
Activist Alana’s political movement would benefit enormously were anthropogenic climate change a myth; donations soar whenever she casts doubt on the consensus.  Yet the scientific evidence is overwhelming.  Because the evidential threshold for disbelief is well exceeded, practical reasons never get a hearing.  Alana ought to believe the consensus, full stop.

Example 3: Religious faith under underdetermination.
Historical evidence for theism vs. atheism, many argue, lands in the Gap—neither side meets threshold T.  Practical reasons (Pascalian prudence, existential yearning, community identity) may therefore permissibly influence one’s doxastic stance.  This explains the social acceptability of faith without licensing epistemic anarchy: faith is rationally optional, not obligatory, and it is constrained by the requirement that evidence does not decisively speak against it.

VI. Replying to two major objections

Objection 1: The arbitrariness of threshold T.  Why privilege a specific evidential cutoff?  First, some threshold is inevitable if beliefs are to be actionable.  Human cognitive systems operate on limited resources, and deliberation must eventually close.  Second, T need not be sharp; what matters is a broad “decisiveness region” accepted by epistemology (e.g., knowledge-level justification).  The proposal is therefore compatible with contextualism or subject-sensitive thresholds.

Objection 2: Practical encroachment arguments claim that practical stakes affect epistemic standards themselves (Fantl & McGrath, Jeremy Goodman, etc.).  Does lexical priority ignore this?  No.  Encroachment can be recast within the present framework: varying stakes tighten or loosen the threshold T.  But crucially, the epistemic verdict remains evidential—only the level of support required for outright belief shifts.  Practical reasoning still does not get directly weighed against truth; it instead modulates how much evidence suffices.  Hence the architecture survives.

VII. Comparison with rival integrative accounts

1. Scalar consequentialism (belief as action maximising expected value) collapses epistemic reasons into the subset of utilities associated with having true beliefs.  That picture cannot explain why we regard a belief that is true only by luck as epistemically defective.  The sequential model, anchored in truth-conduciveness, accommodates this datum.

2. Two-attitude views (e.g., Richard Foley’s) suggest replacing belief with “acceptance” for pragmatic purposes.  My model keeps the ordinary category of belief but explains which sub-set of pragmatically useful acceptances can also qualify as beliefs, namely those not prohibited by evidence.

3. Jamesian permissivism (“right to believe on insufficient evidence if it yields vital benefits”) lacks principled constraints.  By contrast, the lexical gap mechanism sharply delimits when and why pragmatic reasons can operate.

VIII. Broader theoretical dividends

A. Unifying epistemic norms with moral/legal norms.  Lexical ordering echoes “lexical priority” in Rawlsian justice and emergency triage.  Normative domains often employ filters (e.g., basic rights trump cost-benefit analysis unless overriding emergency): our theory embeds doxastic norms within this familiar normative architecture.

B. Explaining doxastic akrasia.  Someone who says “I know the polling data, but I believe my team will win because I need to stay motivated” exemplifies illicit override: evidence exceeded threshold yet was ignored.  Our model diagnoses the irrationality without rejecting the motivational rationale; what she ought to do is adopt a different attitude (hope, supposition) rather than belief.

C. Mental health and permissibility.  Cognitive-behavioural therapy sometimes recommends adopting “adaptive” beliefs.  The model distinguishes therapeutic contexts where evidence about one’s self-worth is ambiguous (Gap, so adaptive beliefs may be licit) from contexts where self-deception conflicts with clear evidence.

IX. A residual worry: does the picture fragment ‘ought’?

One might fear relativistic slide: if epistemic and practical oughts apply sequentially, are we left with a merely context-sensitive, piecemeal normativity rather than an integrated rational ideal?  Not so.  The all-things-considered ought is unified by the procedure itself.  It is principled, publicly articulable, and generates convergent verdicts among ideal agents who share evidence and practical values.  The fragmentation charge sticks only if one antecedently assumes that integration must be done via additive aggregation.

X. Closing reflections

We began with an apparent incommensurability: truth and utility seem to pull in orthogonal directions.  I have argued that the feeling of paradox arises from the tacit assumption that the only way multiple norm-sources can guide a single attitude is by being weighed in the same scale.  Once we appreciate that norms can be lexically ordered and sequentially applied, the paradox dissolves.  Epistemic reasons speak first; when they fall silent, practical reasons may speak.  Both contribute authentically, neither is reduced to the other, and no mysterious unit of value is needed to “convert” truth into welfare.

The proposed division of normative labour preserves our deepest intuitions—respect for evidence, moral concern for consequences, opprobrium for self-serving delusion, and admiration for hope in uncertainty—while furnishing a crisp procedural story about how these considerations interact.  That, I submit, is how epistemic and practical reasons jointly determine what one ought to believe.

Thesis

We can make sense of the interaction between epistemic and practical reasons for belief by distinguishing three layers of normative governance.  

1. A first-order epistemic “ought” that is lexically prior: one oughtE to believe a proposition just when one’s total evidence makes it more reasonable to believe than to withhold.  

2. A second-order pragmatic “ought” that is conditional on underdetermination: where the evidence leaves one permitted (though not required) either to believe or to suspend, practical reasons may tip the balance.  

3. An all-things-considered “ought” that simply combines the two by heeding the lexical priority of the epistemic ought and letting the pragmatic ought operate only in the residual space left open by epistemic permissibility.  

Because practical reasons never compete head-to-head with undefeated epistemic reasons, the alleged incommensurability problem dissolves: the two kinds of considerations are compared only after an ordering rule has sorted them into distinct deliberative moments. The resulting picture preserves the intuition that truth-conduciveness has a special normative authority while still leaving room for pragmatic considerations to make a genuine, rational difference to what one finally ought to believe.

The rest of the essay defends this view in six steps. (i) I motivate the incommensurability challenge. (ii) I argue that current solutions either collapse practical reasons into epistemic ones or artificially insulate them. (iii) I articulate the hierarchical model in more detail. (iv) I show how it handles standard problem cases—Pascal’s Wager, Clifford’s shipowner, pragmatic encroachment bank cases, and moral encroachment examples. (v) I answer four objections. (vi) I close by situating the proposal in a broader account of responsible agency.

1. The incommensurability challenge

Consider two familiar vignettes.

Pascal. I have weak evidence concerning God’s existence but enormous utility to gain if I believe and God exists—and little to lose if God does not.

Clifford’s Shipowner. A shipowner convinces himself, on wishful grounds, that his deteriorating vessel is seaworthy because postponing repairs would be profitable; disaster ensues.

Pascal makes it tempting to think practical reasons can sometimes override weak evidence; Clifford makes it tempting to deny that usefulness can ever license belief against evidence. The tension tempts us toward an “aggregate” view: perhaps epistemic and practical reasons can simply be placed on a single scale, like different currencies converted at some mysterious rate. But that quickly looks hopeless. Truth-conducive weight and pragmatic value are not commensurable: “one additional micromort avoided” does not obviously translate into “one tenth of a point increase in probability that p.” If they cannot be common-measured, how could they be balanced?

2. Existing strategies and their limits

Two families of responses dominate the literature.

Collapse strategies. Some epistemic purists argue that so-called “practical” reasons are covertly epistemic. For example, a high-stakes situation purportedly changes how much evidence one needs, because if the cost of error is high we should demand more evidence; but that is an evidential, not a pragmatic, difference (Lasonen-Aarnio 2019). Collapse preserves unity but at the price of ignoring genuine pragmatic phenomenology. When a doctor delays a statistically justified but risky diagnosis until a confirmatory scan arrives, her hesitation is partly about what is at stake for the patient, not merely about Bayesian conditionalization.

Insulation strategies. Others concede distinct kinds of reasons but deny that they interact. According to “dual-domain” theorists, there is an epistemic ought and a practical ought, full stop; they never combine into an overall ought (Weatherson 2005). But then we face dilemmas: if the two oughts conflict, which ought governs deliberate reflection? Insulation gives us normative schizophrenia.

The hierarchical model aims to occupy a middle ground: genuine interaction without common-currency aggregation.

3. A hierarchical model of doxastic normativity

3.1 Lexical priority

Start with an analogy from moral theory. Many deontologists, following Rawls, hold that respecting basic rights has lexical priority over maximizing aggregate happiness: one may consult utilitarian considerations only after rights constraints are satisfied. The ordering solves the incomparability problem by forbidding certain comparisons. We can adopt the same architecture for belief.

Principle of Epistemic Priority (PEP): If one lacks sufficient epistemic justification for believing p, then—barring radical sceptical scenarios—one is epistemically required to withhold, full stop; practical reasons cannot make it rational to believe.

3.2 Residual permissibility

Epistemic evidence underdetermines our attitudes surprisingly often. For many everyday propositions—Will the package arrive before noon?—the evidence neither strongly supports nor decisively undermines belief. In that permissive zone, epistemic reasons issue a permission rather than a requirement: one may believe, disbelieve, or suspend. PEP then leaves room for practical reasons to operate.

Practical Tie-Breaker (PTB): When (and only when) epistemic reasons render the doxastic options equipermissible, practical reasons can supply decisive guidance.

3.3 Overall “ought”

Overall Rationality (OR): One ought, all things considered, to believe p if (i) epistemic reasons require belief, or (ii) epistemic reasons permit belief and practical reasons favor belief; analogously for disbelieving and suspending.

Because practical considerations never confront undefeated epistemic requirements, no commensuration is demanded. The structure is ordinal, not cardinal: “epistemically required” outranks any amount of pragmatic utility; within the epistemically permitted set, pragmatic weights become relevant.

4. Putting the model to work

4.1 Pascal revisited

Given ordinary evidence, epistemic reasons neither compel belief in God nor compel disbelief; suspension is rationally permitted. The infinite expected utility of believing (if one accepts Pascal’s mathematics) now operates as a practical tie-breaker. Hence, on the hierarchical view, Pascalian faith can be rational—without ever weighing “infinite utility” against “probability × truth value.” Instead, we appeal to a division of labor: epistemic permission opens the door, pragmatic stakes walk through.

4.2 Clifford’s shipowner

Here the shipowner’s evidence does not epistemically permit belief that the vessel is seaworthy; it mandates doubt. Epistemic priority blocks subsequent pragmatic reasoning (“It would be profitable to believe”) from altering the verdict. The hierarchical model thus reproduces Clifford’s condemnation.

4.3 High-stakes bank cases

Fantl and McGrath’s well-known bank scenarios invite us to think that practical stakes affect whether one knows that the bank will be open Saturday. On the present view, what changes is not the epistemic standard for knowledge but the rational permissibility of acting on that belief. Because acting on a belief is itself a practical undertaking, it is appropriate that practical stakes influence action even while the doxastic status of the belief remains fixed by the original evidence.

4.4 Moral encroachment

Some argue (e.g., Bolinger 2021) that it takes more evidence to rationally believe a morally dangerous proposition (e.g., that a job applicant is less competent because of a protected characteristic). The hierarchical model explains the appearance without granting moral reasons direct epistemic force. The moral stakes make it pragmatically preferable to suspend rather than believe, provided belief is not epistemically mandated. Because underdetermination is rampant in social stereotyping cases, moral encroachment emerges as a second-order practical veto, not a new variety of evidence.

5. Four objections answered

Objection 1: The view is too rigid; sometimes pragmatic reasons should outweigh even strong evidence (e.g., a doctor tells a terminal patient an optimistic prognosis).

Reply. Two clarifications. First, asserting a proposition one does not believe is compatible with withholding belief; one can console the patient without self-deception. Second, rare “self-enhancing” beliefs arguably increase overall epistemic functioning (McKinnon 2023). In those unusual cases, the justification is still epistemic: believing improves future evidence-gathering capacities. So the counter-examples do not require pragmatic override.

Objection 2: The evidential underdetermination condition is fuzzy. How do we know when evidence leaves us merely permitted rather than required?

Reply. Epistemology already faces the vague boundary between knowledge and mere justified belief. Our proposal inherits, but does not exacerbate, that indeterminacy. Moreover, the framework can incorporate any favored account of justification—Bayesian, reliabilist, evidentialist. What matters is that whichever theory is correct, it will often classify multiple attitudes as permissible; those are precisely the occasions for PTB to operate.

Objection 3: The model collapses into status quo evidentialism if epistemic defeats are ubiquitous, leaving no room for pragmatic impact.

Reply. Empirically, radical underdetermination is widespread: memory failures, testimonial conflicts, and time constraints constantly place agents below certainty thresholds. Everyday life is awash in epistemic permissibility. Even historians of science concede that the underdetermination of theory by data was severe in early cosmology, yet pragmatic values (elegance, calculational tractability) plausibly guided acceptance. There is therefore ample playground for practical reasons.

Objection 4: Lexical ordering is ad hoc; why should truth be absolutely prior to value?

Reply. Two arguments: (i) Conceptual role. Belief aims constitutively at truth; to treat usefulness as sufficient for belief would alter the concept of belief into something like acceptance-in-action (Cohen 1992). Lexical priority preserves the constitutive aim. (ii) Regress argument. Allowing pragmatic override without constraint invites epistemic chaos: one could believe anything if the practical payoff is big enough. Lexical priority serves as a stable stopping point in deliberation.

6. Responsible epistemic agency

The hierarchical model sits within a larger picture of agency that distinguishes three nested domains.

Agen﻿cy domain 1: Theoretical rationality—forming beliefs in response to evidence.  

Agen﻿cy domain 2: Planning rationality—adopting policies (including “credal policies” like trusting testimony or using heuristics).  

Agen﻿cy domain 3: Practical rationality—choosing actions given beliefs and values.

Practical reasons affect belief primarily by shaping planning rationality: should I join a religious community that will foster belief? Should I read climate-denial blogs? These second-order decisions are straightforwardly pragmatic. But once the policy funnels perceptual, testimonial, and inferential input into belief formation, first-order theoretical rationality regains priority. The hierarchical view is therefore not merely a patch on a problem case; it captures how diachronic responsible agency actually functions.

Conclusion

Epistemic and practical reasons for belief do not need a common metric to interact. A hierarchical norm structure—epistemic priority plus pragmatic tie-breakers—explains our intuitions about Clifford, Pascal, high-stakes car loans, and moral encroachment while preserving the special authority of truth-conducive reasons. The model avoids collapse into monism or normative schizophrenia, maintains conceptual fidelity to the nature of belief, and retains sufficient flexibility for the messy underdetermination that pervades real cognitive life. If the account is correct, we reconcile the competing insights that (i) believing against the evidence is epistemically wrong, yet (ii) believing is not a value-insensitive enterprise. The resulting reconciliation is not a mysterious weighing of chalk and cheese; it is a disciplined sequence of deliberative stages. That is how incommensurable reasons can, after all, jointly determine what one ought to believe.

A Practical Quietist and an Epistemic Purist are standing on the tracks of the same problem. The Quietist insists that whether you should believe p is ultimately a question of how much good or harm believing p will do; the Purist replies that whether you should believe p is ultimately a question of whether p is true. Many contemporary philosophers think both are partly right: we really do have epistemic reasons (having to do with truth-conduciveness) and practical reasons (having to do with value or welfare) that bear on what we ought to believe. But if those reasons are “fundamentally different in kind,” how could they ever interact to yield a single, all-things-considered (‘ATC’) verdict about belief? Aren’t they, as Bernard Williams once put it, “not on speaking terms”?

My thesis is that the appearance of incommensurability is generated by a level-confusion. Epistemic and practical reasons operate at different normative levels, and once that difference is made explicit there is no need for a mysterious weighing or direct comparison.
