Time—understood as the dimension along which events are ordered earlier-than and later-than—appears unlike light, odor, or force. It does not “press” on anything. Hence, the argument goes, there can be no genuine sensory system for time, and mechanisms that purport to represent it (biological clocks, wristwatches, circadian pacemakers) must do something other than sense.

I shall argue that the objection rests on a mistaken picture of how informational representation works. A mechanism can carry information about a magnitude without being causally acted upon by that magnitude itself; tight, law-governed covariation is enough. Clocks—whether quartz, atomic, or neural—exploit internal processes whose evolutions map, with a lawful regularity, onto temporal intervals. Because of that mapping, their internal states are usable by organisms and engineers alike to guide time-sensitive behavior. Once the representational condition is made clear, the alleged causal impotence of time ceases to threaten the possibility of a sensory system dedicated to it. What follows develops this reply in six steps.

2. Do sensory systems always require direct environmental causation?

Begin with a conceptual housekeeping point: even in uncontroversial modalities, the property represented is often not the property that directly causes receptor activity. Photons do not cause the brain’s representation of “red” by virtue of their intrinsic redness; they cause hyperpolarizations that covary, under the right conditions, with surface reflectances peaking at ~650 nm. Similarly, pain receptors fire not because “damage” literally presses on them but because tissue deformation triggers ionic currents that correlate with potential injury. The philosophical moral—drawn by Dretske, Fodor, and Millikan in different idioms—is that sensory systems traffic in reliable correlations, not direct property-to-neuron pushing.

Instrumental cases make the same point starkly. A mercury thermometer represents temperature by the height of a column of liquid. Strictly speaking, degrees Celsius never exert force on the glass. Molecular motion alters volume, which displaces mercury, which moves the meniscus. Yet we are perfectly happy to say the thermometer senses temperature. Whatever philosophical account one favors—indicator semantics, teleosemantics, predictive coding—the device qualifies as an information-bearing system for temperature despite the absence of a “temperature force.”

So even if time really were causally inert, that would not by itself preclude a sensory coding of temporality. The real question is whether mechanisms exist whose internal states reliably covary with temporal structure so that they can function, biologically or instrumentally, as time indicators.

3. Is time causally impotent?

The objection’s persuasiveness partly derives from a verbal slide. Physicists treat temporal order as a structural aspect of every causal interaction; philosophers of causation sometimes speak of time as the “stage” rather than an actor. From that it is inferred that time lacks the oomph to impinge upon matter. But the same could be said of space: spatial relations are not entities that slam into receptors either, yet we possess robust spatial perception. The retina is not causally poked by “leftness.” Instead, patterns of photic input covary with spatial layout, and neural processing extracts the relevant information.

Moreover, the claim that time is wholly causally impotent outruns physics. What makes a pendulum bob complete a cycle in one second is a complex of causal regularities linking length, gravitational acceleration, and inertial mass. Those regularities are expressed as equations with explicit temporal parameters (t). While one hesitates to say “time causes the oscillation,” temporal metrics are built into the causal laws governing the system. The difference between one-second and two-second periods is causally effective in the sense that it figures in the nomic explanation of the bob’s trajectory.

Still, glossing this debate is unnecessary for our purposes. Grant the strongest reading of the objection—that time itself never exerts a force. The response I shall defend requires only the weaker premise: causal covariation can arise without the target property’s directly impacting the representing mechanism. That premise is already accepted in the thermometer and photoreceptor cases. Therefore, even if time remains a “free rider” on more basic forces, it can be represented.

4. How clocks carry temporal information

4.1. The abstract recipe

A minimal clock consists of two components:

a) A periodic or steadily accumulating physical process whose dynamics are highly regular across environmental contexts (the “oscillator” or “timebase”).

b) A read-out mechanism that counts cycles, measures accumulated change, or samples the state of the oscillator to deliver a usable magnitude.

If (a) unfolds with sufficient stability and (b) links particular oscillator states to particular elapsed-time magnitudes, then, by Dretskean lights, the clock state R carries the information that time t has elapsed: P(t|R) ≈ 1, given background conditions C in which the device was designed or selected.

For a quartz wristwatch, microcrystalline lattice vibrations at 32 768 Hz serve as (a). An electronic circuit divides the oscillations until one pulse per second is achieved, and stepper motors drive the hands: (b). For an atomic clock, transitions between hyperfine energy states in cesium play the oscillator role, counted by microwaves tuned to 9 192 631 770 Hz. For the circadian clock in mammals, gene-protein feedback loops in the suprachiasmatic nucleus produce approximately 24-hour oscillations; neural and hormonal pathways propagate phase information to peripheral tissues.

In none of these cases does “time” bat the mechanism like a ping-pong ball. Nonetheless their states are temporally informative because, given the laws governing quartz lattices, cesium atoms, or molecular feedback, the physical evolution of the system stands in a fixed mapping relation to objective temporal intervals. The metaphysical bridge is nomic rather than direct causal impact.

4.2. Structural representation

Some philosophers (Cummins, Ramsey, Gładziejewski) prefer to explicate representation in terms of structural similarity or “isomorphism” used in a driving task. The pendulum clock’s escapement wheel progresses one tooth per swing; the angular displacement of the hand mirrors the linear temporal progression in virtue of a homomorphism between hand angle and elapsed seconds. This structural mirroring allows a user—whether the owner of a grandfather clock or the neural circuitry controlling diurnal body temperature—to extract temporal facts by reading off clock states.

Notice how this differs from a thermometer. Where the thermometer relies on a single equilibrium state whose value encodes temperature, most clocks rely on dynamical structure: a trajectory of states over which the system moves. Representing time requires representing ordered differences, not merely static magnitudes. Thus the clock mechanism uses its own passage through state-space as the representation. That is why no “time particle” need bang on it; instead, the system’s evolution is itself the vehicle.

5. Biological time-keeping and the status of a “sense”

The complaint, “but internal oscillators are not a sense,” gains traction from a folk picture in which senses must be exteroceptive. Yet cognitive neuroscience now recognizes genuine sensory modalities that primarily or exclusively monitor internal states: proprioception, nociception, vestibular balance, baroreception. The vestibular system, for example, detects angular acceleration via fluid inertia in the semicircular canals—fluid set in motion by head movement, not by an external substance called “rotation.” If the vestibular organs count as sense organs even though there is no “rotation stuff,” then, mutatis mutandis, temporal pacemakers can qualify.

Empirically, organisms deploy multiple such pacemakers on distinct time-scales:

• Millisecond timing for acoustic localization uses phase differences across auditory nerve firing.

• Interval timing in the seconds-to-minutes range recruits striatal beat-frequency models in which cortical oscillations with staggered phases create a “temporal pattern” read by downstream neurons.

• Circadian timing involves the aforementioned SCN loop.

Each system is modulated by environmental cues—light entrainment for circadian rhythm, dopaminergic input for interval timing—analogously to how vestibular signals are calibrated by vision. These relations further support the sensory analogy: clashing sources yield perceptual aftereffects (subjective time dilation under stimulants; “chronostasis” when saccades reset apparent duration) reminiscent of cross-modal illusions in vision and audition.

6. Meeting potential objections

Objection 1: Correlation is cheap; mere covariation does not suffice for representation.

Reply: Correct. Dretskean indicators become representational only when appropriately recruited by a consumer system—what Millikan calls the “normal consumer.” In biological clocks, downstream effectors—hormone release, sleep-wake switches, foraging behavior—are systematically controlled by clock state. Maladjusted clocks (jet lag, constant-light conditions) reveal the teleology: their states continue to change but fail to guide behavior adaptively, just as a broken speedometer’s needle moves without representing speed when disconnected from the consumer (the driver). Thus pacemakers are not accidental correlates; they are entrenched in feedback loops that give them semantic weight.

Objection 2: The mechanism might drift; then states would covary poorly with time. Does representation cease?

Reply: Exactly as with vision under fog or a thermometer left in the sun, representational accuracy is graded. Representation persists though it degrades. Indeed, the need for regular re-entrainment (zeitgebers like dawn light) illustrates the sensory nature of the system: it is open to calibration by external inputs, not sealed like an innate code. The “drift objection” therefore supports, rather than undermines, the claim that timekeeping mechanisms function analogously to other senses.

Objection 3: If time is a dimension of every physical process, any process could serve as a clock; hence clock states fail to provide distinctive information.

Reply: From the premise “any process unfolds over time,” it does not follow that any process unfolds in a reliably measurable way. Boiling water, radioactive decay, or human speech exhibit too much variability to act as clocks. What matters is lawful stability: low variance in period, insensitivity to moderate environmental fluctuation, and predictability across cycles. Only a subclass of systems meets these criteria. The fact that many objects can emit photons does not prevent photoreceptors from counting as vision; what matters is specialized selection and fidelity.

Objection 4: Sensing time is conceptually different because it lacks modality-specific qualia; there is no “time qualia” analogous to color.

Reply: The same complaint could be leveled at proprioception or baroreception. The phenomenology of bodily posture is subtle and easily overlooked, yet its absence (as in deafferented patients) is devastating. Subjective duration, while faint relative to brightness, can be experimentally manipulated (oddball stimuli seem to last longer, etc.). The presence or absence of strong phenomenal character is not a reliable guide to the taxonomic status of a sense. Philosopher Bence Nanay has suggested that sensory modalities form a graded cluster concept rather than a set defined by necessary and sufficient conditions; temporal sensing falls into the cluster by sharing the relevant explanatory roles.

7. A deeper look: counterfactual dependence and nomological necessity

One might press: Why not say that the quartz oscillator merely embodies laws of physics, and those laws, not time, do the causal work? But representation does not require the represented magnitude to be a causal antecedent; it requires counterfactual dependence. If the duration between noon and one o’clock were slightly longer, the oscillator’s state—given unchanged physics—would differ. Quartz periodicity is fixed as “one second” only because of how the actual world’s temporal metric is stitched into physical laws. Thus the clock’s operation counterfactually depends on the temporal structure of the world, satisfying Woodward’s criteria for causal explanation.

This point carries an instructive moral: representation often piggybacks on deeper laws. A barometer need not be shoved by “atmospheric pressure particles”; Boyle’s law plus mercury’s density suffice. Similarly, a quartz crystal is not acted on by “time atoms”; Hooke’s law in the time domain plus the rigidity of silicon dioxide create a reliable correlation. For representation, nomological necessity undergirds informational dependence.

8. Consequences for philosophy of perception

Accepting that organisms possess genuine time-sensing mechanisms forces a reconsideration of familiar dichotomies:

• External vs internal: The time sense blurs boundaries because it is driven by endogenous oscillators calibrated by exogenous cues.

• Analogue vs digital: Biological timekeeping employs both continuously evolving processes (oscillatory phases) and digital-like counting (spike accumulation), illustrating the hybridity of sensory coding.

• Perception vs cognition: Interval judgments as short as 200 ms are modulated by attention and expectation, yet they originate in sub-cortical oscillators. Thus time-perception straddles levels in ways that challenge sharp splits.

Moreover, temporal representation is arguably a necessary precondition for any sensorimotor activity. Acting in the world without encoding duration or simultaneity would be impossible. If so, the “objection from causal impotence” would entail that no organism could ever perceive—hardly a defensible conclusion.

9. An illustrative example: echolocating bats

Consider a bat emitting an ultrasonic chirp and waiting for its echo to return. The bat determines target distance by measuring the time between emission and re-entry of the sound. Crucially, the bat’s auditory system does not rely on an external timer; instead, neural oscillations in the inferior colliculus phase-lock to the outgoing pulse and count cycles until the echo arrives. Experimental lesion studies show that disrupting these oscillations impairs distance estimation even though auditory sensation remains intact. The bat thus possesses a dedicated sense of interval independent of the acoustic content per se. Nothing in the environment “causes” the passage of time between chirp and echo; the bat’s intrinsic neural dynamics do the tracking. If that is not sensory time-perception, nothing is.

10. Synthesis: what licenses calling it a “sense of time”?

A minimal functional characterization runs as follows:

Sense X is a system that (i) transduces energy into neural signals, (ii) whose output covaries lawfully with a distal magnitude M, (iii) which is used by the organism to guide behavior related to M.

Temporal pacemakers in the brain satisfy (i) because metabolic energy drives the oscillations; they satisfy (ii) because oscillator phase corresponds lawfully to elapsed time; and they satisfy (iii) because motor planning, hormonal cycles, and learning windows depend on that phase. The lack of a dedicated “time particle” is irrelevant, just as the lack of a “leftness particle” does not undermine spatial perception.

11. Closing remarks

The causal impotence objection dissolves once we notice that representation rides on reliable covariation, not on the represented property’s performing a Newtonian push. Clocks—artificial or biological—achieve temporal representation by enlisting physical processes whose evolution is nomically yoked to temporal intervals. Their informational legitimacy is secured by their integration into feedback loops that exploit that lawlike mapping to steer action. In this respect, temporal sensing resembles more familiar modalities, though it has distinctive features: its vehicles are endogenous oscillations, its mapping is dynamical rather than static, and its phenomenology is diffuse. None of those differences, however, impugns its status as genuine perception.

Thus, philosophers who deny a sense of time on grounds of causal impotence mistake a contingent fact—that time is not a force—for a principled bar to representation. Once the distinction between direct causal action and law-grounded covariation is in view, the path is open: a mechanism can faithfully tell the time without time’s ever having to knock on its door.

Does the fact that time itself exerts no causal force rule out the possibility of a biological or artificial “sense of time”?  I shall argue that it does not.  The objection trades on an overly literal interpretation of what it takes for a system to carry information about some environmental magnitude.  No perceptual system—whether retinal, cochlear, or internal clock—needs to be knocked about by the very property it represents.  What matters is that the system participate in reliable causal regularities that vary as the represented magnitude varies.  A clock, whether mechanical, electronic, or neural, can therefore inform an organism about temporal intervals even though “time” never impinges on the device the way photons strike the eye.  I proceed in four steps.  

(1) I distinguish causal impact from representational dependence and clarify what informational coupling really involves.  
(2) I show, by analogy with familiar measuring instruments, how a system can track an abstract dimension without that dimension’s directly producing a force.  
(3) I develop a positive model of clock-like timing mechanisms—in machines and in brains—that satisfies the informational requirements of perception while respecting the metaphysical fact that time has no mechanical bumping power.  
(4) I reply to three objections: the “mere correlation” worry, the “self-contained oscillator” worry, and the “phenomenology” worry.  

The result is a coherent picture on which a genuine sensory faculty for time is not only intelligible but almost certainly instantiated in many organisms, ourselves included.

1. Causal impact vs. representational dependence  
A quick concession: sensory systems require causal interaction with the world.  Retinas, cochleae, and olfactory epithelia do not operate in informational isolation.  But from this unobjectionable premise one must not leap to the stronger thesis that the very property represented acts as the distinctive causal initiator.  Two distinctions are worth pressing.

a. Token events vs. represented properties  
A single token event (photons hitting rods) can carry information about a higher-level property (e.g., the surface reflectance of a lemon) without that higher-level property itself causing the retinal excitation.  Surface reflectance is a dispositional trait; it manifests in the pattern of light only in the presence of illumination.  Likewise, velocity is represented by the visual system, yet no “velocity force” bombards the receptors.  What causally stimulates the eye are successive positions of an object across time.  The visual system nevertheless registers the property of motion because of law-like correlations between those successive positions and the object’s velocity.  

b. Primary vs. derivative causal links  
Once we broaden our focus from single links to whole causal chains, representation often turns on derivative rather than primary causal relations.  A newspaper thermometer “tracks” economic inflation if an editor instructs reporters to paste the current CPI figure on it every morning.  The reds and blues on the page are causally linked to printers’ ink, not directly to prices.  Yet the thermometer carries authentic economic information because of a stable, historically designed regularity.  In Dretskean terms, what matters is that there be a reliable dependence that the system is poised to exploit, not that the dependence arises from a single, unmediated causal shove by the represented magnitude itself.

These two distinctions jointly undermine the premise that because time exerts no primitive force, it cannot be sensed.  What is required is only that there exist physical processes that unfold in ways lawfully dependent on the temporal variable, such that a biological or artifact system can latch onto those processes.

2. Measuring abstract dimensions: length, temperature, number…time  
Analogies help.  Consider length.  A wooden ruler does not enjoy the benevolent push of the meter property.  Instead, spatial relations between the ruler’s markings and the object under inspection are exploited to yield information.  To be sure, molecules in the ruler and in the object come into contact, but it is hardly the abstract property of “being 10 cm long” that presses itself into the wood.  Similarly, a mercury thermometer measures mean molecular kinetic energy (temperature) via expansion: kinetic agitation of glass and mercury causes volumetric change, but expansion is not driven by some sui generis temperature force.  What is crucial is a law-like monotonic relation between volume and average kinetic energy.  

Time, too, is an abstract dimension.  What we call “a second” or “an hour” is individuated by a certain number of occurrences of a chosen periodic process: today, cesium-133’s 9,192,631,770 hyperfine transitions; yesterday, the swing of a pendulum at sea level; before that, the Solar day.  The link between countable physical cycles and duration is established by convention, engineering practice, and natural law.  Nowhere in this linkage does “time” push anything.  Instead, stable physical processes provide us with markers whose evolution covaries with elapsed time according to principles of mechanics, electromagnetism, or quantum physics.  A clock thus carries temporal information without temporal causation.

3. A positive model: the oscillator-comparator architecture  
Artificial clocks.  In a quartz wristwatch, electrical energy excites a piezoelectric crystal that vibrates at roughly 32,768 Hz.  An electronic circuit counts these oscillations; upon reaching 32,768, it flips a second-register, drives motor steps, and so on.  The quartz crystal is not acted upon by “time.”  It vibrates by virtue of its elastic restoring forces and the conservation laws governing its mass and charge distribution.  Yet because the period of vibration is highly stable across temperature ranges and crystal aging, the tick counts provide a reliable stand-in for elapsed seconds.  The watch converts frequency (cycles per second) into a duration code (seconds per hour) by exploiting law-governed regularities, not by sensing a mysterious temporal ether.  

Biological clocks.  Neurobiologists find an analogous scheme in circadian and interval timing.  In Drosophila and mammals alike, transcription-translation feedback loops (TTFLs) generate roughly 24-h oscillations in protein concentrations.  Specialized “clock genes” inhibit their own transcription with a delay, producing rhythmic peaks and troughs.  Downstream pathways—neural firing patterns in the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN), hormone secretion rhythms, body-temperature cycles—serve as read-outs.  No hypothesized “time particles” bombard SCN neurons.  Nevertheless, those neurons’ changes in firing rate lawfully covary with objective astronomical time because the TTFL oscillations maintain a near-constant period, entrained by ambient light.  

General architecture.  Both artificial and biological time-senses can be modeled by three components:

Oscillator: any physical process with a repeatable, approximately constant period (quartz vibration, thalamocortical spindle, genetic feedback loop, or chemical relaxations).  

Counter/Integrator: a mechanism to accumulate cycles or integrate oscillator phase, thereby generating a monotonic mapping onto elapsed interval length.  

Comparator/Effector: a decision device that uses the accumulator’s state to guide behavior—display digits, trigger expectancy of food, or initiate a saccade.  

This architecture meets the informational desiderata: (i) causal interaction—oscillator dynamics cause counter states; (ii) nomic reliability—periodic dynamics are governed by known laws; and (iii) accessibility—organisms can exploit the accumulator’s state for action.  Crucially, none of the three stages requires a direct force from “time.”  The causal story is entirely local and mechanistic.

4. Replies to objections  

4.1 The “mere correlation” worry  
Objection: If temporal representation is grounded only in correlation, then the system lacks warrant to treat its internal states as about time rather than about the oscillator’s phase.  A stopped watch still goes through micro-vibrations; those won’t track real time.  

Reply: Correct.  Representation is always fallible.  A retinal photoreceptor that is bleached carries no color information.  What secures content is not instantaneous correlation but historically selected, statistically reliable mapping.  Teleosemantics or etiological theories handle this elegantly: the oscillator-comparator system was selected or engineered precisely because, in normal conditions, its states correlate with elapsed interval.  When placed in abnormal environments—e.g., under strong magnetic fields that slow quartz vibrations—the device misrepresents.  Fallibility is not a defeater of content; it is an inevitable consequence of indirect representation.  The same point applies to every other modality.

4.2 The “self-contained oscillator” worry  
Objection: Brain clocks are endogenous.  If the oscillator sits inside the agent, how can it constitute a sensory channel as opposed to pure computation?  Sensory systems draw in something from outside; an intrinsic oscillator seems like internal noise.  

Reply: The retina, too, is partly endogenous—its phototransduction cascade relies on vitamin A stored in the pigment epithelium.  What makes a system sensory is not its physical location but its informational role: delivering world-directed, action-guiding states.  Circadian oscillators do so because their phase is entrained by external light-dark cycles via melanopsin ganglion cells.  Ultradian and interval timers can likewise be calibrated by exteroceptive cues (sounds, motor reafference, social signals).  Endogenous dynamics merely supply gain and stability; they do not undercut the system’s function as a bridge between environment and action.

4.3 The phenomenology worry  
Objection: Even granting that clocks carry temporal information, sensory awareness of time has a distinctive flow or duration quality.  Oscillators seem too mechanical to account for the felt passage of time.  

Reply: Phenomenology raises deeper questions, but here the causal impotence of time is irrelevant.  The objection conflates (i) representing temporal interval objectively and (ii) generating the subjective “passage” phenomenology.  One can coherently hold that internal oscillations provide the quantitative metric, while network-level integration and attention shape temporal qualia.  Representation is a necessary component of experience, but the phenomenology depends on additional neural dynamics, much as color experience depends on cortical opponent processing beyond cone excitation.  Thus, the informational story is a prerequisite and remains untouched.

Conclusion  
The objection that time cannot be sensed because it lacks causal oomph mistakes how representation works.  Clocks—biological and artifact—measure time by embedding themselves in law-governed causal chains that covary with elapsed intervals.  They receive no blows from “time” itself, but neither do rulers from “length” or thermometers from “temperature.”  What matters are reliable, exploitable regularities, which abound in oscillatory physical processes.  Consequently, a genuine sensory system for time is not only metaphysically possible but empirically instantiated.  Denying its existence would require an implausibly restrictive view of what perception demands—a view inconsistent with our best understanding of measurement, representation, and neurobiology.

A Reply to the “Causal Impotence” Objection and an Account of Temporal Information in Clocks

1. Introduction and Thesis  
The “causal-impotence” objection goes roughly as follows: we have genuine senses of light, sound, and pressure because photons, sound waves, and mechanical forces causally impinge upon dedicated receptors. Time, by contrast, is not a force or field; it does not bump into retinas or press on cochleae. Therefore there can be no bona-fide sense of time, and any device (biological or artefactual) that seems to “track” time must be doing something else—at best monitoring metabolic change, light–dark cycles, or some other genuinely causal signal.  

I shall argue that the objection rests on two mistakes. First, it assumes that information about a property or magnitude must arrive via that property’s exerting a direct, isolatable causal influence. But many familiar sensory and measurement systems acquire information through mediated or structural correlations with features that never themselves “strike” the receptor. Second, it trades on an ambiguous picture of what time is: if time is not a worldly feature in addition to events but the relational dimension in which all physical change is embedded, then the demand that time act as an independent causal factor is misplaced. Once these confusions are cleared away, it becomes clear how a clock can carry information about time: not by being kicked by “time particles” but by instantiating a lawful, reliably periodic process whose successive states stand in a law-governed mapping to temporal intervals. A nervous system can exploit the same strategy—e.g. via circadian oscillators or short-period neuronal pacemakers—to ground a rudimentary sense of duration or simultaneity. Causal contact with time is unnecessary; lawful covariation, properly recruited, suffices.

2. The Objection Analysed  
Sensory systems, the objector notes, have a characteristic architecture:  
(1) There is an environmental variable E (light intensity, air pressure, sugar concentration) that matters to the organism.  
(2) E causally affects a receptor R dedicated to that range of stimuli.  
(3) Through a chain of transduction and neural processing, information about E reaches decision and motor centres.  

Time appears to violate step (2). While events occur in time, nothing called “time” strikes R; so either step (1) is misdescribed (there is no such variable) or R is idle. Hence, no temporal sense.

This line of thought is initially compelling, but it equivocates on two distinct claims:

C1. Information that originates in X can reach an organism only if X causally interacts with the organism.

C2. A system can represent X only if X causally interacts with the system in a way the system is specially designed to exploit.

I grant C1; you cannot discover the colour of a distant nebula without causal traffic from nebula to you. C2, however, is false. Representation can be based on reliable intermediaries. A barometer represents atmospheric pressure, not because “pressure particles” press directly on its dial (they do not) but because changes in pressure causally influence air density, which influences the mercury column. The mercury’s height is about pressure in virtue of a law-governed chain that preserves a strict mapping. The proximate cause is mercury expansion; the represented magnitude is air pressure.

An exactly parallel story can be told for clocks. What directly causes the displacement of the quartz crystal or the motion of the pendulum is electromagnetic interaction or gravity; nonetheless the readings are about time because the underlying dynamics are lawfully periodic in a way that establishes a stable correlation with elapsed durations. Hence C2 is too restrictive. Once we admit representation via lawful covariation, the alleged gulf between time and its “senses” evaporates.

3. What Would Count as a Sense of Time?  
Before defending the positive proposal, we need a minimal functional criterion: an organism S possesses a sensory system for magnitude M just in case

(Functional Adequacy) States of S systematically covary with values of M in a way that (i) is produced by stable internal mechanisms, (ii) can misrepresent M, and (iii) is exploited to guide behaviour adaptively sensitive to M.

This criterion is neutral on whether M’s values impinge directly on the receptor. It emphasises function: to sense temperature, a snake’s pit organ need not be touched by heat per se; it merely has to evolve a mechanism whose states reliably track temperature and serve control. If that is right, a temporal sense is possible in principle: an internal pacemaker whose cumulative phase difference tracks external durations and modulates behaviour (e.g. foraging or predator avoidance) would qualify.

4. Time, Change, and Causation  
A second thread in the objection is metaphysical: time, it is claimed, does no causal work at all. Events are causes; time is just the background. So how could tracking time provide novel information? The answer lies in distinguishing two roles of “time”:

(Physical Time) A relational parameter t in the fundamental laws, ordering events and spacing them by intervals measured by standard processes.

(Manifest Time) The phenomenological or ecological feature that matters to agents: how much “later” one event is than another, constraints on simultaneity, rates of change.

For creatures embedded in the world, what matters is manifest time: knowing whether dawn is three hours away or whether a looming object will collide in 0.5 seconds. The covariance exploited by clocks—pendula, atomic oscillations, neuro-oscillators—links the unfolding of some local physical process to parametric time in the laws. Therefore, although time qua dimension causes nothing, lawful correlations between parametric time and the phase of an oscillator allow the oscillator to serve as an informational surrogate. To reject this would also force us to deny that a thermometer gives information about temperature (temperature is not a particular causal agent but a statistical property of molecular motion), or that a galvanometer measures voltage (no “voltage particle” exists). The objection thus overgeneralises.

5. How Clocks Carry Temporal Information  
Consider a simple pendulum clock.

5.1 The Physical Story  
A pendulum of length L, under gravity g, exhibits small-angle oscillations with period T = 2π√(L/g). The positions of the pendulum bob at successive moments are governed by Newtonian dynamics with no explicit time-dependant forcing. Yet if we record the number of completed swings N since a reference moment t0, we can reconstruct elapsed time Δt ≈ N·T. Crucially:

(a) The pendulum is endogenously periodic: its state space trajectory returns to near the same point every T seconds.  
(b) The law linking N to Δt is stable across a wide range of conditions (to first order).  
(c) The counting mechanism—an escapement advancing gears—transforms these cycles into a representational medium (dial position).

5.2 The Informational Story  
On a broadly Dretskean picture, a physical event E carries information about proposition P when the conditional probability of P given E is high because of a law-like dependence. Each additional tick raises the probability that one minute has passed by a factor determined by the reliability of the mechanism. Nothing in this account requires time itself to do causal work; it suffices that (i) physical laws fix a one-to-one mapping between time parameter t and oscillator phase φ, and (ii) the mechanism is designed (by selection or engineering) so that downstream consumers read φ as a cue to Δt.

5.3 Semantic Uptake  
Suppose the gears drive a bell that chimes each hour. The bell’s striking is causally triggered by gear alignment; semantically, the strike signifies: “an integer hour has elapsed.” That content is underwritten by the history of design (the clockmaker intended hours to be signalled) or in the biological case by natural selection. Again, direct causal contact between “time itself” and the striker is not needed.

6. Biological Parallels: Circadian and Interval Timing  
Nature is full of temporal sensors:

a. Circadian clocks: Suprachiasmatic-nucleus neurons express transcriptional–translational feedback loops with near-24-hour periods. Light inputs entrain the oscillator, but after entrainment the clock free-runs. If you place an organism in constant darkness, gene-expression cycles continue, and behaviour (sleep, hormone release) follows. The internal state misleads if the organism is transported across time zones—jet-lag is temporal misrepresentation.

b. Interval timing: Cerebellar and striatal circuits implement millisecond-to-second timers via ramping firing rates or population clocks. Experiments show animals can be conditioned to expect a reward one second after a tone; lesions disrupt this expectation without impairing other senses, indicating specialised temporal circuitry.

In each case, causal interactions with metabolic or photic cues fine-tune the oscillator, but the core timing signal is generated intrinsically. The brain uses the oscillator states as surrogates for external time. The causal work is done by molecular reactions; the representational target is duration.

7. Objections and Replies  
Objection 1: Correlation is not representation. Why say the pendulum position represents time rather than just bob displacement?

Reply: Representation depends on function. A barometer tube also correlates with mercury temperature, but we say it represents air pressure because the device was built to track pressure and because downstream consumers treat the reading as information about pressure. Similarly, the clock was built so that dial positions guide time-keeping actions (meeting, prayer, factory whistles). In biological contexts, evolutionary success calibrates which correlations matter. Teleology, not bare covariance, grounds semantic content.

Objection 2: Without a genuine receptor for time, we lack sensory phenomenology of time. Clocks may measure duration, but organisms do not feel it.

Reply: The argument conflates sensory input channels with conscious phenomenology. Many genuine senses operate below awareness (blood-oxygen chemoreceptors, vestibular otoliths). Experiments on “temporal adaptation” show that humans can experience altered duration perception (e.g., after prolonged exposure to rapid flicker, subsequent events seem longer). Such after-effects suggest dedicated neural pathways analogous to orientation-selective cells in vision. The presence of adaptation and illusion fulfils a standard mark of sense modality.

Objection 3: If tracking time depends on periodic change, the system really senses change, not time.

Reply: Change and time are conceptually intertwined. Yet the crucial feature is that lawful periodic change provides a metric for temporal intervals independent of specific events measured. The pendulum’s cycles do not represent swings; they represent seconds. What makes them seconds rather than swings is their role as a standard unit parasitic on the invariance of T. Likewise, a yardstick is a stick, but we say it represents length, not cellulose. Representation supervenes on use.

Objection 4: General relativistic effects (gravitational time dilation) break the uniform mapping between oscillator phase and time; hence clocks can mislead. Does that not undercut the informational link?

Reply: Fallibility is a virtue of representation: only things that can mis-represent count as representations. Pendulum clocks fail on a ship; quartz watches drift with temperature; atomic clocks require relativity corrections. These breakdowns show that the system really purports to represent physical time, otherwise we would not call the discrepancies errors.

8. Distinctions Clarified  
The debate is clouded by several conflations; let me draw three distinctions.

D1: Direct vs. mediated causation. Direct impingement is a special case of mediated causal chains. Sensing via proxy is ubiquitous.

D2: Physical vs. semantic information. Physical information is covariance; semantic information requires functional use. The causal-impotence objection targets the wrong level.

D3: Ontic vs. epistemic roles of time. Physics treats time as a dimension; organisms treat time as a variable to estimate. The second role can be filled by tracking periodic processes.

9. Dialectical Up-shot: From Sensory Limitation to Design Opportunity  
By reframing the issue around covariance and function, we dissolve the claim that a temporal sense is impossible. Indeed, the objection yields a research program: identify the internal oscillators, their noise characteristics, and how neural architectures read out and correct them. Computational neuroscience now models “central pattern generators” and “population clocks” that subserve rhythmic motion and duration judgement. Far from exposing a conceptual impossibility, the causal-impotence challenge highlights where empirical investigation should look: to the design of internal dynamics rather than to mythical time particles.

10. Conclusion  
A clock—or a circadian pacemaker—carries information about time without time’s exerting causal force. It does so because (i) physical law tightly correlates oscillator phase with parametric time, and (ii) the system is functionally organised so that those correlations guide behaviour. The causal-impotence objection thus misfires. Time need not “hit” a receptor; stable lawful structure suffices for sensing. This moral generalises: whenever a magnitude lacks a proprietary force, organisms and engineers can nonetheless achieve representation via internally generated processes whose unfolding mirrors the magnitude’s order and metric. Rejecting such representation would force us to abandon not just the sense of time, but thermometers, voltmeters, and barometers too. An adequate theory of perception must make room for information delivered by structure as well as by impact—a lesson we already rely on each time we glance at a clock.

How a Mechanism Can Tell Time
                               (And Why This Requires No Causal “Push” From Time Itself)

1. Setting the Problem

Many philosophers and neuroscientists speak loosely of a “sense of time.”  Critics charge that this talk is metaphysically confused.  Standard sensory modalities rely on causal impingement from an external feature onto a sensory receptor: light on the retina for vision, pressure on the skin for touch, molecules on olfactory cilia for smell.  Time, however, does not buffet our nervous system the way photons buffet photoreceptors.  Time—so the objection goes—is not a causally efficacious substance or field; it is a dimension, a parameter in the laws.  Since nothing literally “emanates” from time and strikes our receptors, there cannot be a bona fide time sense.  Similarly, a physical clock seems puzzling: if time has no causal powers, how can a mechanism reliably encode temporal information?  Must we conclude that talk of “sensing” or “measuring” time is metaphorical at best?

I shall argue that the objection rests on an overly narrow conception of how a system can carry information.  A mechanism can lawfully covary with some worldly magnitude even when that magnitude exerts no independent causal force.  What matters is that (a) the mechanism’s internal dynamics unfold according to laws that make its state a reliable function of the magnitude to be represented, and (b) the system can be calibrated so that users (biological or artifactual) can exploit that reliable covariance.  Once this broader notion of information‐carrying is in view, both biological “time sensing” and mechanical timekeeping present no mystery.  A quartz crystal or a neural pacemaker does not need to be shoved by time; it needs only to instantiate dynamical regularities whose evolution, when counted or read off, is correlated with elapsed temporal interval.  The work is done by lawful self-propagation, not by an external “influx” of temporal stuff.

The argument proceeds in five steps.  Section 2 clarifies two rival pictures of sensory representation.  Section 3 sketches an information-theoretic account on which lawful covariance—rather than direct causal impingement from a proprietary stimulus—is sufficient for representation.  Section 4 applies the account to paradigmatic clock mechanisms from pendulums to atomic transitions; Section 5 turns to neurobiological timing.  Section 6 replies to three lingering worries, and Section 7 concludes.

2. Two Pictures of Sensory Representation

Call the first picture the Impingement Model:

     (I) A sense modality requires a dedicated receptor that is selectively excited by a proprietary stimulus energy.  
     (II) The presence of that energy at the receptor is the proximate physical cause of sensory signals.

On the Impingement Model, what it is to be a genuine stimulus for a sense just is to be the kind of thing that impinges causally on the receptor surface.  Vision owes its existence to the fact that photons deliver energy to retinal photopigments.  Hearing exists because acoustic pressure waves jostle the basilar membrane.  

From (I) and (II) a quick objection seems to follow: time is not the sort of thing that can impinge; therefore there is no time sense.

Yet philosophers of perception have long recognized a second, broader picture, call it the Lawful Covariance Model:

     (LC) A receptor variable R can represent environmental variable E provided there is a counterfactual-supporting lawlike dependency such that, across normal conditions, the value of R is correlated with (and explained by) the value of E, in a way that can be exploited by downstream systems.

Under (LC) the sun’s position represents time of day to a sundial, even though the sun does not impinge on the gnomon with a proprietary “time particle.”  What impinges is light; but what is represented, via lawful functional dependence, is the hour.  More precisely, there is a stable mapping f between solar elevation and clock time under ordinary terrestrial conditions; the sundial exploits f to make hour‐indicating shadows.

Notice that LC does not deny causal influence; the dial’s shadow is caused by light.  But causal impingement need not come from the represented magnitude itself.  Likewise we routinely say that a mercury thermometer “represents temperature”: the causal influence is pressure on the glass‐mercury system, yet what is tracked is kinetic energy per molecule.  The thermometer’s reading depends lawfully on temperature, even though the latter is not a distinct causal stuff.

The opponent might reply that thermometers still rely on causal energy transfer.  True; but the transfer is not from temperature per se.  Nor does the thermometer possess a special receptor for temperature; it merely has constituents whose expansion lawfully covaries with molecular agitation.  The crucial lesson is that tracking can be mediated: a system can represent X via causal mediation by Y, so long as there is a suitable law linking Y’s states to X’s values.

3. Information Without Direct Impingement

We can make this precise using Dretskean informational semantics.  Signal S carries information about condition C when, given background laws L,  

      P(C | S) = 1.  

That is, under L, S would not occur unless C occurs.  To know that the signal S has obtained is ipso facto to know C.  C may, but need not, be the immediate cause of S; it suffices that S lawfully covaries with C.  

Shannon’s quantification of information is likewise correlation-based, not impact-based.  Mutual information I(S;C) is high when observing S reduces uncertainty about C.  Whether C ever physically touches the channel through which S travels is irrelevant.

Therefore, the notion that “senses must be caused by what they sense” is too strong.  They must be caused by something that is suitably related by law to what is sensed—a weaker and far more general requirement.  Photons lawfully covary with external reflectance features, so retinal excitation informs us about macroscopic shapes.  Light is merely the mediator.

Once we adopt the lawful-covariance view, the puzzle about time evaporates: a mechanism can represent temporal intervals if its states stand in a reliable mapping to those intervals, regardless of whether time causally “pushes” those states.  All that matters is that each temporal interval be associated (under normal conditions) with a distinctive, readable state of the mechanism.

4. How Physical Clocks Work

(a) Pendulum Clocks  
A pendulum of length l oscillates with period T = 2π√(l/g).  Neglecting air resistance and temperature drift, the pendulum’s own prior displacement plus gravitational force suffices to determine its next displacement.  Time plays no causal role beyond entering the second-order differential equations as a parameter.  Yet the pendulum’s state at t₀ + nT (namely, “has crossed the mean position n times”) is nomically linked to the amount of elapsed time nT.  By counting the swings, an escapement gear converts that lawful regularity into dial motion.  Anyone who sees the minute hand, therefore, gains information about elapsed time, not because time forces the hand into place, but because the hand’s angle is functionally constrained by the pendular dynamics that lawfully unfold at a fixed rate relative to inertial time.  

(b) Quartz Oscillators  
In a quartz watch, an electric circuit drives a crystal cut so that it mechanically resonates at 32,768 Hz.  Elapsed time is represented by counting cycles of electrical vibration.  Again, it is the feedback loop between piezoelectric deformation and the circuit that causes the next oscillation; time does no work.  Why trust the watch?  Because under quantum-grounded physical laws, the resonant frequency of quartz is extraordinarily stable across ordinary ranges of temperature and acceleration.  Stability grounds counterfactual dependence: had 10 seconds not elapsed, the counter in the CMOS register would not yet have received 327,680 pulses.

(c) Atomic Clocks  
The same story unfolds at higher precision.  Cesium-133 atoms possess a hyperfine transition whose frequency is fixed by natural constants.  Microwave radiation is locked in phase with that transition; a servo loop adjusts cavity frequency until maxima in absorption indicate resonance.  The atom’s internal dynamics—stemming from quantum electrodynamics—are the causal drivers; but they evolve in a way we treat as temporally invariant.  Hence we use the count of oscillations (9,192,631,770 for one SI second) as an index of time, and indeed define the second that way.  Causation runs from atomic constitution to detector clicks, not from a metaphysical “flow of time,” yet the correlation is robust enough to ground temporal representation.

(d) Error, Drift, and Calibration  
These examples also show why time representation need not be perfect.  Friction shortens a pendulum’s effective length; voltage drift alters quartz period.  Such errors reveal that the mechanism’s reliability, not some mysterious causal power of time, underwrites successful timekeeping.  Calibration—comparing one oscillator with another taken as standard—is our way of ensuring the necessary lawful linkage.  If two watches diverge, the poorer is corrected or discarded; no metaphysical crisis ensues.

5. Biological “Clocks”

Human and animal brains contain multiple timing systems:

(i) Circadian oscillators (the suprachiasmatic nucleus) implement roughly 24-hour gene-protein feedback loops.  Light resets the phase each day, but once entrained the loop free-runs in constant darkness.  Time of day is internally represented by the concentration profile of certain proteins; the mapping holds by biological law, not because time beams its hours into our neurons.

(ii) Seconds-to-minutes interval timing appears to rely on cortical-striatal circuits in which ensembles of neurons show ramping or oscillatory firing.  In “pacemaker-accumulator” models, a quasi-Poisson pacemaker emits pulses that are collected until a threshold representing the criterion interval is reached.  Pulse generation is caused by intrinsic membrane dynamics; time does not strike the brain like hail.  Yet organismal behavior (pressing a lever after 12 s for reward) indicates that pulse count covaries with objective duration.

(iii) Millisecond timing for speech and music probably exploits oscillatory interference patterns in auditory cortex and cerebellum.  Again, lawful dependencies between phase relationships and real time allow perception of rhythm and syncopation.

In each case the nervous system uses internal change—oscillation, drift, ramping—to stand in for elapsed time.  Exteroceptive calibration (sunlight, social schedules, metronomes) refines accuracy, but the basal mechanisms need no external causal influx from time itself.

6. Replies to Three Worries

Worry 1. “But these devices only measure change, not time.  Counting oscillations is just tracking one process’s internal state.  Calling the result ‘time’ is conventional.”

Reply:  All measurement involves mapping an unknown to a known.  A mercury column measures temperature by tracking its own expansion; a voltmeter measures potential difference by tracking coil deflection.  What licenses the description “measurement of X” is not metaphysical directness but reliable, law-grounded correlation plus agreed calibration.  Oscillation counts are therefore perfectly legitimate temporal measurement.  The fact that the mapping is conventional (we could have defined the second as 18,385,263,540 oscillations) does not undermine the reality of what is measured; conventions merely fix units, not the magnitude itself.

Worry 2. “Even if clocks measure physical time, a ‘sense’ requires sensory transduction of an external magnitude.  Biological timing is endogenous, so it is not perception but cognition.”

Reply:  The boundary between perception and cognition is porous.  Proprioception and vestibular balance rely on internal receptors (muscle spindles, semicircular canals) driven by self-motion, not by external objects.  We rightly treat them as senses because they deliver non‐inferential, phenomenologically immediate information usable for action.  Interval timing shows the same profile: we can feel a rhythm speed up or a movie’s frame rate stutter without inference.  What qualifies a system as sensory, on contemporary embodied views, is its role in guiding perception–action loops, not the exteroceptive origin of its signals.

Worry 3. “If time has no causal efficacy, how can there even be laws that state t-dependence?  Surely equations like dθ/dt = √(g/l) presuppose something about temporal becoming.”

Reply:  The objection conflates metaphysical accounts of time (A‐theory, B-theory, presentism, eternalism) with causal power.  Whatever one’s stance on becoming, the differential equations remain empirically confirmed.  They describe how system states at one parameter value (t) entail states at another (t + dt).  Nothing additional needs to push systems along the parameter; determinism plus initial conditions suffice.  Saying “time does no causal work” is not to deny that physical evolution is temporally indexed; it is simply to reject the reification of time as an agent.  Clocks exploit the indexed regularities, not a mysterious flow.

7. Conclusion

The challenge to a genuine time sense stems from an overly restrictive template for sensory representation—a template that demands proprietary causal impingement from the represented magnitude.  Once we adopt the more general lawful-covariance conception, the mystery dissolves.  A quartz watch, a pendulum clock, or a cortical timing circuit does not wait for time to knock on its door; it only needs internal dynamics that unfold at a stable rate.  Those dynamics, when appropriately calibrated and read, lawfully encode elapsed temporal interval.  Biological creatures evolved to exploit such internal clocks, integrating them with exteroceptive cues in complex ways that support circadian regulation, motor coordination, and conscious temporal experience.  

Therefore, the absence of a distinctive “temporal particle” is no bar to sensing time.  Information can ride on causal processes whose relation to the represented magnitude is indirect yet lawful.  Clocks tell time not because time causally tells them what hour it is, but because they reliably tell us where, in the invariant dynamical structure of the world, we currently stand.  That is all representation requires.

The “no-sense-of-time” objection trades on a simple syllogism:

1.     A genuine sensory system must be driven by causal influence from the environmental feature it detects.  
2.     Time exerts no causal influence on anything.  
∴    There can be no time-sense (and no mechanism—biological or artefactual—that really “detects” time).

The syllogism looks neat, but both premises are defective.  Below I argue:

•   Premise (1) misdescribes how information bearing works; lawful covariation, not direct causal impact of the property “as such,” is what matters.  
•   Premise (2) equivocates on what it means to be “causally impotent.”  Time is built into the causal structure of every physical process, so processes can be causally sensitive to temporal relations without being pushed by a mysterious “force of time.”  

Once these points are in view, the clock case ceases to be mysterious.  A pendulum clock, a suprachiasmatic nucleus in the mammalian brain, or an oscillating quartz crystal carries information about elapsed time because its state tokens stand in stable, law-grounded correlations with temporal magnitudes.  Time, like temperature, is tracked indirectly via physical processes whose dynamics are fixed by general laws, rather than by a sui generis “time ray” impinging on the mechanism.

I proceed in five steps:

I.    Distinguishing three senses of “sense” and why none requires direct causal impingement by the sensed magnitude.  
II.   How clocks work: lawful dynamics, calibration, and information without direct causal force.  
III.  A comparison case: thermometers and “causally impotent” temperature.  
IV.   Biological timekeeping and the same explanatory template.  
V.    Replies to four residual objections.

Total length is roughly 2,050 words.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
I.  What must a sensory system do?
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Talk of a “sense of X” can mean at least three different things.

Sense1:    A transducer that is selectively sensitive to a magnitude, transforming it into neural signals.  
Sense2:    A representational system that keeps track of a magnitude well enough to guide action.  
Sense3:    A phenomenological modality—there is “what it’s like” to experience X.

The objection under consideration targets Sense1: If no causal influence of time reaches a transducer, there is nothing to register.  The critic tacitly assumes a *Contact Principle*: for a system to carry information about M, M itself must strike the system.  But that principle is false both philosophically (on any information-theoretic account) and empirically (many instruments work via correlations rather than direct contacts with the measured property).

Notice also that the critic jumps from “time exerts no force” to “no system can use time-related information.”  This overlooks the pervasive fact that *time is a parameter in the equations governing every causal process*.  The pendulum bob does not feel a separate temporal shove, yet its motion is *indexed* by the temporal parameter because Newton’s second law contains derivatives with respect to t.  That is enough for information-bearing.

A more defensible principle, I suggest, is:

Informational Covariation Principle (ICP):  
A state S of mechanism C carries information about magnitude M if, in virtue of general physical laws and boundary conditions, P(S at t | M = m) ≈ 1 and P(S at t | M ≠ m) ≈ 0 within the relevant calibration range.

ICP makes no mention of M’s delivering a causal “kick” directly to C.  What matters is the nomic reliability of the correlation.  This is Dretske’s idea in *Knowledge and the Flow of Information* dressed in Bayes’ clothing; one can also connect it to Shannon’s mutual information.

If ICP is right, the critic’s premise (1) is wrong; causal covariation is enough, direct causal mediation by the property as such is unnecessary.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
II.  How a clock keeps time
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Take the paradigmatic artefact-clock: a simple pendulum.

Dynamics.  For small amplitudes θ, the period T ≈ 2π√(L/g).  This result is derived from *F* = m·a and the small-angle approximation of the sinusoidal restoring torque.  Neither the derivation nor the resulting motion invokes a force of time.  Nevertheless, *the number of oscillations completed* by the pendulum in an interval covaries one-to-one with the duration of that interval because the equations governing the system are time-translation invariant.

Calibration.  To turn a lawful covariation into a *measurement*, we calibrate.  Choose an arbitrary conventional unit—say, “the duration of 86,400 such periods shall equal a day.”  The markings on the clock face encode that mapping.  The clock does not *need* to know what days are; it need only maintain the invariant oscillatory dynamics.  

Information flow.  Let Sₙ = “the escapement wheel has advanced n teeth.”  By construction, P(Sₙ | elapsed time = n·T/teeth) ≈ 1 to a high degree of precision (modulo thermal drift, friction, etc.).  Sₙ therefore carries the information “n seconds have passed.”  The causal chain runs: gravitational field + rigid rod length + initial amplitude → oscillatory motion → escapement advancement.  Time doesn’t enter as a free cause; it is the parameter with respect to which the entire causal story is *described*.  That is enough.

No mystical residue remains.  Time appears *implicitly* as the independent variable of the dynamical law.  Because the law is stable, the mechanism’s state trajectory can stand in for elapsed time.  In short: a clock is a *law-rigged correlator*.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
III.  Temperature: a diagnostic analogy
--------------------------------------------------------------------

The critic might grant the pendulum story but complain that we have only replaced one puzzle with another: isn’t the notion of “standing in lawlike covariation” itself suspect when the measured magnitude does no causal work?

Consider thermometers.  Temperature, on statistical-mechanical accounts, is a macroproperty defined as mean molecular kinetic energy.  Molecules in the mercury bulb collide with glass molecules, transferring kinetic energy, causing volume expansion.  But “temperature” itself—*the mean*—never strikes the mercury.  Yet nobody doubts that thermometers measure temperature.

The thermometer case shows:

1.  Indirect detection via lower-level causal processes is common and unproblematic.  
2.  The property measured need not be an independent causal entity; it can be a higher-level abstraction realised in the very same causal goings-on.  

Time is analogous.  It is not a force; it’s a structural parameter built into every causal evolution.  Mechanisms that exploit invariant dynamics to produce reliably changing states can therefore carry information about time in exactly the way thermometers carry information about temperature.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
IV.  Biological timekeeping
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Sceptics sometimes shift ground: “Pendulum clocks are artefacts calibrated by us; living organisms had no engineer to do the calibration.  So how could evolution deliver a genuine time sense?”

The answer is: the same lawful invariances exploited by clockmakers furnish raw material for natural selection.  Two examples:

1.  Circadian oscillators.  The cyanobacterial KaiABC protein loop exhibits a roughly 24-hour phosphorylation rhythm even in vitro.  Differential growth rates among mutant strains show that strains whose oscillation period better matches the environmental light-dark cycle outcompete others.  Natural selection ratchets the oscillator’s period towards 24 hours.  The proteins are “calibrated” by differential reproductive success, not by a watchmaker.

2.  Neural pacemaker-accumulator systems.  In vertebrates, dopaminergic neurons in the basal ganglia fire at quasi-regular rates.  Psychophysical experiments (peak-interval procedures, temporal bisection tasks) reveal scalar timing: the standard deviation of time estimates grows linearly with mean duration.  This is predicted by a simple tick-counter model (pacemaker emitting pulses stored in an accumulator, read out by reference memory).  Dopamine manipulations that speed or slow the pacemaker rate predictably contract or dilate subjective duration.  Again, no force of time is detected; rather, stable neural oscillations correlate with elapsed time, and behaviour exploits that correlation.

So biological “senses of time” rest on exactly the same explanatory schema as artefact clocks: lawful regularities + calibration (via selection or learning) → informative states.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
V.  Four residual objections
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Objection 1.  “If time exerts no causal force, calling the clock’s state ‘informative about time’ is merely conventional.  We could equally say it tracks *oscillations*.”  

Reply.  Conventions settle which variable we map to which physical state, but the *nomic structure* supporting high mutual information is objective.  We could indeed re-describe the clock as a counter of pendulum bobs, yet because the period is stable, the state also reliably indicates elapsed seconds.  That double-description is typical: a barometer “counts” mercury column heights *and thereby* barometric pressure.  Objective informativeness does not reduce to human convention, though our interests select which correlation we exploit.

Objection 2.  “Relativity teaches that time is frame-dependent, so any single oscillator can’t tell ‘what time it really is’.”  

Reply.  True, but irrelevant.  Clocks measure proper time along their world-lines.  Two world-lines with relative velocity will record different intervals between shared events.  That fact vindicates, rather than undermines, the present account: each clock’s internal dynamics track the invariant integral ∫√(1−v²/c²) dt along that path.  What the objection shows is that no single device gives *God’s time*, not that no device carries temporal information.

Objection 3.  “Illusions of duration (e.g., oddball stimuli seem longer) show that our time sense is too malleable; therefore it cannot be a bona fide sense.”  

Reply.  Every sensory system is susceptible to context-driven illusions (consider color constancy failures, Muller-Lyer lines).  Illusions demonstrate *processing*, not absence of a sensory modality.  Moreover, the very possibility of systematic misestimation presupposes a representational standard that can be deviated from.  A blank slate cannot err.

Objection 4.  “Even granting lawful covariation, why isn’t temporal tracking just an internal monitor, not a *sensory* system?  Vision and audition are exteroceptive; timing mechanisms seem endogenous.”  

Reply.  The exteroceptive/interoceptive divide is a red herring.  Proprioception senses limb position via muscle spindles—an internal signal—yet is rightly called a sensory system.  What matters is informational function.  Organisms need to coordinate with rhythms in the environment (day/night, predator approach, speech flow).  Internal oscillators provide access to a dimension—temporal location—crucial for successful action.  They are therefore perfectly analogous to other senses in their teleofunctional role.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------------------------

The no-sense-of-time objection dissolves once we replace the “force” model of perception with an information-theoretic model.  Time is not a causal agent, but its metric structure constrains every physical process.  Mechanisms—artefactual or biological—that embody stable dynamics thereby come to carry reliable information about elapsed time.  Calibration (by design, selection, or learning) harnesses those correlations for action guidance.  Thus a clock *can* keep time, and animals *can* sense time, without needing a causal shove from Father Time himself.  The objection mistakes absence of a mysterious “chronon flow” for absence of information; in reality, information piggybacks on lawful covariations, and those are everywhere.

Time Without Temporal Push: How A Mechanism Can Sense and Represent Time Even Though Time Does Nothing

1. Introduction and Thesis

A venerable line of skepticism insists that there can be no “sense of time.” Sensory systems, the thought goes, work by causal impingement: light waves strike the retina, pressure deforms the skin, odorant molecules bind to olfactory receptors. Time, by contrast, is routinely characterized as “causally impotent.” It is not a force or substance that can buffet a receptor. Hence (the objection concludes) time cannot be sensed, and mechanisms such as biological clocks do not literally carry temporal information.  

I shall argue that the objection mis-conceives both the nature of sensing and the way in which information is carried. Once we keep track of the distinction between (a) something’s being a *causal source* of a sensory stimulus and (b) its being a *law-governed correlate* that a system can exploit, we see that time can be represented without exerting causal force. A clock—biological or artificial—stores information about temporal relations in virtue of internal causal processes whose behavior is systematically dependent on the parameter t. What matters for representation is not that time *pushes* the mechanism, but that the mechanism’s states vary with time in a stable, counterfactually robust way that a consumer system can use. In short: causal covariation suffices; causal *origin* is not required.

After clarifying the causal requirement implicit in the objection (§2), I show (§3–4) how a physical process whose dynamics are governed by laws with an explicit time-parameter naturally comes to carry temporal information. I then illustrate with pendulum clocks, radioactive decay, and endogenous circadian oscillators (§5). Section 6 addresses three residual worries: (i) calibration, (ii) the “mere change” objection, and (iii) the alleged difference between perception and inference. I conclude (§7) by situating the proposal within contemporary theories of representation.

2. What Do Senses Really Require? Relaxing the Causal Source Condition

The objection trades on an intuitive but overly strong principle:

(Causal Source Condition, CSC)  
A system S perceptually represents property P only if P causally produces, or partially constitutes, the proximal stimulations that drive S.

CSC is plausible for paradigmatic exteroception: the *light* is the proximal cause of retinal excitation; the *pressure* wave from a sound makes the eardrum vibrate. But two preliminary points already chip away at CSC’s universality.

First, even in vision, the distal property that interests us—say, the *shape* of an object—is **not** itself the causal source of retinal activity. What shapes the retina is a pattern of reflectance; “shape” enters the causal chain only by law-governed correlation. CSC therefore over-states what standard senses require.

Second, biology teems with *endogenous* sensing. Vertebrate vestibular organs sense head rotation partly by monitoring inertia of internal fluids; the fluid’s movement is generated by the subject’s own motion, not by an external medium. Proprioception similarly samples muscle spindles that the organism itself stretches. In such cases there is causal stimulation, but it is not imposed by an independent environmental source. The property represented (joint angle, head acceleration) is *constituted* by the organism’s relation to its own previous states. Again, causal origination by P is absent.

These cases suggest replacing CSC with a weaker principle:

(Relational Covariance Condition, RCC)  
A system S perceptually represents property P if changes in P are reliably correlated, by natural law, with changes in some internal variable V such that S is functionally organized to use V as a guide to P.

RCC still insists on causal traction—there must be a dependable causal pathway—but it does not demand that P be the immediate causal *source*. Lawlike covariance and functional exploitation suffice. The question is whether clocks satisfy RCC for time. I now show that they do.

3. Dynamics, Parameters, and the Time Variable

Physics describes systems by state variables x(t) whose evolution is governed by ordinary differential equations like dx/dt = f(x). Here, t appears as an *independent parameter*—the axis along which change is plotted. Time does not enter as a force term; nevertheless, if you know the law and the current state, you can read time off the system’s subsequent states. A trivial example is uniform motion: x(t) = x0 + vt. From the distance traveled you can calculate the elapsed time ∆t = (x – x0)/v.

The general pattern is this:

1. There is an internal variable V whose value is given by a law V(t).  
2. V changes monotonically over ordinary temporal intervals (monotonicity prevents ambiguity).  
3. The mapping from V to t is stable under a range of perturbations.  

Whenever 1–3 are satisfied, reading V is tantamount to reading t. That is precisely how a clock, broadly construed, works.

Crucially, nothing in 1–3 requires that *time itself causes the change in V*. Rather, V’s evolution is a manifestation of a causal mechanism (pendulum dynamics, radioactive decay, gene-regulation feedback loops) whose *law* explicitly involves t. The representation relation piggy-backs on lawful covariation rather than on t’s supposed causal potency.

4. A Generic Model of Clock Information

Let us formalize the foregoing intuition. Suppose a mechanism M has an internal state space Σ and a read-out function R: Σ → ℝ. Call R(σ) the *display variable*. We add three properties:

(i) Law of Motion: For initial state σ0 at t0, the evolution σ(t) obeys σ(t) = Φt(σ0). Φt is a deterministic flow indexed by t.  
(ii) Rate Condition: R(Φt(σ0)) = kt + c for constants k, c.  
(iii) Consumer Link: Some downstream system C relies on the value r = R(σ) to guide behavior that is adaptively successful only if r correctly tracks t.

Given (i)–(iii), Shannon-style mutual information between R and t is maximized (subject to noise); on a teleosemantic reading, R *represents* t because it is recruited by selection for that very purpose. Note that t never impinges on M as a cause; what drives the change is the mechanism’s own internal dynamics plus energy supplied by gravity, spring tension, metabolic reactions, etc. Still, RCC is satisfied: variations in t covary with R in a way M and C exploit.

5. Concrete Cases

5.1 Pendulum Clocks  
The period of a simple pendulum of length L in a uniform gravitational field is T = 2π√(L/g). Gravity and mass distribution set the *rate*, but once constructed the device counts atoms of time via successive swings. Each swing advances the escapement wheel by one tooth; the wheel’s rotation angle α(t) is piecewise linear in t. Reading α is reading elapsed seconds. Time does not *press* the pendulum; gravitational potential energy and inertial motion do the work. Yet α carries temporal information because α(t) has a stable harmonic relation to t modulated only by small perturbations (temperature, air resistance)—hence the historical quest to isolate the pendulum from such noise sources.

5.2 Atomic Clocks  
A cesium-133 atom switches between hyperfine energy levels at a frequency f = 9,192,631,770 Hz. An electronic circuit counts the oscillations. The causal origin of the transitions is quantum electrodynamics, not “time,” but because the frequency is remarkably constant, the count N is proportional to t, allowing the Bureau International des Poids et Mesures to define one second as *exactly* 9,192,631,770 cycles. Atomic clocks illustrate how improving the stability of the law (ii) above refines temporal resolution without invoking temporal causation.

5.3 Circadian Oscillators  
Many organisms possess gene-regulatory feedback loops (e.g., the PERIOD–TIM complex in Drosophila) with an intrinsic 24-hour limit cycle. The phase variable φ of the molecular oscillator entrains to day-night cues but persists under constant conditions (free-running rhythms). Neural circuits read φ to modulate metabolism, hormone release, and sleep. In mammals, lesions to the suprachiasmatic nucleus abolish φ and produce arrhythmic behavior, demonstrating consumer dependence (iii). Again, no “time rays” strike the neurons; information arises from the oscillator’s consistent phase advance with respect to t.

6. Replying to Three Objections

6.1 Calibration Worries  
One might concede that internal dynamics can track time *in principle* but worry that, absent external temporal cues, drift would soon destroy accuracy. True, mechanism M must be *calibrated*. But calibration does not undermine representational status. Vision relies on ocular growth, lens accommodation, and neural plasticity to keep images in focus; proprioception recalibrates via efference copy. Clocks are no different: entrainment to the light-dark cycle, temperature compensation, or periodic synchronization to a radio time signal refine k in R(Φt). Calibration is a ubiquitous feature of sensing, not a mark against temporal representation.

6.2 The “Mere Change” Objection  
Perhaps what clocks register is not time per se but *change* in some physical magnitude. A pendulum measures angular displacement, the cesium clock counts energy state transitions, the circadian oscillator tracks protein concentration. While true descriptively, the objection conflates *vehicle* with *content*. To see why, recall that retinal cones register glutamate release rates, yet we say they represent color. Vehicle/content separation is forced by the consumer relation: what matters downstream is not the pendulum’s angle but the answer to “how much time has elapsed?” If changing angle ceased to correlate with time—say, on a spacecraft with variable g—the same angular readings would no longer guide successful temporal predictions. Teleosemantic theories make representation dependent on *proper function*; the proper function here is tracking time, not angular displacement.

6.3 Perception versus Inference
