A final worry insists that because the organism must *compute* time from endogenous change, the phenomenon is cognitive inference, not sensory perception. The line between perception and inference, however, is porous. Color constancy requires complex neural computation; yet we call color a perceptual attribute. Similarly, vestibular perception of rotation subtracts efference-copy from semicircular-canal signals. Many psychologists classify interval timing (milliseconds to hours) as a form of “internal sense” because its error profile (scalar variability, adaptation aftereffects) mirrors that of canonical senses. Rejecting its sensory status on the ground of internal processing would overshoot and threaten to declassify much of perception.

7. Situating the Account: Information, Structure, and Representation

Several contemporary accounts of representation endorse exactly the sort of covariation-plus-use relation exploited above.

1. Dretskean Informational Semantics: A variable R carries information about t if the probability distribution P(t | R) differs from the prior P(t). Monotonic functions of t maximize this information.  
2. Teleosemantics (Millikan, Neander, Papineau): R represents t when natural selection has recruited R because it *indicates* t, and consuming systems use it accordingly. Biological clocks fit the bill handsomely.  
3. Structural Representation (Cummins, Ramsey, Gładziejewski): An internal model M structurally maps onto features of the target domain. The phase space trajectory of an oscillator is homomorphic to the linear time-axis; the mapping preserves temporal order, enabling prediction.

In all three cases, causal *origin* in t is unnecessary. What matters is reliable correspondence and functional exploitation. That is why the initial objection conflated two distinct roles played by causality: (a) transmitting energy that perturbs a receptor, and (b) underwriting nomic correlations on which a system relies. Time fails at (a) but succeeds at (b). Hence the objection does not go through.

8. Conclusion

We began with a challenge: if time cannot causally impinge on a mechanism, how could any system “sense” it? The answer is that sensing is not limited to direct causal bombardment by the represented property. A clock, whether hanging in a train station or ticking in the suprachiasmatic nucleus, harnesses an internal process whose evolution law includes time as a parameter. Because that law is stable, monotonic, and exploitable by a consumer system, the mechanism’s state variables encode elapsed time. This satisfies a relaxed but principled account of what sensory representation requires.

Recognizing this point unifies exteroceptive and interoceptive phenomena under a common informational framework, while freeing us from reifying time as an occult causal agent. The sense of time is real, not because time pushes on us, but because organisms have evolved ingenious ways of letting the river of change leave a mark in organized matter—marks we, and they, can read.

How can an organism, or a machine, be said to “sense” time if time itself never reaches out and pushes on anything?  The objection rests on a familiar causal-transduction picture of the senses: photons strike retinas, pressure waves strike cochleae, chemical molecules bind to olfactory receptors.  Because time is not the sort of entity that exerts forces, the thought goes, there can be no sense dedicated to time.  In what follows I argue that the objection conflates two very different ways in which a feature of the world might underwrite representation.  A feature can be (i) a direct causal source of signals in the transducer, or (ii) a law-governed parameter that systematically modulates other states of affairs which, in turn, do exert causal influence.  Temporal magnitude falls into the second category.  The upshot is that a clock—whether a pendulum in a cathedral or a circadian pacemaker in a suprachiasmatic nucleus—can carry actionable information about time even though time itself never “hits” the device.  Sensing time requires only that there be (a) an internal process whose evolution is monotonically related to elapsed duration and (b) an information-picking relation between that process and action-guiding systems.  Once we see that, the causal-impotence objection loses its grip.

1.  Two Routes to Representation

The first step is to separate causal interaction from information content.  Call the immediate impinging cause of a transducer’s state a “primary signal.”  In normal daylight vision, the primary signal is photon absorption in photopigments.  But consider vision at night.  Because photon flux is low, the visual system relies heavily on temporal integration: rods accumulate charge over ∼100 ms before generating a neural spike.  Crucially, what the spikes represent (spatial layout and reflectance) is not identical to what impinges on the receptor (electromagnetic quanta); there is a many-to-one inference from input to distal cause.  So even paradigmatic senses involve a gap between causal source and represented property.  That gap is bridged by lawful regularities linking the impinging energy to the environmental property of interest.  The same strategy applies to temporality, only in a purer form: the represented property is a *parameter* that structures the lawful evolution of physical processes rather than an energetic source in its own right.

2.  Time as a Parameter in Dynamical Laws

Physics treats time as an independent variable in differential equations: x(t + Δt) = f(x(t), Δt).  Although time does not exert a Newtonian force, it is not inert from an informational point of view.  Given any sufficiently regular system—radioactive decay, crystal oscillator, migrating interneuron bursts—there is a lawful mapping between elapsed duration and the state of the system.  If an organism has access to the current state, and knows the law (whether innately or through calibration), it can infer how much time has passed.  The lawful mapping plays the same epistemic role as the optics equations that link wavelength distributions to surface properties.  That role is enough to ground representation even in the absence of direct causal contact with time itself.

3.  Clocks and the Information-Carrying Relation

What, then, is a clock?  Nominally: a physical mechanism whose state S(t) instantiates a monotone, invertible function of elapsed time.  A pendulum’s angular displacement, a caesium atom’s hyperfine oscillation, or a thalamic network’s spiking rhythm each satisfy that condition.  The second ingredient is a *read-out* mechanism: an observer (human, animal, or robot) that couples to S(t) and maps it onto action.  For instance, bees use oscillatory levels of PER protein as a phase indicator to decide when to leave the hive.  Notice that what interacts causally with the read-out is not time but the *surrogate variable* S.  The surrogate is causally efficacious; it vibrates, decays, or changes concentration, and thus triggers downstream activity.  Yet by virtue of lawful correlation, S carries Shannon information about t.

4.  Addressing the Causal-Impotence Worry

The critic may concede that clocks correlate with time but protest that a mere correlation is insufficient for genuine sensory representation.  After all, barometer readings correlate with impending storms; yet no one says the barometer *senses* storms.  The missing ingredient, however, is *appropriate use.*  A clock is hooked up to behavioral controllers in a way that enables on-line temporal regulation: circadian gene expression schedules metabolic cycles, cerebellar Purkinje cells fine-tune motor commands in milliseconds, bats adjust emission rates of echolocation pulses in microseconds.  The barometer, by contrast, sits on the wall and is ignored.  One can formulate the point in Ruth Millikan’s teleosemantic terms: the proper function of the pacemaker is to provide the organism with time estimates; the proper function of the barometer is not to guide anyone’s actions.  Proper function completes the step from correlation to representation.

5.  “Photons Hit Retinas” and Other Red Herrings

Still, the critic might insist: in vision the distal cause and the energetic signal are token-identical (photons), whereas in time-keeping the distal cause (elapsed duration) is a parameter, so the analogy fails.  But the comparison is weaker than it appears.  When colors are perceived, the relevant distal cause is *spectral reflectance,* not photons.  Reflectance is a dispositional property, realized across indefinitely many photon-events; yet we do not deny that color vision is a sense.  Similarly, pitch perception represents the frequency of a sound source, not the pressure waves themselves.  Frequency is an abstract parameter, again realized in but not identical to its energetic substrate.  So the ontology of the represented property—dispositional, statistical, or parametric—poses no barrier to sensory status.

6.  Objection from Multiple Realizability

Suppose the critic reformulates the worry: because any physical process unfolds in time, *any* change in S is correlated with elapsed duration.  So the correlation between a clock variable and time is trivial; hence reading S provides no non-accidental information.  Response: what matters is not mere covariation but *law-grounded, counterfactually robust* correlation.  If the pendulum were shorter, its period would change in a lawful way; if ambient temperature altered the quartz crystal, the oscillator would speed up.  These counterfactual patterns are precisely what is exploited when we calibrate a clock or when neural learning rules adjust synaptic weights to track reliable temporal regularities.  By contrast, accidental correlations do not support such cross-world stability.  That is why the angle of my cat’s tail, though temporally extended, is useless as a chronometer.

7.  Is a Temporal Sense Redundant?

One line of criticism suggests that, given extramental clocks in the environment (the sun’s position, tidal cycles), organisms need no internal time sense.  Yet ethological evidence shows otherwise.  Desert ants *Cataglyphis* integrate outbound stride counts to compute homing vectors even when the sky is occluded; songbirds rehearse nocturnal migratory routes using endogenous circannual rhythms; humans deprived of zeitgebers still display free-running circadian periods.  These behaviors require sensitivity to time intervals in the absence of external synchronizers.  External clocks supplement but do not replace internal timing mechanisms.

8.  The Metaphysics of Temporal Qualia

A more phenomenological version of the objection targets consciousness: even if clocks exist in the nervous system, why should their activity manifest as a *sense* that time is passing?  Here the reply mirrors the broader representational argument.  Just as activation in V4 gives rise to red-experience because of its role in tracking spectral features, activation in timing circuits (e.g., striato-cortical loops) gives rise to duration experience because of its role in estimating elapsed time.  No additional “chronokinetic force” must impinge on consciousness.  The sense of time emerges from the brain’s use of temporal proxies, not from brute causal contact with time.

9.  A Constructive Model: Oscillatory Timestamping

To make the proposal concrete, consider an “oscillatory timestamp” model.  (i)  A central pattern generator emits rhythmic bursts at frequency f.  (ii)  Downstream neurons integrate spike counts; the integral n approximates elapsed time t = n/f.  (iii)  Whenever a sensory event occurs (say, the onset of a tone), its neural representation is tagged with the current n in working memory.  (iv)  Decision circuits compute Δt by subtracting the stored n from the current counter.  Throughout, time is never a causal factor; what does the causal work are spike trains.  Yet the system gains actionable duration information.  Experimental data on hippocampal “time cells” and striatal beat-frequency models line up well with this abstract architecture.

10.  Extending the Account: Relational Senses and Ersatz Proxies

Finally, note that the clock-as-proxy strategy generalizes.  We lack receptors for mass, yet we perceive weight via pressure exerted on muscles and tendons.  We lack receptors for numerical quantity, yet we subitize small numerosities via parallel individuation circuits.  In each case, the system leverages a causal surrogate (pressure pattern, cortical accumulator) whose evolution is lawfully tied to the target property.  Time is simply an extreme case in which the surrogate must track a dimension rather than a localized stimulus.  Once we accept surrogate-based sensing as legitimate—and biological cognition abounds with it—the special pleading that bars time drops away.

11.  Summing Up the Argument

(A)  Sensing requires a causal transducer, but the transducer need only be affected by *something* that lawfully covaries with the target property.  
(B)  Physical processes evolve according to laws with time as a parameter, so their states provide lawful surrogates.  
(C)  If an organism hooks action to those states in a teleologically appropriate way, the states represent elapsed time.  
Therefore, a genuine time sense is metaphysically coherent even though time itself is causally impotent.

12.  Closing Reflection: From Objection to Opportunity

Seen in this light, the causal-impotence objection is not merely answerable; it illuminates a deep point about epistemology.  Much of what we know—causal power, probability, moral value—is not delivered by single dedicated receptors but inferred from patterns in more basic sensory inputs.  Temporal magnitude belongs to this “higher-order” class.  Our success in tracking it testifies to the brain’s capacity to leverage lawful structure rather than to wait passively for nature to slap it with the relevant property.  Once the objection is defused, the remaining task is empirical: chart the surrogate variables, map their neural read-outs, and explain how their interaction yields the rich phenomenology of time.  Philosophy’s role is to clear the conceptual ground; biology and cognitive science can then get on with filling in the details.

Sensing Time Without Time’s Touch:
Covariance, Clocks, and the Causal Impotence Objection
≈ 2,000 words

1. Introduction and Thesis  
Most philosophers accept a “causal contact” requirement on genuine perception: a sensory system carries information about a feature F only if that feature exerts—or is mediated by—causal influence on the system. Time, however, is often said to be “causally impotent”: nothing is pushed, pulled, or impinged upon by time itself.  Hence (the objection runs) there can be no sense of time.  Human time‐experiences, and clock mechanisms more generally, must therefore be either inferential constructs or purely conventional; they cannot be perceptual in anything like the way vision, audition, and the other canonical senses are.  

I shall argue that the objection rests on a mistaken picture of how information reaches a sensory system.  What a system needs is not direct causal action by the *abstract property* it represents; it needs reliable causal *covariance* between some detectable state of affairs and that property.  Because physical processes necessarily unfold in law-governed ways, many internal and external processes covary with elapsed temporal interval.  By harnessing one of those regularities, a mechanism—biological or artefactual—can be a perfectly respectable time-sensor.  The pendulum clock, the oscillating quartz crystal, and (arguably) the human cortico-striatal beat-frequency network all exemplify this strategy.  Time, while not itself a causal agent, is trackable because every causal process leaves temporally structured traces.  

In short:  

Thesis A sensory or measuring system can legitimately represent time provided (i) some state of the system covaries lawfully with temporal magnitude, and (ii) that covariance is appropriately exploited for control or inference.  Direct causal action from “time itself” is unnecessary, because lawful covariance suffices for information-carrying.  Once the causal-contact principle is recast in this more perspicuous way, the purported impossibility of time perception dissolves.

2. Unpacking the Causal Contact Principle (CCP)  
The objection relies on a strong reading of CCP:  
(CCP-Strong) For S to perceptually represent F, F must *cause* S’s representational state.  

In ordinary cases this looks plausible: photons hitting photoreceptors, airborne molecules binding to olfactory cilia, mechanical deformation of hair cells in the cochlea.  But even here, what does the causing is not “color” or “smell” in the abstract; rather, concrete micro-physical events that reliably *correlate* with those higher-level properties.  Redness is not a force; photons of certain wavelengths are.  Warmth is not a molecule; faster molecular motion is.  If CCP-Strong disqualified time-sensing, parity of reasoning would disqualify color- and temperature-sensing as well.  The realist about vision does not insist that “redness reaches out and touches the retina”; she insists that world-states whose possession of the property “red” is lawfully linked to patterns in the retina.  

That observation suggests a weaker, and more defensible, formulation:  
(CCP-Covariance) For S to perceptually represent F, there must be a causal chain from some state of affairs G to S’s receptors such that (i) G covaries with F under the relevant background laws, and (ii) S is sensitive to G in virtue of that very covariance.  

Temperature is perceived because molecular agitation (G) causally affects thermoreceptors, and there is a lawlike covariance between average kinetic energy and temperature (F).  Crucially, the average kinetic energy *grounds* temperature, but grounding is not itself a causal relation; what *causes* the sensor to fire are still the molecular impacts.  Nothing violates CCP-Covariance.  

3. Time and Causal Impotence  
Granting CCP-Covariance, why think time is special?  Two reasons are often given.  

(1) Time is ubiquitous.  Because every physical process unfolds in time, nothing can vary with time in the way molecular impact varies with temperature; temporal passage is merely the background medium.  
(2) Time’s features—earlier, later, t-seconds elapsed—cannot be localized; thus no “temporal particles” can impact a receptor.  

Both points are accurate but innocuous once we keep separate:  
• being a direct causal influence,  
• standing in a lawful co-variation relation.  

Every causal process unfolds over time; precisely *for that reason* many processes are suitable proxies for temporal magnitude.  Pendulum displacement, radioactive decay counts, cellular circadian oscillations, and cortical beta-band phase drift each instantiate a reliably monotonic or periodic function of elapsed time.  That is enough to satisfy CCP-Covariance.  No temporal particles required.  

4. How Clocks Carry Information Without Time as Cause  
Consider a classical pendulum clock.  What enters into causal commerce with the escapement mechanism is the *position* of the pendulum bob, which in turn depends on gravitational torque, length, and energy dissipation.  Under small-angle and constant-g assumptions, the period T ≈ 2π√(L/g) is invariant.  Thus the nth swing token-correlates with t = nT.  Time does not cause the swing; *earlier states of the pendulum cause later states* under timeless differential equations, and those equations guarantee the requisite covariance.  

Formally:  
Let S(t) be the pendulum’s state at real time t.  The laws of motion yield S(t + T) = S(t).  Define a readout function R on the gear train that maps states S to numerals.  Because the mapping from S to t is bijective (modulo T), R(S(t)) contains (Shannon) information ≈ H(t).  The clock’s users exploit that information: they consult the numeral to catch trains or bake cakes.  At no point must “time” push the gears.  What drives the system is ordinary mechanical causation; what *makes* it a timekeeper is the law-entrained isomorphism between S’s evolution and temporal interval.  

The same template applies to quartz watches (piezoelectric oscillations), atomic clocks (hyperfine transition frequencies), and biological pacemakers (protein phosphorylation cycles).  In each case:  
i. A physical substrate has a privileged dynamical invariant (period, decay constant, phase drift).  
ii. Sensory or electronic circuitry picks up that invariant.  
iii. A representational state is generated.  

Because the covariance is secured nomically, the representation is as robust—and as fallible—as any other sense.  Heat illusions arise when law-auxiliaries (ambient wind, moisture) disrupt the correlation; temporal illusions arise under psychedelics or high adrenaline, which alter neural pacemakers.  None of this threatens the legitimacy of the modality.  

5. Human “Time Sense”  
Sceptics sometimes grant that *devices* can measure time while denying that *organisms* can *perceive* it.  But the dichotomy crumbles on inspection.  Three lines of empirical evidence:

A. Interval Discrimination.  Humans and many animals can reliably distinguish, without counting, auditory or visual events that differ by as little as 20 ms in duration—well below the threshold at which attention shifts or memory cues intervene.  

B. Neural Implementation.  The Striatal Beat Frequency model posits cortical oscillators with slightly different periods whose coincident firing gates striatal neurons.  The coincidence pattern after elapsed interval Δt encodes Δt.  Dopamine modulates both frequency and coincidence-detection sensitivity, explaining pharmacological distortions of experienced time.  Again, no temporal rays impinge; internal dynamics suffice.  

C. Multimodal Recalibration.  In the “temporal ventriloquism” paradigm, vision and audition co-adapt so that if a beep leads a flash by 100 ms repeatedly, the system recalibrates perceived simultaneity for unrelated stimuli.  Such plasticity mirrors spatial prism adaptation, the gold standard for sensory modality status.  

Objection: These are *inferences* from memory of earlier states, not perceptions.  
Reply: They bear all the hallmarks of perception: low-level, fast, cognitively impenetrable, and subject to adaptation.  Memory plays no larger role than it does in color constancy (which compares current input with recent illumination statistics).  The distinction between online perceptual processes and offline inferential reconstruction therefore does not map cleanly onto the time-sense case.  

6. Examples that Do Philosophical Work  
Example 1: The Radioactive Hourglass.  
Imagine an hourglass filled with a known mass of ¹³⁷Cs.  Each decay event flips a bistable circuit; after N flips, the device strikes a bell.  Because the decay is genuinely random, no earlier state predicts the exact micro-pattern, yet the aggregate conforms to half-life τ.  Lawlike covariance, not micro-determinism, is what matters.  The set of bell rings encodes elapsed multiples of τ without time causing anything—only the weak force operates.  The example shows that even *stochastic* processes can serve as temporal proxies so long as the statistical law is known.  

Example 2: The Planetless Observer.  
Suppose a voyager in intergalactic void floats with no external cues—no sunsets, no ticking devices, only her heartbeat.  She straps a plethysmograph to her wrist; each pulse drives an LED, providing temporal “pips.”  If autonomic drugs double her heart rate, the same device now mis-represents: she believes less time has passed than actually has.  The case parallels color illusions under monochromatic lighting.  It confirms that misrepresentation and adaptation are possible, strengthening the claim that heartbeat was genuinely encoding time before the intervention.  

7. Dialectical Engagement  
Could the sceptic reply that covariance without causal influence by F renders the representation merely *derived*?  In clocks, any local causal chain is *about* mass displacements, electrical potentials, or photon emissions; “time” enters only from the theorist’s standpoint.  Hence the representation is not *original*, unlike vision where color is *immediately* given.  

Three counter-points.  
First, philosophy of perception increasingly acknowledges that sensory systems encode distal properties only via proximal surrogates—think of color vision carving reflectance from spectral power distributions plus illumination priors.  If that makes color “derived,” so be it; the term then does no disqualifying work.  

Second, original/derived content is a matter of informational architecture.  A representation is original if the system’s *use* of the state does not need an external interpreter.  Clock gears drive alarm bells that wake sleepers; cortico-striatal coincidence firing drives muscular responses for timed interception; no homuncular interpreter is needed.  

Third, there exist hybrid cases—echolocation, electric fish electro-sense—whose status nobody doubts despite depending on self-generated pulses correlated with environmental structure.  The organism emits the pulses; the environment echoes them; the echoes carry spatial information.  By parity, a brain can emit oscillations, then re-compare them to encode temporal distance.  Self-generated does not mean non-perceptual.  

8. Precision in Distinctions  
Much confusion stems from failing to separate:  
• Time *as abstract parameter* vs. time *as measured variable* (elapsed interval).  
• Direct *impression of passage* vs. *representation of duration*.  
• Externally driven sensing (photon influx) vs. internally driven sensing (oscillator phase).  

Only the second pair—representation of duration via lawful covariance—concerns the status of a time sense.  Whether or not the feeling of “nowness” is perceptual is orthogonal.  Likewise, internal drivers do not demote a modality; proprioception is largely internally generated yet is a paradigm sense.  

9. Substantive Pay-Off: A Research Program  
If the above argument succeeds, philosophers and cognitive scientists should treat temporal perception as on a par with other modalities, with corollary methodological shifts:  

• Just as vision science maps color spaces, we can map *chronometric spaces*—psychophysical functions relating physical duration to perceived duration under sundry physiological states.  

• Cross-modal interactions (temporal ventriloquism, sensorimotor synchrony) merit study for what they reveal about sensory integration principles more generally.  

• Disorders of time perception (Parkinson’s disease, ADHD) should be investigated alongside color blindness and amusia, not relegated to abstract “cognitive” impairments.  

These empirical recommendations flow directly from conceding that temporal representation qualifies as sensory under CCP-Covariance.  

10. Objections Handled  

Objection A: Covariance is not enough; fortune tellers’ card spreads covary with future events by mere accident (if the lucky guess comes true).  
Reply: The requirement is *lawful*, exploitation-attuned covariance, not mere correlation.  Fortune teller correlations are neither reliable nor used by a mechanism evolved or engineered to exploit them.  Clocks and brains rely on dynamical invariants underwritten by physics and honed by selection or design.  

Objection B: If covariance suffices, *everything* represents time because everything changes.  
Reply: Representation is not mere change; it is change *interpreted by the system* to guide behavior or inference.  A rock expands in heat but does not use the expansion.  A clock gear’s angular position drives downstream readouts; a neural coincidence pattern drives motor timing.  Representation demands functional downstream use.  

Objection C: The feeling of temporal flow remains unexplained.  
Reply: True, the metaphysics of passage is distinct from the epistemology of time measurement.  My claim is only about the latter.  Establishing a sensory basis for duration does not settle whether flow or the present moment are objective features.  But even if the dynamicist view of passage is illusory, the sense of duration can still be perceptual, as color remains perceptual even if secondary-quality realists strip it of mind-independent status.  

11. Summary  
1. CCP-Strong is overly restrictive; the more plausible CCP-Covariance allows representation wherever a property is reliably tracked by causally efficacious surrogates.  
2. Physical processes supply an abundance of such surrogates for temporal interval.  
3. Clocks, both artefactual and biological, harness those processes to encode time.  
4. The objection that time’s causal impotency bars a time sense therefore fails.  
5. Recognizing temporal perception as genuine opens empirical and philosophical research avenues analogous to those of the other senses.  

Time’s hand never touches the pendulum, the quartz crystal, or the neuronal oscillator, yet they all keep faithful count of its passing.  The moral is not that they cheat; it is that *information without direct causation by the abstract property is the norm, not the exception, in sensory systems*.  Once that lesson is learned, the purported mystery of the time sense evaporates, and we can turn to the more intriguing question of how good the human chronometric apparatus can become.
